For those wanting a bit more elbow room, simply divide the apartment rental of £496 by the number of people sharing. The price includes Channel tunnel crossings for a car and passengers. Val Thorens is part of the Trois Vallées ski area and is connected - though linking pistes are sometimes icy on spring mornings - with resorts including Méribel and Courchevel. Still on the theme of Easter skiing, tour operator First Choice (0870 7543477) says it has relatively few flight seats left but can easily find beds for customers prepared to drive to the Alps. Most availability is for one week from Good Friday or Easter Saturday. It has holidays starting on April 13 in a variety of French resorts including Les Deux Alpes (from £399), Val d'Isère (from £409) and Alpe d'Huez (from £449). Some space is still available to these resorts from Gatwick, Manchester and Belfast. And it can offer packages with departures the following day to resorts such as Tignes (from £489) Les Arcs (from £259), Méribel (from £399) and Courchevel (from £409). Late-season skiers seeking cheap flights to the Alps should note that easyJet will switch its Stansted-Geneva service to Gatwick next month. The airline will continue to fly to the Swiss city from Luton. It already operates one daily flight there from Gatwick. From March 25, it will offer two flights a day. Meanwhile, stand by for another round of competitive fares to Colorado next winter. On the same date Lufthansa will launch a new service from Frankfurt to Denver. How aware are skiers and snowboarders of the danger of skin cancer? Experts in the US have launched research aimed at finding out. Clear air and the reflection of sunlight from snow intensify the effect of ultra-violet radiation on all slopes, but in the Rockies and other western mountain ranges the problem is particularly acute because most resorts there are very high. Researchers from the Denver-based American Medical Centre have been riding with visitors on chairlifts in 28 resorts this season and quizzing them on their knowledge. They are asking, for example, how easily they burn, and whether they have used sunscreen. Next season the centre will launch an awareness campaign in one resort, yet to be chosen, and compare the results with one in which no such action has been taken. Anyone still skiing in the Austrian resort of Ischgl on April 30 will almost certainly be flirting with ice and slush - but the compensation will be a free concert by Sting. It starts at 1pm at Idalp, described as "a natural amphitheatre" at over 7,000ft. All you need do to hear him is buy a lift pass, which is included in some special local deals at that time. Four nights' bed and breakfast between April 27 and May 1 costs from around £150. (Ischgl Tourist Office: 0043 5444 52660).

fields.headline: The going is good
fields.standfirst: The birthplace of Bluegrass, Bourbon and Muhammad Ali is also home to one of the greatest horse races, says Nicholas Faith
fields.trailText: The birthplace of Bluegrass, Bourbon and Muhammad Ali is also home to one of the greatest horse races, says Nicholas Faith
fields.body:
It's where Scott Fitzgerald got his first glimpse of the High Life, where he wrote much of The Great Gatsby, often while prone in the bars, and where he situated the wedding of Daisy Fay and Tom Buchanan. Other, less distinguished guests have included six presidents of the US and Al Capone. The gangster would dine and play blackjack in a private room, which featured a special staircase that led down to a private door, just in case he had to get away from his enemies.

The Seelbach hotel in downtown Louisville, Kentucky, is no ordinary mid-Western hostelry. Thankfully, it is now much as it was when the brothers Seelbach opened it back in 1905 as the acme of luxury, complete with the biggest genuine Ratskeller in the world and a mass of heavily decorative marble.

That the establishment retains its allure is all due to Roger Davis, star of the TV series Alias Smith and Jones. The place had shut down in the mid-1970s, and Davis ruined himself financially in restoring it. Today, even Miss America is prepared to use the Seelbach for her wedding reception - her beloved just happens to be the lieutenant governor of Kentucky (not a state but a commonwealth because it was originally formed from its split with Virginia).

More relevantly for travellers, the hotel's Oak Room is probably the best restaurant in the state. No mean compliment because there's at least one other in Louisville, Lilly's Gourmet, which is probably more inventive - Kathy Cary, the owner and chef, has even contrived to transform hominy grits into a genuinely delicate delicacy.

The thing to remember - and this was by far the most agreeable surprise to a visitor previously rather snobby about American food - is that any half-decent restaurant in Kentucky is insistent, bordering on fanatical, about the variety and freshness of the foodstuffs they and the local agricultural college encourage local farmers to produce. These are startlingly various. There's wild ginger, Kentucky hams, which once aged for a year or more would satisfy even an Italian palate, Bibb lettuce, fresh-water shrimp and a very decent Port Salut made by local Trappist monks.

Then again, who could resist Rattlesnake Hill organic garlic? And there's even paw-paw from a nook in the woods which has a startlingly sub-tropical climate. The only dishes I could (easily) resist were the products of the local ostrich farms.

Moreover the menus are not confined to local foods. The chefs can also buy supplies of fresh fish, including tuna and turbot, thanks to UPS, which has a hub at Louisville airport. But the chefs' greatest pride is their fried green tomatoes (as featured in the film of the same name) which are jolly good, especially when some of the spent grain from bourbon distillation is included in the batter - a residue also used to make Sour Mash Bourbon bread, while the wood from the barrels serves as splendid fuel for smoking peppers as well as sundry meats and fishes.

But the commonwealth has more going for it than Fitzgerald and fried green tomatoes. For example, the more adventurous can try white-water rafting on the Cumberland River; or any of the spectacular caves which litter the countryside. They culminate in Mammoth Cave, the biggest cave system on earth, (and a World Heritage Site to boot) with 350 miles of passageways already discovered and 600 more still to be surveyed.

Kentucky is quintessential USA - it's no coincidence that it houses the birthplaces of both Abraham Lincoln and Jefferson Davis, president of the Confederacy. The contrast between history and recent past can be seen in its monuments, to Harriet Beecher Stowe who wrote Uncle Tom's Cabin after witnessing a slave auction in Old Washington, to the Underground Railway that smuggled fleeing slaves to the north and freedom, and to Muhammed Ali, who has now returned to his native Louisville - where the Browns of Brown-Forman, the leading firm in the Bourbon business, provided the finance for his early career.

The sheer scale of the country emerges in one statistic: the National Parks in Kentucky add up to one million acres, offering a beguiling mix of lakes, hills and forests, replete with trails for hiking or biking. The scenery is delightful, rolling, restful, green, without being overbearing, complete with small towns that sum up the American dream (ie fine for a shop and a stroll, boring as hell to live in).

Perhaps this embodiment of all things American is best summed up in two museums: one in Paducah dedicated to quilts, the other in Bowling Green that celebrates the Corvette sports cars that have been manufactured for many years in the local General Motors factory.

Not surprisingly, the best-kept landscape can be seen in the famous Bluegrass country near Lexington which was once known as the "Athens of the West"'. Strange this: I've never heard of Athens itself being called the Lexington of the South. Anyway, it's the American equivalent of Newmarket.

The numerous famous horse farms are home to animals belonging to such well-known owners as Queen Elizabeth. Tours provide visits to a number of them. The horses provide most of the runners for the state's thriving racing programme, which culminates in the Kentucky Derby held in early June on the Churchill Downs track in Louisville (complete with the largest equine museum in the world). These centres of excellence are also highly active stud farms - children are welcome, says the brochure, provided "they are ready to hear an often-detailed description of how horses breed".

Bluegrass, also the original home of that strangely melancholy music, much played at the local music festivals, is so named because for a time in the spring its rolling grassy countryside is a purple colour, a sign of the solid limestone beneath, which not only makes for rich grass to strengthen horses' bones but also provides the clear pure water required for making the county's single best known product: Bourbon whiskey. The liquor is named after the Bourbon King Louis XVI, the Americans' most improbable ally when they revolted against theBritish in 1776.

The Bourbon trail covers seven of the few distilleries remaining out of the hundreds that were busy before Prohibition. Nevertheless, these distilleries can produce a surprising variety of whiskies, many of dangerous smoothness, all most acceptable when drunk with ice or as a julep. The variety is due to careful selection by the blenders of the individual casks in which the whiskey is matured (but not for too long - it's at its peak at between eight and 10 years of age, becoming woody in taste if left any longer).

None of the distilleries is industrial in scale, and they are all, as they used to say, "picturesquely situate", none more so than the Labrot & Graham distillery which dates back to 1812 and has recently been restored by Brown Forman to make Woodford Reserve, a particularly warm and satisfying premium (or as they would prefer it "super-premium" whiskey. They've even installed the handsome copper-pot stills otherwise employed to distil cognac and malt whiskey.

The site is ridiculously charming, with a handsome "visitor centre" overlooking the old stone buildings on the banks of a little creek that supplies the pure limestone-impregnated water required for the whiskey. The only catch, or rather reminder of our inevitable mortality, is the cemetery conveniently placed just opposite the entrance to the distillery. However if one wanted to end one's days in the US, then a corner of Kentucky sounds mighty appealing.

The practicals

Delta Airlines (0800 414767) flies from Gatwick to Cincinnati from£376. For information on Kentucky call 020-72280782, www.kentuckytourism.com

Fly-drive packages are available from US Airtours (0208 559 2020) and Delta Vacations (0870 900 5001).

For stud farmtours tel 00 800 8453959 or e-mail visitlex.com.

Seelbach Hotel 500 S Fourth Street Louisville (001 502 585-3200) Lilly's Gourmet 1147 Bardstown Road (001 502 451 0447). Mammoth Cave tel 001 502 758 2328.

webTitle: General Bonaparte reviewing troops, Antoine-Jean Gros (after 1796)

fields.headline: General Bonaparte reviewing troops, Antoine-Jean Gros (after 1796)
fields.body:
· View the work online

Artist: Antoine-Jean Gros (1771-1835), who became Napoleon's first propagandist painter during his northern Italian campaign in 1796. Josephine met the struggling artist and introduced him to her husband, who posed for his first official portrait. Gros went on to paint vast military scenes in which Napoleon appears as a Christ-like figure; in Napoleon Bonaparte visiting the Plague Victims at Jaffa (1804), the general touches his men's buboes; and in Napoleon Bonaparte on the Battlefield of Eylau (1808), he succours the dying. The empire's downfall left Gros without a subject; in 1835 he drowned himself in the uniform Napoleon had awarded him.

Subject: Napoleon Bonaparte (1769-1821), the son of impoverished Corsican nobility. Trained at the Ecole Militaire in Paris, his participation in late 18th-century culture is revealed by his love of the Celtic bard Ossian - whose poetry was in reality faked by Scottish writer James Macpherson. Napoleon carried Ossian into battle. After the Terror and Robespierre's fall, Napoleon emerged as the national saviour, making himself first consul in 1799 and emperor in 1804. Even quixotic gestures, such as his invasion of Egypt, did wonders for national pride. The even greater hubris of attacking Russia precipitated his downfall. He haunted Europe long after his death in exile on St Helena.

Distinguishing features: This is the young Napoleon, angular man of action, as taut as the horse he rides, conducting wars not from afar but on the front line. He inspects cavalry that are lined up as regularly as horses on a classical frieze. Napoleon is not yet emperor but already he has an eye on history: he looks beyond and away from his troops, into the light of destiny.

Gros romanticises his general, lingering on his dark eyes, fine bone structure (a lot finer than in other paintings of the stocky emperor) and unkempt, revolutionary hair. Napoleon's passion is embodied in his horse; the white stallion is wild in its movements, its neck straining, its tail swishing, yet Napoleon controls it effortlessly. The horse might be the army, full of patriotic fervour, which Napoleon harnesses; it might also be a personification of the general's spirit, dynamic yet controlled. Either way, Gros's passion for Napoleon is that of a believer. He finds in the general a perfect Romantic icon. The tempestuous horse is worthy of the younger Romantic painters, of Géricault or Delacroix. Yet there is something disturbing, and familiar, about the way Gros marshals Napoleon's cavalry. The troops, lined up in such a way that each is a perfect reproduction of the other, have the same lack of individuality as the Nazis Leni Riefenstahl's camera captured at Nuremberg. This is the beginning of a certain kind of modern portrait, which subsumes an entire people into its leader. Gros implies that the general is France, that his personality is big enough to express that of the nation.

Inspirations and influences: Gros's portraits of Napoleon were followed by masterpieces by some of France's greatest painters: David painted an equestrian portrait of Napoleon in 1800, and in 1806-7 created a 20ft-wide canvas of the emperor's coronation, with Bonaparte crowning Josephine. In 1806 Ingres monumentalised him as an almost divine figure, glistening in velvet and ermine.

Napoleon fascinated his enemies, too. The Duke of Wellington was presented by a grateful British nation with Canova's colossal nude statue of Napoleon as Mars, which can be seen at Apsley House.

Perhaps the oddest portrait is JMW Turner's War: The Exile and the Rock Limpet (1842), at Tate Britain, which has the defeated general contemplating, enviously, a shellfish.

Where is it? Wallace Collection, Manchester Square, London W1 (020-7935 0687).

fields.headline: Somewhere for now
fields.trailText: Rome | Spain | Bruges | Tunisia | Grenada | San Francisco | Hawaii | New York | Kuala Lumpur | Mauritius | New South Wales
fields.body:
Europe

Rome: Two nights at the centrally-located three-star Hotel Gioberti before April 5 costs £289pp including Alitalia flights. Bridge City Breaks (0870 7275917).

Spain: Seven nights with golf at the San Roque Club on the Costa del Sol. The price of £477pp includes B&B and green fees. Longshot Golf Holidays (01730 268621, www.longshotgolf.co.uk.

Bruges: Two nights' B&B at the Hotel Asiris throughout March cost £109pp from Eurotours. Price includes Eurostar tickets (0870 333 889, www.eurotours.co.uk.

Africa

Tunisia: A week at the Sol Azur hotel in Hammamet costs £382pp. The price includes flights from Heathrow or Gatwick, departing March 19-25. Wigmore Holidays (020-7836 4999).

Caribbean

Grenada: Depart throughout February and March from Gatwick for a seven-night, all-inclusive package at the Rex Grenadian for £849pp. Flights every Wednesday and Friday. Caribbean Journeys (0870 709 3020 22).

North America

San Francisco: Seven nights' room only at a three-star hotel with car hire for £469pp until March 31 from American Journeys (0870 7093020).

Hawaii: Two weeks on Oahu for £799pp from March 1 from Page & Moy (08700 106 456), and for another £100 add a two-night stopover in either Las Vegas or Los Angeles.

New York: Two nights (three days) at the three-star Newton Hotel for £299pp, including Virgin flights. Travel from now until March 27, book by March 16. Quest Travel (0870 4445552).

Asia

Kuala Lumpur: From March 3 to April 3, Malaysia's capital holds a shopping sale carnival with discounts of up to 70% and a lifting of import duty on many branded goods. Five nights at the Swiss Garden Hotel costs £527. Asia Direct (0870 789 3335, www.asia-direct.co.uk.

Indian Ocean

Mauritius: Two weeks for the price of one at the Sugar Beach Resort. (The second week is room only). Valid for stays from March 1 to April 8, the cost is £1,485pp from Expressions Holidays (020-7435 8484, www.expressionsholidays.co.uk.

Australasia

New South Wales: Spend 11 days exploring the state, flying on February 27. Nights in Sydney, Port Stephens, the Hunter Valley and the Blue Mountains. Price of £724pp includes return flights from Manchester, 10 nights' accommodation and six days' car hire. Austravel (0870 0550206 www.austravel.com.

fields.headline: What's on when
fields.trailText: Virtually Blue Suede Shoes, Manchester | Omizutori Festiva, Japan | The blessing of the cars, Rome | The Eden Project, Cornwall | St Patricks Day, Chicago
fields.body:
Virtually Blue Suede Shoes

Date: March 9.

Location: Manchester Evening News Arena, Trinity Way, Manchester M3 1AR.

Description: Ingeniously-edited concert footage of the King himself projected on to a two-storey screen and accompanied by a live band. The result is uncannily like a genuine concert.

Contact: 0161-950 5000.

Website: www.whatsonwhen.com/themes/music.jml.

Omizutori Festival

Date: March 1-14.

Location: Todaiji Temple, Nigatsudo Hall, Nara, Japan.

Description: The largest wooden structure in the world sees a spectacular annual ceremony involving monks dashing round the perimeter with 8m-long blazing torches.

Contact: + 81 (0) 74 222 3900

Website: www.whatsonwhen.com/places/japan.jml

The blessing of the cars

Date: March 9.

Location: Santa Francesca Romana, Piazza Colosseo, Rome, Italy.

Description: The feast day of St Frances of Rome - patron saint of motorists and taxi-drivers - sees motor vehicles of all sorts parking outside her church to receive the annual blessing.

Website: www.whatsonwhen.com/themes/religion.jml

The Eden Project

webTitle: Livingstone defies Prescott in row over Whitehall papers

fields.headline: Livingstone defies Prescott in row over Whitehall papers
fields.standfirst: Special report: Livingstone's London
fields.trailText: A furious row broke out last night between Ken Livingstone and John Prescott after the London mayor refused to hand over a series of confidential government documents which are highly embarrassing to ministers.
fields.body:
A furious row broke out last night between Ken Livingstone and John Prescott after the London mayor refused to hand over a series of confidential government documents which are highly embarrassing to ministers.

In the first confrontation between a devolved body and central government over control of Whitehall papers, the new mayor threw his weight behind an all party group of London assembly members who started to trawl through the documents yesterday.

The files, which detail the fiasco of the New Year's Eve celebrations in London which eventually had to be cancelled, inadvertently fell into the hands of the assembly during the transition of power from Whitehall last July.

Amid fears that ministers could be embarrassed by publication of the documents, Mr Prescott's Department of the Environment yesterday threatened the assembly with legal action unless it handed back the 84 files. The assembly members, led by Trevor Phillips, the Labour chairman, and the Tory member Eric Ollerenshaw, brushed aside the threat of an injunction and opened up the files, which contain letters between ministers who were in charge of organising the celebrations until last July.

One letter, from Keith Hill, the London minister, to the deputy prime minister, could prove particularly embarrassing for ministers. In the confidential letter, Mr Hill sets out a series of options to Mr Prescott to ensure that the celebrations are allowed to go ahead. One idea, Mr Hill proposed, would be to ask the chief secretary to the Treasury to stump up extra money. Mr Hill concluded in blunt terms that the government could "forget it and leave it to the mayor".

Such language will be seized on by a committee of assembly members which is investigating the circumstances which forced Mr Livingstone to cancel the New Year's Eve celebrations. Tory members of the committee believe that the government's failure to prepare for the event may have played a role in Mr Livingstone's decision.

Mr Phillips threw open the doors to the room where the files were stored despite a last minute appeal from Sir Richard Mottram, the most senior civil servant in Mr Prescott's department, to leave the files alone.

Mr Livingstone last night laughed off the government threat: "There is no reason why we cannot see files which discuss the cost of a party. I'd be happy if Trevor [Phillips] is carted off to jail - I promise to visit him with some food."

fields.headline: Wrong types of snow
fields.standfirst: Former Olympic skier Martin Bell tells you what to do when the going gets tough
fields.trailText: Former Olympic skier Martin Bell tells you what to do when the going gets tough
fields.body:
Everyone loves to ski freshly-fallen light powder snow, but Mother Nature is not always so accommodating. Sometimes you have to ski the nasty stuff to get to the good stuff - or sometimes, the nasty stuff is all there is. Whatever your level of skiing, you should never stop trying to push yourself, if you want to improve. This means skiing the tough stuff, as well as the "hero snow".

Light and heavy snow

It may come as a surprise that not all fresh snow is alike. In mountain ranges near the sea (California, Alaska, western Canada or the Alps), it tends to be heavier, with a higher water content. As you get closer to the centre of a continent (Alberta, Wyoming, Utah, Colorado), the snow becomes drier and lighter.

Lighter snow tends to be easier to ski, because you sink through it and usually reach the firm support of the older snow underneath. In heavy snow, such as the "Sierra Cement" of California, you need to be more precise and forceful with your movements, although the technique remains the same.

Crud

Fresh powder snow soon becomes "skied out", or "tracked out". This is sometimes known as "crud" (although this term is also used for breakable crust - see below). The problem is that the fresh snow is now packed down in some areas, and piled up in others. So the amount of resistance that your skis encounter is always changing. You need to constantly look ahead and anticipate this. When you're about to go through a deep pile, push your feet forward slightly. For the firmer sections, stand more in the middle of the ski. Rather than persisting with the short, bouncy turns of true powder, you will be better served in crud by longer, rounder, carved arcs.

Crust

Too much wind or sun can turn the top layer of powder into a hard crust. As long as this crust remains fairly thin, skiers can break through it easily, and barely notice it. And once the crust becomes thick enough, skiers remain on top of it, and it's almost like skiing on a piste. But between these two extremes is the worst-case scenario: breakable crust. Sometimes it will support you; sometimes it will break through. There are only two reliable ways to negotiate breakable crust: jump turns, or step turns.

With jump turns, you have to make the whole turn in the air, pivoting your feet beneath you, and only touching down to make a brief edge set. But this is exhausting, and even experts cannot keep it up for long. The other option is step turns, where you don't try to turn your skis but merely step them around, using four of five steps to complete a long turn. This is only feasible if the terrain is not too steep, and make sure you don't catch an edge doing this.

Slush

Once the air temperature becomes warmer than the freezing point, the snow starts to melt. Its water content becomes very high, the delicate snow crystals change into large grains of ice, and "granular snow" or slush, is formed. These conditions make it hard to pivot your skis, because whenever your skis are moving sideways, they need to push aside large piles of heavy snow. So, to cope with slush, you need to "round out" your turns. This will ensure that your skis move forwards through the slush, rather than sideways. If possible, you should even try to carve these longer turns.

With rounder turns, you will pick up speed in the middle of the turn. But as long as you finish off each turn, carving your skis all the way around across the hill, until you're nearly heading uphill, you'll always be able to bring your speed under control at the end of each turn.

Sticky snow

One more tip for the spring: when the snow gets really sticky on the lower slopes, you should aim for the higher parts of the mountain. If you have to ski low down, below the tree-line, then try to use areas of the runs that are shaded by the trees; they will be slightly cooler and less sticky.

webTitle: John O'Farrell on being married to Labour

fields.headline: It's awful, but I like it
fields.standfirst:
Being married to the Labour party means having to put up with some annoying habits

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Being married to the Labour party means having to put up with some annoying habits.
fields.body:
Political activism on the left is like those stickers on the back of lorries that say "How am I driving?" You're only going to phone up the number if the driver makes you angry enough to do so. None of us goes on demos or organises petitions to say that we are generally satisfied with the government's overall performance, any more than we are likely to call the number on the back of the truck and say: "Put me through to your boss immediately! I wish to report that one of your lorries is doing a steady 50 miles per hour along the inside lane of the motorway!"

The left in this country has traditionally been motivated by the outrages of the right; we have always been spurred into action by seeing horrific images of Vietnam or Ann Widdecombe's dresses. We are used to being in opposition to things; against the pit closures, against the poll tax, against extending committee meetings beyond last orders. But in as little as six weeks' time we may have the opportunity to enter a new phase - to help re-elect a Labour government for a second full term. It means campaigning in favour of something for a change. And that's why there's a whole section of the left who, though they will vote for a Labour government, will find themselves unable actually to participate in helping this come about.

Part of the reason that Labour has spent so little time in power is that closely allied to the traditions of socialism is another "ism" that has always prevented us from consolidating our gains - and that's "oppositionalism". You may well have oppositionalists in your neighbourhood. When the local school was threatened with closure they were fantastic; organising protests, making placards - they were as active as anyone. But now the school is safe again you won't see them helping repaint the patterns in the playground on Sunday morning or running a stall at the Christmas fair. When Labour was trying to get the Tories out, the oppositionalists were tireless in their campaigning. But now that Tony Blair is organising a crowd of us to repaint the playground, they don't want anything to do with it, even if Cherie brings lemonade and sandwiches for all the helpers.

Anyone can campaign for the Labour party when the Tories are in power; that's the easy bit. But being politically active on the left in sup port of the government of the day - that's the real challenge; that's being a David Bowie fan when the The Laughing Gnome is in the charts. One of the secret weapons of the right is that it is so comfortable with power. It comes to Tories naturally, like talking too loudly in restaurants and not ducking their heads slightly in front of the screen when they're late at the cinema.

T he left feels awkward compromising itself with the reins of office and so there'll always be a faction who would rather remove themselves completely and snipe from the sidelines rather than be tainted by association. Much of Ken Livingstone's support was based on the fact that he was in opposition to the prime minister. Make Red Ken PM and he'd never keep those supporters; they'd switch to whoever was standing against him. The same thing would have happened if Che Guevara had ever become president. "Tory sell-out!" they would have shouted as Che went on the telly to talk about the tough spending choices facing his government. Like the greatest pop icons, the ultimate leftwing heroes die before they hit the middle-age of actual government. Somehow I suspect that John Lennon would not be so revered if he was alive and well and diligently working away as a member of the European parliament.

But I regard myself as married to the Labour party. Yes, my political spouse drives me mad sometimes and yes, I confess I have fantasised about having a one-night stand with another political body. The Liberal Democrats know all the seductive chat-up lines about raising taxes, the Socialist Alliance look fresh and exciting and the far off Green party will always look greener. But I've made a commitment to Labour and just as my wife puts up with all the annoying things that she didn't know about me on our wedding day, so I tolerate all the maddening habits that Labour never warned me about before they were elected.

Okay, so politically speaking Jack Straw picks his nose and Tony Blair uses all the hot water in the shower and John Prescott leaves his underpants for me to pick up -but it's still all worth it. Because the Labour party remains the best means by which this country can be changed for the better and that's why everyone on the left should do what they can to get this administration re-elected. Of course our political partners aren't perfect and it gets less exciting when you've been together a few years, but that's what long-term commitment is all about.

fields.headline: Get your kit out
fields.standfirst: Cébé glasses
fields.trailText: If you want some glasses that cross the clubbing, street life, sporty and practical spectrum, try Cébé's new range, called Take Off. They come with replaceable lenses.
fields.body:
I'm looking for a hardy, sporty pair of sunglasses, that won't baffle me with optical technology.

If you want something that crosses the clubbing, street life, sporty and practical spectrum, try Cébé's new range, called Take Off. They come with replaceable lenses.

Replaceable lenses?

You have a choice of styles: subdued cool lenses for use at high altitude, or yellow lenses for grey and foggy conditions.

What makes them different from their rivals?

They are classy, well-priced for the quality and very comfortable, having flexible PVC arms that are curved to fit snugly.

What if they don't suit me?

Well Cébé does have other styles but the Take Off combines serious sun protection and great field of vision.

So what do they cost?

There are two sizes, in a choice of colours, and they cost £52. Extra lenses are between £10-15. Phone 020-7304 7031 for stockists.

webTitle: Islamic militants seek foothold on campus

fields.headline: Islamic militants seek foothold on campus
fields.standfirst:
Student groups under surveillance over alleged recruitment for holy war abroad
Special report: human rights in the UK
Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Student groups under surveillance over alleged recruitment for holy war abroad.
fields.byline: Jamie Wilson, Angelique Chrisafis and Richard Norton-Taylor
fields.body:
A North London business park filled with low rent dot.com start-ups and cheap software manufacturers is probably the last place you would expect to find an organisation allegedly engaged in waging war on the Russian state.

According to the authorities in Moscow the spartan office of Al Muhajiroun, with three ageing computers and paper-strewn conference table, is the hub of an operation to recruit and send Muslim students to Chechnya to fight in a holy war against the Russian army in the Caucasus.

Earlier this week Vladimir Putin's official spokesman, Sergei Yastrzhembsky, called on Britain to ban the organisation under the Terrorism Act, which has just come into force and allows the authorities to target groups which promote terrorism abroad.

He also made the startling claim that "mercenaries" from the London School of Economics had been recruited to fight in Chechnya. The assertion was met with disdain by the school's Islamic Society, and Mr Yastrzhembsky has so far failed produce any evidence to back up his statement.

But it has once again focused attention on allegations that students are being recruited on British campuses by Islamic extremists.

Exactly how many undergraduates have gone to fight in conflicts from Kashmir to the Middle East is impossible to quantify. As the Home Office admits, when people leave the country they do not say they are going to train as soldiers in a holy war, they say they are going on holiday.

But some students, often second generation immigrants persuaded to rediscover their parents' faith, have joined the military struggle for the sake of Islam.

So concerned are the security services that MI5 has set up a unit to monitor the activities of young British Muslims targeted by extremists.

"We can identify people but there is a problem of deporting them to countries with human rights records," said an intelligence source. Many individuals are wanted by, for example, India, Egypt, Russia or Turkey and would face terrorist charges if returned. MI5 and the police special branch are also aware of the sens itivity of appearing to be targeting people just because they are Muslims.

Al Muhajiroun - which translates as "the emigrants" - is the organisation most often linked to the recruitment. Established in Saudi Arabia in 1983, it is run by Sheikh Omar Bakri Muhammad, a Syrian born cleric whose stated aim is the creation of khilafah, a global Islamic state, and who believes it is the duty of all Muslims to engage in jihad.

The group has been barred from almost every UK university campus. But it manages to make its presence felt by using different names, such as the Muslim Media Forum, or by setting up shop outside the campus.

Change

In the past Sheikh Bakri has openly admitted to being responsible for sending as many as 700 undergraduates to fight abroad, mostly in Kashmir. But the new terrorism legislation has made him change his stance. "People keep saying that we send people abroad to fight," he said in his London office. This is just not true. All I do is tell people whether it is permissible for them to go under Islamic law.

"If people want to go and fight, that is up to them; we certainly do not get involved in recruitment."

Around 150 miles north, next to a row of halal fast food shops opposite Manchester Metropolitan University, three representatives of Al Muhajiroun handed out homemade leaflets.

"Israel, Hell is your promised land," read one of their placards, and, under a computer print-out of a Kalashnikov: "Jihad! The only way to liberate occupied Palestine."

In Manchester, Al Muhajiroun is coordinated by a 19-year-old A-level student from Bury, Abdullah. He said the group did not promote terrorism, nor did it actively recruit for jihad. It would offer advice on taking up arms in struggles abroad if an individual felt that was their mission. He said five Muslim students and graduates had left Manchester of their own accord in the past year to train and fight with militia in Chechnya and Palestine.

Abdullah, who joined Al Muhajiroun aged 15 after he was approached by canvassers on a stall, said: "Personally, I have thought about going to fight many times. But as an only son, I have to be in Britain to support my parents."

The Manchester branch has up to 100 members, many students, who take it in turn to engage passersby in conversation. Stalls are set up five days a week at lunchtime outside Manchester University and Metropolitan University student unions - they are barred from inside. Men and women hand out leaflets and flyers and chat to students on the union steps. On Saturday they move to Blackburn and the centre of Manchester.

Some decide to take up the cause. In an earlier interview with the Guardian, Sheikh Bakri said Al Muhajiroun was divided into two wings, the da'wah or propagation network, and the jihad network. Da'wah attracts students to the organisation on campuses through lectures, conferences, stalls and leaflets.

The students who join are told about the possibility of military training. If they are interested they would be put in touch with sources in Britain who have connections with guerrilla training camps in Europe, the Middle East and Asia.

The routes to the training camps are long and complicated, often involving stop-offs in numerous countries to prevent the authorities from tracing them.

Training

"People go abroad for all sorts of reasons - on holiday, to see their family; if they want to do a bit of Jihad training at the same time, then that is up to them," said one former student who has been to a training camp but did not want to elaborate. "With the new terrorism law that has just been passed we do not know who the government is going to target. I am not willing to say anything."

One of the security services' tactics is to "disrupt" the activities of extremist organisations, by letting it be known they are being watched - in other words, by declaring overtly what they had been doing covertly by regularly visiting the groups.

MI5 monitors the activities of students suspected of trying to gather information useful for their nations' attempts to acquire weapons of mass destruction - that is nuclear, biological and chemical warfare. University authorities are asked to pay particular attention to students from the Middle East or "rogue" states such as Libya that are studying physics or chemistry.

Many Muslim students claim that the security services help to foster "Islamaphobia" on campuses, and result in innocent students being targeted unfairly.

A spokesman for Manchester University Islamic Society said: "Ultimately we see people involved with Al Muhajiroun as Muslim brothers and sisters with a different opinion on some subjects - something that we don't have a problem with as long as they don't try to impose them on others.

fields.bodyText: A North London business park filled with low rent dot.com start-ups and cheap software manufacturers is probably the last place you would expect to find an organisation allegedly engaged in waging war on the Russian state. According to the authorities in Moscow the spartan office of Al Muhajiroun, with three ageing computers and paper-strewn conference table, is the hub of an operation to recruit and send Muslim students to Chechnya to fight in a holy war against the Russian army in the Caucasus. Earlier this week Vladimir Putin's official spokesman, Sergei Yastrzhembsky, called on Britain to ban the organisation under the Terrorism Act, which has just come into force and allows the authorities to target groups which promote terrorism abroad. He also made the startling claim that "mercenaries" from the London School of Economics had been recruited to fight in Chechnya. The assertion was met with disdain by the school's Islamic Society, and Mr Yastrzhembsky has so far failed produce any evidence to back up his statement. But it has once again focused attention on allegations that students are being recruited on British campuses by Islamic extremists. Exactly how many undergraduates have gone to fight in conflicts from Kashmir to the Middle East is impossible to quantify. As the Home Office admits, when people leave the country they do not say they are going to train as soldiers in a holy war, they say they are going on holiday. But some students, often second generation immigrants persuaded to rediscover their parents' faith, have joined the military struggle for the sake of Islam. So concerned are the security services that MI5 has set up a unit to monitor the activities of young British Muslims targeted by extremists. "We can identify people but there is a problem of deporting them to countries with human rights records," said an intelligence source. Many individuals are wanted by, for example, India, Egypt, Russia or Turkey and would face terrorist charges if returned. MI5 and the police special branch are also aware of the sens itivity of appearing to be targeting people just because they are Muslims. Al Muhajiroun - which translates as "the emigrants" - is the organisation most often linked to the recruitment. Established in Saudi Arabia in 1983, it is run by Sheikh Omar Bakri Muhammad, a Syrian born cleric whose stated aim is the creation of khilafah, a global Islamic state, and who believes it is the duty of all Muslims to engage in jihad. The group has been barred from almost every UK university campus. But it manages to make its presence felt by using different names, such as the Muslim Media Forum, or by setting up shop outside the campus. Change In the past Sheikh Bakri has openly admitted to being responsible for sending as many as 700 undergraduates to fight abroad, mostly in Kashmir. But the new terrorism legislation has made him change his stance. "People keep saying that we send people abroad to fight," he said in his London office. This is just not true. All I do is tell people whether it is permissible for them to go under Islamic law. "If people want to go and fight, that is up to them; we certainly do not get involved in recruitment." Around 150 miles north, next to a row of halal fast food shops opposite Manchester Metropolitan University, three representatives of Al Muhajiroun handed out homemade leaflets. "Israel, Hell is your promised land," read one of their placards, and, under a computer print-out of a Kalashnikov: "Jihad! The only way to liberate occupied Palestine." In Manchester, Al Muhajiroun is coordinated by a 19-year-old A-level student from Bury, Abdullah. He said the group did not promote terrorism, nor did it actively recruit for jihad. It would offer advice on taking up arms in struggles abroad if an individual felt that was their mission. He said five Muslim students and graduates had left Manchester of their own accord in the past year to train and fight with militia in Chechnya and Palestine. Abdullah, who joined Al Muhajiroun aged 15 after he was approached by canvassers on a stall, said: "Personally, I have thought about going to fight many times. But as an only son, I have to be in Britain to support my parents." The Manchester branch has up to 100 members, many students, who take it in turn to engage passersby in conversation. Stalls are set up five days a week at lunchtime outside Manchester University and Metropolitan University student unions - they are barred from inside. Men and women hand out leaflets and flyers and chat to students on the union steps. On Saturday they move to Blackburn and the centre of Manchester. Some decide to take up the cause. In an earlier interview with the Guardian, Sheikh Bakri said Al Muhajiroun was divided into two wings, the da'wah or propagation network, and the jihad network. Da'wah attracts students to the organisation on campuses through lectures, conferences, stalls and leaflets. The students who join are told about the possibility of military training. Training "People go abroad for all sorts of reasons - on holiday, to see their family; if they want to do a bit of Jihad training at the same time, then that is up to them," said one former student who has been to a training camp but did not want to elaborate. "With the new terrorism law that has just been passed we do not know who the government is going to target. I am not willing to say anything." One of the security services' tactics is to "disrupt" the activities of extremist organisations, by letting it be known they are being watched - in other words, by declaring overtly what they had been doing covertly by regularly visiting the groups. MI5 monitors the activities of students suspected of trying to gather information useful for their nations' attempts to acquire weapons of mass destruction - that is nuclear, biological and chemical warfare. University authorities are asked to pay particular attention to students from the Middle East or "rogue" states such as Libya that are studying physics or chemistry. fields.headline: Judge throws out bullying claim
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: A high court judge yesterday threw out a damages claim by a young woman who said that bullying at school had driven her to a suicide attempt.
fields.body:
A high court judge yesterday threw out a damages claim by a young woman who said that bullying at school had driven her to a suicide attempt.

Mr Justice Wright said that Emma Hansen's "most unhappy action", which will cost the taxpayer £250,000, should never have been brought.

He said: "This pursuit can have done little or nothing to assist Emma's personality problems in the time taken to bring it to trial."

Ms Hansen, 24, took a drugs overdose in February 1993 when she was 16 and remains severely depressed and unable to work. The judge said that she was "a sad figure - immature, emotional, unhappy and imbued with self-pity".

Ms Hansen, from Ryde, on the Isle of Wight, alleged that a "persistent and sustained campaign of bullying" by five girls at Ryde high school was responsible for her continuing psychiatric injury.

Isle of Wight council disputed that she was bullied or that it failed to make adequate provision for her special educational needs. Ms Hansen, who had dyslexia, transferred to the mixed comprehensive in April 1991 when her private convent closed down.

Her case, in which she was legally aided, was that other pupils would snigger and point, calling her "gormless, thick, stupid and dumb", and intimidate her by crowding her, tripping her up and flicking bits of paper at her in class.

She said that she reported the bullying but was just told to ignore it. She said: "I used to feel physically sick walking to school with stomach pains and headaches. My sleeping was disturbed."

The judge said that the five girls denied the allegations, which were supported by evidence from contemporaries.

He ruled that there was collusion between Ms Hansen and her friends over what evidence should be given and he exonerated the school.

From the outset the school regarded Ms Hansen as having special needs because of her dyslexia and provided her with the relevant help.

He said that when one looked at her history - including sexual abuse and a failed relationship - there was no basis to think that the source of her unhappiness was connected to the school.

David Pettitt, her former headteacher at Ryde high school and now assistant director of education with the council, said: "This has been going on for six years, our teachers and these five girls wrongly accused - I am pleased that they have been so completely exonerated."

fields.headline: Travel tips
fields.trailText: Readers' advice
fields.body:
There is no need to take a travel plug to Asia, despite what the guide books say. Also, small items of clothing can be washed in the shower using shampoo and every hotel has a bucket that you can borrow for heavier items. Shampoo is better than detergent as it rinses out much more quickly and doesn't irritate the skin.

Rachel Davies

To stop sand sticking to damp feet on the beach, dust with talcum powder. It will dry your feet and prevent sand from rubbing when you put your shoes on.

Emma Edwards

Coconut oil applied to the skin is an excellent chemical-free mosquito repellent. Washing with coconut soap also helps.

B Bailey

fields.headline: Sixty seconds in: Policing
fields.standfirst: Constable Lee Hopkins, based at Kingston in Surrey, talks to Miles Brignall
fields.trailText: Constable Lee Hopkins, based at Kingston in Surrey, talks to Miles Brignall
fields.body:
When you get a call over the radio directing you to an incident, it could be anything from a shoplifter to someone wielding a shotgun. It's very unpredictable, but also very exciting.

I'm six months into a two-year probation period and I don't think I've ever been so busy. Although I graduated with a degree in leisure management, I suppose I always wanted to be a policeman and did the course in case my training didn't work out.

At the start of each shift I will be assigned to a response car driver and we'll be given our duties. The day can literally change in a moment - for example today we were on the way to take some witness statements but a call diverted us to a domestic dispute. It's a case of priorities. Getting the statement has to take second place to a threat to someone's life - the only problem is the statement will have to be taken later.

When we get a call, we only have as much information as the caller who dialled 999 was able to give and if they were in shock or injured, that can be very little. So far, I have only had to deal with one very serious incident - a man wielding a knife. When it happened there was no time to stop and think. I'm happy to say my training took over and we disarmed him quickly. We are issued with body armour or the "Met vest", which I wear all the time.

At Kingston station we work any one of three shifts of eight hours starting at 6.30am, 2pm, and the night shift at 10pm. I've got used to working different hours and actually enjoy the nights because it's when we do our most proactive policing - trying to prevent crimes such as burglary. I find it difficult getting up for the earlies.

Because we are part of the Met we're sometimes called in to police large gatherings such as a political demo in town or a rugby match at Twickenham. We don't work with the same partner every day which is helpful as I get a chance to see how the more experienced officers handle difficult situations.

One downside of the job is the current shortage of officers. When you turn up for a briefing and they are only four PCs when there should be eight, it's a bit disheartening. The other downside is the havoc it wreaks with your social life. If you are due to finish at 2pm but your last act is an arrest, you have to process the paperwork before leaving. If you were due to play golf, it's just too bad.

webTitle: Help: I need a personality check-up!

fields.headline: Help: I need a personality check-up!
fields.standfirst: What sort of personality do you need to be a retail management trainee? I'm about to be tested and want to make sure I get it right.  PH, final year student, Northampton
fields.trailText: What sort of personality do you need to be a retail management trainee? I'm about to be tested and want to make sure I get it right. PH, final year student, Northampton
fields.body:
Somewhere on your personality test it will say there are no right or wrong answers. That's not completely accurate, otherwise why test at all? Show no interest in commerce, working Saturdays, or appeasing difficult customers and you won't be getting any interview practice out of this one.

Of course, the questions are not as straightforward or transparent as that. Look closely and you'll see the same thing is asked in lots of different ways to check the consistency of your replies. Most tests have built-in lie detectors to identify those more concerned with getting to the next stage than with honesty.

If you're determined and careful about the uniformity of your answers, you could fake it entirely. But what's the point of expending all that effort, to end up in a job that is completely at odds with your character? Personality tests identify suitable individuals for particular roles and help employers construct compatible teams. If the job you're going for is a realistic choice, you'll instinctively answer in the desired way.

Should you have a flexible or partially formed personality and wish to adjust it to ensure you are destined for a successful career in retail, concentrate on showing enthusiasm for anything shopping related, leadership potential, communication skills, geographical mobility and a desire to work long hours.

webTitle: Discrimination makes fat a graduate issue

fields.headline: Discrimination makes fat a graduate issue
fields.standfirst: In the current marketplace, image is everything
fields.trailText: In the current marketplace, image is everything
fields.body:
Greed is good. Hunger to succeed, an excellent quality. Fat cats are rewarded with enormous bonuses and huge corporations swallow each other up. In the world of business, big is best and gluttony admirable. But the workplace's love of all things large does not extend to the overweight individual. Quite simply, fat people, especially fat women, don't get promoted. And that's a fact.

A recent Michigan University study found that women judged obese by their employers were far less likely than their slimmer counterparts to progress at work. And, according to Dianah Worman, Chartered Institute of Personnel and Development adviser on diversity and equality, there's little doubt that the situation is the same in this country.

"Discrimination against the overweight and obese is a problem in the UK," she states. "But unlike in the US, where there are movements supporting the rights of the obese, it doesn't have a high profile here."

Last week, the National Audit Office published a report which revealed that obesity in England is nearing epidemic proportions, with one in five adults now dangerously overweight. Obesity costs the NHS at least £500m a year and the economy another £2bn a year.

What we don't know - and what no one has asked - is how much discrimination against the obese costs the economy. How many qualified, talented and hard-working people have been sidelined, never promoted or never even recruited because they're judged too fat to make a valuable contribution?

Fat is very much a graduate issue. That's because in today's marketplace, image is everything. "As we become a more service-based, client- orientated economy, the way that people look and present themselves is increasingly important," says John Philpott, chief economist for the CIPD. This preoccupation with looks means that the overweight - who aren't considered to be as attractive or presentable as their slim counterparts - lose out.

In 1996, the CIPD published Managing Diversity , a report which probed employers' prejudices. The authors carried out qualitative interviews with 30 recruitment consultants around the UK to see whether they felt that some groups of people were more likely to encounter discrimination from employers.

Their findings make alarming reading; the majority of recruiters said their clients would be likely to discriminate against fat people. Comments included "being overweight shows a certain laxness" and "being overweight is equated, to some degree, with sloth". One London-based recruitment consultant admitted: "To put it bluntly, fat people are bad for an organisation's image. We wouldn't put an overgrown tree in the foyer, and we wouldn't let an overgrown person deal with our clients."

Psychologist Jane Wardle of University College London says studies have shown that there are three main negative stereotypes attached to the overweight: "Fat people are seen as lazy and lacking in willpower. This is one basis for discrimination - if you're fat, you won't make an effort to do a good job.

"The second stereotype is that fat people are considered unattractive. Since employers make their initial judgements about an employee on the basis of looks, this is another black mark against the overweight. Third, some employers believe that obesity is a sign of ill-health. They may feel that an obese employee will take more time off sick and won't be able to perform certain tasks."

Helen Eyre, an IT desktop support worker with a degree in electronic engineering, experienced this discrimination first-hand. She says she had no idea how much being overweight impeded her career until she joined Weight Watchers and lost more than six stone, going from a size 22 to a slim size 12. "I realise that people treat me differently now that I'm slim and that many more opportunities are open to me. When I was overweight, I missed out on many of the social aspects of the job - things like team sports - which were important for networking. I also know that I lost contracts because company sales people preferred to make appointments with beautiful, slim women, even if they were less able or knowledgeable than me. It's not a hunch - they've told me.

"Not long ago, I was called in to sort out a technical problem at a City merchant bank. While I was fixing his computer one of the bankers said to me, 'You're a lot better at this than the last girl who came in. She was sloppy and took ages to do it'. I nearly laughed out loud: I was the 'last girl'. Not only had he not recognised me, but also he perceived that because I was thin I must be more efficient at the job than a fat person."

It's now illegal to discriminate on the basis of race or disability, but little is being done to counter discrimination on the basis of size. The CIPD believes it needs to be addressed within the broader agenda of accepting all diversity.

"Companies can't afford to clone," says Dianah Worman. "They need to reflect the diversity of society, to appreciate that people come in all shapes and sizes so that they can access the best talent around. Employers must recognise that we need to value people as individuals."

The Association of Graduate Recruiters is shortly to send out a revised briefing paper, warning graduate assessment centres of the need to be objective when recruiting new graduates. "We're spelling out the importance of only measuring factors relevant to the job," says chief executive Carl Gilleard.

"In theory, the process should eliminate personal or subjective preferences. Recruitment decisions should never be taken by one person alone and good organisations will have checks and balances in place to ensure that an individual's prejudices don't affect the decision.

"But I can't put my hand on my heart and say that discrimination against overweight applicants never happens."

No one is yet sure how the new Human Rights Act will impact on this problem. But there's no sign of any anti-discrimination legislation on the horizon. For one thing, says John Philpott, it would not be enforceable.

"Unlike race or disability, which can't be changed, most people assume that an obese person can do something about their weight - they can slim down. It may be unfair, but by taking this view employers who discriminate on the basis of weight are simply reflecting prevailing social attitudes.

"If the problem is going to be addressed, there needs to be a change in society as a whole. We need more overweight role models, more people like Sophie Dahl who prove you don't have to be thin to be beautiful. Discrimination won't stop until we change our attitudes to people who don't fit into the 'norm'."

webTitle: An ABC guide to  handling information overload

fields.headline: An ABC guide to  handling information overload
fields.trailText: Moving on up
fields.body:
A. Light work

If you're not suffering from information overload, you could be forgiven for feeling left out. Everyone with a job of any importance complains about being inundated by emails, deluged by voice messages and overcome by the internet - all tools designed to save time if you choose to use them that way. A message inviting callers to ring back at a certain time, disciplining yourself to check email infrequently and good search techniques could lighten your load considerably.

B. Freshly picked

Learn to manage knowledge so that it serves rather than swamps you. Be careful about what you store and how. Good electronic and paper filing systems are essential but become unusable if too big. Be selective about what you keep: an up-to-date address book or 'favourites file' saves time, but folders full of every interesting snippet you ever came across don't. Resist the temptation to amass as much information as you can.

C. Space age

Treat your computer, desk and brain to some free space by getting rid of clutter. Finish tasks so you can forget about them and discard information once you've finished with it. If you worry that as soon as you get rid of something you'll find a use for it, have an interim bin that's emptied regularly. Take advantage of the fact that technological advances mean what you know is often less significant than how quickly you can find out.

fields.headline: Why has he got away with it?
fields.standfirst: Henry Kissinger is revered as a statesman, cosseted guest, star of the lecture circuit. He is also the one-time US Secretary of State who oversaw the destruction of civilian populations, the assassination of politicians and the kidnapping of those who got in his way - from Indochina to Cyprus, East Timor and, here, Chile. Christopher Hitchens lays the charges

fields.body:
On December 2, 1998, Mr Michael Korda was being interviewed on camera in his office at Simon & Schuster. As one of the reigning magnates of New York publishing, he had edited and "produced" the work of authors as various as Tennessee Williams, Richard Nixon and Joan Crawford. On this particular day, he was talking about the life and thoughts of the singer Cher, whose portrait adorned the wall behind him. And then the telephone rang and there was a message to call "Dr" Henry Kissinger as soon as possible. A polymath like Mr Korda knows - what with the exigencies of publishing in these vertiginous days - how to switch in an instant between Cher and high statecraft. The camera kept running, and recorded the following scene for a tape which I possess.

Asking his secretary to get the number (759 7919 - the digits of Kissinger Associates), Mr Korda quips drily, to general laughter in the office, that it "should be 1-800-cambodia . . . 1-800-bomb-cambodia". After a pause of nicely calibrated duration (no senior editor likes to be put on hold while he's receiving company, especially media company), it's "Henry - Hi, how are you? . . . You're getting all the publicity you could want in the New York Times, but not the kind you want . . . I also think it's very, very dubious for the administration to simply say yes, they'll release these papers . . . no . . . no, absolutely . . . no . . . no . . . well, hmmm, yeah. We did it until quite recently, frankly, and he did prevail . . . Well, I don't think there's any question about that, as uncomfortable as it may be . . . Henry, this is totally outrageous . . . yeah . . . Also the jurisdiction. This is a Spanish judge appealing to an English court about a Chilean head of state. So it's, it . . . Also Spain has no rational jurisdiction over events in Chile anyway so that makes absolutely no sense . . . Well, that's probably true . . . If you would. I think that would be by far and away the best . . . Right, yeah, no I think it's exactly what you should do and I think it should be long and I think it should end with your father's letter. I think it's a very important document . . . Yes, but I think the letter is wonderful, and central to the entire book. Can you let me read the Lebanon chapter over the weekend?" At this point the conversation ends, with some jocular observations by Mr Korda about his upcoming colonoscopy: "a totally repulsive procedure".

By means of the same tiny internal camera, or its forensic equivalent, one could deduce not a little about the world of Henry Kissinger from this microcosmic exchange. The first and most important thing is this. Sitting in his office at Kissinger Associates, with its tentacles of business and consultancy stretching from Belgrade to Beijing, and cushioned by innumerable other directorships and boards, he still shudders when he hears of the arrest of a dictator. Syncopated the conversation with Mr Korda may be, but it's clear that the keyword is "jurisdiction". What had the New York Times been reporting that fine morning? On that December 2, 1998, its front page carried the following report from Tim Weiner, the paper's national security correspondent in Washington. Under the headline "US Will Release Files On Crimes Under Pinochet", he wrote:

Treading into a political and diplomatic confrontation it tried to avoid, the United States decided today to declassify some secret documents on the killings and torture committed during the dictatorship of Augusto Pinochet in Chile . . . The decision to release such documents is the first sign that the United States will cooperate in the case against General Pinochet. Clinton Administration officials said they believed the benefits of openness in human rights cases outweighed the risks to national security in this case.

But the decision could open "a can of worms", in the words of a former Central Intelligence Agency [CIA] official stationed in Chile, exposing the depth of the knowledge that the United States had about crimes charged against the Pinochet government . . .

While some European government officials have supported bringing the former dictator to court, United States officials have stayed largely silent, reflecting skepticism about the Spanish court's power, doubts about international tribunals aimed at former foreign rulers, and worries over the implications for American leaders who might someday also be accused in foreign countries.

President Richard M Nixon and Henry A Kissinger, who served as his national security advisor and Secretary of State, supported a right-wing coup in Chile in the early 1970s, previously declassified documents show.

But many of the actions of the United States during the 1973 coup, and much of what American leaders and intelligence services did in liaison with the Pinochet government after it seized power, remain under the seal of national security. The secret files on the Pinochet regime are held by the CIA, the Defense Intelligence Agency, the State Department, the Pentagon, the National Security Council, the National Archives, the Presidential libraries of Gerald R Ford and Jimmy Carter, and other government agencies.

According to Justice Department records, these files contain a history of human rights abuses and international terrorism:

 In 1975 State Department officials in Chile protested the Pinochet regime's record of killing and torture, filing dissents to American foreign policy with their superiors in Washington.

 The CIA has files on assassinations by the regime and the Chilean secret police. The intelligence agency also has records on Chile's attempts to establish an international right-wing covert-action squad.

 The Ford Library contains many of Mr Kissinger's secret files on Chile, which have never been made public. Through a secretary, Mr Kissinger declined a request for an interview today.

One must credit Kissinger with grasping what so many other people did not: that if the Pinochet precedent became established, then he himself was in some danger. The United States believes that it alone pursues and indicts war criminals and "international terrorists"; nothing in its political or journalistic culture yet allows for the thought that it might be harbouring and sheltering such a senior one. Yet the thought had very obliquely surfaced in Mr Weiner's story, and Kissinger was a worried man when he called his editor that day to discuss a memoir (eventually published under the unbearably dull and self-regarding title Years Of Renewal) that was still in progress.

"Harbouring and sheltering", though, are understatements for the lavishness of Henry Kissinger's circumstances. His advice is sought, at $25,000 an appearance, by audiences of businessmen and academics and policymakers. His turgid newspaper column is syndicated by the Los Angeles Times. His first volume of memoirs was part written and also edited by Harold Evans, who with Tina Brown is among the many hosts and hostesses who solicit Kissinger's company, or perhaps, one should say, society, for those telling New York soirées. At different times, he has been a consultant to ABC News and CBS; his most successful diplomacy, indeed, has probably been conducted with the media (and his single greatest achievement has been to get almost everybody to call him "Doctor"). Fawned on by Ted Koppel, sought out by corporations and despots with "image" problems or "failures of communication", and given respectful attention by presidential candidates and those whose task it is to "mould" their global vision, this man wants for little in the pathetic universe that the "self-esteem" industry exists to serve. Of whom else would Norman Podhoretz write, in a bended-knee encomium to Years Of Upheaval:

What we have here is writing of the very highest order. It is writing that is equally at ease in portraiture and abstract analysis; that can shape a narrative as skilfully as it can paint a scene; that can achieve marvels of compression while moving at an expansive and leisurely pace. It is writing that can shift without strain or falsity of tone from the gravitas befitting a book about great historical events to the humor and irony dictated by an unfailing sense of human proportion.

A critic who can suck like that, as was once drily said by one of my moral tutors, need never dine alone. And nor need his subject. Except that, every now and then, the recipient (and donor) of so much sycophancy feels a tremor of anxiety. He leaves the well-furnished table and scurries to the bathroom. Is it perhaps another disclosure on a newly released Nixon tape? Some stray news from Indonesia, portending the fall or imprisonment of another patron (and perhaps the escape of an awkward document or two)? The arrest or indictment of a torturer or assassin, the expiry of the statute of secrecy for some obscure cabinet papers in a faraway country - any one of these can instantly spoil his day. As we see from the Korda tape, Kissinger cannot open the morning paper with the assurance of tranquillity. Because he knows what others can only suspect, or guess at. He knows. And he is a prisoner of the knowledge as, to some extent, are we.

Notice the likeable way in which Mr Korda demonstrates his broadmindedness with the Cambodia jest. Everybody "knows", after all, that Kissinger inflicted terror and misery and mass death on that country, and great injury to the United States Constitution at the same time. (Everybody also "knows" that other vulnerable nations can lay claim to the same melancholy and hateful distinction, with incremental or "collateral" damage to American democracy keeping pace.) Yet the pudgy man standing in black tie at the Vogue party is not, surely, the man who ordered and sanctioned the destruction of civilian populations, the assassination of inconvenient politicians, the kidnapping and disappearance of soldiers and journalists and clerics who got in his way? Oh, but he is. It's exactly the same man.

And that may be among the most nauseating reflections of all. Kissinger is not invited and feted because of his exquisite manners or his mordant wit (his manners are in any case rather gross, and his wit consists of a quiver of borrowed and secondhand darts). No, he is sought after because his presence supplies a frisson: the authentic touch of raw and unapologetic power. There's a slight guilty nervousness on the edge of Mr Korda's gag about the indescribable sufferings of Indochina. And I've noticed, time and again standing at the back of the audience during Kissinger speeches, that laughter of the nervous, uneasy kind is the sort of laughter he likes to provoke. In exacting this tribute, he flaunts not the "aphrodisiac" of power (another of his plagiarised bons mots) but its pornography.

In a famous expression of his contempt for democracy, Kissinger once observed that he saw no reason why a certain country should be allowed to "go Marxist" merely because "its people are irresponsible". The country concerned was Chile, which at the time of this remark had a justified reputation as the most highly evolved pluralistic democracy in the southern hemisphere of the Americas. The pluralism translated, in the years of the Cold War, into an electorate that voted about one-third conservative, one-third socialist and communist, and one-third Christian Democratic and centrist. This had made it relatively easy to keep the Marxist element from having its turn in government, and ever since 1962 the CIA had - as it had in Italy and other comparable nations - largely contented itself with funding the reliable elements.

In September 1970, however, the Left's candidate actually gained a slight plurality of 36.2% in the presidential elections. Divisions on the Right, and the adherence of some smaller radical and Christian parties to the Left, made it a moral certainty that the Chilean Congress would, after the traditional 60-day interregnum, confirm Dr Salvador Allende as the next president. But the very name of Allende was anathema to the extreme Right in Chile, to certain powerful corporations (notably ITT, Pepsi Cola and the Chase Manhattan Bank) which did business in Chile and the United States, and to the CIA.

This loathing quickly communicated itself to President Nixon. He was personally beholden to Donald Kendall, the president of Pepsi Cola, who had given him his first corporate account when, as a young lawyer, he had joined John Mitchell's New York firm. A series of Washington meetings, held within 11 days of Allende's electoral victory, essentially settled the fate of Chilean democracy. After discussions with interested parties, and with CIA director Richard Helms, Kissinger went with Helms to the Oval Office. Helms's notes of the meeting show that Nixon wasted little breath in making his wishes known. Allende was not to assume office. "Not concerned risks involved. No involvement of embassy. $10,000,000 available, more if necessary. Full-time job - best men we have . . . Make the economy scream. 48 hours for plan of action."

Declassified documents show that Kissinger - who had previously neither known nor cared about Chile, describing it offhandedly as "a dagger pointed at the heart of Antarctica" - took seriously this chance to impress his boss. A group was set up in Langley, Virginia, with the express purpose of running a "two track" policy for Chile: one the ostensible diplomatic one and the other - unknown to the State Department or the US ambassador to Chile, Edward Korry - a strategy of destabilisation, kidnap and assassination, designed to provoke a military coup.

There were long- and short-term obstacles to the incubation of such an intervention, especially in the brief interval available before Allende took his oath of office. The long-term obstacle was the tradition of military abstention from politics in Chile, a tradition which marked off the country from its neighbours. Such a military culture was not to be degraded overnight. The short-term obstacle lay in the person of one man - General René Schneider. As chief of the Chilean General Staff, he was adamantly opposed to any military meddling in the electoral process. Accordingly, it was decided at a meeting on September 18, 1970, that General Schneider had to go.

The plan was to have him kidnapped by extremist officers, in such a way as to make it appear that leftist and pro-Allende elements were behind the plot. The resulting confusion, it was hoped, would panic the Chilean Congress into denying Allende the presidency. A sum of $50,000 was offered around the Chilean capital, Santiago, for any officer or officers enterprising enough to take on this task. Richard Helms and his director of covert operations, Thomas Karamessines, told Kissinger that they were not optimistic. Military circles were hesitant and divided, or else loyal to General Schneider and the Chilean constitution. As Helms put it in a later account of the conversation, "We tried to make clear to Kissinger how small the possibility of success was." Kissinger firmly told Helms and Karamessines to press on in any case.

Here one must pause for a recapitulation. An unelected official in the United States is meeting with others, without the knowledge or authorisation of Congress, to plan the kidnapping of a constitution-minded senior officer in a democratic country with which the United States is not at war, and with which it maintains cordial diplomatic relations. The minutes of the meetings may have an official look to them (though they were hidden from the light of day for long enough) but what we are reviewing is a "hit" - a piece of state-supported terrorism.
