webTitle: The heart of a vanished world

fields.headline: The heart of a vanished world
fields.standfirst: The seal has a unique place in western isles folk-tales, collected by the late David Thomson. His friend  Seamus Heaney celebrates the poetic force of these evocative stories, as Thomson's classic book is reissued
fields.trailText: The seal has a unique place in western isles folk-tales, collected by the late David Thomson. His friend Seamus Heaney celebrates the poetic force of these evocative stories, as Thomson's classic book is reissued
fields.body:
"It canna be true," says Osie, the Orkney crofter who appears in David Thomson's memorable book, "but there was supposed to be a creature in the water for every one on land." And a moment later - insisting again, "This canna be true" - he tells the author a story about a stranger cow that came up from the sea and installed herself in a byre on the land. "And she had grand calves. But I forget, now, was it a seal or another cow came years after to the door o' the byre . . . and the cow went away to the sea again." And then comes the clinching cadence: "An old woman told me yon," said Osie. "Well, there was supposed to be cows and sheep and every animal there. But the seals were the people o' the sea."

In the presence of such alluring inventions and such substantial voice, analysis and appreciation feel superfluous. Talk of the willing suspension of disbelief, of the salubrious effect of imaginative narrative, characterisations of the mental habits of pre-industrial societies, conjectures about how the sociological facts got displaced in earlier days into the parallel universe of the mythological - all such commentary seems to lead in the wrong direction. David Thomson's book is luminously its own thing; it had its origins in one man's rambles round the highlands and islands of Scotland and the west coast of Ireland, in search of stories and folklore surrounding the "selchie" or grey Atlantic seal. It was written at a great moment in the history of radio, during the 1940s and 1950s, when the BBC employed poets and writers to record and collect oral material and - most important - gave them permission to re-create it in a new artistic form. Consequently it survives not as a period piece but as a poetic achievement, one of those whose works written by "a man speaking to men: a man, it is true, endued with more lively sensibility, more enthusiasm and tenderness, who has a greater knowledge of human nature, and a more com prehensive soul, than are supposed to be common among mankind . . ."

William Wordsworth's definition of a poet, which I have just quoted, seems an appropriate characterisation of the man who wrote The People Of The Sea. Indeed, what kept coming to mind as I re-read the book was Wordsworth's poem, The Solitary Reaper. One of the most haunting lyrics in the English language, this too was written after a tour in Scotland and is about the experience of listening to one of the local people express herself unforgettably in her native Gaelic. The sight of women working in the harvest fields must have been a common one at the time, but interestingly enough, the poet found his immediate inspiration in the manuscript of a book by his friend Thomas Wilkinson: "Passed by a Female who was reaping alone, she sung in Erse as she bended over her sickle, the sweetest human voice I ever heard. Her strains were tenderly melancholy, and felt delicious long after they were heard no more." Wordsworth's final stanza uses some of Wilkinson's exact words, but what was notation in the prose becomes incantation in the poem:

Whate'er the theme, the Maiden sang

As if her song could have no ending;

I saw her singing at her work,

And o'er the sickle bending;

I listened, motionless and still;

And, as I mounted up the hill,

The music in my heart I bore,

Long after it was heard no more.

This famous stanza is like a spell that keeps time, in two senses: it keeps the metrical beat of the octosyllabic line, and it also manages to shift into the eternal present of song-time an incident that might otherwise have remained part of the accidental record. When Wordsworth's lines are repeated, the reader or listener re-enters the prolonged trance that the first listener experienced; "the Maiden" still sings "as if her song could have no ending" because of the entranc ing, prolonging power of the rhymes and cadences. The chance words of Thomas Wilkinson's Tour of Scotland have been magicked into the domain of the eternally recurrent, the once-upon-a-time world of story, where the strains of "no ending" and "still" and "more" echo and overflow above the brim of the usual.

The transformations and transports that Wordsworth effects in verse in The Solitary Reaper, David Thomson manages to encompass in the prose - narrative, lyrical, dramatic - of The People Of The Sea. Here too, what was heard in the "chaunt" of the storyteller gets fixed on the page, only to rise in all its formality and down-to-earthness at each re-reading. Notations of the author's different tours of Scotland (and of Ireland) have been re-imagined and re-presented in an idiom that makes the reader a kind of dual citizen, at once the inhabitant of a poetically beguiling world of pure story and of a realistically documented world of fishermen and crofters. By performing the task of the historian he was trained to be and that of the artist he was born to become, David Thomson is answering the two calls that reality made upon him. He envisages, even as he records, with the result that librarians are probably hard put to find an exact category for the book: it has elements of both "fiction" and "non-fiction". Readers, on the other hand, will be carried away on the successive waves of pleasure, as the here-and-nowness of the people and scenes evoked by the author gives way to there-and-thenness of the stories they narrate.

David Thomson's achievement is pre-eminently stylistic; his writing combines a feel for the "this-worldness" of his characters' lives with an understanding of the "otherworldness" they keep a place for in their consciousness. Which is a way of saying that the stylistic achievement depends upon a deep imaginative sympathy. What could have been a matter of fieldwork being written up into a casebook becomes a matter of memory and its contents being liberated into a new and transfigured pattern. The book recovers and revives the old trope of human beings as creatures dwelling in a middle state, caught between the worlds of the angels and the animals; it is obviously an archive of lore about the seal, and obliquely an account of traditional cultures on the verge of dissolution, but at the mythic level it presents us with an image of ourselves in those amphibians we have evolved from, all of us (to quote Wordsworth again) "inmates of this active universe", all susceptible to "the still, sad music of humanity".

What delights is the absence of nostalgia. Even as the men in a cabin give themselves up to an eerie tale of child-kidnap by a seal, one of them is talking about remedies for the warble-fly: "I tried motor oil and sulfur powder mixed." Even as a storyteller invokes the ancient glamour of the Celtic ceo draíochta , he resolutely de-mystifies it: "So the seal set up a magic fog, or what is called in modern parlance a smoke screen . . ." And yet, for all the up-to-dateness of the idiom, the fundamental understanding of these characters is shaped by what the poet Edwin Muir once termed "that long lost, archaic companionship" between human beings and the creatures. Plainly, memorably, repeatedly, instances of this old eye-to-eye and breath-to-breath closeness between living things appear in the narrative. Michael the Ferryman judges the strength of the current he is rowing into by watching the toils of the big seal in heavy water adjacent to the boat; a child escaped from drowning is warmed back to consciousness in a "Black House" in South Uist between the generous bodies of two cows; on Papa Stour in Shetland, in an old cowshed, the author himself gradually attains a state of almost animal consciousness:

"I heard a raven croak twice. I felt the autumn coldly on my face, but because this old cowshed had been lately used for dipping sheep there was a smell of dung as though the warm life of the farm lingered on."

Edwin Muir's sense of the need for a renewed covenant with all life and a respect for its sacredness was inspired directly by the shadow of nuclear destruction that loomed over the 1950s. It may be pushing things to suggest that Thomson's book was equally prompted by the prevailing mood, but it is no exaggeration to say that it continues to present itself to the understanding as an elegy for certain salvific elements which "progress" and modernity were bound to destroy.

The sweetness and intimacy of David Thomson's imagination mean that he is able to bring us very close to that vanished world. His complete at-homeness in the crofts and cabins and "Black Houses" he entered, his ability to be all ear and eye, allow the reader access to the otherness of the minds and manners of those he met there. Total respect, intuitive understanding, perfect grace and perfect pitch - possessed of such gifts, he was never regarded as an intruder. The naturalness of his presence seems always to have made up for its unexpectedness; he arrived into other people's lives as simply and mysteriously as Michael the Ferryman arrived into his:

"I stopped to look at a cairn of stones by the roadside. Out of a hole in the ground about fifty yards away, where he was cutting turf, a man came slowly to me.

'It's a nice day,' I said.

'It is grand drying weather, thanks be to God.' "

In this exchange, the one tiny variation that the Mayo man plays on the author's opening greeting is a guarantee of the complete delicacy and accuracy of David Thomson's ear. The replacement of "It's" by "It is" indicates the different measure and ever so slight caution of the Irish voice in the English tongue, and reveals in detail the overall trustworthiness of this writing. Little touches carry us at one time out into the exposed spaces of the elemental world, as when he talks of Shetland sheep, "their horns warm to touch in the rain"; at another time, a whole culture of human endurance is conjured up in a single observation, as when the young Ronald Iain Finlay remembers coming to in his mother's arms. His father had been drowned and the boy had been washed ashore: "My mother was weeping again, and I clung to the warmth of her, watching the faces about us, and the faces were steady." That steadiness reminds me of Homer's Odysseus bearing up, "his eyelids steady as wrinkled horn or iron", listening incognito while the bard Demodicus recites the tale of Troy.

And yet for all the Homeric sombreness underlying the attitude of the characters, what is constantly to the fore in the writing is something more gambolling, something more like Arion escaping on the dolphin's back. It is the benignity and essential justice of the relations pertaining between the people of the land and the peo ple of the sea that give these stories an irresistible holistic beauty. Mother seals that suckle human infants, gentlemen seals that provide seal-back rides to the November fair and then go for a drink afterwards, wounded seals that require the hand that cut them open to close them up again, lover seals that arrive "at the seventh stream" to meet the yearning young wife - "and it wasna for good they met so often" - these are not escapist fantasies but a form of poetry, especially if we think of poetry in terms of its definition as a dream dreamt in the presence of reason.

I was lucky enough to get to know David Thomson and his wife, Martina, 20 years after the publication of The People Of The Sea. Woodbrook (1974), a book that was at once an erotic idyll and a work of historical reconstruction, had just appeared and was making a great stir. It told of David's arrival in Ireland in the 1930s as tutor to the young daughter of an Anglo-Irish family in County Roscommon, and through that story contrived also to tell the story of other realities - social, cultural, historical and political - that had been central to Irish life for centuries. Again, this was a version of pastoral, the world regarded through an artfully innocent eye, one that thereby revealed all the more lucidly rights and wrongs, hurts and beauties, usually taken for granted.

A result of its success was the increased frequency of the Thomsons' visits to Dublin and other parts of the country, and the opportunity to become friends. By the time of David's death in 1988, the writer whom I had first got to know in print as the co-author (with George Ewart Evans) of another classic beast-book, The Leaping Hare (1972), had published two further books of autobiography, In Camden Town (1983) and Nairn In Darkness And Light (1987), work where he followed his own creative, truth-telling bent with character- istic unpredictability and sprightliness.

Nairn In Darkness And Light takes him back to the house he calls Tigh na Rosan in the first chapter of The People Of The Sea, and in the later book he re-creates the Edwardian order of life that reigned there for a few years after the first world war. As the son of a father who had served in the Indian army and had been wounded in the trenches, David was sprung from that socially privileged world, but at the age of 11 what might have been an education and a career typical of one of its members was interrupted. Because of an injury to his eye, which would drastically impair his sight for years to come, his parents sent him north out of England to the large, sea-lit security of his grandparents' home, and it was because of the uncanny purity of his account of that place, and of the life he lived in it, that I found myself one summer night a few years after David's death, on the pier at Nairn.

Behind me, the big house he had dwelt in was now a hotel, but out beyond, the Moray Firth still clucked at the pier-head and glimmered like cloudy pewter as far as the horizon. Then suddenly in the early dark the strollers were murmuring and halting, hands were pointing toward an agitation in the water farther out. I heard the word "dolphins". There was a perceptible flitter and rollick in the dark offing, and all through my body a tremor of joy: I couldn't help imagining the spirit of our friend, out there astride the dolphin's back, scanning the waves for a selchie, haring it for dear life toward the open sea.

The naturalness of his presence seems always to have made up for its unexpectedness; he arrived into other people's lives as simply and mysteriously as Michael the Ferryman arrived into his: "I stopped to look at a cairn of stones by the roadside. Out of a hole in the ground about fifty yards away, where he was cutting turf, a man came slowly to me. 'It's a nice day,' I said. 'It is grand drying weather, thanks be to God.' " In this exchange, the one tiny variation that the Mayo man plays on the author's opening greeting is a guarantee of the complete delicacy and accuracy of David Thomson's ear. The replacement of "It's" by "It is" indicates the different measure and ever so slight caution of the Irish voice in the English tongue, and reveals in detail the overall trustworthiness of this writing. Little touches carry us at one time out into the exposed spaces of the elemental world, as when he talks of Shetland sheep, "their horns warm to touch in the rain"; at another time, a whole culture of human endurance is conjured up in a single observation, as when the young Ronald Iain Finlay remembers coming to in his mother's arms. His father had been drowned and the boy had been washed ashore: "My mother was weeping again, and I clung to the warmth of her, watching the faces about us, and the faces were steady." That steadiness reminds me of Homer's Odysseus bearing up, "his eyelids steady as wrinkled horn or iron", listening incognito while the bard Demodicus recites the tale of Troy. And yet for all the Homeric sombreness underlying the attitude of the characters, what is constantly to the fore in the writing is something more gambolling, something more like Arion escaping on the dolphin's back. It is the benignity and essential justice of the relations pertaining between the people of the land and the peo ple of the sea that give these stories an irresistible holistic beauty. Mother seals that suckle human infants, gentlemen seals that provide seal-back rides to the November fair and then go for a drink afterwards, wounded seals that require the hand that cut them open to close them up again, lover seals that arrive "at the seventh stream" to meet the yearning young wife - "and it wasna for good they met so often" - these are not escapist fantasies but a form of poetry, especially if we think of poetry in terms of its definition as a dream dreamt in the presence of reason. I was lucky enough to get to know David Thomson and his wife, Martina, 20 years after the publication of The People Of The Sea. Woodbrook (1974), a book that was at once an erotic idyll and a work of historical reconstruction, had just appeared and was making a great stir. It told of David's arrival in Ireland in the 1930s as tutor to the young daughter of an Anglo-Irish family in County Roscommon, and through that story contrived also to tell the story of other realities - social, cultural, historical and political - that had been central to Irish life for centuries. Again, this was a version of pastoral, the world regarded through an artfully innocent eye, one that thereby revealed all the more lucidly rights and wrongs, hurts and beauties, usually taken for granted. A result of its success was the increased frequency of the Thomsons' visits to Dublin and other parts of the country, and the opportunity to become friends. By the time of David's death in 1988, the writer whom I had first got to know in print as the co-author (with George Ewart Evans) of another classic beast-book, The Leaping Hare (1972), had published two further books of autobiography, In Camden Town (1983) and Nairn In Darkness And Light (1987), work where he followed his own creative, truth-telling bent with character- istic unpredictability and sprightliness. Nairn In Darkness And Light takes him back to the house he calls Tigh na Rosan in the first chapter of The People Of The Sea, and in the later book he re-creates the Edwardian order of life that reigned there for a few years after the first world war. As the son of a father who had served in the Indian army and had been wounded in the trenches, David was sprung from that socially privileged world, but at the age of 11 what might have been an education and a career typical of one of its members was interrupted. Because of an injury to his eye, which would drastically impair his sight for years to come, his parents sent him north out of England to the large, sea-lit security of his grandparents' home, and it was because of the uncanny purity of his account of that place, and of the life he lived in it, that I found myself one summer night a few years after David's death, on the pier at Nairn. Behind me, the big house he had dwelt in was now a hotel, but out beyond, the Moray Firth still clucked at the pier-head and glimmered like cloudy pewter as far as the horizon. Then suddenly in the early dark the strollers were murmuring and halting, hands were pointing toward an agitation in the water farther out. I heard the word "dolphins". There was a perceptible flitter and rollick in the dark offing, and all through my body a tremor of joy: I couldn't help imagining the spirit of our friend, out there astride the dolphin's back, scanning the waves for a selchie, haring it for dear life toward the open sea. ©Seamus Heaney, 2001. From his introduction to a new edition of The People Of The Sea: Celtic Tales of the Seal Folk by David Thomson, published by Canongate Classics, £6.99. fields.headline: Bite size
fields.standfirst: Harriet Porter looks at  My Canapé Hell, by Imogen Edwards-Jones, Dead Long Enough, by James Hawes,  Dressing Up for the Carnival, by Carol Shields,   Danny Boy, by Jo-ann Goodwin and Grits, by Niall Griffiths
fields.trailText: Harriet Porter looks at My Canapé Hell, by Imogen Edwards-Jones, Dead Long Enough, by James Hawes, Dressing Up for the Carnival, by Carol Shields, Danny Boy, by Jo-ann Goodwin and Grits, by Niall Griffiths
fields.body:
My Canapé Hell,
Imogen Edwards-Jones
(Flame, £6.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Oh dear. When Edwards-Jones's alter ego Abigail reacts to a nervy moment by telling us she wants to throw up all over her consul (sic), we begin to realise that the author is not, perhaps, Henry James. But as a light-hearted, insiderish account of the squalid world of celebrity, PR, drugs, drink and impossibly small skirts, does My Canapé Hell work? Er, not really. The problem largely relates to having one's cake and eating it. If you want to send up vacuous, stupid people who divide the world into A, B and C-list invitees, then you have to strive not to sound quite so admiring and envious of them. In contrast, this sounds too much like the author's idea of heaven.

Dead Long Enough
James Hawes
(Vintage, £6.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

In which we learn how truly dreadful it is to be a rather successful but faintly balding man facing his 40th birthday. And how much worse to be his somewhat less successful sidekick. Archaeologist Harry MacDonald - presenter of the "arse-clenchingly trendy" Among the Dead, Live - is adept at off-the-wall celebrations; every year he gathers together his old pals for a drink-fuelled dérive around the low-spots of Britain. This time, however, they head for Ireland, whereupon beautiful girls with implausibly spelt names and IRA renegades get in on the act. It's a well-made comedy, if disappointingly short on surprises; but not, perhaps, for the 39-year-olds.

Dressing Up for the Carnival
Carol Shields
(Fourth Estate, £6.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Despite the comic whimsy that informs most of these stories - tales of what happens when the weather disappears, or we are suddenly deprived of windows, or a harp falls on top of you - this collection reveals some uncompromising attitudes. At this particular carnival, Shields masquerades as the confectioner, presenting us with treats that look as light as candy-floss, but lurking beneath are her real subjects: isolation, abandonment, deprivation, cruelty. Her conspiratorial wittiness prevents the stories from depressing preachiness, preferring instead to render them as "cycles of consolation and enhancement".

Danny Boy
Jo-ann Goodwin
(Bantam, £6.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

It sounds like a terrible mess: Trainspotting uprooted and set in sunny Doncaster, some gangsterish capers and, worst of all, a handful of magical realism involving a medieval monk and an elusive princess. In fact, it's a hugely impressive debut, in which Goodwin at once manages to sustain the narrative voice - that of 19-year-old drug addict Danny MacIntyre - and to manipulate our sympathy and distaste. There's also a pacy plot, as Danny and pals are forced to quit Doncaster and seek anonymity down south after one of their circle is brutally murdered. The stations on Danny's pilgrimage to some sort of humanity are bleakly, but beautifully, observed.

Grits
Niall Griffiths
(Vintage, £6.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

More unavoidable Trainspotting comparisons with this in-your-face first novel, a vernacular tale of a group of wasted drifters in west Wales (the cover of which bears fulsome praise from Welsh himself). Yet Griffiths combines his extraordinary ear for idiom with a grand mythic strain: the nine unrelenting monologues of pills, raves and red wine for breakfast are counterpointed with a rugged sense of the beauties of landscape. He also tackles unflinchingly the less fashionable horrors of alcoholism, while the fact that he keeps the reader absorbed for nigh-on 500 pages of plotless entropy, the narrative soaring on voice alone, is an achievement in itself.

fields.headline: A Child Called It, written and read by Dave Pelzer
fields.standfirst:
(Orion Audio, £8.99, 85 min)
Buy it at a discount at BOL
Hear an extract
You will need RealPlayer to listen to this clip. You can download it here free
fields.trailText: This is very short, but ample for its dreadful litany of banal cruelty. We are used to upbeat American accounts of comfy, secure middle-class childhoods. Hearing the similar voice here underscores the enormity of the crimes suffered.
fields.body: This is very short, but ample for its dreadful litany of banal cruelty. You can't bear very long to hear someone describe how his drunken mother starved him for days at a time, beat, burned and stabbed him, force-fed him ammonia, and held his head under the bathwater. The young Pelzer was the household slave. Despised by schoolmates for stealing their food to survive and for his noxious smell - his mother never washed his clothes - he accepted her repeated verdict that he was utterly worthless, no boy like his brothers but an "it". The point, says Pelzer, who is now an author and self-help preacher, is that he survived, and that we all have this indomitable instinct. We are used to upbeat American accounts of comfy, secure middle-class childhoods. Hearing the similar voice here underscores the enormity of the crimes he suffered.

fields.headline: Hardline history
fields.standfirst: John Dugdale looks at an account of Israel's history in The Iron Wall by Avi Shlaim, plus Continental Drifter by Tim Moore, and Moments of Reprieve by Primo Levi
fields.trailText: John Dugdale looks at an account of Israel's history in The Iron Wall by Avi Shlaim, plus Continental Drifter by Tim Moore, and Moments of Reprieve by Primo Levi
fields.body:
The Iron Wall
Avi Shlaim
(Penguin, £10.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Israel's founders and their successors, Shlaim argues, have adhered to Ze'ev Jabotinsky's 1920s "iron wall" strategy, based on building up military strength to force the Arabs to negotiate from a position of weakness - but Jabotinsky's expectation of eventual coexistence with the Palestinians was rejected by later hardliners such as Netanyahu. Ending with Barak's election in 1999, this compellingly myth-busting history of Zionism reminds you how many of today's personalities and issues have been around since the Jewish state's infancy. Ariel Sharon makes his first appearance as a commando general in 1953, slaughtering 69 civilians while obliterating a Jordanian village.

Continental Drifter
Tim Moore
(Abacus, £10.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Visiting countries simply because he hasn't covered them before, Bill Bryson has it easy. Bryson wannabes, in contrast, need a gimmick. Tim Moore's is to retrace the itineraries of pre-modern travellers, making an admired debut by shadowing a Victorian explorer, and now re-enacting Thomas Coryate's pioneering 1608 Grand Tour. Journeying to Venice in a moribund Rolls Royce, Moore whinges with unflagging wit. But his main rival for Bryson's mantle, Tony Hawks ( Beating the Moldovans at Tennis ), still holds the crown, as his books are based on bets that require him to befriend and enlist foreigners. Moore rarely meets anyone other than surly waiters and hoteliers.

Moments of Reprieve
Primo Levi
(Penguin, £6.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

These brief recollections of figures the author knew in Auschwitz do not concern the "anonymous, faceless, voiceless" Nazi victims of his darker If This Is a Man , prostrate and close to forfeiting their humanity, but those, as Levi writes in his Introduction, "begging me to help them survive and enjoy the ambiguous perennial existence of literary characters". They include a gypsy, a juggler-cum-burglar, a smart rogue and a cantor; they are all resiliently human, unsuppressibly individual. The Holocaust in this book looms largely unmentioned, with Levi concentrating on "bizarre, marginal moments of reprieve" in lives spent as starving slaves.

webTitle: Review: Les Onze Mille Vièrges, or The Amorous Adventures of Prince Mony Vibescu by Guillaume Apollinaire

fields.headline: Les Onze Mille Vièrges, or The Amorous Adventures of Prince Mony Vibescu by Guillaume Apollinaire
fields.trailText: The definitive version of this entertaining erotic novel didn't see the light of day in French until 1973. As the TLS uncharacteristically pronounced: "The rutting is non-stop."
fields.body:
(Peter Owen, £9.95)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

In 1907 the distinguished poet Apollinaire clandestinely published this entertaining erotic novel. The definitive version wouldn't see the light of day in French until 1973. As the TLS uncharacteristically pronounced: "The rutting is non-stop." There is a pun in the title: verge means a rod or switch, and also stands for a penis, while vièrge means virgin. During the fifth century, the Huns massacred 11,000 ( onze mille ) virgins at Cologne. Prince Mony himself meets a fate involving 11,000 flagellations.

webTitle: A life in writing: Phillip Horne

fields.headline: Correspondence games
fields.standfirst: Phillip Horne tells Nicholas Wroe how he came to edit Henry James's letters
fields.trailText: Phillip Horne tells Nicholas Wroe how he came to edit Henry James's letters
fields.body:
Philip Horne's first exposure to Henry James came when he read The Golden Bowl as an undergraduate at Cambridge in 1976. "I read about five pages an hour and it took three weeks," Horne recalls. "It was a total immersion." A quarter of a century on, Horne is still immersed. His book Henry James and Revision was published in 1990 and he has edited new editions of three James novels.

This month sees the paperback publication of his Henry James: A Life in Letters . As the book evolved over 10 years, Horne realised that he was "fashioning a Victorian life and letters. I felt that the letters were very close to making a narrative you could follow. I just needed to fill in the gaps."

Through the use of links and introductory paragraphs, Horne builds a convincing case for the letters being, in James's phrase about his brother William's letters, "his real and best biography". They are packed with contacts with the leading literary figures of the age - Flaubert, Zola, Turgenev, Thackeray and Ezra Pound all crop up - and contain some of James's major writing. "There are passages that are quoted as much as anything else he wrote," says Horne.

There is no complete edition of James's letters, and about half of the 296 letters in Horne's book have not been published before. The consensus is that James wrote between 12,000 and 15,000 letters in his lifetime, but this is guesswork: it could be as high as 40,000. "I'm not a vocational editor," Horne explains. "I edited them because I felt that someone should and no one else would. I wanted them to be there so I could read them, so this is really the book I wish somebody else had done for me to refer to."

Unlike many biographers who have worked on a subject for such a long time, Horne has not grown to hate James. He is proud to be the owner of one James's letters to a magazine editor. ("I was a prisoner in London all winter with gout and fetters," James complains in it.) "A lot are still in private hands and collectors often don't want them published because it reduces their value," explains Horne. "I paid £400 specifically so I could give myself permission to include it. I'd like a portrait of James, but they are rather more expensive."

Academic study of James has in recent years been energised by speculation as to James's sexuality. Horne makes no judgment but acknowledges: "I know others are more eager to read between the lines than me. I was interested in James as, primarily, a creative writer. I thought attention to things that we could definitely know was more rewarding than being preoccupied with things we could only guess at, however interesting they are. But it's not an area I would rule out. There is no question that James knew lots of gay writers and gay men and was on close terms with them. But he was on close terms with lots of people."

One area where Horne has offered a new reading is that of James's relations with the business of publishing. "It rather complicates the picture of him as a helpless, unworldly artist in his ivory tower - although that has some truth to it," reports Horne. "He could also be quite hard-nosed and tough, and some of the letters to publishers and editors are fairly firm and even aggressive."

Horne's next James project takes this theme on, and will further explore James rubbing up against various harsh aspects of the real world - "James on American politics, the theatre and on the critical controversies of the 1880s," says Horne. "It was quite a knockabout world of polemic and abuse through which he tried to pick his way."

Although best known through his work on James, Horne has also managed to engage in a wide range of other literary activities. He has been writing literary journalism since he started reviewing new fiction for the London Review of Books in 1983. As Reader in English Literature at University College, London since 1995, he says he has done as much teaching of film - he writes for the film journal Sight and Sound - as he has of Henry James.

"I very much enjoy teaching. When you can get it right, the balance between teaching, writing and journalism can be very good. That balance between solitude and human contact can be the ideal. It keeps your feet on the ground and reminds you what people are interested in."

His next publication will be an introduction to the new Penguin edition of Oliver Twist . "Very good fun. A refreshing change from James - and it's nice to work on a best-seller."

What about the future of letters? Will technology kill off this literary resource? "Well, someone will need to print out emails in order for them to survive," say Horne. "The electronic form is always liable to be cleaned out or the software won't be supported. Paper is still the primary medium, and I certainly print out the interesting emails I get."

One way in which email will help is by solving the problem of indecipherable handwriting. By re-examining the originals, Horne has uncovered several mistakes in previous editions of the letters that alter the sense of what James actually said.

"But while emails will of course make it easier, it will also be less exciting," says Horne, whose enthusiasm for tracking down odd scraps all over the world appears undiminished. "It just won't be the same as a scholar in the archives looking at crumbling old letters written in mauve ink with an actual signature on the end."

"It just won't be the same as a scholar in the archives looking at crumbling old letters written in mauve ink with an actual signature on the end."

fields.headline: Hotel Rosa
fields.trailText:
In the open briefcase

of the man across the aisle

on the bus from the airport

lies the manuscript of my poems...
fields.body:
In the open briefcase
of the man across the aisle
on the bus from the airport
lies the manuscript of my poems.
I keep sneaking glances,
wondering about that haircut.
As we cross the lagoon,
and a smell of decaying fish
pervades the bus,
he turns to face me
with the look of one interrupted
by yet another of the pointless
bureaucratic intrusions
to which travellers are prone.
*
The style, Herr Fischer remarks of A-,
over our breakfast omelette
under the jacaranda tree
at the Hotel Rosa,
is that of a man
whose work has been translated
into forty-two languages
and then back into English.
His fingers are long and bony
but heavy on the keys.
From his room overlooking the garden
bouts of regular typing
alternate with curious bleats.
*
Two lime-green Sunbeam taxis
idle outside the gate.
One driver is asleep,
the other reminds me
of a tennis ex-pro
my father once packed me off to
after school, to practise my backhand.
I can't write a thing...
Herr Fischer has asked me
for a list of my favourite songs.
*
Sleep deprivation
may account for my headache today.
Last night, as we sat on the verandah
counting the fireflies,
an almighty splashing -
than a tall red-bearded man
came stumbling towards us,
shaking water off his clothes
like a wet dog.
Lawrence has arrived
with his difficult wife.
*
The Lawrences, Herr Fischer and I
shared a taxi to the open-air museum.
'The working model
of the funicular railway
(the original having been damaged
beyond repair) was made
by the metalwork class
of the boys' reformatory.'
Somehow I lost the others
and then got lost myself.
I am writing this
in a bar near the harbour,
surrounded by naked women
and drunken Chinese sailors.
Rarely have I been so happy.
*
Herr Fischer's birthday.
A storm that came out of nowhere
has cut off the electricity.
We play cards by candlelight
with the hotel proprietor,
who lost an arm in the war
( Which war? I keep meaning to ask.)
In the yard at the back for cars
Lawrence is attempting to light a fire
of unseasoned wood
to spit-roast a kid.
Rain at the window again...
I feel certain Frieda is cheating *
Lawrence at a loss for words!
Going down to the lobby
to ask for a plug for the bath,
I find him failing to convince
an itinerant vendor
of the worth of his Seiko watch.
He seems none too sure himself
of the provenance
of the mahogany statuette he desires
*
Is it something I said?
Herr Fischer is avoiding me.
All day I've been carrying around
the money I owe him
from our game of pontoon.
*
So quiet this morning.
Alone in the dining room,
I very gently banged the gong.
There followed a shriek of laughter
from behind the kitchen door.
Herr Fischer and Lawrence
have departed upriver
on the trail of dark gods,
leaving me to cope as I can
with poor Frieda.

fields.headline: Seriously funny
fields.standfirst: A best-selling comic novelist, he is also a respected academic. His fiction tackles grand abstract themes as well as sexual philandering, but on the latter he describes himself as 'a war correspondent, not a combatant'.  Nicholas Wroe  on an 'agnostic Catholic' writer who uses humour to address the questions of self and soul
fields.trailText: A best-selling comic novelist, he is also a respected academic. His fiction tackles grand abstract themes as well as sexual philandering, but on the latter he describes himself as 'a war correspondent, not a combatant'. Nicholas Wroe on an 'agnostic Catholic' writer who uses humour to address the questions of self and soul
fields.body:
Read the review

Early on in David Lodge's latest novel, Thinks..., one of his characters tells a joke about consciousness. "Two behaviourist psychologists have sex, and afterwards one says to the other, 'it was good for you, how was it for me?'" It is a quintessential Lodge joke; funny, includes sex, is clever and is told by an academic. Lodge and his close friend and former university colleague Malcolm Bradbury - who died late last year and whose career was apparently so entwined with Lodge's in the public mind that the word Lodgebury was coined for them - for a time made the territory of layered jokes, literary allusions and sexual hijinks featuring lecturers their own. It was a popular combination. Lodge's novels were best-sellers and critically acclaimed - he has been twice shortlisted for the Booker Prize for his books Small World and Nice Work.

But this represents only part of his story: only three of Lodge's previous 10 novels have been set on campuses, and as professor of modern English literature at the University of Birmingham - he took early retirement in 1987 - he deliberately set out to distance himself from the levity in his fiction. He was seen as a rather serious and forbidding figure, and his reputation as a critic, which is still high, was made in the dauntingly difficult fields of post-structuralist literary theory.

Fellow Birmingham novelist Jim Crace says he was intrigued by Lodge's two roles and how they overlapped. It only really made sense to him, he says, after attending one of Lodge's lectures. "I realised that when he wrote novels he wasn't in any way trashing his academic vocabulary or instincts. It was just that here was someone from an ordinary south London background whose natural voice was an idiomatic one. He has the capacity to put complicated ideas over in ordinary language while retaining great depth and clarity."

Crace says that because of this Lodge's novels are inherently democratic. "You can read his books for a while without realising the clever intellectual beasts that are lurking beneath the surface. For instance you could read Nice Work [in which a young female leftist English lecturer meets a male middle-aged Thatcherite businessman] as just an attractive, sexy and convincing love story. But it's also all about the relationship between literature and making things, between the academy and industry. These things are not just central to his work, they are central to the life of the city he lives in. He uses plot as the Trojan horse to smuggle in really interesting ideas."

The scientist, novelist and playwright Carl Djerassi - dubbed the father of the contraceptive pill - agrees. He used quotations from Lodge's 1965 novel, The British Museum Is Falling Down, in his lectures on the ethics of birth control. "In that novel [Lodge] presented the case of the Catholic disillusioned with the church's unyielding message," says Djerassi. "It was a very effective statement of that viewpoint in the debate."

Lodge's Catholicism has been a consistent strand throughout all his fiction. Graham Greene called his 1980 Whitbread prizewinning novel, How Far Can you Go?, "a magnificent book". In it Lodge chronicled a group of Catholics over 25 years as they wrestled with the moral implications of the second Vatican Council and its encyclical Humanae Vitae on birth control and abortion. The critic and poet Crag Raine claims it is "one of the great post-war novels", praising its telling mixture of comedy and pathos. "I remember reading it until three in the morning. When I went to bed my wife switched on the light and asked what had happened. My face was swollen with tears. It is a tremendously sad book but also very funny." Lodge's work is extremely popular in Catholic Europe, and particularly in France.

In Thinks..., partly through the device of making a philandering academic who is investigating artificial intelligence and consciousness speak his most secret thoughts into a tape recorder, he subtly mixes ethical and spiritual issues with a blend of science, literature, love and ambition. Raine, who recently extracted the opening section in his literary magazine Arete, says it is incredibly funny. "But the stream of consciousness in the English novel, of that radical sort, seemed to have come into its own and been exhausted by Joyce at the end of Ulysses. But it seemed to me that David had got new mileage out of it - an astonishing thing to have done."

Lodge's character claims that the problem of consciousness "is the biggest game in town". Lodge plainly agrees. He describes himself as "terrifically interested" in the implications of the new artificial intelligence and neurobiology view of consciousness - "that all your hopes and fears and everything you think of as yourself are just a lot of molecules interacting in your brain" - for someone who shares the traditional Christian idea of the soul and the self.

Lodge did not have a typical Catholic upbringing. He says his mother was not particularly devout and his father wasn't even a Catholic. His Catholicism came mainly through education, and he now describes himself as an agnostic Catholic hanging on by his fingernails. "While I can't say I believe literally in the articles of Catholic faith, I see some value in continuing to belong to the church. It still addresses fundamental questions that remain even if you kick religion into touch."

He was born in Dulwich, south London, in 1935. A year later the family moved a few miles north east to Brockley where he was brought up. His mother, Rosalie, was a secretary and clerical worker whose last job was at Goldsmiths College Library, where Lodge is now an honorary fellow. His father, Bill, played saxophone and clarinet professionally with popular dance bands. They bought the house in Brockley because it was on the all-night tram route so he could get home from gigs in London. Lodge says he also sang, "in one of those high, sweet tenor voices people used to like in those days."

When war came his father was posted to India in a kind of It Ain't Half Hot Mum concert party, but despite being in the air force, never once went up in an aeroplane. After the war he diversified and became a TV and film walk-on actor. "He was in Porridge and the film There's A Girl In My Soup," smiles Lodge. "He'd phone me up to tell me when the repeats were on." He died last year aged 93 in the Brockley house. Rosalie Lodge died in 1989.

Lodge says the war ensured he had a very disturbed education: he attended at least six schools. One was a convent in Surrey. "If I were a psychoanalyst I would say that this was a crucial experience for me," he says. "My mother left me there, aged about five, as a boarder, and I was traumatised by it. I had never been on my own before. I hated the food and was frightened of many of the nuns. It was a real Dickens-in-the-blacking-factory feeling. She came back after a fortnight, saw I was very unhappy, then stayed in the village and we lived in digs. But I felt I had been abandoned."

He says it has left him with a residual propensity to anxiety. While not wishing to give examples he says he still gets very anxious about things which in retrospect are not worth it. "I imagine worst scenarios and frighten myself," he explains. "But I suppose recognising that you are neurotically anxious is half way to coming to terms. It took me some time to realise I had this trait."

Lodge went to secondary school at Saint Joseph's Academy, Blackheath which was run by the De La Salle order of Catholic brothers. Frank Pycroft was in the same form as Lodge for five years and remembers him as, "a very brilliant child. He stood out and was ahead of most of us. He still speaks in exactly the same tone of voice as he did then." Lodge says the brothers, "weren't very intellectual, the quality of the teaching was not good and they were deep into corporal punishment, as were most Catholic schools of that period. It now seems to me barbarous. We were punished for getting things wrong, and the idea that teaching should be instilled in that way was taken for granted. But that pretty much ceased in the sixth form. It was much more relaxed and I could really start to enjoy learning."

He was encouraged by an Irish teacher who had written novels in Gaelic. Although Lodge wanted to leave school to become a cub reporter, the headmaster advised his parents that he was clever enough to go to university. "This was unknown territory for the family," he says. "The first short story I ever wrote was about being interviewed at County Hall for a London County Council scholarship."

He says he literally didn't know there were any universities apart from Oxford, Cambridge and London. "I didn't apply to either Oxford or Cambridge because I knew from Evelyn Waugh's Decline And Fall that it was all getting debagged in the quad by raving drunken aristocrats." So he lived at home and attended University College London where he gained a first. While there he wrote a novel which was never published - "it was called The Devil, The World And The Flesh and I knew nothing about any of them" - and when he was offered a post-graduate studentship he first declined, saying his intention was to leave and write full time, but then deferred it until after his national service. "Two weeks into basic training I knew I wanted to get back to that nice world where you read books in warm libraries."

His experience in the army was faithfully covered in his 1962 novel Ginger You're Barmy. "I was in the Royal Tank Regiment at a depot in Dorset. My strategy was to get as much privacy as possible so I wangled myself a bunk in a barracks completely on my own. It was supposed to be a security thing but it was just a skive. It meant I could write and read in the evenings. I took all my possible leave and used to go to London for 36 hours to see my girlfriend and go to the theatre."

While he describes himself as unpolitical, he did identify with the Angry Young Men and their sense of opposition to the establishment. "I saw Look Back In Anger at the Royal Court. I was going through this dreary and pointless servitude, and hearing Jimmy Porter talk about chinless wonders with such a savage satirical tone was a joy."

When he returned to London as a postgraduate he produced a 700-page thesis on Catholic fiction. The following year the authorities introduced a word limit. "There were many more Catholic novels than I or anyone else had ever dreamt of," laughs Lodge. "Many of them in the British Museum library had never even been cut, so I was there with a paper knife ripping my way though these terrible books. I can't believe I did it now."

Park Honan, emeritus professor at the University of Leeds, has known Lodge since they were at UCL together. "David was intense, well focused and a delightful chap. We met at a short story circle at which he was already in effect teaching a group of students and staff the techniques of the short story."

In 1959 Lodge got his first academic job working for the British Council in London, where he taught English language and gave a weekly lecture in English literature from Beowulf to Virginia Woolf. "And we had to introduce foreign students to English life, so we would solemnly tell them how to eat a kipper and use a gas meter and things like that." In the same year he also submitted his thesis, finished his first novel, The Picturegoers, and married his long-time girlfriend, Mary Jacobs.

They had met while undergraduates. They now have three children and two grandchildren. Mary went on to be an English teacher specialising in teaching teenagers with special needs. "That's partly because we have a Down's syndrome boy ourselves," Lodge explains. Their daughter, Julia, is a micro-biologist and their elder son, Stephen is a solicitor specialising in employment law, Their younger son, Christopher who is 31, has Down's and lives in a community in Ironbridge, Telford, which is about an hour from their home in Edgbaston in Birmingham.

"Christopher was a terrific shock," says Lodge. "It never occurred to me that anything could go wrong. Mary was very healthy, wasn't old and had produced the first two children with tremendous ease. It took a long time to come to terms with, but in many ways it has been a very valuable educative experience. Chris is a delightful person and shows extraordinary intuition and intelligence. Sometimes you can see what could have been an exceptional person if he hadn't had the extra chromosome. But he is quite able and can travel alone and can read and write. He lived at home until he was 21 but he now needs to be in a community where he is under supervision."

Park Honan says: "Christopher has been rewarding in ways that one's children are often not rewarding. They tend to go off and get married and have separate lives. Christopher remains a close, affectionate, amusing member of the family with skills of his own. He is passionately devoted to David."

Lodge says Christopher's birth was the first thing that taught him his life wasn't necessarily going to be a smooth upward escalator. "But fortunately his handicap was not too severe and he has achieved a lot. We feel we have maximised his potential and that he has a pretty full life. I don't think I could have psychologically handled someone who suffered terribly from cerebral palsy, say. I'm aware of cases where a severely disabled child has either damaged the marriage or damaged relationships with the siblings. I am very pleased that we have avoided that. But there is always a sense of some human potential there that is forever negated, which is kind of sad."

Lodge was appointed to Birmingham University in 1960 on a one year temporary contract. The following year the post was made permanent and he has never had a formal interview for a job since. Richard Hoggart, who was professor of English at Birmingham when Lodge was a young lecturer there, remembers him as "a very good member of department. Which is interesting if you are also trying to make your name as a writer. The temptation is to let the department look after itself." Hoggart says when he first arrived at the university he felt isolated. "A new professor is in a funny position. You're a bit of a tin god and people are hesitant about intruding on you. But David was one of the few who made the effort to come to my office and say hello and ask if I wanted a coffee or to have lunch. He wasn't trying to butter me up, he was just being friendly."

It was at Birmingham that Lodge met Malcolm Bradbury. "We were eager to make friends as we were the youngest members of the department and were the only ones really interested in a modern literature," recalls Lodge.

Each had just published his first novel and had similar career plans to run an academic career alongside a writing career. They collaborated on a stage review for the Birmingham rep which Lodge says was a formative experience for him. "I had never tried to write anything just to make people laugh. My first two novels were rather sober realism and Malcolm encouraged me to write comedy. I found I both enjoyed it and could do it and it became a much more important part of my work as a result."

But Lodge acknowledges that after a few years it became clear the two could not go on in the same department, "it would have become too incestuous. Although I was sorry when he left, [Bradbury set up the creative writing and American literature courses at the University of East Anglia] in retrospect it was probably a good thing for both of us."

Another great spur to Lodge's writing were two trips he made to America in the mid and late 60s. "I was in Berkeley just as flower power was reaching its peak. I was there for the first big teach-in with Norman Mailer. I remember thinking 'this was history'. I also discovered the possibilities of life that America can offer." Park Honan, an American himself, says "David found himself inundated by talk and enthusiasm and questioning and he was energised by that."

But despite this enthusiasm for the States, and several job offers elsewhere in England, Lodge chose to stay in Birmingham. "As the family became more rooted so the idea of moving became less attractive", he says. The Birmingham playwright David Edgar praises Lodge's commitment to the city. Lodge has written two plays himself and contributed to Edgar's MA playwriting course at the university. "We had a session on the difference between real speech and dramatic speech," says Edgar. "We analysed a Pinter play and Prince Charles's mobile phone conversation with Camilla. The students liked David a lot. He is a very good teacher."

Edgar also attended a series of lunches Lodge organised for West Midlands writers. "David has played an important role in which saying you are a Birmingham writer is a badge of pride. He's not an uncritical advocate for Birmingham. But that he's chosen to set so many novels here, chosen to live here, chosen it as his place of work has been very important."

Rummidge was Lodge's fictional Birmingham, affectionately satirised, and the novels set in the city and university are amongst his best known, including Changing Places and Small World. Richard Hoggart particularly praises another Rummidge novel, Nice Work as, "a penetration of the inadequacies of academic views of industry. There are few academic novelists who would do that. It's not just a novel about academic life, it's a novel about the limits of academic life."

It is Changing Places and Small World that most prominently feature libidinous lecturers running all over the world to conferences while swapping wives and engaging in witty literary debate. Friends who know Lodge say how surprised they are at how much sex he includes in his books. He describes his stance as, "a war correspondent, not a combatant. My wife is my first reader. If she had some deep objection to something I would have to take that into account. But that hasn't happened."

He says his children didn't read the books when they were growing up and acknowledges a certain amount of embarrassment. "With your family you just implicitly draw a boundary. It's like children don't usually ask their parents about their sex life, but would ask somebody else about their sex life. There is a taboo."

He says part of the appeal of fiction is that it is about the inner life and it is revealing what is normally kept private. "Novels give us this illusion of insight into what people are really thinking, and sex is the great area of mystery and curiosity. The novel has always been focused on that area of life, whether it was sexually explicit or not. Jane Austen gives you this detailed sense of what people are really thinking in terms of their choice of marriage partner. That means there is always some sort of implied self-exposure when you write a novel. People say it may not have happened to him, but he must have been thinking about it."

Jim Crace says that while in one way Lodge's books are completely autobiographical, you actually learn nothing about him from them. In Therapy [his 1995 novel about a popular television writer in mid-life crisis who finds hope in a Catholic pilgrimage to Santiago de Compostella and the philosophy of Kierkegaard], a man had just taken on a little flat in London. Crace says, "So had David. The man spent a lot of time on the train to London like David, and had just been on the Compostella route like David. It was like he had been playing pinball with his own life, lighting up all the things he had just done, so it seems to be an entirely autobiographical work. But in a strange way we learn nothing about him from that book."

Lodge has practised this discretion in both his guises - as writer and academic. He says he always tried to draw boundaries between the two professions. "When I retired it was something of a relief for that reason. I had kept my novel-writing as a private activity but there was a sort of contradiction which became more and more acute as I got more senior: the responsible persona of the professor and the rather anarchic and subversive persona of the novelist. So the way I coped was to split myself in two and I had a rather severe teaching persona as a result."

Does he miss the chalk-face of academic criticism? "Not really. As the post-structuralist movement became more and more institutionalised I think it became increasingly arid. I was engaged in that revolution in criticism, but by the time I retired I was beginning to get a little weary of it. Academic criticism has become terribly professionalised and is no longer addressed to an educated general public. It is sad that there is no longer a cross-fertilisation between academic criticism, literary journalism and creative writing."

Lodge himself has maintained the links, and still reviews widely. In 1992 he began a weekly column for the Independent on Sunday, looking at different aspects of writing; repetition, a sense of place, interior monologue. The articles were later published as a book, The Art Of Fiction, but one column, on plagiarism, wasn't included. Lodge and the newspaper had been sued for libel by a Mills & Boon writer after alleging that she had plagiarised his novel Nice Work. They subsequently apologised and accepted that the similarities were coincidental. Three years later the Mills & Boon author was given "substantial" damages and a public apology in the high court.

As part of the settlement, there are constraints on what Lodge can say about the case, but there is no evidence that it has blunted his critical edge or dampened his enthusiasm for literature. After 40 years, though, his perspective on the novel has shifted.

When Malcolm Bradbury died, Lodge said to a friend that he felt an epoch had ended. And he admits "I find it more and more difficult to write fiction. And in a way I get less and less pleasure out of reading fiction than I used to, although I still enjoy re-reading classic fiction. I think it is something to do with getting old. Reading fiction requires quite a lot of brain work." But his commitment to the novel is fundamentally still strong "as a way of exploring experience. It is still the format I have had the highest regard for and the most interest in. It is the most flexible and inclusive literary form.

"I don't have any answer to the problem of consciousness, the problem of religious belief or the problem of materialism versus transcendentalism. But to me one of the attractions of fiction is that it is a way of exploring ideas or large abstract themes in a way which doesn't necessarily oblige you to answer the questions definitively. If you explore them in terms of human interaction you can appreciate their import in a way you wouldn't in an abstract philosophical discussion."

Life at a glance David John Lodge

Born: January 28 1935, London.

Education: Saint Joseph's Academy, Blackheath; University College London (MA); Birmingham University (PhD).

Married: 1959 Mary Frances Jacob (one daughter, Julia, and two sons, Stephen and Christopher).

National service: 1955-57.

Career: British Council 1959-60; University of Birmingham department of English '60-87, honorary professor, modern English literature '87-.

Some criticism: Language Of Fiction '66, The Novelist At The Crossroads '71, Working With Structuralism '81, After Bakhtin '90.

Television: Nice Work '89, Martin Chuzzlewit '94.

Novels: The Picturegoers '60, Ginger You're Barmy '62, The British Museum Is Falling Down '65, Out Of The Shelter '70, Changing Places '75, How Far Can You Go? '80, Small World '84, Nice Work '88, Paradise News '91, Therapy '95, Thinks... '01.

 Thinks... is published by Secker & Warburg at £16.99
