"But the stream of consciousness in the English novel, of that radical sort, seemed to have come into its own and been exhausted by Joyce at the end of Ulysses. But it seemed to me that David had got new mileage out of it - an astonishing thing to have done." Lodge's character claims that the problem of consciousness "is the biggest game in town". Lodge plainly agrees. He describes himself as "terrifically interested" in the implications of the new artificial intelligence and neurobiology view of consciousness - "that all your hopes and fears and everything you think of as yourself are just a lot of molecules interacting in your brain" - for someone who shares the traditional Christian idea of the soul and the self. Lodge did not have a typical Catholic upbringing. He says his mother was not particularly devout and his father wasn't even a Catholic. His Catholicism came mainly through education, and he now describes himself as an agnostic Catholic hanging on by his fingernails. "While I can't say I believe literally in the articles of Catholic faith, I see some value in continuing to belong to the church. It still addresses fundamental questions that remain even if you kick religion into touch." He was born in Dulwich, south London, in 1935. A year later the family moved a few miles north east to Brockley where he was brought up. His mother, Rosalie, was a secretary and clerical worker whose last job was at Goldsmiths College Library, where Lodge is now an honorary fellow. His father, Bill, played saxophone and clarinet professionally with popular dance bands. They bought the house in Brockley because it was on the all-night tram route so he could get home from gigs in London. Lodge says he also sang, "in one of those high, sweet tenor voices people used to like in those days." When war came his father was posted to India in a kind of It Ain't Half Hot Mum concert party, but despite being in the air force, never once went up in an aeroplane. After the war he diversified and became a TV and film walk-on actor. "He was in Porridge and the film There's A Girl In My Soup," smiles Lodge. "He'd phone me up to tell me when the repeats were on." He died last year aged 93 in the Brockley house. Rosalie Lodge died in 1989. Lodge says the war ensured he had a very disturbed education: he attended at least six schools. One was a convent in Surrey. "If I were a psychoanalyst I would say that this was a crucial experience for me," he says. "My mother left me there, aged about five, as a boarder, and I was traumatised by it. I had never been on my own before. I hated the food and was frightened of many of the nuns. It was a real Dickens-in-the-blacking-factory feeling. She came back after a fortnight, saw I was very unhappy, then stayed in the village and we lived in digs. But I felt I had been abandoned." He says it has left him with a residual propensity to anxiety. While not wishing to give examples he says he still gets very anxious about things which in retrospect are not worth it. "I imagine worst scenarios and frighten myself," he explains. "But I suppose recognising that you are neurotically anxious is half way to coming to terms. It took me some time to realise I had this trait." Lodge went to secondary school at Saint Joseph's Academy, Blackheath which was run by the De La Salle order of Catholic brothers. Frank Pycroft was in the same form as Lodge for five years and remembers him as, "a very brilliant child. He stood out and was ahead of most of us. He still speaks in exactly the same tone of voice as he did then." Lodge says the brothers, "weren't very intellectual, the quality of the teaching was not good and they were deep into corporal punishment, as were most Catholic schools of that period. It now seems to me barbarous. We were punished for getting things wrong, and the idea that teaching should be instilled in that way was taken for granted. But that pretty much ceased in the sixth form. It was much more relaxed and I could really start to enjoy learning." He was encouraged by an Irish teacher who had written novels in Gaelic. Although Lodge wanted to leave school to become a cub reporter, the headmaster advised his parents that he was clever enough to go to university. "This was unknown territory for the family," he says. "The first short story I ever wrote was about being interviewed at County Hall for a London County Council scholarship." He says he literally didn't know there were any universities apart from Oxford, Cambridge and London. "I didn't apply to either Oxford or Cambridge because I knew from Evelyn Waugh's Decline And Fall that it was all getting debagged in the quad by raving drunken aristocrats." So he lived at home and attended University College London where he gained a first. While there he wrote a novel which was never published - "it was called The Devil, The World And The Flesh and I knew nothing about any of them" - and when he was offered a post-graduate studentship he first declined, saying his intention was to leave and write full time, but then deferred it until after his national service. "Two weeks into basic training I knew I wanted to get back to that nice world where you read books in warm libraries." His experience in the army was faithfully covered in his 1962 novel Ginger You're Barmy. "I was in the Royal Tank Regiment at a depot in Dorset. My strategy was to get as much privacy as possible so I wangled myself a bunk in a barracks completely on my own. It was supposed to be a security thing but it was just a skive. It meant I could write and read in the evenings. I took all my possible leave and used to go to London for 36 hours to see my girlfriend and go to the theatre." While he describes himself as unpolitical, he did identify with the Angry Young Men and their sense of opposition to the establishment. "I saw Look Back In Anger at the Royal Court. I was going through this dreary and pointless servitude, and hearing Jimmy Porter talk about chinless wonders with such a savage satirical tone was a joy." When he returned to London as a postgraduate he produced a 700-page thesis on Catholic fiction. The following year the authorities introduced a word limit. "There were many more Catholic novels than I or anyone else had ever dreamt of," laughs Lodge. "Many of them in the British Museum library had never even been cut, so I was there with a paper knife ripping my way though these terrible books. I can't believe I did it now." Park Honan, emeritus professor at the University of Leeds, has known Lodge since they were at UCL together. "David was intense, well focused and a delightful chap. We met at a short story circle at which he was already in effect teaching a group of students and staff the techniques of the short story." In 1959 Lodge got his first academic job working for the British Council in London, where he taught English language and gave a weekly lecture in English literature from Beowulf to Virginia Woolf. "And we had to introduce foreign students to English life, so we would solemnly tell them how to eat a kipper and use a gas meter and things like that." In the same year he also submitted his thesis, finished his first novel, The Picturegoers, and married his long-time girlfriend, Mary Jacobs. They had met while undergraduates. They now have three children and two grandchildren. Mary went on to be an English teacher specialising in teaching teenagers with special needs. "That's partly because we have a Down's syndrome boy ourselves," Lodge explains. Their daughter, Julia, is a micro-biologist and their elder son, Stephen is a solicitor specialising in employment law, Their younger son, Christopher who is 31, has Down's and lives in a community in Ironbridge, Telford, which is about an hour from their home in Edgbaston in Birmingham. "Christopher was a terrific shock," says Lodge. "It never occurred to me that anything could go wrong. Mary was very healthy, wasn't old and had produced the first two children with tremendous ease. It took a long time to come to terms with, but in many ways it has been a very valuable educative experience. Chris is a delightful person and shows extraordinary intuition and intelligence. Sometimes you can see what could have been an exceptional person if he hadn't had the extra chromosome. But he is quite able and can travel alone and can read and write. He lived at home until he was 21 but he now needs to be in a community where he is under supervision." Park Honan says: "Christopher has been rewarding in ways that one's children are often not rewarding. They tend to go off and get married and have separate lives. Christopher remains a close, affectionate, amusing member of the family with skills of his own. He is passionately devoted to David." Lodge says Christopher's birth was the first thing that taught him his life wasn't necessarily going to be a smooth upward escalator. "But fortunately his handicap was not too severe and he has achieved a lot. We feel we have maximised his potential and that he has a pretty full life. I don't think I could have psychologically handled someone who suffered terribly from cerebral palsy, say. I'm aware of cases where a severely disabled child has either damaged the marriage or damaged relationships with the siblings. I am very pleased that we have avoided that. But there is always a sense of some human potential there that is forever negated, which is kind of sad." Lodge was appointed to Birmingham University in 1960 on a one year temporary contract. The following year the post was made permanent and he has never had a formal interview for a job since. Richard Hoggart, who was professor of English at Birmingham when Lodge was a young lecturer there, remembers him as "a very good member of department. Which is interesting if you are also trying to make your name as a writer. The temptation is to let the department look after itself." Hoggart says when he first arrived at the university he felt isolated. "A new professor is in a funny position. You're a bit of a tin god and people are hesitant about intruding on you. But David was one of the few who made the effort to come to my office and say hello and ask if I wanted a coffee or to have lunch. He wasn't trying to butter me up, he was just being friendly." It was at Birmingham that Lodge met Malcolm Bradbury. "We were eager to make friends as we were the youngest members of the department and were the only ones really interested in a modern literature," recalls Lodge. Each had just published his first novel and had similar career plans to run an academic career alongside a writing career. They collaborated on a stage review for the Birmingham rep which Lodge says was a formative experience for him. "I had never tried to write anything just to make people laugh. My first two novels were rather sober realism and Malcolm encouraged me to write comedy. I found I both enjoyed it and could do it and it became a much more important part of my work as a result." But Lodge acknowledges that after a few years it became clear the two could not go on in the same department, "it would have become too incestuous. Although I was sorry when he left, [Bradbury set up the creative writing and American literature courses at the University of East Anglia] in retrospect it was probably a good thing for both of us." Another great spur to Lodge's writing were two trips he made to America in the mid and late 60s. "I was in Berkeley just as flower power was reaching its peak. I was there for the first big teach-in with Norman Mailer. I remember thinking 'this was history'. I also discovered the possibilities of life that America can offer." Park Honan, an American himself, says "David found himself inundated by talk and enthusiasm and questioning and he was energised by that." But despite this enthusiasm for the States, and several job offers elsewhere in England, Lodge chose to stay in Birmingham. "As the family became more rooted so the idea of moving became less attractive", he says. The Birmingham playwright David Edgar praises Lodge's commitment to the city. Lodge has written two plays himself and contributed to Edgar's MA playwriting course at the university. "We had a session on the difference between real speech and dramatic speech," says Edgar. "We analysed a Pinter play and Prince Charles's mobile phone conversation with Camilla. The students liked David a lot. He is a very good teacher." Edgar also attended a series of lunches Lodge organised for West Midlands writers. "David has played an important role in which saying you are a Birmingham writer is a badge of pride. He's not an uncritical advocate for Birmingham. But that he's chosen to set so many novels here, chosen to live here, chosen it as his place of work has been very important." Rummidge was Lodge's fictional Birmingham, affectionately satirised, and the novels set in the city and university are amongst his best known, including Changing Places and Small World. Richard Hoggart particularly praises another Rummidge novel, Nice Work as, "a penetration of the inadequacies of academic views of industry. There are few academic novelists who would do that. It's not just a novel about academic life, it's a novel about the limits of academic life." It is Changing Places and Small World that most prominently feature libidinous lecturers running all over the world to conferences while swapping wives and engaging in witty literary debate. Friends who know Lodge say how surprised they are at how much sex he includes in his books. He describes his stance as, "a war correspondent, not a combatant. My wife is my first reader. If she had some deep objection to something I would have to take that into account. But that hasn't happened." He says his children didn't read the books when they were growing up and acknowledges a certain amount of embarrassment. "With your family you just implicitly draw a boundary. It's like children don't usually ask their parents about their sex life, but would ask somebody else about their sex life. There is a taboo." He says part of the appeal of fiction is that it is about the inner life and it is revealing what is normally kept private. "Novels give us this illusion of insight into what people are really thinking, and sex is the great area of mystery and curiosity. The novel has always been focused on that area of life, whether it was sexually explicit or not. Jane Austen gives you this detailed sense of what people are really thinking in terms of their choice of marriage partner. That means there is always some sort of implied self-exposure when you write a novel. People say it may not have happened to him, but he must have been thinking about it." Jim Crace says that while in one way Lodge's books are completely autobiographical, you actually learn nothing about him from them. In Therapy [his 1995 novel about a popular television writer in mid-life crisis who finds hope in a Catholic pilgrimage to Santiago de Compostella and the philosophy of Kierkegaard], a man had just taken on a little flat in London. Crace says, "So had David. The man spent a lot of time on the train to London like David, and had just been on the Compostella route like David. It was like he had been playing pinball with his own life, lighting up all the things he had just done, so it seems to be an entirely autobiographical work. But in a strange way we learn nothing about him from that book." Lodge has practised this discretion in both his guises - as writer and academic. He says he always tried to draw boundaries between the two professions. "When I retired it was something of a relief for that reason. I had kept my novel-writing as a private activity but there was a sort of contradiction which became more and more acute as I got more senior: the responsible persona of the professor and the rather anarchic and subversive persona of the novelist. So the way I coped was to split myself in two and I had a rather severe teaching persona as a result." Does he miss the chalk-face of academic criticism? "Not really. As the post-structuralist movement became more and more institutionalised I think it became increasingly arid. I was engaged in that revolution in criticism, but by the time I retired I was beginning to get a little weary of it. Academic criticism has become terribly professionalised and is no longer addressed to an educated general public. It is sad that there is no longer a cross-fertilisation between academic criticism, literary journalism and creative writing." Lodge himself has maintained the links, and still reviews widely. In 1992 he began a weekly column for the Independent on Sunday, looking at different aspects of writing; repetition, a sense of place, interior monologue. The articles were later published as a book, The Art Of Fiction, but one column, on plagiarism, wasn't included. Lodge and the newspaper had been sued for libel by a Mills & Boon writer after alleging that she had plagiarised his novel Nice Work. They subsequently apologised and accepted that the similarities were coincidental. Three years later the Mills & Boon author was given "substantial" damages and a public apology in the high court. As part of the settlement, there are constraints on what Lodge can say about the case, but there is no evidence that it has blunted his critical edge or dampened his enthusiasm for literature. After 40 years, though, his perspective on the novel has shifted. When Malcolm Bradbury died, Lodge said to a friend that he felt an epoch had ended. And he admits "I find it more and more difficult to write fiction. And in a way I get less and less pleasure out of reading fiction than I used to, although I still enjoy re-reading classic fiction. I think it is something to do with getting old. Reading fiction requires quite a lot of brain work." But his commitment to the novel is fundamentally still strong "as a way of exploring experience. It is still the format I have had the highest regard for and the most interest in. It is the most flexible and inclusive literary form. "I don't have any answer to the problem of consciousness, the problem of religious belief or the problem of materialism versus transcendentalism. But to me one of the attractions of fiction is that it is a way of exploring ideas or large abstract themes in a way which doesn't necessarily oblige you to answer the questions definitively. If you explore them in terms of human interaction you can appreciate their import in a way you wouldn't in an abstract philosophical discussion." Life at a glance David John Lodge Born: January 28 1935, London. Education: Saint Joseph's Academy, Blackheath; University College London (MA); Birmingham University (PhD). Married: 1959 Mary Frances Jacob (one daughter, Julia, and two sons, Stephen and Christopher). National service: 1955-57. Career: British Council 1959-60; University of Birmingham department of English '60-87, honorary professor, modern English literature '87-. Some criticism: Language Of Fiction '66, The Novelist At The Crossroads '71, Working With Structuralism '81, After Bakhtin '90. Television: Nice Work '89, Martin Chuzzlewit '94. Novels: The Picturegoers '60, Ginger You're Barmy '62, The British Museum Is Falling Down '65, Out Of The Shelter '70, Changing Places '75, How Far Can You Go? '80, Small World '84, Nice Work '88, Paradise News '91, Therapy '95, Thinks... '01.  Thinks... is published by Secker & Warburg at £16.99

fields.headline: Atom bomb
fields.standfirst: You're not meant to like Atomised, by Michel Houellebecq, warns Nicholas Lezard
fields.trailText: You're not meant to like Atomised, by Michel Houellebecq, warns Nicholas Lezard
fields.body:
Atomised
Michel Houellebecq, trs Frank Wynne
(Vintage, £6.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL
The friends of Michel Houellebecq: an online introduction
Houellebecq interview

Not that many novels get chosen by me as Pick of the Week. After reading Atomised , the reasons for this become clear. For against it, the contemporary British novel, with a few, scattered exceptions, suddenly seems timid, bogus, and footling. Not to mention atrociously written. I was prodded into thinking this by a remark by Julian Barnes on the back cover: "a novel which hunts big game while others settle for shooting rabbits". He is right; although Atomised also makes you wonder if other, ordinary writers have the coordination even to do the Shake 'n' Vac, let alone hunt fictional rabbits.

It tells the story of two half-brothers, Bruno and Michel, both children of a libertine hippy mother who had as little as possible to do with their upbringing. Houellebecq's childhood was very similar to this; the two main characters can be seen as divergent yet related elements of his own self.

Michel Djerzinski is a diligent, brilliant scientist who gives up his job as a researcher working on decoding genomes or whatever in order "to think". As his superior puts it: "decoding DNA, pfff . . . you decode one gene, then another and another . . . it's like following a recipe. From time to time someone comes up with better equipment and they give him the Nobel Prize. It's a joke." From which you can decipher not only that Houellebecq's cynicism is sincere and well researched, but that he can be very funny indeed. (And, in passing, that the translation would appear to be first-rate.)

How can you not warm to a book that contains observations such as the following: "Some people live to be 70, sometimes 80 years old believing that there is always something new just around the corner, as they say; in the end they practically have to be killed or at least reduced to a state of serious incapacity to get them to see reason." How can you fail to love a writer who creates a character who, filling in a questionnaire at the back of a supermarket magazine, is described thus: "the only three activities he could actually tick off were sitting, lying down and sleeping". Michel turns out to be a hero who rescues the human race from itself; his solution is a gauntlet Houellebecq throws down to all of us. You may not like it; you're not meant to.

Michel's half-brother, Bruno, is a more problematic individual; where Michel has virtually no sex drive at all, Bruno is obsessed, with the unfortunate twist that for long periods of his life, he doesn't get enough. He exposes himself to a girl in the class to which he teaches literature; he is sent to a mental institution (as was Houellebecq, if not for the same reason). He goes to a hippy holiday commune, the Lieu du Changement, and the vacuity of all New Age bullshit is brilliantly attacked. ("Tantric Zen, which combined vanity, mysticism, and frottage, flourished.") Bruno is the id to Michel's ego, if you want to use specious terms.

This is a bold and unsettling portrait of a society falling apart: the rage that both left and right, the piously religious as well as the humanists, have expressed towards Houellebecq is pretty much the rage of Caliban seeing his face in the glass. There is not too much doubt that Houellebecq is an unpleasant person. (We're no slouches in this regard, but France has a gift for producing nasty writers.) One does not want to examine his ideas on race too deeply, just yet. I would get this and read it before that particular time bomb explodes.

webTitle: Review: The Avengers by Rich Cohen

fields.headline: Freedom fighters
fields.standfirst: Andrew Pulver on Zionist passion in The Avengers by Rich Cohen
fields.trailText: Andrew Pulver on Zionist passion in The Avengers by Rich Cohen
fields.body:
The Avengers
Rich Cohen
262pp, Cape, £17.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL
The 1943 FPO proclamation calling for revolt in Vilna
Further information on the Vilna ghetto
Biography: Abba Kovner

The attempt to do justice to the Holocaust in print is one of the most relentless endeavours in post-war literature; one survivor's account after another testifies to the sheer vastness of the atrocity. The Israeli poet Abba Kovner is one of the more redoubtable figures of the era, having been a leader of the Jewish armed resistance in the Lithuanian city of Vilna. Kovner, though, prefers poetry to prosaic detail when relating his experiences in the Fareinikte Partizaner Organizatsie (the United Partisans Organisation). In the 1980 essay "A First Attempt to Tell", he writes: "It is beyond my power today to tell the whole story of the FPO's struggle."

Fortunately, Rich Cohen, Rolling Stone journalist and author of ethnic-mobster hagiography Tough Jews , has no such inhibitions. The subject of the Vilna resistance has been covered before, in Yitzhak Arad's scholarly Ghetto in Flames , but Cohen expends much imagination and artistry on his emotive account of this particular band of extremely tough Jews. Tough Jews was clearly Cohen's bid to be the Jewish answer to Nicholas Pileggi. The Avengers , fortunately, cuts back on style-slave self-referentialism and concentrates on giving us a story, pure and simple.

From the outset, the tale follows the familiar path of the doomed Jewish communities of eastern and middle Europe. Activists across the political spectrum banded together and set about their desperate work of fending off the Nazi threat. "No one who has never been in the ghetto will understand the mass fear of collective responsibility," Kovner was to write later. Cohen, however, does an impressive job in drawing out the emotional trauma of law-abiding citizens suddenly forced to confront the barbaric arbitrariness of German administration methods: every sabotage action would automatically be greeted with a round of random executions and torture.

Cohen also expertly dramatises the central conundrum of the ghetto, the thing that seems unimaginable in hindsight: that hardly anyone saw it coming. Kovner was one of the few who did, with his now-celebrated manifesto - "we will not be led like sheep to the slaughter" - in January 1943. The second half of The Avengers follows Kovner and the FPO to postwar Palestine where, as Jewish Europe lay in ruins, the Zionist dream was taking shape. Detailing an era in which Zionism was the mantra of a righteous crusade, Cohen's rich narrative explores the seismic shifts that Jews experienced in the late 1940s, exchanging the shattered landscape of Europe for the Biblical vistas of the infant state of Israel.

Enthralling as Cohen's story is, it's a pity that the pivotal episode of the tale - and the one that gives the book its title - is so brief. In 1945, after the war was over, Kovner and his group plotted a series of revenge killings against Nazis in Allied jails. Their most successful attack - poisoning the bread supply of a Nuremberg prison camp - accounted for more than 2,000 Einsatzgruppen and concentration-camp guards. No figures for fatalities were ever released. But, like the desire for retribution itself, Kovner's plans were swept aside as the drive to create the Jewish state swamped all other considerations.

fields.headline: The human sponge
fields.standfirst: A B McKillop's new biographical study The Spinster and the Prophet asks the question: was H G Wells a plagiarist? By  Michelene Wandor
fields.trailText: A B McKillop's new biographical study The Spinster and the Prophet asks the question: was H G Wells a plagiarist? By Michelene Wandor
fields.body:
The Spinster and the Prophet: A Tale of H G Wells, Plagiarism and the History of the World
A B McKillop
496pp, Aurum Press, £18.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL
Audio interview with AB McKillop

Literary debts and borrowings are inevitable: any researched material undergoes transformation, whether it is facts reproduced in a non-fiction book or local colour reimagined for fiction. Conventions of acknowledgment are common, and in academic books following these is seen as essential. But there are grey areas - and sometimes they involve marriages and romantic liaisons. Recently books have revealed the unacknowledged literary debts writers such as Brecht and Joyce owed to the women in their lives. Inadequately concealed research in novels sometimes reaches the headlines too.

In The Spinster and the Prophet , Canadian historian A B McKillop combines these two themes. The phenomenon of the woman as an unacknowledged literary handmaid and the ethical issue of plagiarism join forces in a poignant and shocking story that aired publicly between 1930 and 1933. During this time, the Canadian Florence Deeks took on first H G Wells and his publishers, Macmillan, then the British privy council and the law lords. She finally attempted to petition King George V. In all these she failed. Legal and other costs came to around half a million dollars, paid by her brother and an unknown benefactor.

When lawyers refused to represent her, she became her own advocate. Her charge was that Wells's massive non-fiction work, The Outline of History , was a plagiarised version, in substantive plan and detail, of her own unpublished manuscript, The Web . Drawn to the subject via a footnote in his other researches, McKillop undertook some literary detective work of his own to uncover Deeks's story. His narrative carefully juxtaposes the two authors' lives, alternating parallel narratives until the trial gets going.

Unmarried, briefly a teacher, Deeks apparently worked hard during the four years of the first world war, writing her history of the world. In 1918 she took the manuscript to John Saul, an editor at Macmillan Canada, where it remained for six months. Meanwhile, on our own shores, in 1919 H G Wells began writing his history of the world. While knowledgeable about science, he was less sure-footed on history, and had to build up a "think tank" of experts. The book began to be published in serial form later the same year.

In Canada, Deeks read reviews, then the book itself. Shocked at what she read, she had to badger Saul to get her manuscript back. Eventually he relinquished it - well-thumbed, and torn. Her case would be that the structure of her book and Wells's were very similar, as were many of the ideas. Much of the phrasing was virtually identical too, she argued; both had the same mistakes and omissions. Deeks spent the best part of a year compiling a concordance of hundreds of verbal similarities; by the time this was done, she was certain of her ground. With her family's support, she tried to get justice, and the admission that there had been a serious act of literary piracy. Her case depended on two points: the intrinsic evidence of the verbal and structural similarities between her manuscript and The Outline of History , and the assumption that Wells had somehow seen her manuscript and plundered it. However, the apparatus of both the publishing world and the male-dominated judiciary were against her. The judges dismissed the case.

Wells and Deeks never met. He caricatured her as an obsessive spinster, and she remained unpublished; a footnote in biographies of Wells, which have perpetuated the myth of her as a monomaniacal freak. McKillop is very much on Deeks's side. Mischievously, he rounds off his neat account of the trial with a dénouement of his own. Leaping into the present tense, he tells a story whereby Saul and his boss, desperate to get Wells on their publishing list, slip Deeks's manuscript across the Atlantic. With the collusion of Catherine, Wells's devoted but much put-upon wife, they make sure that a ready-made model is there for him when he comes to write his own book. It is a persuasive thesis.

While Deeks's story is relatively new, Wells's familiar biographical details take on a darker cast. Moving from place to place and from lover to lover, but always coming back to Catherine, he does not seem an attractive character. His very fecundity - sexual and literary - serves by juxtaposition to highlight Deeks's heroic tenacity. McKillop's description of the trials, his convincing lists of mirror phrases and his rehabilitation of Deeks all demonstrate how unscrupulous the literary world can be. Plagiarism is not a new accusation to level at Wells; McKillop is in no doubt that "as writer, husband and lover, H G Wells was a vast sponge that absorbed any work or any person that served his purpose".

McKillop is sensitive to the attention feminist historians have drawn to the concealed narratives and hidden voices of women, and this rigorous and compassionate book is a valuable contribution. And he does, so far as one can tell, acknowledge all his sources in full.

fields.headline: Revealing the lord of war
fields.standfirst: Kitchener by John Pollock reveals a big man with big faults. By Jad Adams
fields.trailText: Kitchener by John Pollock reveals a big man with big faults. By Jad Adams
fields.body:
Kitchener
John Pollock
598pp, Constable, £20
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Horatio Kitchener was brutal and sensitive, shy and domineering; ferociously unforgiving in battle, but acquisitive of porcelain to the point of kleptomania. He was a tower of masculinity, the Empire's hard man, but his letters show him sidling up to matriarchal women to be stroked, at which he would purr with deep satisfaction.

The new part of this biography covers his life from 1902-1916 and is issued with a reprint of John Pollock's book on Kitchener's earlier life, in which he reconquered Sudan with overwhelming fire-power and laid waste to South Africa with a scorched-earth and concentration-camp policy. It was in an appendix to this first book that Pollock dealt with the controversial subject of Kitchener's sexuality, declaring him not to have been homosexual and rejecting the (more probable) explanation that he had homosexual inclinations but chose to be celibate.

Kitchener was a man built on a heroic scale, with immense powers of determination and self-control; but big people have big faults, and he was always in the thrall of petty jealousies and doubts. Occasionally his beloved young aide, Frank "the brat" Maxwell - Patroclus to his Achilles - would correct him with remarks such as "it seems such a pity that a big man like he is should make an idiot of himself".

The hero's reward for his African victories was to become Jang I Lat Sahib , Lord of War in India. Yet the position had a small flaw: his power was not absolute, but constrained by the constitutional check of a "Military Member" of the Viceroy's council. Kitchener determined his task in India would be to reorganise the army to accumulate all authority under himself.

He was "a molten mass of devouring energy", according to Lord Curzon, the Viceroy, whose thankless task it was to rein in his ferocious subordinate. They were two arrogant, powerful men, both supremely gifted and both twisted out of shape by abusive childhoods. While Curzon showed him every courtesy, Kitchener treated his willingness to compromise as weakness. He would "outmanoeuvre the enemy or leave the field", according to Pollock - his approach to any obstacle in his path, whether military, social or political.

Kitchener despised politics and open argument but took a feline pleasure in conspiracy, dripping poison in unattributable briefings to people close to the prime minister, with the warning to be "careful that nothing comes from me and that my name is never used". Finally he got his way by threatening to resign. Curzon found this bad form, and Kitchener helpfully sug gested that he square the scales by "throwing in your own resignation as a counterbalance". Of course, it was Curzon who went, his brilliant career in tatters. Kitchener went on to set up an over-centralised administration which failed at its first test, the disastrous Mesopotamian campaign of 1915, where the Indian Army was doomed by the inefficiency of his system. He lived to see the disaster, but not the royal commission which condemned his reorganisation as the cause of it.

Kitchener's great service to his country took place in the initial weeks of the first world war, most importantly in his understanding of the nature of the conflict and his statement to the stunned war council that, contrary to common belief, the war would not be over in six weeks: it would last three years and to wage it he needed a million-man army. Always at his best as a field commander, he crossed the Channel when British leadership in France was weakening, to order his army not to make a run for it when the going looked bad.

After September 1914, however, it was downhill all the way. He believed that the day-by-day plans for an industrialised nation's war machine could be kept in his head, and his colleagues viewed his utter failure to manage the power he had accrued to himself with deepening horror. When he died in 1916, his ship hitting a mine in the North Sea, amid the grief of the nation a small sigh of relief went up in Whitehall: the lumbering behemoth would impede them no longer. Yet he was a big man in every sense, and deserves at least this one big, sympathetic biography.

fields.headline: Unjust deserts
fields.standfirst: Geoff Dyer  examines the art of snapping the sands in The Desert by  Raymond Depardon, Wilfred Thesiger, Paul Virilio, Mounira Khemir et al
fields.trailText: Geoff Dyer examines the art of snapping the sands in The Desert by Raymond Depardon, Wilfred Thesiger, Paul Virilio, Mounira Khemir et al
fields.body:
The Desert
Raymond Depardon, Wilfred Thesiger, Paul Virilio, Mounira Khemir et al
236pp, Fondation Cartier/Thames & Hudson, £24.95
Buy it at a discount at BOL
Images and texts from the exhibtion

Different kinds of landscape gained their reputations for beauty at specific historical moments; the desert was one of the last topographic categories to be rehabilitated in this way. According to Michael Ondaatje in The English Patient , "There is, after Herodotus, little interest by the western world towards the desert for hundreds of years. From 425BC to the beginning of the 20th century there is an averting of eyes. Silence." This is a slight exaggeration. The silence was disturbed by a few 19th-century travellers, but the emphasis was less on terrain than on people encountered. It is only with the publication in 1901 of John C Van Dyke's masterpiece The Desert that "the weird solitude, the great silence, the grim desolation" come to be seen as manifestations of the sublime. Significantly, Van Dyke - who is not mentioned in this book, even though it shares his title - was an art historian; in the 20th century, the idea of desert and its visual representation have proved inversely fertile to the aridity of the subject. As Don DeLillo puts it in The Names , "The desert fits the screen. It is the screen."

Accompanying an exhibition at the Fondation Cartier in Paris, this book showcases some artists who have used photography and film to frame or contain the emptiness of the desert. The project was inspired by French film-maker/ photographer/journalist Raymond Depardon and the book opens with the transcription of an interview with him. Later there's an interview with Wilfred Thesiger. These two dusty celebrities are intermittently interesting, but interviews are poor substitutes for the measured contemplation of prose. Why didn't they write something? And why didn't someone persuade historian of photography Mounira Khemir not to? Either she can't write or her translators can't translate. "The question is, then, is to take a photograph of the desert to live differently in space, carry fragments or a trace of memory?" Sorry, I didn't quite follow that.

After a couple of pages of this heartfelt nonsense it comes as a relief to turn to Paul Virilio, a thinker for whom sense long ago reached escape velocity. Anyone who has wondered if Virilio and Jean Baudrillard are actually one and the same - or, to use the idiom, simulacra of one another - will have their suspicions confirmed here. In Death Valley, readers of America may recall, Baudrillard was entranced by "the silence of the whole of this heat over the mineral expanses that stretch out before us for hundreds of miles, the silence of the gentle wind . . ." For Virilio "the silence is an expansive affair: the mineral silence of the soil or the silence of the sky, everything is silent and for ever". It's not plagiarism, but it's not very original either. Reliant on a discursive software badly in need of updating, Virilio's histrionic babble about the "desertification" of this, that and the other seems more like a symptom of the desertification of contemporary French thought.

These texts are complemented by banal artworks drawing on some of Depardon's photos by Titouan Lamazou and an adolescent collage by Lara Baladi. Far better are the cool, gimmick-free photographs of hot places by William Eggleston and Balthasar Burkhard. Most remarkable of all are the 19th- and early 20th-century photos of Algeria and Egypt by Emile Frechon, John Beasley Greene and others. In these images the abiding sense, as a character in Antonioni's The Passenger says when confronted by a sea of sand, is of "a kind of waiting". At the time they were taken they showed a landscape alien to traditional pictorial aesthetics; over time, they have acquired the silence of the space depicted.

Whatever the quality of individual images, the book lacks the conceptual coherence of, for example, Perpetual Mirage , an exhibition and book that traced the developing tradition of "Photographic narratives of the Desert West". It is also diminished by some glaring omissions: the failure to include images from Richard Misrach's ongoing Desert Cantos series is akin to excluding Mapplethorpe from a survey of gay photography. If the sepia photographs of pyramids from the 1870s had been complemented by Lynn Davis's stunning contemporary images of Giza, we would have seen how the timeless ages and the changeless changes.

Also notable by its absence is the most important artistic/cultural event in the history of the desert: the annual Burning Man festival in Nevada (photographed by Misrach in 1991). The editors have included one of Michael Light's digitally enhanced Nasa images of the lunar desert from his Full Moon project; what is not mentioned is that the full sequence was first exhibited on the night of the full moon at Burning Man 1998, arranged in the form of a 175ft landing strip. The centrepiece was a 1:1 scale image of the surface of the moon; effectively, the lunar desert was imprinted on the Black Rock Desert. A more graphic demonstration of the book's theme - the elision of the actual and photographed desert - is hard to imagine. A more general feeling that things have not been realised pervades this seductive book. It is alluring, full of promise, but - despite its bulk - as substantial as a mirage.

webTitle: Review: The Testament of Yves Gundron by Emily Barton

fields.headline: O brave new world
fields.standfirst: Justine Jordan on The Testament of Yves Gundron, Emily Barton's dazzling debut
fields.trailText: Justine Jordan on The Testament of Yves Gundron, Emily Barton's dazzling debut
fields.body:
The Testament of Yves Gundron
Emily Barton
303pp, Canongate, £9.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL
Read the first chapter

In this dazzling fable of progress in miniature, Yves Gundron, yeoman farmer of the remote village of Mandragora, asks us to imagine the aeons of undifferentiated time before technology gave humankind the leisure for desire, contemplation, travel and doubt. Like his forefathers, he scratches a meagre living from the soil: furrowing the fields with his fingernails, pulling puny loads of produce to market on a one-wheeled cart bound to the throat of a straining horse. The horses don't survive long, and neither do the villagers: though they pray fervently to God and spit to ward off evil spirits, they daren't name their children until they achieve their first birthdays. Then, one day, Yves invents the harness, and "the present as we know it began".

To the modern eye, the consequences of Yves's breakthrough unfold with the inevitability of hindsight: bigger carts, paved roads, the joys of speed and purposeless driving, for which Yves must invent a new name: "Pass-Time". And although this feels like a time-travel narrative, one of us soon steps into the tale: a young American anthropologist, the "editor" of Yves's testament. Ruth Blum has grown up with stories of the mythical Mandragora (its dreamlike name a nod to the narcotic powers of the mandrake root), a rumoured hamlet on an island off the coast of Scotland, "tucked like an egg in the middle of a nest of mountains" and undiscovered by the modern world. As she breathes with wonder when she hikes into the annual village fete, with her immodest clothes and shockingly white teeth, "a tumour . . . all reds and purples like raucous spring flowers, and sprouting everywhere shiny protuberances and black tendrils" on her back: "They're having a Renaissance fair, only they're not."

Yves is extremely relieved when Ruth takes the cancerous rucksack off, and, ignoring the villagers' misapprehensions, invites her into his home (where she stares about so, he assumes she's never seen a house before). There she begins her study of pre-industrial society. Yet despite her determination not to "mess with my data set", her unwitting hints of brakes and double axles threaten to develop her thesis subject out of existence, and an unsettling love affair blossoms in her footnotes to Yves's text. Meanwhile, "the Beyond" comes calling in the shape of a crashed airplane and the US soldiers sent to investigate its disappearance.

Barton ploughs rich comic material from Ruth's unwonted toast and toothpaste, while Yves's wondering narrative allows her to bring a delightfully fresh eye to the accustomed marvels of the modern world: a photograph "a wafer bearing a remarkable likeness", a tape recorder a loaf of bread "with the gentle whir of a distant mill wheel". As Ruth realises to her shame, she is as unable to explain our technology as Yves is to comprehend it. The villagers, of course, study Ruth too: Yves's brother Mandrik, a holy man and the only Mandragorian to have travelled, begins a treatise on the broken postlapsarian language of the stranger, with its "sharp bursts", ubiquitous umming and phatic repetition, and draws grave conclusions about the state of her soul.

It's remarkable that The Testament of Yves Gundron is only a first novel. Barton effortlessly combines a numinously convincing recreation of peasant society and a sci-fi sensibility for cultural conflict with a delicate fable of the Fall, as Yves takes us from the time of his grandfather's grandfather, "when the darkness was newly separated from the light", to his first awful realisation that his life has "somehow ceased to be enough". Yet this is also a surprisingly suspenseful page-turner; as "the future rushes forward to devour us" and it becomes gradually clear that Mandrik has been less than truthful about his travels in the Beyond, Barton's narrative gusto speeds the reader with ease past some hard-to-take twists in the tall tale, and she invests the inevitable conclusion with a nicely judged ambiguity.

Her imaginative daring extends to the playful rhythms of the villagers' parlance, cries of "yo", "land, schmand" and extempore blues ditties scattered among their quasi- King James Bible speech. Like his forefathers, he scratches a meagre living from the soil: furrowing the fields with his fingernails, pulling puny loads of produce to market on a one-wheeled cart bound to the throat of a straining horse. The horses don't survive long, and neither do the villagers: though they pray fervently to God and spit to ward off evil spirits, they daren't name their children until they achieve their first birthdays. Then, one day, Yves invents the harness, and "the present as we know it began". To the modern eye, the consequences of Yves's breakthrough unfold with the inevitability of hindsight: bigger carts, paved roads, the joys of speed and purposeless driving, for which Yves must invent a new name: "Pass-Time". And although this feels like a time-travel narrative, one of us soon steps into the tale: a young American anthropologist, the "editor" of Yves's testament. fields.headline: Rewarding experience
fields.trailText: At the time of writing, the Loafer is busy preparing for the British Book Awards, the publishing world's equivalent of the Oscars, or of a nice old-fashioned bingo evening, depending on your point of view.
fields.body:
 At the time of writing, the Loafer is busy preparing for the British Book Awards, the publishing world's equivalent of the Oscars, or of a nice old-fashioned bingo evening, depending on your point of view. Held at the Hilton in Park Lane, the evening consists of book folk in best bib-and-tucker craning their necks to see who's won Best Supply Chain Company of the Year. Invitations are greeted with groans of faux-despair, while those left out in the cold desperately try to butter up the organisers. A full report will follow next week.

 You have to admit: there are times when one is forced to rethink one's initial reactions. So it was when the Loafer happened across Imagining Marketing: Art, Aesthetics and the Avant-Garde, edited by Stephen Brown and Anthony Patterson and published by the wilfully opaque Routledge. Battling through its analysis of Harry Potter as "the model for 21st century marketing" and a pronouncement that J K Rowling's work holds "the secret of marketing success", the Loafer struggled to stifle snorts of impatience. Until, that is, we came across Bookubes - "a book turned into an exciting multi-faceted plastic cube . . . perfect for reducing executive stress" - whose latest coup is to sign up Potter up. Four HP bookubes will appear in June, with more to follow. Imaginative marketing indeed.

 The most recent figures on Public Lending Right, which calculates earnings for authors according to the number of times they've been borrowed, shows a nation indifferent to diversity, with Catherine Cookson still reigning supreme. Fascinating to note, though, that Shakespeare would have earned a bumper £3,535 were he still alive - only £2,465 behind A A Milne.

 The latest news from the internet reaches us courtesy of The Bookseller magazine. Iain Dale, the flamboyant head of Westminster bookshop Politico's, has snappily registered the domain name bringbackmandy.com. His motive, aside from a deeply held belief in natural justice? The bookish Mandelson, apparently, is a very profitable customer.

 Competition news. Our win-your-height-in-books contest, run in conjunction with bol.com, has produced a winner in Fiona Wilkie. Measuring up at 5 ft 6.5 inches, she received 85 books from bol.com. She also won the affection of the judges by neglecting to complain, like many other entrants, about their lack of stature -blamed variously on increasing age, gender or genetic ill-luck. And, we might add, by submitting her entry in a neat and orderly fashion, rather than on ripped A4 paper adorned by squiggles in 2H pencil. Those who weren't successful, and the irredeemably short, might like to try their hand at our World Book Day quiz.

webTitle: Reviews: The Rotters' Club by Jonathan Coe and deadkidsongs by Toby Litt

fields.headline: Boys will be boys
fields.standfirst: Peter Bradshaw  on two views of youth in The Rotters' Club by Jonathan Coe and deadkidsongs by Toby Litt
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw on two views of youth in The Rotters' Club by Jonathan Coe and deadkidsongs by Toby Litt
fields.body:
The Rotters' Club
Jonathan Coe
406pp, Viking, £14.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

deadkidsongs
Toby Litt
452pp, Hamish Hamilton, £9.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL
Read an extract from deadkidsongs on tobylitt.com

These two novels are excursions not just into childhood but into the more specific, compromised and pungent world of boyhood: a 1970s boyhood, what's more, a world of cliques and gangs, of fervid, imaginary adventurism, hidden yearnings and callow posturing. For today's thirty- or fortysomething male it's a foreign country, where they do things differently, but - disconcertingly - not all that differently. Coe's novel feels autobiographical. I very much hope Toby Litt's isn't.

Gangs of four are at the heart of both. Litt's book is about a quasi-military outfit in a fictional middle-England village, Amplewick; its troops go by the stoutly Anglican names of Andrew, Paul, Matthew and Peter. These teenage lads, encouraged by Andrew's creepy and abusive father, "the Major-General", fantasise about resisting the Russkies' invasion and go on increasingly sinister and fanatical manoeuvres. They're all blond and call themselves Gang, without the definite article, which has an icily Germanic ring.

Coe's bunch are much less disturbing. Trotter, Harding, Anderton and Chase are the precocious, school-uniform-wearing, Oxbridge-material heroes at the independent "King William's School" in Birmingham. They progress much further than Gang into late adolescence, a period more amenable to bitter-sweet comedy. They form bands; they co-edit the school magazine; they get hung up about girls. To borrow a comparison from boys' books, Toby Litt's Aryan Gang looks like a droogish clone of Richmal Crompton's William and his Outlaws, in that their internal code of rank and precedence has nothing to do with school, where they are hardly ever seen. When Andrew leads his followers on one of their missions, he is seen "thrashing at stray stalks with a stick he'd picked up" - pure William. Coe's boys are more like sophisticated, knowing versions of characters from the pages of Ronald Searle and Geoffrey Willans or Anthony Buckeridge. For them, school is everything. It provides the culture and the weather of the novel: a benignly privileged institution represented largely without irony or even criticism.

Deadkidsongs is about as far as it could be from the hip cosmopolitan sophistication of Litt's previous book, Corpsing . With its solidity and substance and its feel for the English countryside, it reads almost like a classroom classic itself. Litt has always been a smart writer, but deadkidsongs shows signs of something more than that. There is an effortless felicity in his prose, and a discreetly happy invention in almost every sentence. But the inflections of comedy and fun have been bleached out of his writing in favour of something much darker, tauter and more unsparing. Litt's Gang, with their fierce Führerprinzip , their casual acquaintance with death and their unwholesome indifference to the outside world, have created their own desert island, comparable to William Golding's in Lord of the Flies . But what makes it more disturbing is that it is far from impervious to adult influence. On the contrary, Gang's dysfunction and murderous fanaticism are licensed and directed by the grown-up world, in the form of Andrew's father - known as "the Best Father". Deadkidsongs is not merely an essay on the dark heart of childhood, but on the dark heart of adulthood too.

Where deadkidsongs is uncertain is in its structure. Ostensibly a "found" manuscript discovered by one of Gang's future sons, the novel comprises not just a fragment from its earnest typewritten archive but conventional omniscient narration from the points of view of different Gang members in turn, sometimes in the first person, sometimes in the third. It is not easy to see how all this technique has materialised in the form of the "500 sheets of going-brown A4 paper", and it slightly diminishes the documentary immediacy that Litt appears to be aiming at. Moreover, in its closing pages it appears to be striving for a sweeter, more empathetic insight into boyhood than is altogether plausible, given the horror and alienation of all that has gone before. But Andrew is certainly a compelling character, who in his tiny megalomania reminded me irresistibly of General Woundwort in Watership Down .

Jonathan Coe's genial, likeable novel can only be described as a kind of lit-prog-rock concept album: the concept in question being what it was like to be a talented adolescent at a prestigious boys' school in the 1970s, and heavily into appalling bands like Yes and Gentle Giant. In fact, it's the first half of a double gatefold album: Coe is in the studio now recording a sequel to The Rotters' Club , which brings all the characters up to date in the early 21st century.

Coe recreates the period with such loving accuracy that I frankly suspect him of having planted a secret microphone in the tin Oxford Mathematical Instruments box I carried around in my school days. Without recourse to the clichés of Spacehoppers and flares, he provides lots of horribly authentic detail: "he was carrying his books and his PE kit in the same bulky sports bag, from which the handle of his squash racket protruded like a permanently erect penis".

Coe is often praised for combining anger and amiability. But despite the fact that the book includes some of the grimmest news from that dire decade, there's a weird dominance of amiability here - a sort of McCartney without the Lennon. His protagonist, Ben Trotter, claims that he is always missing the big events, having slipped out to make a cup of tea at key moments. But this is disingenuous. Coe contrives to give him a ringside seat at all the big historical crises - the pub bombings, British Leyland - as well as at lots of pop-culture high points. He's the opposite of the teen hero of Julian Barnes's Metroland , who goes to Paris in 1968 and gormlessly fails to notice any riots. In fact, Coe cheats with retrospective wisdom. There is much arch comment from Harding, the class joker, about the corruption of the West Midlands Serious Crime Squad - but this only became common knowledge much later. An awful moment comes when Miriam, a sexy young secretary, gets into trouble with union boss Bill Anderton, runs away and vanishes. Her fate will presumably be disclosed in the next book - is it too late to dissuade Coe from sending her to 25 Cromwell Street, Cheltenham?

Unlike his dissection of the 1980s, What a Carve Up! , there is no very obvious anger, scorn or political perspective in the book. In fact, there is something strangely equable in Coe's tone as the long parade of ghastliness passes by, in background and foreground, an odd parallel to the mawkish teenage outpourings. Well, the personal is political, so the sting in the tail presumably comes in the sequel, when his boys have grown up.

It's a long time to wait. But as always with Jonathan Coe, the sheer intelligent good nature that suffuses his work makes it a pleasure to read. Perhaps Litt's book has more visceral power - but Coe's, with its embarrassments and comic vanities, is closer to what being a boy is actually like.

webTitle: Jonathan Coe: a bit of a rotter

fields.headline: Jonathan Coe: a bit of a rotter
fields.standfirst: He's painstakingly truthful and generous, but he can also be ferociously satirical. He tore apart the 80s and now, in his new novel, he's taking a puzzled, autobiographical look at the 70s. Sally Vincent finds Jonathan Coe as grave as you'd expect a funny writer to be
fields.trailText: He's painstakingly truthful and generous, but he can also be ferociously satirical. He tore apart the 80s and now, in his new novel, he's taking a puzzled, autobiographical look at the 70s. Sally Vincent finds Jonathan Coe as grave as you'd expect a funny writer to be
fields.body:
Earl's Court's a funny place to live. It used to be all itinerant Aussies and gays, with the street life to match. Nowadays, its citizens are either the senior sort who got lucky with the 60s rent-control system or thirtysomething European bankers. Not what you'd call an area manifesting much in the way of community spirit. Jonathan Coe lives here because he was priced out of Chelsea and eased westwards before his novels took off and put him into the VAT-registered income bracket, which is a rare distinction for any writer. Ask me about it.

Anyway, these are the streets he walks every day from the basement flat where his loved ones are, between dead-faced Edwardian houses and parked BMWs to the anonymous office complex where he rents a space in which to have a bit of a think, catch up on admin, that sort of thing. It takes about 10 minutes, the stroll, and, as usual, it's raining. He doesn't have an umbrella, just a long, dark-coloured overcoat that makes him look even longer than he is, which is long. Long and singular and solitary and awesomely self-contained.

Come to think of it, he suits Earl's Court. They're stately, the pair of them, otherworldly yet structurally sound and nice to look at. I'd describe Coe as somewhere between handsome and beautiful, except there's something weird going on in the retinal vicinity, a slight distortion of the pupils, perhaps, and between the eyes this deep indentation suggesting a lifelong sense of perplexity. Then, too, someone has given him a sort of pre-adolescent's pudding-bowl haircut, so that every so often you get a flash of an etiolated pixie who's strayed from the enchanted forest and is feeling a tad edgy about getting back in. At all events, we're not talking run-of-the-mill here.

For want of something better to say, I'd been bitching all the way there about his latest narrator and why he keeps whingeing on about being a narrator. Apologising for it. What kind of question's that, I said, "Does narrative have a purpose?" He crossed the road without signalling, so I had to scamper to catch up. "You might as well ask does breathing?" I nagged.

He didn't answer, just looked sideways for a second and made a rushing sound through his nose, which is Coe for laughing. It turned out he's one of those literary blokes who wanders about a room picking up books and referring to them all the time. Hence, once out of the rain, he fished out an old BS Johnson, riffled confidently to the desired page and left me with it for 15 minutes.

It is a memoir regarded as highly innovative in the late 60s called Aren't You Rather Young To Be Writing Your Memoirs? in deference to those who felt that such soul-searching must be the preserve of older gentlemen. On page 35 or thereabouts, Johnson torments himself with the potential destructiveness, if not downright wickedness, of the business of storytelling. He is not interested, he writes, in telling lies. (An admirer of Joyce and Beckett, what he did write was experimental novels using such innovative techniques as holes in the page and diagrammatic type.) Johnson quotes his friend, the poet Philip Pacey: "Telling stories is telling lies about people... is creating or hardening prejudices... is providing an alternative to real communication and/or communication itself... is an escape from the challenge of coming to terms with real people." For a novelist who had never heard of virtual reality, or even of internets, these are pretty hard words.

Burn all the books and jack it all in, I wondered when Coe came back with some rather horrid coffee. Which turned out to be somewhat tactless, as Mr Johnson apparently did away with himself a couple of years after he had delivered himself of this particular spate of self-interrogative nihilism. At age 39, put his affairs in order and cut his wrists in the bath. The Roman style. Why? God knows why. Why does anyone, ever? Coe doesn't know, and doesn't expect to know, dig and delve as he most certainly will. It's just that Johnson's authorised biography is his for the writing, and these precious questions have a way of preying on an open mind.

Subscribe or not, it's a respectable issue. It so happens that Coe does not agree with these despairing sentiments - neither the belief that storytelling is no better than lying nor the impulse to suicide. He doesn't imagine readers hurl novels across rooms because they suspect that what they're reading is not literally true. There's a pact involved, as he sees it. You invite someone along while you tell your story - or your lies - and you mould narrative shapes in order to get at the more universal truth. And while you're doing that, you have to ask yourself why you're doing it and what manner of moral exercise you're engaged in. Things don't have to be literally true, so long as they are true in their component parts. If you see what he means. And you won't achieve that truth if you stop flagellating yourself with your own perfidy. Which Johnson didn't. And why Coe admires him so much. Meanwhile, he's holding on to the eternal verity that people are consoled by patterns imposed on life - or art, as we pretentiously call it - because our lives are such ghastly chaos.

When Coe's magnum opus, the impertinently titled What A Carve Up! was published in 1994 - his fourth published novel, but the first to be panoramic in ambition and noticeable in impact - literary critics uniformly raved about its brilliance, its sociological and political acuity and its general, all-round hilarity. Not that they did him much good. It was a full year before the novel began to sell, and then by word of mouth - recognised as the book that put the definitive boot into the 80s and Thatcherism. Meanwhile, Coe was installed, much to his astonishment, as our very own prince of postmodernism. Whatever that means, ism-wise. Considering the load of faux fin de siècle intellectual maundering that coined the term, you'd expect it to suggest a sort of canonic revolution or disintegration, a merry heralding of an anything-goes, whoopsadaisy brave new genre where there are no longer any value systems, nobody comes over all judgmental, and high and low cultures are either the same or they cancel each other out. When Coe thought about his new label, he decided to wear it with good grace. He could be postmodern in form, yes, and arse about with farce, pastiche, larky allusion and so forth, while smuggling in his own brand of 19th-century moralism and Puritanism by way of content. He could live with that.

Considering the autobiographic nature of the burden of his work, Coe is strangely reticent about his background. His mother and father are alive and well and living in the home he grew up in and have done absolutely nothing to court anyone's attention. It wouldn't be fair... but then, neither is having a writer in the family fair. So he was born in 1961 in a leafy suburb of Birmingham, best described by Tolkien as Hobbiton across the water. A nice, civilised, three-bedroomed house brought to maximum grace by the addition of a fourth, strictly unnecessary apartment annexed to the space over the garage.

Anyway, he lapped up Sherlock Holmes and everything by Wodehouse until school took the edge off his reading pleasure. He began to sense that they were not, after all, "the canon". Not that he knew the word at the time. He simply began to sense the difference between what gave him joy and what he was supposed to read in order to better himself. The "canon", therefore, was what they made him read: To Kill A Mockingbird, Animal Farm, Lord Of The Flies, books presented as serious and worthy, books to teach you something important about which you would later be examined. But he did his homework like the good, clever little schoolboy he was, got to the posh grammar school and then rediscovered the mischievous, romping, outlandish, slightly subversive undertow that had drawn him to Wodehouse in the work of television scriptwriters: Galton and Simpson, Le Frenais, Dick Clement, John Cleese, the great 70s cock-snookers. And this time his taste was shared by all other boys.
