"They think it was all about wide collars, and glam rock and they get nostalgic about Fawlty Towers and kid's TV programmes and they forget the ungodly strangeness of it."

Or, come to that, the ungodly strangeness of being a growing boy in any decade. In the light of its past-historic authenticity, it is all too easy to perceive our aforementioned hero, Benjamin Trotter, known to his peers as Bent - Bent Rotter (geddit) - as the moulded image of Jonathan Coe, near as dammit. The man himself is fairly accommodating about this assumption, which has been applied to all his novels, barring the one with a heroine and the first to be published, The Accidental Woman, which he now repudiates as "too cruel".

You have only to say, hey, was that you in A Touch Of Love, holed up in a bedsit having a depressive breakdown and going ballistic over a flat-pack of sausages and mash because it had a photo on the wrapping of a knife, fork and plate containing half sausages and half mash, just that, and underneath the caption "Serving suggestions"? Because when I read it I was on a train between Cambridge and King's Cross and it caused me to suffer attacks of catalepsy in front of all the mobile phone users. And he says, yes, that was him, except his had been the most minute and laughable of breakdowns.

All that happened was he didn't get out of bed for a few days because when he did get up he kept falling over and crashing into things. He'd put food into the oven and forget to turn the oven on, things like that, which was how he came to be examining the packet in the first place. It was just that his PhD wasn't writing itself and he was being a bit irrational because, after all, if they'd put a sprig of parsley and a dollop of beans in the picture by way of "serving suggestions", people like him would ring them up and ask where their parsley and beans had got to.

Or you can ask: was that you in The Rotters' Club, the schoolboy so crazed with fear of being seen naked that you prayed to God for deliverance and He was moved to fling a wet pair of bathers into your orbit. Yes and no. There was no such epiphanous moment, he says, and besides, he's an atheist. But the fear was true. They had this rule at school that if a boy forgot to bring his swimming trunks for swimming lessons, he'd be made to swim naked. This wasn't so much authoritarian sadism as a rule to persuade boys to remember their kit. It wouldn't have been an ordeal to be seen naked if everyone else was; it was just that if it was only one set of genitals in the pool and those genitals chanced to be your own, you'd pretty well wish for death to come before the mockery.

That's what it's like at the sort of highly academic, highly competitive school he went to. There's no physical bullying at all; the way to get one over on another boy is through sharp and devastating verbal stuff. To a schoolboy of this ilk, everything is good for a laugh, especially, they all believe, their own sexuality, and since they have yet to distinguish between ego and id, their penises and their immortal souls, the best - the most relieving - thing they can do is to project their worst-nightmare scenarios on to each other.

Which brings us to the matter of Dickie's Bag. There are two Richards in Bent's year, one is black and known wittily as Rastus. The other, for reasons more profoundly rooted in the fear of the unknown, they insist on calling Dickie. There is nothing intrinsically disturbing about Dickie. He isn't effete or macho, nor is there anything about his bag to distinguish it from any other boy's bag. They all have similarly featureless holdalls to carry their books about; blue, black, brown, nothing fancy. Anyway, for unfathomable reasons, Dickie's bag is unanimously elected as a sort of sex object. Every morning, as Dickie hoves into view, the cry goes go up, "Dickie's Bag! Dickie's Bag!" And the whole bunch of them fall upon the luckless receptacle and hump the daylights out of it.

Coe nearly smiles at the memory. It was true, yes. He recently met a man he hadn't seen for 22 years and found it difficult talking with him after all that time until he mentioned Dickie's bag. What can he say? It was just something they did. They humped the bag and it kind of set them up for the day. Did he join in? Of course he joined in. The whole point of the exercise was that it was collective. Collective, sublime and incomprehensible, as all schoolboy humour is. He went a bit shifty-eyed then and swivelled his focus around the floor until his eye fell upon my bag, a rather fine carpet number much admired by taxi-drivers, lying open and vulnerable with all its used tissues and fag packets showing. "No," he says drily. "Not my type."

It is an uncharacteristic moment of levity. Coe is courteous, painstakingly truthful, co-operative and generous, but he is not a man to demean himself by courting a cheap laugh. I've often noticed that about people who are funny for a living; it's as though the other side of the coin of anarchy - which is what funny's all about - the one they front up with, is an abiding gravity, a wall of diffidence five feet thick that you'd be ill-advised to try to penetrate. All his narrators have this kind of withdrawn, hesitant quality.

I had to ask. Was that you lurking at the open door to watch daft, fat Joan sprawled naked on her bed? The man who covertly marvelled at the staggering beauty of her body, but then, when she said something matey like, "Aren't you coming in then?", turned and tippy-toed silently away?

No, he says. He made it up. Yet he cannot tell a lie. If he hadn't made it up, if it had really happened then, yes, he'd have skipped off. "Men say to me, come on, any man in that situation would have been in like Flynn, but my impression - and maybe this is just the kind of friends I have gathered around myself - is that people aren't nearly as sexually confident or assertive as they portray themselves, or as they are portrayed in 95% of fiction. The truth is, there is nothing more frightening than a huge, succulent girl lying naked on a bed saying Come On In. Nothing. No. Really..."

He is in earnest. "Men," he says, solemn as a polytechnic sociology tutor, "have been disenfranchised by the sexual politics of the past 20 years. Much as Old Labour voters don't have anywhere to put themselves any more. The options offered by our culture, or the media, or whatever you want to call it, are New Lad and New Man. And neither really exists. New Lad is hedonistic, emotionally ruthless, uncommitted, full of bravado. New Man is emotionally, comically conscientious and domesticated. One would leap on Joan, the other tiptoe away. It's a pathetic choice."

A typical victim of male disenfranchisement would be Robert, the poor sod in The House Of Sleep who gets in such a sweat getting in touch with his other gender self that he winds up having a sex change. Which is clearly neither true of the author, nor any kind of stab at social realism. But it is a metaphor. We get nurtured, for all we know against our nature, to be acceptable, attractive members of our sex, then when we fail to find nirvana we re-nurture ourselves, and - in extremis, turn to the other absurdity. And that doesn't work, either. It's nothing to laugh at.

Coe had written three unpublished novels - four if you include the Jason oeuvre when he was eight - by the time he was 25. It was then he took a violent dislike to all his male protagonists and decided, in a purely literary sense, to change sex. The Accidental Woman (for it was she) wrenched £200 from the publishers Duckworth and became, he says, the literary non-event of the 80s. But it broke, as it were, his duck. He remembers what it was like back then, living in a bedsit in Coventry, sending off the Jiffy bag and getting it back with the rejection slip over and over again. He kept them. Sometimes, he gets them out and reads them again.

At the time, they failed to daunt; in fact, they came as terribly thrilling missives from the throbbing head of literary London. He knows now they're just stock phrases that publishers dash off a hundred times a day, but back then "shows promise" or "we'd be interested in your next effort" told him that he existed, that he was a contender. He remembers getting a rejection slip from Punch for a short story. It was just the standard thing, except that someone had written, in handwriting, "Thanks" at the bottom. It was like a beaker of water, he says, to a thirsty man.

Encouraged, he moved to a shared dump in Bermondsey and set about A Touch Of Love, for which Duckworth doubled its ante. Coe, meanwhile, had already embarked on his own personal sentimental journey, a trip that strangely exemplifies the promise that life will imitate art if you take both of these things seriously.

In the mid-80s, you'll recall, people read Amis and Barnes and Ishiguro et al, and Coe was no exception to this rule. His own God, however - the writer of whom he actually pronounces the word "Phew!" - is Alasdair Gray. The first Gray to strike him in the solar plexus ("And this is quite odd, actually," he understates) was called 1982, Janine. It was a novel about the Thatcher years and one night in the life of a deeply depressed man confronting the cock-up he made of his life. Janine is the fantasy figure he creates to take his mind off the loss of the love of his life. In other words, she is the great sex symbol, the redeemer of the great inconsolable cataclysm in the hearts of man. The woman.

And then Coe met Janine. I mean, that was her name. So, in 1987, Janine. Coe was keeping body and soul together by working part-time in the Dickensian office of a firm of solicitors, proof-reading legal documents. It was an ideal job for a novelist in that it was so mind-numbingly boring it didn't sap your imaginative juices, so you'd be feeling quite creatively spry by the time you got back to your Oliver portable. Meanwhile, the other side of his desk, Janine was similarly employed, unaware of the significance of her Christian name.

They developed a modus operandi in order to stay awake. He'd read a lease aloud to her, putting in all the punctuation marks and capitalisations, then she'd do the same back. This went on for six months. Call it a courtship. "It was strange," he says in his enigmatic way. "There was all this talking going on, but not about anything. Just a lot of noise being made." No shades of Joan, then? There were, he concedes, "textural factors". The office began a thing where people went for a drink together after work and, yes, he asked her out and, yes, they married. Suffice it to say that the dedication of What A Carve Up! reads "1994, Janine", and subsequent novels have extended their dedications to Janine and Matilda and to Janine and Matilda and Madeline. And that Alasdair Gray, when Coe eventually met his hero, vowed to pulp 1982, Janine if anything went wrong with their marriage.

Fatherhood was not a place he entered without trepidation. He had thought he would never have children, he has almost forgotten why. When you think that it's a choice you can make, that's the problem: you think about it. He thought he had parent's block the way other people have writer's block. The simple fact was that he was scared. He'd grown up, or rather not grown up, believing himself to be clever and funny, as if that was enough to be going on with. And it's not. Clever and funny doesn't come close. It equips you, maybe, to be a comic novelist, not an adult male. So he stopped thinking about it. Now that his daughters have been born, he realises he wasn't wrong. But then, he didn't know, either, what he was made of. You don't until you've lived with a three-year-old, plumbed the depths of your reserves of energy and generosity, found strengths in yourself you never dreamt you had. You grow up.

And this is the easy bit. A small child is a lunatic, there's no doubt about it. They're nuts. "I mean," he says, "what can you do when the tantrum's because the imaginary friend hasn't called round when they promised they would? You're in the realm of the deeply irrational, but it's a kind of a relief to be in that realm for a while, knowing that terrible, earth-shattering disappointment is only in the head. It's a dismal thought that it's going to become rational later on."

There is no end to catastrophic expectation for any of us, it seems. At the end of The Rotters' Club, Coe has written a sentence that goes on for 15,000 words, which will doubtless be featured in the next edition of the Guinness Book Of Records. As a triumph of form over content it has to be seen to be believed. Coe is fairly sanguine about it. He reckons the content dictated the form. Had Bent not won the girl of his dreams? Had Mrs Thatcher not been elected to lead our benighted country? Do these twin dramas not merit the odd stylistic firework? And, besides, there's a Czech writer who once wrote a whole novel with nary a full stop. So how's that for clever and funny?

Coe is already working on a sequel to The Rotters' Club, which will leap forward to the 90s, so putting paid to the 20th century - or rather his treatment of the last three decades of it. This afternoon he will listen to BS Johnson's tapes on the big, 50s tape-recorder. Johnson recorded everything, as luck has it. Dinner parties, conversations with his friends, everything. And then? He'd prefer not to contemplate what comes next. "How do you write a novel about global warming?" he says. And answers himself. "You can't. It's too big. The tools just don't do the job. You can't get your head round it."

He will.

 The Rotters' Club is published by Viking at £14.99

 Jonathan Coe will be live online on Guardian Unlimited, Books, at 3pm on March 8. To post your questions, go to www.theguardian.com/books

Nowadays, its citizens are either the senior sort who got lucky with the 60s rent-control system or thirtysomething European bankers. Not what you'd call an area manifesting much in the way of community spirit. Jonathan Coe lives here because he was priced out of Chelsea and eased westwards before his novels took off and put him into the VAT-registered income bracket, which is a rare distinction for any writer. Ask me about it. Anyway, these are the streets he walks every day from the basement flat where his loved ones are, between dead-faced Edwardian houses and parked BMWs to the anonymous office complex where he rents a space in which to have a bit of a think, catch up on admin, that sort of thing. It takes about 10 minutes, the stroll, and, as usual, it's raining. He doesn't have an umbrella, just a long, dark-coloured overcoat that makes him look even longer than he is, which is long. Long and singular and solitary and awesomely self-contained. Come to think of it, he suits Earl's Court. They're stately, the pair of them, otherworldly yet structurally sound and nice to look at. I'd describe Coe as somewhere between handsome and beautiful, except there's something weird going on in the retinal vicinity, a slight distortion of the pupils, perhaps, and between the eyes this deep indentation suggesting a lifelong sense of perplexity. Then, too, someone has given him a sort of pre-adolescent's pudding-bowl haircut, so that every so often you get a flash of an etiolated pixie who's strayed from the enchanted forest and is feeling a tad edgy about getting back in. At all events, we're not talking run-of-the-mill here. For want of something better to say, I'd been bitching all the way there about his latest narrator and why he keeps whingeing on about being a narrator. Apologising for it. What kind of question's that, I said, "Does narrative have a purpose?" He crossed the road without signalling, so I had to scamper to catch up. "You might as well ask does breathing?" I nagged. He didn't answer, just looked sideways for a second and made a rushing sound through his nose, which is Coe for laughing. It turned out he's one of those literary blokes who wanders about a room picking up books and referring to them all the time. Hence, once out of the rain, he fished out an old BS Johnson, riffled confidently to the desired page and left me with it for 15 minutes. It is a memoir regarded as highly innovative in the late 60s called Aren't You Rather Young To Be Writing Your Memoirs? in deference to those who felt that such soul-searching must be the preserve of older gentlemen. On page 35 or thereabouts, Johnson torments himself with the potential destructiveness, if not downright wickedness, of the business of storytelling. He is not interested, he writes, in telling lies. (An admirer of Joyce and Beckett, what he did write was experimental novels using such innovative techniques as holes in the page and diagrammatic type.) Johnson quotes his friend, the poet Philip Pacey: "Telling stories is telling lies about people... is creating or hardening prejudices... is providing an alternative to real communication and/or communication itself... is an escape from the challenge of coming to terms with real people." For a novelist who had never heard of virtual reality, or even of internets, these are pretty hard words. Burn all the books and jack it all in, I wondered when Coe came back with some rather horrid coffee. Which turned out to be somewhat tactless, as Mr Johnson apparently did away with himself a couple of years after he had delivered himself of this particular spate of self-interrogative nihilism. Anyway, for unfathomable reasons, Dickie's bag is unanimously elected as a sort of sex object. Every morning, as Dickie hoves into view, the cry goes go up, "Dickie's Bag! Dickie's Bag!" And the whole bunch of them fall upon the luckless receptacle and hump the daylights out of it. Coe nearly smiles at the memory. It was true, yes. He recently met a man he hadn't seen for 22 years and found it difficult talking with him after all that time until he mentioned Dickie's bag. What can he say? It was just something they did. They humped the bag and it kind of set them up for the day. Did he join in? Of course he joined in. The whole point of the exercise was that it was collective. Collective, sublime and incomprehensible, as all schoolboy humour is. He went a bit shifty-eyed then and swivelled his focus around the floor until his eye fell upon my bag, a rather fine carpet number much admired by taxi-drivers, lying open and vulnerable with all its used tissues and fag packets showing. "No," he says drily. "Not my type." It is an uncharacteristic moment of levity. Coe is courteous, painstakingly truthful, co-operative and generous, but he is not a man to demean himself by courting a cheap laugh. I've often noticed that about people who are funny for a living; it's as though the other side of the coin of anarchy - which is what funny's all about - the one they front up with, is an abiding gravity, a wall of diffidence five feet thick that you'd be ill-advised to try to penetrate. All his narrators have this kind of withdrawn, hesitant quality. I had to ask. Was that you lurking at the open door to watch daft, fat Joan sprawled naked on her bed? The man who covertly marvelled at the staggering beauty of her body, but then, when she said something matey like, "Aren't you coming in then?", turned and tippy-toed silently away? No, he says. He made it up. Yet he cannot tell a lie. If he hadn't made it up, if it had really happened then, yes, he'd have skipped off. "Men say to me, come on, any man in that situation would have been in like Flynn, but my impression - and maybe this is just the kind of friends I have gathered around myself - is that people aren't nearly as sexually confident or assertive as they portray themselves, or as they are portrayed in 95% of fiction. The truth is, there is nothing more frightening than a huge, succulent girl lying naked on a bed saying Come On In. Nothing. No. Really..." He is in earnest. "Men," he says, solemn as a polytechnic sociology tutor, "have been disenfranchised by the sexual politics of the past 20 years. Much as Old Labour voters don't have anywhere to put themselves any more. The options offered by our culture, or the media, or whatever you want to call it, are New Lad and New Man. And neither really exists. New Lad is hedonistic, emotionally ruthless, uncommitted, full of bravado. New Man is emotionally, comically conscientious and domesticated. One would leap on Joan, the other tiptoe away. It's a pathetic choice." A typical victim of male disenfranchisement would be Robert, the poor sod in The House Of Sleep who gets in such a sweat getting in touch with his other gender self that he winds up having a sex change. Which is clearly neither true of the author, nor any kind of stab at social realism. But it is a metaphor. We get nurtured, for all we know against our nature, to be acceptable, attractive members of our sex, then when we fail to find nirvana we re-nurture ourselves, and - in extremis, turn to the other absurdity. And that doesn't work, either. It's nothing to laugh at. Coe had written three unpublished novels - four if you include the Jason oeuvre when he was eight - by the time he was 25. It was then he took a violent dislike to all his male protagonists and decided, in a purely literary sense, to change sex. The Accidental Woman (for it was she) wrenched £200 from the publishers Duckworth and became, he says, the literary non-event of the 80s. But it broke, as it were, his duck. He remembers what it was like back then, living in a bedsit in Coventry, sending off the Jiffy bag and getting it back with the rejection slip over and over again. He kept them. Sometimes, he gets them out and reads them again. At the time, they failed to daunt; in fact, they came as terribly thrilling missives from the throbbing head of literary London. He knows now they're just stock phrases that publishers dash off a hundred times a day, but back then "shows promise" or "we'd be interested in your next effort" told him that he existed, that he was a contender. He remembers getting a rejection slip from Punch for a short story. It was just the standard thing, except that someone had written, in handwriting, "Thanks" at the bottom. It was like a beaker of water, he says, to a thirsty man. Encouraged, he moved to a shared dump in Bermondsey and set about A Touch Of Love, for which Duckworth doubled its ante. Coe, meanwhile, had already embarked on his own personal sentimental journey, a trip that strangely exemplifies the promise that life will imitate art if you take both of these things seriously. In the mid-80s, you'll recall, people read Amis and Barnes and Ishiguro et al, and Coe was no exception to this rule. His own God, however - the writer of whom he actually pronounces the word "Phew!" - is Alasdair Gray. The first Gray to strike him in the solar plexus ("And this is quite odd, actually," he understates) was called 1982, Janine. It was a novel about the Thatcher years and one night in the life of a deeply depressed man confronting the cock-up he made of his life. Janine is the fantasy figure he creates to take his mind off the loss of the love of his life. In other words, she is the great sex symbol, the redeemer of the great inconsolable cataclysm in the hearts of man. The woman. And then Coe met Janine. I mean, that was her name. So, in 1987, Janine. Coe was keeping body and soul together by working part-time in the Dickensian office of a firm of solicitors, proof-reading legal documents. It was an ideal job for a novelist in that it was so mind-numbingly boring it didn't sap your imaginative juices, so you'd be feeling quite creatively spry by the time you got back to your Oliver portable. Meanwhile, the other side of his desk, Janine was similarly employed, unaware of the significance of her Christian name. They developed a modus operandi in order to stay awake. He'd read a lease aloud to her, putting in all the punctuation marks and capitalisations, then she'd do the same back. This went on for six months. Call it a courtship. "It was strange," he says in his enigmatic way. "There was all this talking going on, but not about anything. Just a lot of noise being made." No shades of Joan, then? There were, he concedes, "textural factors". The office began a thing where people went for a drink together after work and, yes, he asked her out and, yes, they married. Suffice it to say that the dedication of What A Carve Up! reads "1994, Janine", and subsequent novels have extended their dedications to Janine and Matilda and to Janine and Matilda and Madeline. And that Alasdair Gray, when Coe eventually met his hero, vowed to pulp 1982, Janine if anything went wrong with their marriage. Fatherhood was not a place he entered without trepidation. He had thought he would never have children, he has almost forgotten why. When you think that it's a choice you can make, that's the problem: you think about it. He thought he had parent's block the way other people have writer's block. The simple fact was that he was scared. He'd grown up, or rather not grown up, believing himself to be clever and funny, as if that was enough to be going on with. And it's not. Clever and funny doesn't come close. It equips you, maybe, to be a comic novelist, not an adult male. So he stopped thinking about it. Now that his daughters have been born, he realises he wasn't wrong. But then, he didn't know, either, what he was made of. You don't until you've lived with a three-year-old, plumbed the depths of your reserves of energy and generosity, found strengths in yourself you never dreamt you had. You grow up. And this is the easy bit. A small child is a lunatic, there's no doubt about it. They're nuts. "I mean," he says, "what can you do when the tantrum's because the imaginary friend hasn't called round when they promised they would? You're in the realm of the deeply irrational, but it's a kind of a relief to be in that realm for a while, knowing that terrible, earth-shattering disappointment is only in the head. It's a dismal thought that it's going to become rational later on." There is no end to catastrophic expectation for any of us, it seems. At the end of The Rotters' Club, Coe has written a sentence that goes on for 15,000 words, which will doubtless be featured in the next edition of the Guinness Book Of Records. As a triumph of form over content it has to be seen to be believed. Coe is fairly sanguine about it. He reckons the content dictated the form. Had Bent not won the girl of his dreams? Had Mrs Thatcher not been elected to lead our benighted country? Do these twin dramas not merit the odd stylistic firework? And, besides, there's a Czech writer who once wrote a whole novel with nary a full stop. So how's that for clever and funny? Coe is already working on a sequel to The Rotters' Club, which will leap forward to the 90s, so putting paid to the 20th century - or rather his treatment of the last three decades of it. This afternoon he will listen to BS Johnson's tapes on the big, 50s tape-recorder. Johnson recorded everything, as luck has it. Dinner parties, conversations with his friends, everything. And then? He'd prefer not to contemplate what comes next. "How do you write a novel about global warming?" he says. And answers himself. "You can't. It's too big. The tools just don't do the job. You can't get your head round it." He will.  The Rotters' Club is published by Viking at £14.99  Jonathan Coe will be live online on Guardian Unlimited, Books, at 3pm on March 8. To post your questions, go to www.theguardian.com/books

webTitle: Review: Idolizing Pictures: Idolatry, Iconoclasm and Jewish Art by Anthony Julius

fields.headline: Art attacks
fields.standfirst: Michael Kustow investigates the history of Jewish iconoclasm in Idolizing Pictures: Idolatry, Iconoclasm and Jewish Art by Anthony Julius
fields.trailText: Michael Kustow investigates the history of Jewish iconoclasm in Idolizing Pictures: Idolatry, Iconoclasm and Jewish Art by Anthony Julius
fields.body:
Idolizing Pictures: Idolatry, Iconoclasm and Jewish Art
Anthony Julius
120pp, Thames & Hudson, £8.95
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Anthony Julius has written a restless book, brief but bristling with questions and buffeted by bigger waves than art-world spasms, for it does nothing less than dare to raise the question of "Jewish art". Julius is well qualified to explore this perilous category, which Hitler and Stalin used to "cleanse" their cultures. He has written a study of T S Eliot's anti-Semitism, and completed Idolizing Pictures while acting for the defence in the David Irving libel trial. Irving's display of anti-Semitism red in tooth and claw has sharpened what began as a scholarly lecture in memory of publisher Walter Neurath, a German-Jewish émigré. Julius defiantly attempts "to affirm the vitality of the Jewish tradition, which does not depend on anti-semites to sustain it". The result is a teasing text, part philosophy, part theology, part art criticism, full enough to strain at its seams.

"Thou shalt not make unto thee any graven image, or any likeness of anything that is in heaven above, or that is in the earth beneath, or that is in the water under the earth." This prohibition from Exodus chapter 20, Judaism's most prickly admonition to art and artists, is the launchpad of Julius's quest. It has provided philistines, zealots and tyrants with scriptural justification for all manner of censorships, persecutions and bonfires, massacres of images and their makers. It has also pushed artists to capture the transcendental.

Julius plots the different Christian and Jewish responses to the prohibition by initially contrasting two pictures: Ingres's "The Vow of Louis XIII" (1824) and Komar and Melamid's "The Origins of Socialist Realism" (1982-3). The first, he says, is a work of Christian art - "theology in a frame" glorifying the monarch, the Virgin and painting itself. The second, produced by a wry Russian-Jewish duo, deploys pastiche on the verge of camp to subvert the cult of Stalin and the neo-classical solemnity of socialist realist art itself. It is, says Julius, deeply Jewish.

A work of Christian art is made possible, despite the ban on graven images, by Christianity's escape clause, the Incarnation. If Jesus is a representation of the Holy Spirit, the painter is thereby, in Julius's contractual terminology, "mandated" to represent the world. Jewish artists, whose religion encompasses no Incarnation and whose god is incorporeal and invisible, are more boxed in by the Second Commandment. One of Chagall's great-uncles refused to shake hands with him when he learned that he made drawings.

In a central section of forensic ferocity, armed with wide philosophical and theological reference, Julius distils three alternatives for a Jewish art or aesthetics under the Biblical prohibition: an art, or anti-art, of the sublime and the infinite (the abstract expressionists Barnett Newman, Mark Rothko and Adolph Gottleib); an iconic art, devoted to Jewish motifs (Chagall, Kitaj, but also Holocaust survivors' "art of witness"); and an art of idol-breaking through irony, which Julius differentiates from avant-garde anti-bourgeois iconoclasm, which still idolises art.

Komar and Melamid are once more his exemplars: in their "What is to be Done with Monumental Propaganda" (1992) they offered a Swiftian modest proposal aimed at turning Moscow into "a phantasmagoric garden of post-totalitarian art" - not by demolishing statues, as violent Byzantine iconoclasts and post-communist celebrants had, but by mockery and ironic recycling that lay bare the machinery of idolising anything. In one reworking prompted by their appeal, the gigantic worker and peasant of a 1937 Moscow statue stride purposefully off their pedestal into a void.

There's little doubt that Komar and Melamid are talented painters and sly polemicists, and Julius's contrast of their profound irony with the self-importance of other iconoclastic artists - Duchamp, Gustav Metzger, Anselm Kiefer - is a tonic challenge to current art values and to the "reverence" (Bernard Berenson's pious term) of connoisseurs. But I wanted to know more about how he is affected by the pictures he views and ranks with such clarity. When Ruskin wrote about Turner as an exemplary artist, he made you feel what the pictures were like as well as what they stood for in his argument.

But Julius does enlarge the debate, precisely because his book crosses categories. The "art-making iconoclasm" that he, with some diffidence, calls Jewish - does it apply only to the visual? What about Kafka or Pinter, who have destabilised their art form by transforming its iconography and language? Were they too pushed by some Jewish rage against the idolatry of art? But then, what about Blake's alternative cosmology: isn't that Old Testament in spirit, too? Beckett makes artistic images of the unnameable, and he's certainly not Jewish. There are so many questions.

And then what about Israel, of whose art Julius offers a brief and not very striking glimpse? His most tantalising reference is to the "radical art of the Territories . . . which tends to take as its subject what might be described as the idolatry of the land". In this time of stones and guns, bombs and ambushes around the West Bank settlements, the work of Israeli artists against the cult of "Judea and Samaria" might have further actualised Anthony Julius's troubling reminder of the persistent human drift to idolatry: of gods, rulers, holy scripture and even art itself.

fields.headline: Et cetera
fields.standfirst: Steven Poole  on The Mechanization of the Mind by Jean-Pierre Dupuy, The Three Ecologies, by Félix Guattari, and  Spectacular Narratives: Hollywood in the Age of the Blockbuster, by Geoff King
fields.trailText: Steven Poole on The Mechanization of the Mind by Jean-Pierre Dupuy, The Three Ecologies, by Félix Guattari, and Spectacular Narratives: Hollywood in the Age of the Blockbuster, by Geoff King
fields.body:
The Mechanization of the Mind
Jean-Pierre Dupuy
(Princeton, £18.95)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Can a machine think? Of course it can. After all, you're a machine, and you think. That's not the right question, as Dupuy's elegant and lucid work argues. The revolution in what we now call cognitive science in the middle of the last century lay not in an anthropomorphisation of machines, but, as his title suggests, in a project to mechanise our understanding of the human. It all began at the 10 so-called Macy Conferences held in New York between 1946 and 1953, at which scientists - including John von Neumann and Norbert Wiener - invented a field they called "cybernetics". Dupuy argues that these conferences also anticipated developments of chaos theory and complexity theory, and that modern cognitive science ought to take another look at their astonishingly far-sighted methods. Short and very crunchy, Dupuy's book is a superb example of detective work in the history of ideas.

The Three Ecologies
Félix Guattari
(Athlone, £14.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

How, mused Guattari at the end of his life, to counter the forces of Integrated World Capitalism, which invades and commodifies our Existential Territories? Why, with Ecosophy, which generalises the concerns of ecology to the social and mental spheres. In this provocative utopia, we will reinvent our "modalities of group-being", and by a kind of artistic social psychoanalysis will allow free but safe expression to violent and destructive phantasmagorias. Fantastic. Now I've got a really good reason to blow the heads off virtual zombies. Attractive in a maddeningly opaque way, Guattari's brief, dreamlike pseudo-utopia is padded out with commentary and a helpful biog.

Spectacular Narratives: Hollywood in the Age of the Blockbuster
Geoff King (I B Tauris, £12.95)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Just as Ludwig Wittgenstein enjoyed whiling away the afternoons watching westerns at the cinema, so one imagines today's philosophers covertly thrilling to modern blockbusters when they get bored of compatibilism. King's book is a likeable romp through the kind of joyously expensive film-making that rarely features on film-critical radars. There is a detailed discussion of "impact aesthetics" (that's how explosions are made sensually gratifying) in The Long Kiss Goodnight and The Rock ; "frontier narrative" in Twister (featuring, of course, the "vaginal vortex of the tornado"); and an excellent deconstruction of the contrived "authenticity" of the Normany landings in Spielberg's jejune special-effects extravaganza, Saving Private Ryan . All good fun, apart from a feeling that "text" is too often privileged at the expense of a deeper analysis of the mechanical paradigms of visual rapture. Why do people still insist on calling films texts, anyway? It's like post-structuralism never died. Shall I call this book a film? Would that be OK?

fields.headline: Soft-centred
fields.standfirst:
Director Lasse Hallstrom seems to have a knack
for sweet-natured, award-winning dramas. Could
his apprenticeship with Abba have anything to do
with it?
fields.trailText: Director Lasse Hallstrom seems to have a knack for sweet-natured, award-winning dramas. Could his apprenticeship with Abba have anything to do with it?
fields.body:
Best-known for his affectionate portrayals of dysfunctional families in films such as My Life As A Dog and What's Eating Gilbert Grape, 54-year-old Swedish director Lasse Hallstrom changed pace a little with 1999's acclaimed The Cider House Rules. Now he's back in Oscar contention with Chocolat, in which Juliette Binoche sets about changing lives in a small French town. Married to the actress Lena Olin, who's also in Chocolat, Hallstrom now lives in New York state.

Do you like chocolate?

I try and stay away from it. I'm on this diet where you're supposed to eat only fish and meat. I'm trying to lower my cholesterol, so now I'm fanatically anti-chocolate.

What was it like to finally work with your wife?

It was great. We met 10 years ago and immediately decided to work together on something, and we've been looking for material ever since. It's been a very frustrating wait.

Some people might be wary about directing their wife.

Yes. I imagined that it might be awkward to talk to your wife about her performance, so going into it I was a little nervous. But doing it was actually a wonderfully inspiring experience.

Do you specialise in whimsical stories?

Yeah, they end up being a little whimsical, don't they? It's not what attracts me though. My key interest in choosing scripts is character-driven stories, because there are so many stories that sacrifice character for plot. I just can't get interested in those. I have an affinity for eccentrics and outsiders, and portraying them and not being judgmental about them.

There's also a sweet tone to your films.

Yeah. I can see that but I hate it. Sweetness per se is something that I'd shy away from and wouldn't consciously do. But I notice that there is a lack of darkness in my movies and I don't know where that comes from. I try to be honest and truthful with the performances. Cider House had a lot of sweet kids but I didn't want to emphasise that. It's a good question and I don't know how to respond.

Were you surprised with the way Leonardo DiCaprio's career took off after Gilbert Grape?

I remember saying he was going to be a big star one day. Go back into the archives and look it up! I really thought he was brilliant. I think he'd be good at anything he'd do. The Titanic experience must have been horrifying for him but things are sort of back to normal now.

Your first film was Abba: The Movie. Do you have happy memories of it?

I do. Five weeks in Australia, it was wonderful. It was 1977 and coming from Sweden to Australia was fantastic. They're very nice. I made all their videos, apart from the last two, so if you ever see an Abba video on TV then it's my stuff. They look their age now. I saw a couple the other week and things have moved on. I'm still proud of them though.

Are you still in touch with them?

I am. I meet up with Benny and Bjorn occasionally. I actually went to see Mamma Mia! in London and it was the strongest theatrical experience I've ever had. It was great to hear that music again because they were frowned upon at the time: Abba were seen as too commercial, but I knew that their music was going to survive.

But doing it was actually a wonderfully inspiring experience. Do you specialise in whimsical stories? Yeah, they end up being a little whimsical, don't they? It's not what attracts me though. My key interest in choosing scripts is character-driven stories, because there are so many stories that sacrifice character for plot. I just can't get interested in those. I have an affinity for eccentrics and outsiders, and portraying them and not being judgmental about them. There's also a sweet tone to your films. Yeah. I can see that but I hate it. Sweetness per se is something that I'd shy away from and wouldn't consciously do. But I notice that there is a lack of darkness in my movies and I don't know where that comes from. I try to be honest and truthful with the performances. Cider House had a lot of sweet kids but I didn't want to emphasise that. It's a good question and I don't know how to respond. Were you surprised with the way Leonardo DiCaprio's career took off after Gilbert Grape? I remember saying he was going to be a big star one day. Go back into the archives and look it up! I really thought he was brilliant. I think he'd be good at anything he'd do. The Titanic experience must have been horrifying for him but things are sort of back to normal now. Your first film was Abba: The Movie. Do you have happy memories of it? I do. Five weeks in Australia, it was wonderful. It was 1977 and coming from Sweden to Australia was fantastic. They're very nice. I made all their videos, apart from the last two, so if you ever see an Abba video on TV then it's my stuff. They look their age now. I saw a couple the other week and things have moved on. I'm still proud of them though. Are you still in touch with them? I am. I meet up with Benny and Bjorn occasionally. I actually went to see Mamma Mia! in London and it was the strongest theatrical experience I've ever had. It was great to hear that music again because they were frowned upon at the time: Abba were seen as too commercial, but I knew that their music was going to survive.

fields.headline: Work hard - and play plenty of golf
fields.standfirst: No one played Dracula like Christopher Lee, yet the master of horror says his finest performance was as the founder of Pakistan. He tells  Will Hodgkinson  how he rates today's chillers - and reveals the secret of a long life
fields.trailText: No one played Dracula like Christopher Lee, yet the master of horror says his finest performance was as the founder of Pakistan. He tells Will Hodgkinson how he rates today's chillers - and reveals the secret of a long life
fields.body:
Twenty-seven years have passed since Christopher Lee last played Count Dracula, but the Lord of the Undead's cloak still shrouds him. And seeing Lee in person just confirms that he was born to play the part. Now almost 80, he looks uncannily young; he still has his air of slightly sinister, haughty majesty; and his voice remains sonorous. As he puts it himself: "We were both an embarrassing member of a great and noble family."

Defying the protestations of his high-born mother, who considered acting infra dig and a profession only for people with no morals, Lee went on to make his name playing some of the most morally bankrupt characters of all time. Two hundred films on from having a one-word part in Olivier's Hamlet, Lee is still working as hard as ever. He is currently doing post-production work on Peter Jackson's The Lord of the Rings, which is purported to have used pretty much all of New Zealand as a set; and he recently finished filming the latest of the Star Wars prequels.

"Hammer was an important part of my life, and generally speaking, we all had a lot of fun," says Lee of his horror days. Even if he wasn't playing Dracula, he was almost always the villain or the monster, from his myriad reincarnations as Fu Manchu to his return from the dead as The Mummy. "Fun seems to be a three-letter word these days, although with directors like Tim Burton and George Lucas, it's fun, fun, fun while working yourself to death. But if you compare those Hammer movies to what has been made in the last 20 years_ Brian de Palma, Francis Ford Coppola, Martin Scorsese, George Lucas, Wes Craven, Tim Burton and Peter Jackson have all said the same thing to me: 'We were brought up on your movies.' And it certainly shows in theirs."

While many of Lee's old horror films were hard to distinguish from one another - nobody really needs to see Dracula AD 1972 and The Satanic Rites Of Dracula - a few were genuinely daring. Lee himself put pressure on Hammer to make an adaptation of Dennis Wheatley's tale of high-flying diplomats indulging in Satan worship, The Devil Rides Out. "I thought that people should know about the dangers of Satanism, and diabolism does exist - there's no question about it," says Lee, dramatically. "We're trying to get that remade by the new Hammer company. It would be a great first film for them to make. Think of the special effects."

Then there was The Wicker Man. One of the most bizarre films to come out of the UK, it tells the story of pagan worship on a remote Scottish island, with Edward Woodward's puritanical policeman coming over from the mainland to confront Lee's dissolute Lord of Misrule, and getting sacrificed to appease the gods in the process. Its mixture of rustic shopkeeper-philosophy soap opera, sap-rising lewdness and unexpected death makes for a truly shocking movie, and it remains Lee's favourite. "Wonderful film... had a hell of a time getting it made. It's the story of two beliefs - one is organised religion and the other is the old belief that we must revere nature and appease it if necessary. Its power lies in the fact that you never expect what eventually happens, because everyone is so nice. All the negatives and out-takes vanished, and I do not believe it is possible that that was an accident. It is even difficult to see the longer version of the film that exists, in which Britt Ekland initiates a young man while I recite a poem by Walt Whitman over two snails making love."

But Lee has no time for today's horror. "There have been some absolutely ghastly films recently, physically repellent. What we did was fantasy, fairy tales - no real person can copy what we did. But they can do what Hannibal Lecter does, if they're so inclined, people like Jeffrey Dahmer and Dennis Nilsen, and for that reason, I think such films are dangerous."

Theoretically, however, there's nothing to stop a bunch of Scottish islanders laying pagan waste to a virginal copper; but that's nitpicking. Lee has forsaken horror for some much meatier roles in recent years, including a portrayal of the founder of Pakistan in the 1997 film Jinnah. It was filmed in that country despite a campaign by a national newspaper to get Lee deported for daring to portray such an iconic figure. "We subsequently discovered that the man writing the articles had auditioned for the role himself, and this was his way of getting back. Although I'm not the best judge, I think it's the finest work I've ever done because it was the greatest challenge. How do you play an icon who is also a real man? Who only died 50-odd years ago? I did play Ramses II once, who lived to be 91 and had 120 children, but he died 4,000 years ago."

Lee is not at liberty to say much about The Lord of the Rings, a three-film adaptation of the Tolkein trilogy; but since he has read the books every year since they were published (1954-55), playing the character of Saruman is the realisation of a long-held ambition. "The book is such a work of brilliance and majesty - Tolkein wrote an epic on the scale of The Iliad or The Odyssey. He even created a language, Elfish, which you can read, write and speak. Despite having seen absolutely nothing of the film, I still think it's going to create cinema history. Peter Jackson's instincts are extraordinary, as is his stamina. My God, it would have to be, to film solidly for 15 months."

Lee's longest stretch between projects, in a career spanning 55 years, has been four weeks. "The thing I have always tried to do is surprise people, to present them with something they didn't expect. As an actor, I have always tried to be unconventional. Even Scaramanga in The Man With The Golden Gun could be charming - he would be dull if I had just played him as a thug. I'll be 80 next year, if it pleases God. How many actors of my age are playing leading roles in major films?"

How many are still alive? All of Lee's contemporaries - Peter Cushing, John Carradine, Vincent Price - are now gone; and while Bela Lugosi and Boris Karloff ended their days parodying their greatest characters, Lee managed to transcend the roles of one Fu Manchu and Dracula after another a long time ago. And he looks pretty good on it, too. The secret, he maintains, is hard work, plenty of golf, and being safely asleep before the Prince of Darkness can call the hours his own.

 Christopher Lee is in conversation with his biographer Jonathan Rigby at the Barbican Screen (020-7638 8891) on Wednesday, following a screening of Jinnah.

webTitle: Joe Queenan on Keanu Reeves in The Watcher

fields.headline: This time, it's personal
fields.standfirst:
Once just the goofy dimwit, Keanu Reeves finally
looks as if he's playing with a full deck as a
vindictive killer in The Watcher. Joe Queenan
admires a star coming of age
fields.trailText: Once just the goofy dimwit, Keanu Reeves finally looks as if he's playing with a full deck as a vindictive killer in The Watcher. Joe Queenan admires a star coming of age
fields.body:
In recent times, Keanu Reeves has been cast as a brilliant hacker in The Matrix, as a cold-fusion specialist in Chill Factor, and as a resourceful SWAT team specialist who must outwit the mad bomber Dennis Hopper in Speed. Since Reeves started his career by playing morons in Bill & Ted's Excellent Adventure and I Love You To Death, dimwits in Parenthood and Bram Stoker's Dracula, and average guys who didn't seem to have all that much on the ball in River's Edge, Johnny Mnemonic and A Walk In The Clouds, this on-screen intellectual evolution is edifying indeed. It is as if the ageing Gary Cooper, the apotheosis of laconic stolidity, suddenly found himself cast as a dashing nobleman, a preening fop or even a gay caballero.

In The Watcher, Reeves continues his laudable migration away from lunkheaded roles, playing a talented serial killer who moves from California to Chicago to be near James Spader, the FBI agent he delights in tormenting. A few years earlier, while Spader was working his case, the two had developed a textbook cat-and-mouse camaraderie. An obvious victim of unresolved self-esteem issues, it was never enough for Reeves to strangle a large number of women with piano wire; he also needed to be respected for his craft. Through his passion and industry, Spader, a gifted pro in his own right, grudgingly provided that homage.

But one day Reeves pushes the relationship too far by invading Spader's space and incinerating the woman he loves. Devastated by the murder, Spader relocates to the Windy City, seemingly to be closer to the woman's grave.

Initially, the change of scenery does not help. Spader, perfectly cast as a zombie, spends day after day in his tiny apartment injecting or ingesting every pharmaceutical known to man. But things get a whole lot worse when Reeves turns up, announcing his arrival by murdering a young woman who lives in Spader's apartment building. And things really deteriorate when Reeves begins sending Spader photos of his next victim, giving him a scant 12 hours to save her. As hoped, this has the salubrious effect of yanking Spader out of his funk.

It is inevitable in a relationship such as this that one of the parties is finally going to break down and seek psychiatric help. Spader is the first to crack, hooking up with a psychologist played by Marisa Tomei. Tomei, who once won an Academy Award for her supporting role in My Cousin Vinny, has lately become a sort of poor man's Sandra Bullock. Not much of an actress in the best of times, Tomei does bring a much-appreciated perkiness to an exceedingly dark motion picture. Unfortunately, this only lasts until Reeves also decides to seek her services. Although Tomei does advance a number of provocative theories, hypothesising that Reeves and Spader secretly need one another to bring meaning into their otherwise empty lives, she is basically no help at all.

As the movie progresses, it becomes clear that Spader has not learned a whole lot from his previous experiences with Reeves. Since he knows that the killer is a voyeur and a stalker who likes to murder pretty young women, it would have made more sense for him to find an ugly male psychiatrist to help sort out his problems, but no, he has to choose Tomei, thereby signing her death warrant. This is one of the strange ironies of this unwholesome but generally endurable movie; though Spader seems like an intelligent man, he keeps doing incredibly stupid things, while Reeves, who seems about as intelligent as a Santa Monica car valet, continually astounds us with his prodigious homicidal wizardry. At this rate, he might still live to play Galileo.

Eventually, Reeves begins to weary of the game and raises the stakes by abducting Tomei and putting her in a situation from which she cannot possibly extricate herself without having Spader put himself at the killer's mercy. At this point, the screenplay's connect-the-dots Freudian underpinnings come into play, as Spader must outwit the serial killer by addressing his gaping self-esteem problems. Though cathartic, the ending of the film is not terribly ingenious; indeed, the best thing about the last 15 minutes of the film is that Tomei has duct tape across her mouth and is thereby prevented from delineating any more of her inane theories.

The most interesting question about The Watcher is why the three players chose to do it. In Spader's case, he will probably take whatever work he can get. In Tomei's case, she will definitely take whatever work she can get. In Reeves' case, who knows? For years he has been one of Hollywood's least predictable stars, now launching himself into the stratosphere with massive hits like Speed and The Matrix, now appearing in screwy duds like Feeling Minnesota, Cold Fusion and this. His choices have always been strange, and they are not getting any less strange as he gets older.

For my money the best-looking actor in Hollywood, Reeves is slowly but surely approaching the point where he can no longer play vulnerable, charismatic young men who are definitely not playing with a full deck. It is hard to imagine Reeves at age 50 still playing the goofy Valley Boy. But then again, it was hard to imagine Reeves at age 25 playing a French nobleman in Dangerous Liaisons or a callow youth in Much Ado About Nothing. Someone once said that God protects drunks, babies and the United States of America. Surveying Reeves' consistent ability to bounce back from substandard films like The Watcher and return to the big time, one has to believe that the name "Keanu" also appears on God's list of protected species.

fields.headline: Labour to win by 90 - right, that's sorted
fields.trailText: The choking smell is everywhere, informing everything - but nobody wants to talk about it.
fields.body:
 There is a sumptuous passage in Brideshead Revisited about the way Sebastian's alcoholism permeates the castle:

"For the subject was everywhere in the house like a fire deep in the hold of a ship, below the waterline, black and red in the darkness, coming to light in acrid wisps of smoke that curled up ladders, crept between decks, oozed under hatches, hung in wreaths on the flats, billowed suddenly from the scuttles and air pipes."

Thus it is now with the general election. The choking smell is everywhere, informing everything - but nobody wants to talk about it.

It is always fashionable to say that elections are boring. It's a view that I normally don't care for, partly through stern views about the necessity and importance of democracy, partly because I love the fun of the fair. You get the excitement of the best sporting occasions together with the vague illusion that it might actually matter. Also, it forces politicians into a period of humility, which is extremely salutary.

Somehow it's hard to raise the enthusiasm this time. We are facing a contractual obligation election, without any artistic imperative. No one really wants to go on with it. The problem is not just that the conclusion appears to be foregone. There was no serious doubt about the outcome of the two elections in the 1980s either. But voters either loved or hated the Thatcher government, and there was an intensity of feeling that made election time more important, rather than less.

Hardly anyone really hates this timid lot, except those handful of columnists in the Telegraph and Spectator who still cannot believe that they don't matter any more, and are getting more and more hysterical about it with each passing week.

Elsewhere, there is a consensus view on a consensual administration: a grudging respect for their technical competence and a distaste for their arrogance and low-grade mendacity, flaws that are only going to be magnified in the second term, when the habits of power start to become second nature.

And no one at all believes the Tories would be any better, including the Conservative leadership. Indeed, in the event of a Tory victory, there would be serious doubt whether William Hague could find the requisite number of MPs capable of even opening a red box, never mind understanding the contents.

So here's a small set of proposals that would make everyone happy.

1 We abandon the election.

2 The main party leaders sit down and negotiate appropriate figures for the next parliament. A Labour majority of about 90 would suit everyone nicely. Mr Blair doesn't want more Labour MPs, who might, after all, one day discover that God gave them one brain each. And that would be enough of a triumph, on handicap, for Mr Hague to keep him going for a while. There would need to be heavy mid-level negotiations to ensure that Labour did not only sacrifice the rebellious.

3 The Lib Dems could stay as they are, which should suit them. There would be separate deals for Scotland and Wales, in keeping with the spirit of the times.

There, sorted. Where shall we go for Easter?

 Twice in the past fortnight, I have been on the road, needing to ring acquaintances, for their benefit rather than mine, and been forced to call directory inquiries only to be told the number was ex-directory.

You are charged for this information, which is infuriating in itself, and a ploy that even those shameless swine on the railways have not contemplated yet.

Has the 10.39 been cancelled again, then?

Dunno, mate. That'll be 40p.

A quarter of UK phones are ex-directory, far more than in other countries. That figure includes fax and data lines which you might expect not to be listed. And you are not charged for the privacy option as in some countries: only the poor sap calling directories has to pay.

The major reason for the ex-directory fetish lies in our national psyche. I can understand that the manager of the England football team or the head of the anti-terrorist branch might not want to be in the phone book but, in most cases, it's just ridiculous. If anyone nasty really wants you, they'll find you. And anonymity won't protect you against junk calls.

However, Britons assume that an unexpected call must be an unwelcome one. It's the same collective negativism that makes us look round a crowded room or railway carriage and see hostile faces instead of friends we haven't met yet.

 There are those who believe that cultural imperialism is an unmitigated ill. But if McDonald's did not give away the same junk toy with the same junk Happy Meal in the same junk plastic bag at the same time right across Europe, I still wouldn't know that "Opozorilo: Zaradi nevernosti zadustive, vrecko odstraniti izven dosega ostrok in dojenckov" is the Slovene for "Warning: to avoid danger of suffocation, keep this bag away from babies and children."

 There was a piece in G2 on Wednesday, commenting on the puzzling way in which a mild vulgarism like "pissing down" was used in a BBC 2 programme on Cornish gardens, but was unacceptable in EastEnders. There are more extreme oddities along these lines.

Readers who were at college in the 1980s will recall Sunday Sport, the paper which became briefly trendy for stories such as a London bus getting lost and ending in the Antarctic rather than Thornton Heath (an understandable error), and a giant sprout eating a man in Tamworth. It still persists, on a daily basis now, though without the gloriously wild sense of invention. The Daily Sport ekes out a living purely as a 37p-a-day masturbatory aid.

However, the Lana Cox agony aunt column has been drawn to my attention. Last Friday it included a letter purporting to come from a man having sex with three different women, all of whom insisted on also giving him dinner every night. There were graphic and salivating descriptions of the food ("smoked salmon starter, lemon chicken, and summer fruit compote with brandy-laced whipped cream ") as well as the sex ("She really got my old fella rising to attention as she led me into the bedroom ").

We may safely assume this was written by a subeditor since, if JM of Kent really were doing what is claimed, he would have neither the necessity nor the energy to share the experience with Daily Sport readers. Anyway, several hundred explicit words got into print until the writer felt obliged to use a word familiar to everyone who has had, or contemplated, sexual intercourse themselves or hit their thumb with a hammer or been in a primary school playground.

At which point the paper lost his nerve. It has to go in as f***. So that's all right then.

You would have thought with his name he would be more attuned to the public mood. But this is not without historical precedents. During the great German invasion scares of the mid-Edwardian period, it was often alleged that the Tory prime minister, Arthur Balfour, would be just as lackadaisical in a crisis. And a popular verse went something like this:

I was playing golf, you know,
the day the Germans landed.
All our ships were blown
away, all our sailors
stranded.
It filled me with such shock
and shame,
It nearly put me off my game.

Thus it is now with the general election. The choking smell is everywhere, informing everything - but nobody wants to talk about it. It is always fashionable to say that elections are boring. It's a view that I normally don't care for, partly through stern views about the necessity and importance of democracy, partly because I love the fun of the fair. You get the excitement of the best sporting occasions together with the vague illusion that it might actually matter. Also, it forces politicians into a period of humility, which is extremely salutary. Somehow it's hard to raise the enthusiasm this time. We are facing a contractual obligation election, without any artistic imperative. No one really wants to go on with it. The problem is not just that the conclusion appears to be foregone. webTitle: Pig experts warn of nightmare scenario

fields.headline: Pig experts warn of nightmare scenario
fields.standfirst:
Trucks touring country for sows add to risk

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Trucks touring country for sows add to risk
fields.body:
The foot and mouth disease outbreak could not have happened in a worse place, according to pig industry experts. The abattoir at Cheale Meats outside Brentwood, Essex, is a specialist operator dealing in cull sows - pigs at the end of their breeding life.

Ian Campbell, regional manager for the National Pig Association, said there is no UK market for cull pigs but they are sought after in Europe for salami and the German sausage trade because lumpy pork meat suits continental tastes.

"Without the German taste for sausages and continental-style salami there would be nowhere to send these pigs. A farmer with a large breeding stock might have 30 or so a year to send but not all at once - they would go singly or a few at a time."

Lorries that tour farms picking up cull sows can potentially spread foot and mouth to many premises on one round. Normally lorries would be disinfected before each pick-up and after each unloading at the abattoir.

It was this nightmare scenario of multiple pick-ups potentially spreading the disease which Ministry of Agriculture vets found when the outbreak at Cheale Meats was confirmed. Up to 400 farms deliver to Cheale Meats.

One of the premises MAFF visited early in the investigation was Burnside Farm at Heddon-on-the-Wall, Northumberland. This was a collecting centre for cull pigs from the North of England and Scotland.

A statement from MAFF yesterday, which confirmed foot and mouth at Burnside Farm, also said the pigs there had been ill for some time, probably showing symptoms for two weeks with an incubation period before that.

The result of the outbreak is a collapse of the continental cull pig trade and with it a useful income for farmers, and a disposal route for old pigs.

Apart from Cheale Meats, where the original outbreak was discovered, there are two other abattoirs that take cull sows as part of the continental sausage trade - Dawkins International at Congerstone, in Warwickshire and EE Pilgrim, of Banham, near Norwich, which is also owned by Cheale Meats.

Because cull sows are not prime meat they fetch less than "clean pigs" bred for the table. According to Peter Kingwell, marketing director of Chippenham livestock market, cull sows were fetching 40p to 50p a live kilo a week ago, compared with 85p a kilo for ordinary pigs. At Northampton livestock market on Thursday only five cull sows were sold, compared with 186 the week before. Peter Reynolds of the meat and livestock commission said prices had dropped to 32p a kilo for cull sows and only 28 were sold in the whole country on Thursday. Clean pig prices were holding steady and 2,162 were sold.

Yesterday Nick Brown, the minister of agriculture, said that as a result of foot and mouth and the recent swine fever outbreak he was asking officials to look at whether modern industrial farming methods made Britain more susceptible to the spread of disease. The trend for larger slaughterhouses and specialist markets such as the cull sows sent to the continent were two areas to be examined.

Some farmers were already calling yesterday for a ban on meat imports because that is widely believed to be the most likely cause of the outbreak.

Infected meat, even deep frozen, will carry the virus and it can even survive in cooked meats if not thoroughly heated through.

webTitle: All smiles as Blair and Bush meet

fields.headline: All smiles as Blair and Bush meet
fields.standfirst: Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: Tony Blair got what he came for at his Camp David summit yesterday when President George Bush gave him a ringing personal endorsement as a charmer and backed Britain's moves to establish a European defence force within Nato.
fields.body:
Tony Blair got what he came for at his Camp David summit yesterday when President George Bush gave him a ringing personal endorsement as a charmer and backed Britain's moves to establish a European defence force within Nato.

Four hours after the two leaders met for the first time, a relaxed Mr Bush and Mr Blair faced the world's press to announce that the special relationship between the US and Britain was alive and kicking in the post-Clinton era. "And we're going to keep it that way," Mr Bush said.

Mr Bush exceeded all British expectations in a performance full of charm, warmth political support for the British prime minister. Mr Bush said Britain was "our strongest friend and closest ally" and dubbed Mr Blair "a pretty charming guy".

"He put the charm offensive on me - and it worked," Mr Bush said. Later he added that he knew now when he telephoned Mr Blair in the future "there'll be a friend on the other end of the phone".

Mr Blair, in a blue sweater, slacks and open-neck shirt, stood alongside Mr Bush, in a presidential bomber jacket, in front of a roaring log fire.

Mr Bush said the UK-US relationship was "an alliance that has made a huge difference in the world", and added: "Ours will be a strong and good personal relationship and an alliance that will stand the test of time."

The most important prize for Mr Blair - the first European leader to visit the Bush administration - in yesterday's meeting came with Mr Bush's endorsement of European defence, an issue which has divided members of the new Republican administration in the US and become a chosen weapon of the Conservative opposition in Britain.

Mr Bush yesterday came down firmly on Mr Blair's side, saying in a statement: "The United States welcomes the European Union's European security and defence policy," a form of words which British diplomats afterwards welcomed as "a 10 out of 10".

There was no breakthrough, however, on the controversial US National Missile Defence project which has caused deep divisions between Washington and Europe as well as with Russia and China.

"We had a long discussion about missile defence," Mr Bush said. "We've got to deal with these things in a realistic way." He said that Mr Blair "asked a lot of really good questions" and pledged that he would look at missile defence in tandem with cuts in long-range offensive missiles.

Asked about the possible building of a ground radar site for the NMD system in North Yorkshire, Mr Bush said: "As to whether there will be sites, it's too early to say."

Mr Blair had arrived at Camp David in time for lunch, attended by the US secretary of state, Colin Powell, who left shortly afterwards for his first Middle East fact-finding visit.

After lunch, Mr Blair and Mr Bush went for a walk in the woods and last night they were joined for dinner by their wives, Cherie and Laura.

If Downing Street had worried that the Republican Mr Bush would be a less warm host to a Labour prime minister, his relaxed demeanour must have swept them away with surprise and delight.

Indeed Mr Blair, who is normally one of the most relaxed politicians under the glare of the television lights, seemed at times to be eclipsed by his host's visible confidence.

When a reporter asked whether the two men had forged a personal bond, Mr Bush announced: "Well, we both use Colgate toothpaste." Mr Blair quipped back: "They are going to wonder how you know that George."

webTitle: Slaughter not vaccination remains preferred option

fields.headline: Slaughter not vaccination remains preferred option
fields.standfirst:
Government has never used its stock of shots

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Government has never used its stock of shots
fields.body:
In all other major outbreaks of the disease in Britain, there has been widespread public opposition to the government's wholesale slaughter of pigs and cattle that have come into even remote contact with foot and mouth disease.

It has been widely argued that foot and mouth has few human health implications and mostly only causes sporadic deaths among young or sick animals, with the vast majority affected suffering only lameness and loss of appetite before recovering within three weeks.

Abigail Woods, a Wellcome Foundation-funded vet studying the history of foot and mouth in Britain at Manchester University, said yesterday that the government's justification for slaughter was based on the fact that those animals which recover from the disease show a decline in meat and milk productivity.

"Given the extreme contagiousness of the disease, officials say that if permitted to spread freely, the economic losses inflicted by FMD would outweigh the costs of disease elimination," says Ms Woods

But there was little opposition to the slaughter policy from leading animal welfare groups yesterday. "The conditions in which most pigs are kept are abysmal. I'd almost say that death is a blessed relief," said Juliet Gellately, director of Viva!

The slaughter policy was first introduced in the 1910s to deal with initial outbreaks rather than epidemics. Since then, the Ministry of Agriculture has refused to contemplate vaccination of animals, even though vaccines are widely used in countries which do not export much meat.

Because more than 400,000 animals had to be slaughtered in 1967, the British authorities were on the brink of resorting to vaccine but drew back when the disease began to recede.

Although the government keeps millions of shots of vaccine, it has never been used in the EU and is against policy in all 15 member countries. Part of the reason is because to resort to vaccine is seen as an admission that the disease can never be eradicated, according to the government's chief vet, Jim Scudamore.

Vaccination, says Maff, can limit the chances of a much wider spread of the disease if wiping out infected herds does not work.

But there is also an economic argument against vaccination because some countries will not take food products from vaccinated herds.

With Europe almost foot and mouth free for 20 years, the policy of slaughter has been vindicated, according to the Ministry of Agriculture. However, with the virulent type O foot and mouth virus currently at large in the UK having caused outbreaks across much of the developing world, the policy may have to be reviewed, Mr Scudamore said.

webTitle: Lover found guilty of infecting girlfriend with HIV

fields.headline: Lover found guilty of infecting girlfriend with HIV
fields.standfirst: Former heroin user deliberately transmitted virus, court rules
fields.trailText: A man who infected his girlfriend with the HIV virus despite knowing it would put her life in danger made legal history yesterday when he was convicted of reckless behaviour.
fields.body:
A man who infected his girlfriend with the HIV virus despite knowing it would put her life in danger made legal history yesterday when he was convicted of reckless behaviour.

Stephen Kelly, 33, was found guilty at the high court in Glasgow of recklessly endangering Anne Craig, a mother of three, by repeatedly having sex with her between January and March 1994 when he knew he carried the virus. He will be sentenced next month.

It was thought to be the first prosecution in a British court of someone deliberately transmitting the HIV virus to another person. HIV support groups have voiced concern at the verdict, saying criminalisation of the disease will only increase the stigma borne by sufferers.

Kelly, who had denied the charge of culpable and reckless conduct, was prosecuted under common law in Scotland. In England and Wales, the Home Office said prosecution could be pursued under the 1861 Offences Against the Person Act.

During the nine-day trial, the court heard how Kelly, of Provanmill in Glasgow, tested positive for the HIV virus during at outbreak at Glenochil prison in Stirlingshire in 1993, where he was a prisoner. A heroin user, he had become infected through shared needles and was advised to practice safe sex and tell sexual partners of his status.

Ms Craig, 34, told the court that she did not know Kelly was HIV positive when they started a sexual relationship and had asked him if there was any reason other than pregnancy that they should not have unprotected sex. The pair first had sex just hours after meeting at a party in Glasgow in January 1994 and began a whirlwind relationship days afterwards. Ms Craig, from Manchester, had been visiting Scotland for the weekend.

In the following months, Ms Craig began feeling unwell and took a blood test on March 28 1994 that confirmed she had contracted the virus. It was then that Kelly revealed the truth about his condition. At first he told her he believed he may have caught the virus from a previous girlfriend, but later confessed he had contracted it from sharing needles in prison.

Ms Craig said she had been devastated when she discovered that she had contracted the virus, and had since been spurned by family and friends. "People think that if a flea from my dog bites me then bites them, they can catch it," she told the jury.

Donald Findlay, QC, defence counsel for Kelly, had suggested to Ms Craig that she knew Kelly was infected when she started a relationship with him and only decided to blame him after she became infected herself and her life took a downward turn. Ms Craig denied that.

The court had heard that Kelly told police officers at first that he believed HIV was only transmittable by blood, but later in the interview he admitted he was aware it could be sexually transmitted and said he knew of the risks and consequences of HIV and Aids.

After the verdict, Ms Craig's lawyer Cameron Fyfe said she would be pursuing a claim for criminal injuries compensation to help support her children, now aged 16, 14 and nine.

Ms Craig was not in court to hear the verdict, but later said in a statement: "I am delighted that justice has been done and hope this will be a deterrent to others. If the verdict saves one life from the misery I have been through then it will all have been worthwhile.

Beyond repair

"Over the last few years I have fought to get my life back together but it can never be the same. Similarly, the lives of my children, other family and close friends have been damaged and some of my relationships with them are beyond repair. I have not had a personal relationship since the one with Mr Kelly and it is unlikely I will ever have one.

"However, I am proud I have found the strength and courage to support the prosecution of Mr Kelly."

After the trial, HIV support groups expressed their concern at the criminalisation of HIV sufferers.

A spokeswoman for the Home Office said yesterday that it had been concluded, however, that there were enough powers under the existing Offences Against the Person Act to prosecute in such a case.

The issue had been raised in 1997 following a recommendation from the law commission. The commission urged reforms on the basis that "intentional or reckless" transmission of disease or illness should be regarded as a crime. Five years earlier, in 1992, the authorities had found themselves powerless to act following an Aids scare in Birmingham in 1992.

A haemophiliac, Roy Cornes, 24, who had contracted the virus from a contaminated blood transfusion, was accused of deliberately infecting four lovers. He died two years later.

Four years ago a fisherman, Paul Georgiou, was jailed for 15 months after a court in Cyprus judged that he was aware he was carrying the HIV virus when he had sex with a British woman, Janette Pink.
