webTitle: Lack of control opens door for suspect meat

fields.headline: Lack of control opens door for suspect meat
fields.standfirst:
Worldwide trade thrives on lax inspection

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Worldwide trade thrives on lax inspection
fields.body:
As Maff officials continue their ever-widening detective hunt into the source of the foot and mouth outbreaks, it emerged yesterday that pork and other meat from countries experiencing foot and mouth outbreaks is regularly being imported into Britain without controls or inspections and could have easily passed into the pig food supply chain.

Last year Britain imported more than 300,000 tons of beef and pork, mostly from countries in the EU and others like New Zealand which are foot and mouth free. But, say Customs and Excise, hundreds of tons of pork and beef is also regularly imported from countries such as Uruguay, Brazil, Zimbabwe, South Africa, Swaziland and Botswana where outbreaks of the disease have occurred in the past year.

Understaffed veterinary services and lack of notification to the authorities in some countries may mean that contaminated animals have not been spotted before being exported. Other meat has been imported from such far eastern countries as Thailand and Japan where there have been serious outbreaks of the same type O disease that has struck Britain, and where the disease is thought to have originated.

One theory gaining ground is that meat from any one of the 30 or more countries who experienced foot and mouth last year could have been imported legally into Britain without having been inspected for foot and mouth. There is no inspection system in Britain for the disease. The Food Standards Agency, set up by Tony Blair to protect consumers, can only rely on the honesty of meat packers and distributors not to trade in illegal or contaminated meat.

Once in Britain, contaminated meat would have passed into the wholesale market and catering trade, whose waste, including pork and beef, is often used in pigswill - usually a mash of waste meat, cereals and vegetable matter. Most pigswill is prepared by Maff-approved animal food suppliers who heat it to 100C and boil it for one hour, but, say industry watchers, it is possible that corners are cut and that the heat treatment does not always destroy contamination.

Many pig farmers are small-scale operations which have been heavily hit in the past three years by the collapse of prices. There are others who have just one or two pigs who make the swill themselves.

The meat industry is notoriously difficult to control. "Meat is coming in from all over the world without any inspection and certainly none for foot and mouth," said the director of a major meat importer in the midlands who asked not to be named yesterday.

"It's open house now. It's coming in from Namibia, Botswana, the far east, anywhere you like _ You can do what you like in the meat industry these days. The authorities don't have a clue.

"The rest of the world is dumping stuff on us. There are effectively no controls at all."

That contaminated food can reach Britain easily was yesterday confirmed by Hull trading standards officer Brian Larard who inspects shipments coming into the port. "We cannot inspect food coming in from Europe because that would be a restriction of trade. But food can come into Europe from outside, and then pass freely into Britain", he said.

"This is an accident that's been waiting to happen", said Harriet Kimbell, a director of the Consumers' Association and a member of the governmental advisory committee against BSE and vCJD. "Anything could be coming in."

fields.headline: Sorry I haven't a loo
fields.trailText: Having employed the term "bog standard" last week I am now assailed with requests to explain what it means.
fields.body:
Having employed the term "bog standard" last week I am now assailed with requests to explain what it means. I shall answer this in one brusque and immaculate sentence: I haven't the slightest idea. Since Alastair Campbell offended David Blunkett and others by applying it to comprehensive schools, the popular verdict seems to be that it derives from bog, meaning lavatory. But this is disputed. An erudite letter to this newspaper suggested it was a short form for British or German (BoG) standards of engineering. Others think it has more to do with a bog or quagmire, as particularly common in Ireland, and therefore amounts to a characteristic English v Irish sneer. People who live in and near bogs are often routinely disparaged. "The bog-bred youth" some bigot averred in 1850 "tells you lies", while others claimed that bog-hay was only one-third the quality of hay made from sown grass.

Sir Walter Scott, who in Smallweed's opinion was someone who knew a thing or two, wrote in The Abbot: "The kelpie must flit from the black-bog pit"; suggesting that bog standard is a level of achievement which even a kelpie would flee from. Bog can also mean bugbear; in the counties of Derby and Lincoln it used also to be an adjective, meaning blustering, proud or saucy.

An old journalist writes: Smallweed is way off the map. Bog standard refers to a newspaper called the Standard which was published in Bog - which my gazetteer says is a locality in the county of Cumberland in the former rural district of Wigton - until its editor ran off with a milkman, this giving its title the broadly pejorative connotations it carries today.

"Let us not mince words", some pompous commentator writes in a pompous newspaper. Yet mincing words is exactly what needs to be done when expressions like "let us not mince words" are used in a public place. They are nothing more than a kind of nervy throat-clearing, a condition they share with "let us not pull our punches" and "let us not beat about the bush". Such sentiments might have rather more relevance if one ever read pleas for the opposite. How I long to read a piece which begins: "Let us mince words", or even, "What is a bush, unless it is something that needs to be beaten about?" The same applies to the common disease of prefacing sentences with the formula: "This is not the time"... "This is not the time", some expert will write, "to blue all our hard-won revenues on worthless spending projects", as if that might be justified at some other juncture. Moreover, I have to say...

Perplexed (Irthlingborough) writes: You have yet to explain what kind of kelpie Sir Walter expected to flee from the bog-pit. Was it the water spirit in the form of a horse which in Scottish folklore delights in drowning its riders? Or was it a breed of Australian sheepdog, derived from the Scottish collie? Both may, prima facie and ipso facto, have loomed large in the life of the author of Ivanhoe.

Smallweed responds with a mildly smarmy courtesy: Let us not beat about the bush. I haven't the slightest idea.As for your Irthlingborough, I hope to include it in my list of places to visit this summer, once I have finished with Driffield.

Places to visit this summer - Driffield. In fact there are two Driffields in Yorkshire, just as there are two Hartlepools to its north. The one which most concerns us is Great Driffield, which calls itself the capital of the wolds. You will find it on the road from York to Bridlington. It is also handy for such tourist hotspots as Scarborough, Whitby and Hull. Not far away is the great city of Leeds; just a little further are Durham and Sheffield. Beyond them are New York, Santiago and Buenos Aires. There's what looks like a handsome mill at River Head (I rely on the internet website here) while the sparkling Driffield Beck, picturesquely named the Water Forlorns, threads first through the park and then through the town centre to join the Driffield canal. Watch out for kelpies. Little Driffield has a pond and a green. This area is also, I'm told, a great place for borage. I only hope that Irthlingborough, of which I so far know little, proves to be even half as enticing.

Like most breeds easily trodden under foot, we Weeds tend to stick together. So I noted with interest an item the other day about Thurlow Weed, a 19th century US politician who was close to Abraham Lincoln and closer to Lincoln's chief associate, William Henry Seward. This Weed, the subject, I see, of a life by Harriet Weed, began life as a journalist, running a paper called the Anti-Masonic Enquirer and founding a party called the Anti-Masonic party. I think we can take it that he didn't much care for freemasons. Later he joined the Whig party and as that expired, the Republicans. After the assassination of Lincoln, he transferred his support to Andrew Johnson, and thus suffered from the backwash of Johnson's impeachment, which failed by a single vote. Johnson's troubles were mainly due to his sympathetic treatment, as others saw it, of the defeated south in the wake of the civil war, but he also paid the price for a lavish distribution of pardons, which allowed undesirable Confederate leaders back into politics. He came from New York, by the way, whereas Clinton merely moved there. There also seems to be a woman senator now in Rhode Island called Senator Paiva-Weed, but she may, in weed terms, be a hybrid.

One takes it for granted nowadays that every bus one travels on, even that mobile intellectual Mecca the route 94 from Piccadilly to Acton Green, will be full of people clutching mobile phones to their faces and pouring out sentences each of which will begin: "I was, like..." But now, aghast commuters report, there's an epidemic of on-board shaving: with electric razors, I presume, though I would not put it past the odd bold and saucy eccentric to bring a bowl of water, a shaving stick and a cut-throat. What next? Here is Smallweed's prediction. Within a week or two of the arrival of summer, reports will begin to flood in of people in sandals ostentatiously cutting their toenails and leaving the slivers of old used nail on the floor, while chattering away on their mobiles about what they are, like, going to be doing tonight.

Smallweed@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Rail figures reveal passenger misery
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The depth of the misery endured by rail passengers in the months since the Hatfield crash was highlighted by performance figures published by the strategic rail authority yesterday.
fields.body:
The depth of the misery endured by rail passengers in the months since the Hatfield crash was highlighted by performance figures published by the strategic rail authority yesterday.

The SRA figures show that in the four weeks immediately after the crash in October last year, in which four people died, Virgin West Coast trains managed to run only one in five of its trains on time, GNER and Virgin CrossCountry managed only one in four, and Midland Mainline about one in two.

By January, GNER was back to running 77% of its trains on time but Virgin West Coast met the timetable with only 27% of its services between December 10 and January 6.

The SRA said that improvements since then were "in most cases very creditable", but the rail users watchdog, the Rail Passengers Council, attacked the train operating companies for hiding behind the Hatfield disaster and said that there would have to be a "radical rethink" about the ownership of rail if anything was to improve.

Even when speed restrictions, flood damage and rebuilding work is taken into account, performance on large parts of the network is very poor, it said. "There are still problems with West Coast, and there are still problems in and out of Liverpool Street [London]. We don't really know why," said RPC director Anthony Smith.

The watchdog's chairman, Stewart Francis, said that the substantial variations between train companies' performance demanded an explanation.

"I am prepared to accept that different train operating companies were under different pressures, but some did better than others in getting out of the crisis. And why was performance going down so much before Hatfield? Prior to Hatfield virtually all the train operating companies were going backwards."

The SRA is due to publish its agenda for rail shortly. Its chairman Sir Alistair Morton said at a rail seminar this week that there should be no revolutionary change in rail. "We must make this structure work. It must be evolution. The question is how radical should evolution be?"

But insiders say that he is moving towards more radical thinking, in particular the creation of new partnerships to build railways which could then be handed over to Railtrack once they were complete.

The Rail Passengers Council wants to see Railtrack brought back into a public trust, and while it accepts that renationalisation is not a possibility, it argues that there should be fewer franchises for the privatised train operating companies.

webTitle: Partner can claim through injuries scheme

fields.headline: Partner can claim through injuries scheme
fields.standfirst: Special report: Aids
fields.trailText: A woman in Anne Craig's position, whose lover has had sex with her knowing he was infected with HIV, can sue him for damages in the civil courts.
fields.body:
A woman in Anne Craig's position, whose lover has had sex with her knowing he was infected with HIV, can sue him for damages in the civil courts.

But Stephen Kelly, the heroin addict and ex-convict who infected her, is unlikely to have the money to satisfy a damages claim. So she plans to file a claim instead with the criminal injuries compensation scheme.

The idea of suing over a sexually transmitted disease is not new. The first known case dates back to 1878, when a Miss Shine sued her "paramour", a Mr Hegarty, in the Irish courts, for assault when she caught VD from him.

An act to which the victim consents cannot normally be an assault and Miss Shine admitted she had not rebuffed Mr Hegarty's advances. But she argued her consent was not a real one because he had committed fraud by concealing the material fact that he had VD.

The case is believed to have been settled out of court.

fields.headline: Moments of solitary madness
fields.standfirst: It's a mystery worthy of Hitchcock: why did Clinton destroy himself?
fields.trailText: It's a mystery worthy of Hitchcock: why did Clinton destroy himself?
fields.body:
Imagine a man whose enemies are trying to kill him. Over a period of eight years, they come up with ever more ingenious and vicious forms of homicide. But somehow he survives them all: twitching his neck out of the noose at the last minute, deflecting the bullet, realising that the drink smells strange before he sips it. Finally, his enemies are all vanquished. The man smiles and takes the applause of his supporters. He then walks into his room and shoots himself in the head.

Hitchcock couldn't script that scene; Freud could not explain it. Bill Clinton, though, has just lived it out. His final hours in the White House will be studied for decades by psychologists and political commentators. During two terms, his Republican opponents had brought against him Whitewater, Filegate, Paula Jones, the Lewinsky affair. He had improbably come through these attacks with his popularity intact.

A deal with the special prosecutor meant that, at little cost to him, he would no longer face the threat of jail as a private citizen. And then, in a moment of political felo de se, he decided to pardon controversial figures, including the fugitive banker Marc Rich. Some of the importunate felons, we now discover, were lucratively represented by the president's brother-in-law, Hugh Rodham. By a legal irony which even John Grisham has never employed, these dealings are so murky that they may yet create new charges which would invalidate the immunity from prosecution which Rich and Clinton now hold. Having notoriously proposed that oral sex isn't sex, Clinton may now have engineered the legal paradox of a pardon which is criminal. A man who had brilliantly preserved his reputation against attacks from others has for some reason destroyed it himself.

What was he thinking of? Republicans and sceptics will claim these events as proof that Clinton is irredeemably sleazy. The more complicated truth is that his political career consisted of long periods of brilliance undermined by moments of stupidity. And, crucially, these idiotic misjudgments always came at the moments of greatest safety.

The English football authorities recently created the new offence of "over- celebrating" because of the ever more weird scenes when someone scored. Clinton's problem was that he over- celebrated his goals. There's a famous clip of him smoking a cigar and playing drums after news of an apparent victory in the Paula Jones case. But this complacency allowed the Jones case to breed the Lewinsky case. And there's some evidence in the timing of the Lewinsky encounters that the blow-jobs from Monica were the president's little present to himself for having seen off the Republican revolution of Newt Gingrich.

And so, alone in the Oval Office after becoming the first two-term Democratic president in modern history - with Gore's failure having maintained his hold on the party and raised the possibility of a Hillary bid - Clinton over-celebrated again, figuring that, with the special prosecutor off his back, it could do no harm to help a few supporters and, perhaps, his brother-in-law.

This self-pitying triumphalism - the sense that America owed him one for all he'd done - was soon apparent again in his attempt to sting the US taxpayer for lavish post-presidential offices in Manhattan. Clinton has rightly been praised for his political skills, but we now see that there was a kink in his antennae. He could sense danger only when he expected it to be there. Able to swim successfully through a pool of sharks, he never understood that he might be stung to death on the beach.

Apart from Clinton's biographies, the main victim in this is Hugh Rodham's sister. Not knowing what her husband was doing with other women was never going to be an electoral handicap for Hillary. It's in the nature of such events for a wife to be uninformed. Complete ignorance of your brother's dealings with your husband - the defence Mrs Clinton has offered - seems more careless, especially from a woman who belongs to a generation which prides itself on awareness. The senator from New York is getting a reputation as a woman who doesn't notice what's going on around her. Vote Hillary - Her Eyes Are Shut is not much of a poster slogan for a senate re-election race in six years' time; it's a no-hoper for the presidential campaign she craved.

In early January, as President Clinton began his final month in office, with unprecedented approval ratings for a lame-duck, I thought about asking William Hill for odds on the Clintons outdoing the Bushes and producing three presidents from the same family: Hillary in 2004 or 2008; Chelsea, as the child of two political icons, in about 2028. Now they seem destined to be a one commander-in- chief family like most of the others. And the clan's single president, who seemed triumphantly to have escaped disgrace and lawyers, has placed himself back in their court.

The effect of killing yourself is to leave questions which torment for ever those who knew and loved you. This suicide will, I suppose, at least leave us a note in the form of his memoirs, but these can be expected to be characteristically evasive. And so we sit and wonder what drove him to put the gun to his head on what should have been the happiest day of his life. The only explanation is that the balance of his mind was disturbed by ego and self-pity.

webTitle: The farmer at the centre of the crisis now gripping agriculture

fields.headline: The farmer at the centre of the crisis now gripping agriculture
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Any movement of farm animals anywhere in the United Kingdom was made a criminal offence last night as Britain's farmers, abattoirs and rural communities cooperated in the attempt to isolate and eradicate the fast-spreading outbreak of foot and mouth disease.
fields.body:
Any movement of farm animals anywhere in the United Kingdom was made a criminal offence last night as Britain's farmers, abattoirs and rural communities cooperated in the attempt to isolate and eradicate the fast-spreading outbreak of foot and mouth disease.

Yesterday the number of confirmed outbreaks of foot and mouth rose to six, the most important at the farm of Ronald Waugh, at Burnside Farm, Heddon-on-the-Wall in Northumberland.

Nick Brown, the minister of agriculture, after consulting Tony Blair, ordered the blanket ban for seven days "to isolate and extinguish these outbreaks and get back to normal trading as quickly as possible".

The unprecedented ban was with the cooperation of farmers' leaders, owners of 700 abattoirs, hauliers and supermarkets, who had earlier been consulted. It may mean shortages of some meats but poultry is not affected and supplies were expected to last the week unless there was panic buying, according to Mr Brown.

The ban would be reviewed in the light of the progress of the disease, he said. "It is better to bear costs and inconvenience now than risk this outbreak getting out of control."

The government's chief vet, Jim Scudamore, said it was most likely the outbreak had started t Mr Waugh's farm.

"This is a notifiable disease yet this farm did not notify anyone," he said. "From the experts that have looked at the ill animals it is quite clear they have been showing clinical signs for two weeks, the blisters have already broken and healed. With incubation this disease could have been present for 28 days, much longer and a far worse situation than we thought at the beginning of the week."

He said the fact that the outbreak had gone on so long unreported was of serious concern. Infected pigs pumped out the virus as they breathed, creating "a plume of infection blown in the wind which falls on other farms".

Vets are investigating why Mr Waugh, 55, failed to report the outbreak, which is technically a criminal offence. Last night Mr Waugh said: "I honestly had not seen anything wrong with any of my pigs in the last few weeks. How could I report something I didn't see?"

Last night it was revealed that environment inspectors had been called to Mr Waugh's farm five times in the past six months, because of the squalid state of the site, the last time in December.

The latest case to be confirmed was four miles away from Mr Waugh's farm, at Prestwick Hill Farm at Ponteland, next to Newcastle airport. Half the 90 cattle apparently caught the disease from airborne infection. All the farm's cattle and 234 sheep will have to be destroyed, the first time in the current outbreak that sheep have been affected.

In Essex, where the outbreak was first noticed, at Cheale Meats at Little Warley near Brentwood, the disease is still spreading. As well as the two outbreaks in close proximity to the abattoir, a third, 20 miles away at Canewdon, was also confirmed. This had links to the abattoir.

In Essex where the outbreak was first identified, at Cheale Meats at Little Warley near Brentwood, the disease is still spreading. As well as the two outbreaks in close proximity to the abattoir, a third, 20 miles away at Canewdon, was also confirmed. This had links to the abattoir.

Dozens of other farms are being investigated and hundreds of animals are being destroyed. Many will be buried on the farms but where that is not practical, because ground water used for drinking may be contaminated, they will be burnt. Some will be removed to incinerators but there is not enough capacity for all of them.

The police were asked yesterday to enforce the ban on the movement of all farm and zoo animals. Any infringement would be a criminal offence punishable by a £5,000 fine. If more than 10 animals were involved the fine could be £1,000 for each extra animal.

Mr Brown said all hunting had been banned including the Waterloo Cup, the top hare coursing event due to take place in Southport next week. He appealed to people not go on farmland unless it was essential and asked for all "large events or gatherings" on farmland to be abandoned.

Ben Gill, president of the National Farmers Union, said: "We have no choice but to batten down the hatches. Movement restrictions on every farm are the only way we can ensure that foot and mouth does not spread any further than it has done already."

Emergency Measures

 All livestock movements in Britain have been halted for seven days, from 5pm yesterday

 Health chiefs have identified a farm at Heddon-on-the-Wall, Northumberland, as the likely source and fear the outbreak may have started 28 days ago

 A sixth case was confirmed in Ponteland, Northumberland, and about 600 farms from Aberdeenshire to the Isle of Wight are being investigated

 Supermarkets are begging shoppers not to panic buy, warning that increased demand could lead to shortages

 The National Trust has closed all landscape parks containing livestock to members of the public

 Monday's horseracing at Newcastle is cancelled

 Wildlife Trusts have appealed to the public to stay away from its 2,300 nature reserves

 The RSPB has announced a seven-day closure of all its nature reserves

 More than half the country's 63 city farms have been closed

 Non-essential military training has been suspended

webTitle: Europe to stop bankrolling Arafat unless US takes role

fields.headline: Europe to stop bankrolling Arafat unless US takes role
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the European commission
>Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The European Union, the single largest financial backer of Yasser Arafat's beleaguered Palestinian Authority (PA), will signal on Monday that it is no longer willing to bail out the organisation unless the United States and Arab nations also contribute.
fields.byline: Andrew Osborn in Brussels and Suzanne Goldenberg in Jerusalem
fields.body:
The European Union, the single largest financial backer of Yasser Arafat's beleaguered Palestinian Authority (PA), will signal on Monday that it is no longer willing to bail out the organisation unless the United States and Arab nations also contribute.

Chris Patten, the former Conservative minister who is the EU's external affairs commissioner, has drawn up a paper for foreign affairs ministers warning that the EU's role as the main provider of emergency loans and funding to Mr Arafat is nearing its end.

"We have done what we can to keep the PA afloat but we cannot go on bankrolling the PA. We need a plan where the PA becomes more solvent," said one EU diplomat yesterday.

Israel's continued closure of border crossings from the West Bank and the Gaza strip means that the authority is running a monthly deficit of some £30m.

EU foreign affairs ministers will be asked to organise a donors' conference by mid-March in a last bid to get non-European nations to increase their financial assistance.

"In the current crisis it [the EU] has been one of the main sources of financial support to the PA, helping it to survive from month to month," the paper says, but "it cannot and should not continue to shoulder this burden alone."

EU foreign ministers, including Britain's Robin Cook, are likely to approve of the new approach when they meet in Brussels. Mr Patten will also push for EU governments to start putting pressure on Israel to lift its border blockades.

The former Hong Kong governor wants the EU to encourage the Israelis to resume collecting customs and tax revenues on the Palestinians' behalf, a measure which used to form the mainstay of the authority's funding base.

Brussels gave the authority around £17m last December and in a one-off emergency measure agreed to loan the authority almost £60m to cover costs for 2001.

But the authority had already spent a third of this money in January. At that rate, the EU would be looking at a bill of almost £230m this year alone.

Mr Patten warns that "any EU decision to provide further financial assistance to the PA will need to be carefully monitored to ensure that funding is used for its intended purpose".

He believes the authority is close to collapse. "There is now a very real risk of a loss of legitimacy and public disillusion with the authority which could lead to anarchy, the atomisation of power and increased lawlessness," he says.

The US Secretary of State, Colin Powell, is also expected to press Israel to end the economic blockade and to release $54m in tax revenues owed to the authority when he begins his Middle East tour tonight.

The Palestinian economy has seen unemployment soar to 38% since the uprising began five months ago. Some 32% of Palestinians are living on less than $2 a day.

webTitle: Mayor calls for ban on march

fields.headline: Mayor calls for ban on march
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone, the mayor of London, yesterday called for a planned march through the capital to be cancelled because of the foot and mouth crisis.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone, the mayor of London, yesterday called for a planned march through the capital to be cancelled because of the foot and mouth crisis.

London could become a breeding ground for the highly infectious virus if the demonstration on March 18, organised by the Countryside Alliance, goes ahead, he told the Metropolitan police commissioner, Sir John Stevens.

The alliance dismissed Mr Livingstone's fears as "scaremongering". But officials said they would cancel the demonstration if advised to do so by health authorities.

The march is likely to receive large support from country dwellers and many might be tempted to bring livestock into London, Mr Livingstone said.

fields.headline: Court downfall of a childcare 'saint'
fields.standfirst: Carer of the year urged children to make up claims of sex abuse
fields.trailText: A woman described as a saint on the BBC's Children in Need after she adopted more than 36 children and fostered many more was yesterday criticised by a judge as a liar and a risk to children.
fields.body:
A woman described as a saint on the BBC's Children in Need after she adopted more than 36 children and fostered many more was yesterday criticised by a judge as a liar and a risk to children.

Jeanette Roberts, 61, was said to be a deceitful, unscrupulous woman who locked up children for long periods and encouraged them to tell stories of sexual abuse. The court heard that children were "clearly at risk" in her care.

Miss Roberts, a devout Christian, has had more than 80 children and young adults pass through her care and has won numerous awards including carer of the year, as well as being the focus of television documentaries and books for her work with children with learning difficulties and behavioural problems.

But her methods were questioned in a judgment handed down at the end of the longest case in the history of Britain's family courts. Mr Justice Hughes criticised her ethos, which involved children changing their name to Roberts and losing contact with their birth families.

The family division of the high court found that Miss Roberts and one of her adopted children, Karen Roberts, who eventually came to help run the Old Convent, in Bicknacre, Essex, encouraged some of the children to make confessions of sexual abuse. It found that Karen Roberts, who suffers from a schizo-affective disorder, also stole £26,000 in criminal injuries compensation from two of these children, with Roberts's knowledge.

The court heard allegations from two families that children had been improperly influenced into making claims of sexual abuse and giving false evidence at the Old Bailey. Two defendants were acquitted but one was sentenced to 12 years. He has maintained his innocence and the children - now adults - have admitted they lied.

The judge believed that this was part of a pattern in the Old Convent. He said: "I am satisfied that both Jeanette Roberts and Karen Roberts, convinced in their own minds that there had been sexual abuse, subjected the children to intense and probably emotionally charged questioning until they told stories which it was believed were there to be told."

He went on: "Jeanette was and remains very likely to question children in such a way as to produce wholly unreliable accusations of sexual abuse."

The court action was brought by Essex county council following concerns about children in Miss Roberts's care. Social services had applied to remove six children but yesterday Mr Justice Hughes said only two would not be returned.

The case followed a raid on the home in November 1998 when more than 100 police officers and social workers removed everyone residing in the Old Convent. Most were vulnerable adults who had once been children in Miss Roberts's care and were allowed to return, but Essex county council said the six should be removed because they might suffer harm.

Mr Justice Hughes said: "That contention is founded upon a large number of very serious complaints about her care for children over very nearly the whole of the 30 years mentioned." These claims of abuse are all denied by Miss Roberts.

The judgment says the complaints "include a great many histories of children unduly influenced in what they said to outsiders... Of these the most serious were the statements of no less than five children from two different families that as a result of improper influence by those at the Old Convent they had made allegations that they had been sexually abused in their former homes when they had not."

Claims that the regime was habitually violent were not founded but the judge said there were occasions when children were smacked, sat on and treated roughly and that "although Miss Roberts generally held herself notably in check, from time to time she lost her temper".

Children had been "disciplined by being confined to their rooms, often locked in", and one autistic child was locked in his room with no one else in the house except a very disabled child. A boy of 22 months was locked in his room at 8am on the day of the police raid. The key could not be found. The judge accepted this was sometimes done because there were so many difficult children to deal with, but what was done was bad practice and potentially dangerous.

Last night, social services and adoption agencies came in for criticism for allowing one woman to adopt so many children and for failing to detect the flaws in her regime sooner.

Mike Leadbetter, Essex director of social services, conceded that there was a lack of coordination and cross-checking between the authorities. "The problem was that no one ever really added the numbers up. Each case was treated individually by social workers and the courts," he said.

An additional problem, he said, was Miss Roberts's public status as a "paragon" of virtue, which meant the adopting authorities gave her a very sympathetic hearing.

Mr Leadbetter defends his authority's decision to spend £6m pursuing the case on the grounds that it had no choice. "With over 120 complainants and such a huge number of allegations, it would have been a breach of duty under the Children Act not to investigate," he said.

Ian Grant, the senior manager seconded to lead the social services investigation, maintains that the raid by police and social workers - the object of bitter criticism by Jeanette Roberts's supporters - was "carefully planned to cause minimum disruption".

The British Agencies for Adoption and Fostering agreed that Miss Roberts's powerful image - along with local authorities' desperation to place children seen as virtually unfosterable or unadoptable - explained the laxity in her case.

Felicity Collier, the director, said: "This distressing case demonstrates that we can be no less rigorous in protecting children placed in foster care and adoption, than at home with parents or in residential care."

Miss Roberts began caring for children in the late 1960s in the East End of London when she was 30. A qualified nurse, she befriended neglected children and started a club for them and soon she began taking children into her home.

She gave up work in 1972 to devote herself to the care of the children. In 1980 she took in 19-year-old Karen Chilvers, just out of borstal for robbery, with a history of hard drugs, mental illness, depression and aggression, and she became a key adult in the home.

In 1985, the ever-expanding family moved to a run-down converted convent with spacious grounds. Over the years charity donations of more than £1m helped turn it into a home. More than 80 children and adults have been in her care. Many display disturbed behaviour, some have severe physical or mental handicaps.

Because she took in children that no one else wanted, and for her success, Miss Roberts became the focus of media and charitable attention. In the foreword to Roberts's biography, Esther Rantzen describes her as "a unique human being who has discovered her own way to heal and survive".

But Miss Roberts became the focus of suspicion because of her unconventional methods. Most children who went to the Old Convent changed their names to Roberts and were encouraged to take a new first name as well. Everyone called Miss Roberts mum. Relationships were allowed within the family and some members married. Children born within the family believed their mothers were their sisters and that Miss Roberts was their mother.

Allegations of abuse and other matters surfaced and Essex police launched Operation Camberley to investigate.

All charges were dropped in the criminal case and Miss Roberts was left to fight to get the children back in her care.

In court she fought to stop the details of the judgment being published but Mr Justice Hughes told her there was a public interest because of the numbers of children she cared for, because of the unusually extensive and expensive investigation and because the Old Convent had been given more than £1m in charity money.

The judgment looked at criticisms of the methods used during the police raid but concluded that they were "steps conscientiously taken in the belief that they were necessary for the protection of the children and vulnerable people".

But her methods often worked and the judgment noted: "In a number of cases children who were very disturbed on arrival have displayed much better behaviour after a while living there." The judge also noted that a number of risks no longer existed and applauded Miss Roberts's "unusual level of commitment to children and other vulnerable people in her care [which] brought undoubted benefits to many".

But his judgment also found that "Jeanette and her adult associates have an undoubted capacity for deception" and that there was "no doubt that there were throughout the years many occasions when children were roughly handled and smacked".

The judge said he "met a great deal of outright untruth" from Miss Roberts and other adults at the Old Convent. Miss Roberts wrote a letter to an adoption agency saying her brother committed suicide: he is still alive. She also told lies about how old her parents were when they died in order to be able to adopt more children.

Additional reporting by Richard Smith

webTitle: Brown's movement ban to test industry

fields.headline: Brown's movement ban to test industry
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Food producers and retailers were last night bracing themselves for the impact of the Ministry of Agriculture's seven-day ban on the movement of livestock in Britain.
fields.body:
Food producers and retailers were last night bracing themselves for the impact of the Ministry of Agriculture's seven-day ban on the movement of livestock in Britain. Wholesalers, butchers and supermarkets said that there was no reason for immediate shortages, but with memories of the public reaction to the fuel shortage, the food industry said the next few days would be critical.

Butchers

Most traditional butchers hang their red meat for seven to 10 days and so hold a week's supply in fridges on their premises. They buy their meat from wholesale markets which will now be closed or from abattoirs which will also have to stop working. "It's the week after next that will count," said Graham Bidston, chief executive of the National Federation of Meat Traders.

There are reasonable stocks of meat in chill stores. "Since Christmas, trade has been quiet and when that happens, abattoirs take meat off the bone, vacuum pack it and chill it, which makes it last five to six weeks," said Essex butcher Roger Kelsey, whose shop is a few miles from the Brentwood abattoir where the outbreak was first found.

If more meat has to be brought out of storage, prices are likely to rise, because the additional cost of haulage and processing.

Supermarkets

The main supermarket chains said they had plenty of food on the shelves and good stores in their depots, although they were reluctant to say how many days supply they usually held. They were preparing to increase the amount of poultry available to meet demand. Sainsbury's urged people not to panic buy and said it had plans in place should the ban be extended. "We'll import where necessary. Sales are not affected at the moment."

Tesco, which sources nearly all its meat in the UK, with the exception of bacon, also said that it was confident it had adequate stocks for the duration of the present ban.

A spokeswoman for Safeway said: "At the moment we haven't noticed any change in buying. We are anticipating an increase in demand for poultry and fish and we are looking at finding new suppliers for that. We have enough meat supplies for a few days but we are looking elsewhere such as Ireland to find new suppliers."

Wholesalers and processors

The government-funded meat and livestock commission said there were enough stocks of British meat to cover the seven day ban. "There is enough in the supply chain but life will get difficult after a week," said a spokesman.

Grampian Country Foods, Britain's largest independent food firm, which slaughters 3.8m chickens and processes 20,000 pigs, 25,000 lambs and 1,400 cattle a week, was last night trying to assess the effects of the transport ban on its business.

"It will be serious for us and potentially for the consumer. We'll be twiddling our thumbs wondering what to do in a short time," said marketing director Alasdair Cox. Grampian, which employs 10,000 people is not contemplating redundancies.

Hauliers

Livestock hauliers feared the crisis could have a devastating effect on their business. Already suffering from fuel prices, many hauliers are ill-equipped to cope with a further blow, according to the Road Haulage Association. "There are about 500 companies in the UK who earn their living from moving animals. They are facing a week without earnings. It's a matter of extreme concern to the whole industry, but everyone I've spoken to is convinced the ban is the responsible thing to do," a spokesperson said.

Farmers

The National Farmers' Union said the industry had no choice but to batten down the hatches. "This will be hard, but not as hard as if foot and mouth spreads throughout Britain," NFU president Ben Gill said. "When the situation has been brought under control, we need to look at how this has happened," he added.

Livestock markets

Livestock markets were facing a week without business, and while they supported the ban they were worried about the long term. "If the ban lasts longer than a week, there are going to be serious cash-flow implications," said Peter Kingwell, of the Livestock Auctioneers' Association. "They will become noticeable in the supermarkets in less than a week."

Additional research by Max Houghton

webTitle: Disease trail led to this squalid farm

fields.headline: Disease trail led to this squalid farm
fields.standfirst:
Few signs of life at centre as farmers tell of 'horrific' conditions
Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Few signs of life at centre as farmers tell of 'horrific' conditions.
fields.body:
Few neighbours have a kind word to say about the collection of long concrete sheds on the western fringe of Newcastle upon Tyne that pass for a farm and are the likely source of the national foot and mouth disease outbreak. Surrounded by rusting tin drums, piles of rubbish and old machinery, they present an ugly image of pig production.

Nearby farmers have long despaired of the animal holding centre - or, more accurately, the pig transit camp - at Heddon-on-the-Wall, Northumberland, and appear unsurprised by the growing crisis on their doorstep. "I don't like what I see over there," said one who left pig farming in the last decade. "To be honest, when I heard about it I thought it has been an accident waiting to happen. The place is an eyesore, a disgrace."

Yet it was the place where pigs arrived from all parts for fattening and were held for several weeks or months before being sent south for slaughter - a vital link in a complex, and potentially lethal national supply chain that may bring British farming to its knees.

Yesterday two skeletal terriers, and a tethered horse in rather better shape, were the only sign of animal life at the centre run by a Sunderland man, Ronald Waugh. He leases the buildings and farmyard from a former pig farmer, Philip Leadbitter, who lives opposite.

Police arrived at 10.30 yesterday morning to cordon off the narrow road leading to the site while Ministry of Agriculture vets in white overalls took samples from buildings and eventually placed a yellow cordon around the centre - itself in the middle of a five-mile exclusion zone. A warning notice - "Foot and mouth disease: please keep out" - had been pinned to a gate the previous night alongside a neighbouring pig farm, run by Jim Brown. "I can't comment," he said. "It's just a precaution."

Mr Leadbitter, who gave up pig rearing five years ago - "if I'd kept going I'd be bankrupt now" - blamed Europe for the latest farming crisis. "I thought this would probably come. The trouble lies with all this suspect feed coming from Europe and getting into our food chain. Maybe someone was eating a ham sandwich, or something, with meat from abroad, and threw it into a field."

Others were not so charitable. For some time, locals have complained about slurry leaking from the centre - which is dominated by a large green silo containing pig swill - and an all-pervading stench from the site. John Simons, who has lived opposite the buildings for almost three years, said yesterday that complaints to Mr Waugh had been ignored.

"I have made numerous complaints to the local council," he said. "They have made at least five visits to the property that I know of but they said nothing could be done."

In desperation, Mr Simons had even tried to buy the centre from Mr Leadbitter. "But he was asking a ridiculous price. It's an eyesore. I just wanted to flatten it and maybe open a riding school or something. But it has been left to rot and decay. I've been inside and, while I know a pig farm isn't going to be clean, the conditions seem to be atrocious. It's like some kind of horror film in there."

Castle Morpeth council was checking its records last night. Tony Woodcock, its director of environment and planning, recalled one recent incident unconnected with foot and mouth. "There certainly was a slurry spillage earlier this year and a feed spillage nearby," he said. "But none of these have any implications with the present issue." However, "repeated instances" would be closely examined and as a last resort farmers would be prosecuted with the help of the environment agency.

But no one appeared more surprised yesterday than some members of the Waugh family. Ronald Waugh, who is in his 40s, lives in a large end-of-terrace house in the Pallion area of Sunderland, beside the city's old docks.

His sisters were shocked by the news. "We have lost everything that we worked for," one said. "We just don't understand how it could have happened and what it means for us now. Like everyone else, we are in the dark and we are finding the whole situation very upsetting and difficult to cope with."

Neighbours said the family had been in pig farming all their working lives and, at one time, bought swill from the local bakery opposite their home. In Heddon-on-the-Wall, others spoke of the Waughs having another site at Gateshead, Tyne and Wear, and experiencing similar complaints from people there.

One former pig farmer, Terry Clark, recalled that holding centres were necessary under new legislation to ensure that animals are more safely transported. "But I don't always like what I see over there. It doesn't look all that nice. I've heard they have a tie-up with this abattoir in Essex."

Mr Clark bred pedigree pigs until three years ago barely a mile from the suspected farm. "I had 1,000 sows once," he said. "Fine pedigrees. When the ministry men came here they said they were the best looking pigs ever. But I had to get out. There's no money in pigs any longer."

"I don't like what I see over there," said one who left pig farming in the last decade. "To be honest, when I heard about it I thought it has been an accident waiting to happen. The place is an eyesore, a disgrace." Yet it was the place where pigs arrived from all parts for fattening and were held for several weeks or months before being sent south for slaughter - a vital link in a complex, and potentially lethal national supply chain that may bring British farming to its knees. Yesterday two skeletal terriers, and a tethered horse in rather better shape, were the only sign of animal life at the centre run by a Sunderland man, Ronald Waugh. He leases the buildings and farmyard from a former pig farmer, Philip Leadbitter, who lives opposite. Police arrived at 10.30 yesterday morning to cordon off the narrow road leading to the site while Ministry of Agriculture vets in white overalls took samples from buildings and eventually placed a yellow cordon around the centre - itself in the middle of a five-mile exclusion zone. A warning notice - "Foot and mouth disease: please keep out" - had been pinned to a gate the previous night alongside a neighbouring pig farm, run by Jim Brown. "I can't comment," he said. "It's just a precaution." Mr Leadbitter, who gave up pig rearing five years ago - "if I'd kept going I'd be bankrupt now" - blamed Europe for the latest farming crisis. "I thought this would probably come. The trouble lies with all this suspect feed coming from Europe and getting into our food chain. Maybe someone was eating a ham sandwich, or something, with meat from abroad, and threw it into a field." Others were not so charitable. For some time, locals have complained about slurry leaking from the centre - which is dominated by a large green silo containing pig swill - and an all-pervading stench from the site. John Simons, who has lived opposite the buildings for almost three years, said yesterday that complaints to Mr Waugh had been ignored. "I have made numerous complaints to the local council," he said. "They have made at least five visits to the property that I know of but they said nothing could be done." In desperation, Mr Simons had even tried to buy the centre from Mr Leadbitter. "But he was asking a ridiculous price. It's an eyesore. I just wanted to flatten it and maybe open a riding school or something. But it has been left to rot and decay. I've been inside and, while I know a pig farm isn't going to be clean, the conditions seem to be atrocious. It's like some kind of horror film in there." Castle Morpeth council was checking its records last night. Tony Woodcock, its director of environment and planning, recalled one recent incident unconnected with foot and mouth. "There certainly was a slurry spillage earlier this year and a feed spillage nearby," he said. "But none of these have any implications with the present issue." However, "repeated instances" would be closely examined and as a last resort farmers would be prosecuted with the help of the environment agency. But no one appeared more surprised yesterday than some members of the Waugh family. Ronald Waugh, who is in his 40s, lives in a large end-of-terrace house in the Pallion area of Sunderland, beside the city's old docks. His sisters were shocked by the news. "We have lost everything that we worked for," one said. "We just don't understand how it could have happened and what it means for us now. Like everyone else, we are in the dark and we are finding the whole situation very upsetting and difficult to cope with." Neighbours said the family had been in pig farming all their working lives and, at one time, bought swill from the local bakery opposite their home. In Heddon-on-the-Wall, others spoke of the Waughs having another site at Gateshead, Tyne and Wear, and experiencing similar complaints from people there. One former pig farmer, Terry Clark, recalled that holding centres were necessary under new legislation to ensure that animals are more safely transported. "But I don't always like what I see over there. It doesn't look all that nice. I've heard they have a tie-up with this abattoir in Essex." Mr Clark bred pedigree pigs until three years ago barely a mile from the suspected farm. "I had 1,000 sows once," he said. "Fine pedigrees. When the ministry men came here they said they were the best looking pigs ever. But I had to get out. There's no money in pigs any longer." Talk about it What do you think? fields.headline: Animal lab boss attacked
fields.trailText: The managing director of Huntingdon Life Sciences, Europe's biggest contract animal research centre, was recovering yesterday after being attacked at his home by three masked people carrying baseball bats.
fields.body:
The managing director of Huntingdon Life Sciences, Europe's biggest contract animal research centre, was recovering yesterday after being attacked at his home by three masked people carrying baseball bats.

Brian Cass, 52, was set upon shortly before 8pm on Thursday outside his home in St Ives, Cambridgeshire. Police believe the attack to be the work of animal rights activists opposed to research carried out by HLS.

The laboratory, which uses 70,000 animals a year, has been the focus of the most concerted and effective campaign in the history of the animal rights movement.

Two men and a third attacker, believed to be a woman, all wearing balaclavas and carrying baseball bats, set about Mr Cass as he got out of his car after driving the short distance from HLS to his home. He was struck on the head and received injuries to his arms as he fended off the blows. Two members of the public witnessed the incident and went to Mr Cass's defence. One of them was sprayed in the eyes with what police believe was CS gas.

Mr Cass was taken to Hinchingbrooke hospital, Huntingdon, for stitches to a head wound. He returned to work yesterday afternoon. Mr Cass is the second senior HLS executive to be assaulted at his home in the last three months. In December a senior manager was attacked by two people at his home.

After returning to work yesterday Mr Cass said: "They beat me with baseball bats. I tried to protect myself but I was knocked over. I received quite a nasty gash on my head.

"I have always been careful. Unfortunately all people in our business need to exercise that level of care. All the work that we do is demanded by the government to improve safety to the public and human health."

Cambridgeshire police described the attack as "callous and cowardly". A spokesman said: "In recent months we have witnessed an escalation in the nature of attacks on people and property associated with Huntingdon Life Sciences. These events make us more determined to catch those who are responsible for these attacks."

The attack is the latest incident in a concerted campaign to close the company, which employs more than 1,100 people in the UK. It gained momentum in late 1999 when a loose coalition of animal rights activists united under the banner Stop Huntingdon Life Cruelty (Shac) began campaigning to close the institution.

Alongside these protests a campaign of intimidation and harassment was conducted. Employees, shareholders and supporters received death threats and hate mail, and incendiary devices were planted under cars. Shac has consistently denied involvement in any illegal methods of protest.

Natasha Taylor of Shac said yesterday: "We unreservedly condemn any act of violence be it against animals or humans. The campaign will go on until Huntingdon is closed."

Stop Huntingdon Animal Cruelty

fields.headline: Hillary faces crime inquiry
fields.trailText: Hillary Clinton's short career as a United States senator was mired in fresh controversy yesterday when a criminal investigation was launched into whether she was the beneficiary of a votes-for-clemency deal.
fields.body:
Hillary Clinton's short career as a United States senator was mired in fresh controversy yesterday when a criminal investigation was launched into whether she was the beneficiary of a votes-for-clemency deal.

Mary Jo White, the US attorney for the southern district of New York, is examining whether former President Bill Clinton granted clemency to four fraudsters in exchange for their Hassidic community supporting his wife in last November's election.

The village of New Square, 33 miles north of Manhattan, votes as a bloc and overwhelmingly supported Mrs Clinton by 1,359 to 10. Two other Hassidic communities in the area voted 3,480 to 152 for her Republican opponent, Rick Lazio.

Several polls in the final weeks of the campaign showed that the race was close but in the end she won by a near landslide.

Only a month ago a seed had been planted that Mrs Clinton might run for president in either 2004 or 2008. Now all talk of another Clinton term in the White House is off.

Mrs Clinton visited New Square last summer and later sat in on a meeting after polling day between her husband and village leaders, who were pressing for clemency. She denies having a hand in the president's decision to grant their wish.

The four Hassidic men, who were tried two years ago, were jailed for stealing $40m in government grants for schemes that included a non-existent school.

They were sentenced to terms of up to 78 months - reduced by Mr Clinton to a maximum of 30 months - and each was ordered to return sums of up to $10m. None of the money has been repaid.

"I did not play any role whatsoever," said the New York senator, who has been criticised for taking an $8m advance for her memoirs and showing great enthusiasm for accepting gifts. "I had no opinion about it."

It is considered unusual for the president's wife to be included in such meetings but Mrs Clinton said this was the first time the Hassidic leaders had mentioned the issue to her.

"This has obviously been a disaster for the Clintons politically," said Steve Russo, a Democratic lawyer. "But I don't think there's been any criminal wrongdoing. What they're going to have to prove here is that there was some kind of agreement before the election that the president would pardon them after the election. That's a very difficult thing to prove."

Meanwhile, Bill Cunningham, a lawyer who was Mrs Clinton's campaign treasurer, was forced to deny yesterday that she knew he was working on behalf of two Arkansas businessmen who were among 176 people pardoned or granted clemency by President Clinton before he left office.

He said that he had been paid $4,062 to prepare applications for pardons granted to the two men, who had been convicted on tax charges. "I did not speak with Senator Clinton or any of her staff about the petitions," he said. "My responsibilities to her were absolutely independent of this."

He is a partner in a law firm with Harold Ickes, a Clinton adviser.

Ms White is already investigating the pardon given to Marc Rich, a fugitive financier who holds the record for tax evasion - $48m on illegal oil transactions of $105m. The inquiry is focusing on whether Bill Clinton was influenced by contributions of about $1.5m to Clinton causes by Denise Rich, the exile's former wife.

One person who certainly attempted to exercise influence was the former president's half-brother, Roger Clinton, himself pardoned for an old cocaine conviction.

"Roger did ask the president to consider a list of less than 10 names of friends and acquaintances," said a spokesman for the former president. "None of those pardons were granted, nor did he receive any money."

But Dan Burton, the Republican chairman of the House of Representatives government reform committee, has written to Roger Clinton asking if he was involved in four pardons that were granted.

fields.headline: Boy, 14, blinded in TA blast
fields.trailText: The boy seriously injured at a Territorial Army barracks when a torch bomb exploded in his hand has been blinded by the blast, a hospital spokeswoman said yesterday.
fields.body:
The boy seriously injured at a Territorial Army barracks when a torch bomb exploded in his hand has been blinded by the blast, a hospital spokeswoman said yesterday.

Stephen Menary, 14, from the White City estate, London, may also lose hearing in his left ear following the explosion on Wednesday night, a spokeswoman for Chelsea and Westminster Hospital said.

Stephen, a cadet at the TA centre in Shepherd's Bush, west London, lost his left hand in the explosion. The spokeswoman said Stephen lost his right eye to cancer as a baby. He has now lost sight in his left eye.

In a statement his parents, Steve and Carol, said: "We appreciate everyone's concern over Stephen and the many messages of support... Our main concern is that our family is given the space and time to care for Stephen, who faces a difficult journey as he starts to recover from his appalling injuries." Press Association

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Lifeboat safety 'needs review'
fields.body:
Lifeboat safety 'needs review'

The marine accident investigation branch called for an international review of lifeboats after a UK survey found a problem with the release mechanism on the hooks fastening lifeboats to ships. "Our report shows 11 incidents, resulting in nine injuries and seven deaths - that's pretty horrific," it said.

Big crowds for robot dinosaur

A robot model of tyrannosaurus rex which stands more than four metres high and roars when approached is attracting 13,000 people each day to the Natural History Museum in central London.

RUC inspector jailed for fraud

A RUC inspector was yesterday jailed for two years after the largest internal anti-corruption investigation undertaken by the force. Derek John Robinson, 45, had pleaded guilty at Craigavon crown court to 17 charges including fraud.

Wild parks firm faces charges

Howletts and Port Lympne Estates Limited, which runs the two wild animal parks of the deceased millionaire John Aspinall, was yesterday charged with six health and safety breaches after elephant keeper Darren Cockrill, 27, was crushed to death at Port Lympne zoo, Hythe, Kent, last February.

Divers arrested over drug haul

Police recovered £2.25m worth of cannabis after arresting two divers underneath a boat in the river Thames at Silvertown, east London.

fields.headline: Long road to new drugs
fields.standfirst: Drug testing: the facts
fields.trailText: • In 1999, the last year for which figures are available, 1,408 licences for testing were granted and 2,656,753 animal experiments took place in UK labs. More than 50% of these were conducted on rodents.
fields.body:
 In 1999, the last year for which figures are available, 1,408 licences for testing were granted and 2,656,753 animal experiments took place in UK labs. More than 50% of these were conducted on rodents.

 It takes, on average, eight years and £330m to bring a new medicine from the laboratory to the pharmacist.

 In the early stages, substances are screened for known toxins.

 The second phase, which can last up to two years, involves animals. Legislation requires that drugs are tested on two mammals, one of them a large non-rodent.

 Following the animal stage, which can last up to two years, clinical trials on humans begin. There are three stages of clinical trials, usually beginning with the most seriously ill sufferers of a particular ailment. Only when these tests are satisfactory is the drug put on to the market.

 Opponents of animal testing advocate using lab-based reconstructions (in vitro) and computer modelling (in silico).

Paul Kelso

webTitle: Saxon jewel fit for princess unearthed dig

fields.headline: Saxon jewel fit for princess unearthed dig
fields.trailText: A jewel from the breast of a Saxon princess has been found in a shallow grave in London, yards from the bustle of Covent Garden.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
A jewel from the breast of a Saxon princess has been found in a shallow grave in London, yards from the bustle of Covent Garden.

Archaeologists at the Museum of London yesterday announced the discovery of the late 7th century jewel (above), the most important Saxon find in years. Made of copper and delicately worked gold, studded with Indian garnets, it is one of 16 brooches apparently associated with the kings of Kent. The find is the richest Saxon burial ever found in London, part of the East Saxon kingdom covering Essex, Middlesex and Hertfordshire. The workmanship closely resembles precious objects from the most famous Saxon burial, Sutton Hoo in Essex.

The brooch was found with corroded silver rings and a few beads, which may all have been in a leather purse on the woman's breast. Nothing remained of her coffin, and only fragments of the skeleton.

The Saxon town of Lundenwic was located a decade ago in redeveloping the opera house, a stone's throw from the new find. That excavation uncovered homes and workshops of humble people. The new find has unveiled the aristocracy. The site had not been expected to yield anything more exciting than medieval foundations, although a museum team found a Saxon grave 10 years ago, and traces of a second. The recent excavation brings the total to five, raising the intriguing possibly that others of the princess's family lie under the adjoining buildings.

Excavating the site before Christmas, the archaeologist Sylvia Warren spotted the top boss of the jewel, the most damaged part, poking from the earth. It was dug out imbedded in a clump of soil.

An x-ray caused wild excitement when it revealed not just the brooch but intricate detail of the gold inlay and the gems. While conservators spent weeks teasing the jewel free, archaeologists sifted through soil in the grave and found a missing tiny boss with a pinhead-sized cabuchon garnet.

The jewel will go on display at the museum today. John Clark, Saxon curator, said similar brooches been found in Kent, probably from the same workshop, but others in Ipswich and Oxfordshire, suggesting a spreading influence through marriage of the Kent kings.

webTitle: Mother of IVF triplets settles for £20,000

fields.headline: Mother of IVF triplets settles for £20,000
fields.trailText: A woman who had triplets through IVF treatment after a doctor implanted three embryos in her womb rather than the agreed two has settled out of court with the clinic which treated her.
fields.body:
A woman who had triplets through IVF treatment after a doctor implanted three embryos in her womb rather than the agreed two has settled out of court with the clinic which treated her.

Patricia Thompson, 34, successfully sued Sheffield fertility centre last year for breach of contract, winning a high court ruling that the clinic had disregarded her stated wishes. The clinic claimed that she had changed her mind and agreed to have three embryos implanted.

She accepted the settlement of £20,000 just before a high court hearing to decide whether she could claim the cost - up to £100,000 - of bringing up the third triplet.

The House of Lords ruled in 1999 that public policy bars parents from claiming the cost of raising an "unwanted" child born as a result of medical negligence, but declined to decide whether different rules applied if the birth resulted from a breach of contract.

A judge had been due to decide that point this week. Had it gone against Mrs Thompson she would have been compensated only for the extra pain and discomfort of carrying and delivering three babies rather than two - which would have been less than £20,000. For this reason she accepted the settlement.

Mrs Thompson, who was on legal aid, had turned down an offer of £20,000 before the original high court hearing last November. The clinic, as the loser, would normally be expected to pay her legal costs. But because she rejected that offer and failed to win more after going to court, she is liable for her own costs.

But her solicitors and barrister have agreed to trim their fees so she will keep most of the £20,000.

Her solicitor, Ben Gent, said she turned down the offer earlier because the clinic had refused to couple it with an acknowledgment that Mrs Thompson and her husband, Peter, 58, were telling the truth when they said they had insisted that only two embryos should be implanted.

The Thompsons said: "We fought this case because we believe no one should undergo medical treatment unless they give consent, whatever the treatment or the outcome, and we were subjected to the clinic's wishes being forced upon us.

"Rather than accept the clinic's offer of money before the high court case, we decided to go ahead with the hearing to prove they were wrong to treat us in that way. This was not about money but about the fact the treatment was given without consent."

Mr and Mrs Thompson, from Thrybergh, Rotherham, South Yorkshire, paid £1,600 for the treatment in 1996 after trying unsuccessfully for a child for five years. The triplets, a girl and two boys, were born in March 1997 and the following year Mrs Thompson conceived naturally and had a daughter.

The couple, who gave up running their shop to concentrate on looking after the children, came in for criticism after launching their case.

During the high court hearing, Mrs Thompson said she was informed three embryos had been implanted only after the procedure was carried out. She was offered foetal reduction when the pregnancy was confirmed but turned it down.

She told the court that the effort of looking after three children, rather than two, was exhausting and expensive.

Suzanne Liversidge, the clinic's solicitor, said: "This has been a highly sensitive case but one we have been determined to defend throughout, to prove the principle that it is against public policy to award damages for the cost of raising a healthy child."

For this reason she accepted the settlement. Mrs Thompson, who was on legal aid, had turned down an offer of £20,000 before the original high court hearing last November. The clinic, as the loser, would normally be expected to pay her legal costs. But because she rejected that offer and failed to win more after going to court, she is liable for her own costs. But her solicitors and barrister have agreed to trim their fees so she will keep most of the £20,000. Her solicitor, Ben Gent, said she turned down the offer earlier because the clinic had refused to couple it with an acknowledgment that Mrs Thompson and her husband, Peter, 58, were telling the truth when they said they had insisted that only two embryos should be implanted. The Thompsons said: "We fought this case because we believe no one should undergo medical treatment unless they give consent, whatever the treatment or the outcome, and we were subjected to the clinic's wishes being forced upon us. "Rather than accept the clinic's offer of money before the high court case, we decided to go ahead with the hearing to prove they were wrong to treat us in that way. This was not about money but about the fact the treatment was given without consent." Mr and Mrs Thompson, from Thrybergh, Rotherham, South Yorkshire, paid £1,600 for the treatment in 1996 after trying unsuccessfully for a child for five years. The triplets, a girl and two boys, were born in March 1997 and the following year Mrs Thompson conceived naturally and had a daughter. The couple, who gave up running their shop to concentrate on looking after the children, came in for criticism after launching their case. During the high court hearing, Mrs Thompson said she was informed three embryos had been implanted only after the procedure was carried out. She was offered foetal reduction when the pregnancy was confirmed but turned it down. She told the court that the effort of looking after three children, rather than two, was exhausting and expensive. Suzanne Liversidge, the clinic's solicitor, said: "This has been a highly sensitive case but one we have been determined to defend throughout, to prove the principle that it is against public policy to award damages for the cost of raising a healthy child."

webTitle: Drink and assault sealed fate of hangman butcher

fields.headline: Drink and assault sealed fate of hangman butcher
fields.standfirst: Public record office papers reveal Churchill's role in mystery of why Britain's chief executioner suddenly left his job
fields.trailText: Public record office papers reveal Churchill's role in mystery of why Britain's chief executioner suddenly left his job.
fields.body:
A 90-year cover-up of why one of Britain's most famous hangmen suddenly left his job as chief executioner has finally been exposed.

The release of confidential Home Office papers by the public record office this week shows that Henry Pierrepoint was struck off the official list of qualified executioners by Winston Churchill, home secretary in 1910, after he turned up drunk at Chelmsford prison to carry out a hanging and "brutally assaulted" his own assistant executioner.

Pierrepoint's son, Albert, who went on to become the last executioner in Britain, always believed his father had not been sacked and others suggested he had resigned in anger at not being offered the job of hanging Dr Crippen.

The Home Office files also show the lengths to which ministers unsuccessfully tried to prevent former hangmen selling their stories to the newspapers, even to the extent of trying to invoke the Official Secrets Act. Hangmen were paid £10 for an execution.

The files show that John Ellis, the assistant executioner, who took over from Henry Pierrepoint, attracted huge crowds when, after his retirement, he nightly re-enacted the hanging of the murderer Charles Peace on the stage.

The Victorians decided that the executioner should not be a prison official but a freelance hangman, to avoid the reputation of the "brutal jailer".

Pierrepoint senior, a Huddersfield butcher with a wife and five children, was on the official list for 10 years after writing to the home secretary claiming that his knowledge of anatomy qualified him for the job. He carried out 99 executions, six of them "double hangings", including that of Amelia Sach and Annie Walter, the Edwardian "baby farmers", and of Joseph Fee, the Irish murderer tried three times.

He was later to describe the last moments of one of his victims, Patrick McKenna, a Bolton murderer. "With all the quickness possible we pinioned McKenna, and then was enacted a scene such as I will never forget as long as I live. The man knew that his last moments on this Earth had come. He broke out into great sobs and in the silence of that prison cell his voice wailed upward in one great tearing cry, 'Oh Lord help me'. It was only a few steps to the fateful spot but McKenna walked slowly and falteringly - we could see that the strain was almost too much for the man we had to hang. Tears were rolling down his cheeks. The moment he toed the chalk mark on the scaffold he cried out aloud: 'Lord have mercy on my soul!' "

But Pierrepoint's career came to an abrupt end in July 1910 when he arrived "considerably the worse for drink" at Chelmsford prison the afternoon before he was due to hang Frederick Foreman. The report to the Home Office from the warder said that after a few minutes in the gate lodge Pierrepoint's "conduct was very bad and the assistant, J Ellis, he called an Irish B and struck him with his fist, threw off his coat, wanting to fight, and gave me trouble by having to keep him off Ellis."

Even though the execution of Foreman was carried out "expeditiously", Mr Churchill had little hesitation in confirming the decision of the prison commissioners: "Make certain this fellow is never employed again," says the home secretary's note on the file. A confidential circular was sent to all sheriffs telling them that Pierrepoint's name had been removed from the official list of executioners.

He himself was never told and in May 1911 wrote to Mr Churchill pleading for his job back, saying he had "strong reasons" to believe that Ellis had been trying to do him out of his job for a long time.

Rules for hangmen

 He must report at the prison not later than 4pm on the day before the execution.

 He must remain in the prison until he has completed the execution and until permission is given to leave.

 The supply of liquor to him will be limited to a pint of malt liquor at dinner and a pint at supper or pint of spirit.

 He should avoid attracting attention in going to or from the prison.

 Fees will not be paid until a fortnight after the execution has taken place.

 The ropes, straps, caps, etc will be provided at the prison and must not be removed.
