webTitle: Luxury flats boost for Labour donor

fields.headline: Luxury flats boost for Labour donor
fields.trailText: The Labour donor Robert Bourne has been let off a £2m bill by a cash-strapped Liberal Democrat council to build a faux Elizabethan theatre and modern luxury flats complex in north London.
fields.body:
The Labour donor Robert Bourne has been let off a £2m bill by a cash-strapped Liberal Democrat council to build a faux Elizabethan theatre and modern luxury flats complex in north London.

The scheme - on the site of an old music hall in the Islington constituency of the culture secretary, Chris Smith - involves reconstructing the theatre set from the award winning film Shakespeare in Love and building 72 luxury flats above.

The idea came from Robert Bourne's partner, Sally Greene, owner of the Old Vic and Criterion theatres, after her friend and one of the stars of Shakespeare in Love, Dame Judi Dench, donated the solid oak set from the award winning film to her trust.

Ms Greene combined the idea of the 600-capacity theatre with a 72 luxury flat complex to be built by Fairbriar Homes whose director and major shareholder is her husband, Robert Bourne.

Islington officials said that under planning policies for London, Fairbriar should either make a quarter of the flats available to local people as affordable homes or pay £2m to the council to build low-cost homes elsewhere in the borough. Fairbriar argued that if they had to do this it would lose all its profits. The flats are expected to be sold for anything from £200,000 and the penthouse could go for £1m.

The council's Liberal Democrat and Labour controlled planning committee vetoed officials' advice. Steve Hitchins, the Liberal Democrat leader of the council, told BBC Radio's File on Four that councillors in both parties were divided about the scheme.

"There was a value judgment. We took the view that the social benefit to the community would be gained by the success of the project in terms of providing cultural entertainment and providing a landmark building for the borough, as well as employment."

Residents appealed to John Prescott, the deputy prime minister and environment secretary, on the grounds that it broke Labour's planning policies for London. He passed it to the government office for London, a quango which decided that the council was able "to decide the application as they think fit" and that it could argue that the flats might subsidise the theatre.

Mr Smith, whose constituency party received a donation from Mr Bourne, has declined to offer a view on whether the council should have pressed his donor.

A spokesman for Mr Bourne said he thought it was a matter for the council and the scheme had been approved by Mr Prescott's department.

fields.headline: Dressed for success
fields.standfirst: Interview: Werner Baldessarini, chairman, Hugo Boss
fields.trailText: Dress-down Friday is not an option for staff at Hugo Boss's head office in Metzingen, near Stuttgart. The very idea brings a glint of rage to the eye of chairman Werner Baldessarini. "Casual Friday - this is a disaster," he snorts. "Why should you come in on a Friday and say it's sporty Friday, so I'm going to wear a jogging suit?"
fields.body:
Dress-down Friday is not an option for staff at Hugo Boss's head office in Metzingen, near Stuttgart. The very idea brings a glint of rage to the eye of chairman Werner Baldessarini. "Casual Friday - this is a disaster," he snorts. "Why should you come in on a Friday and say it's sporty Friday, so I'm going to wear a jogging suit?"

A trim, silver-haired figure, Baldessarini is elegantly turned out in a dark jacket with open-necked white shirt. "I think I look good today," he says. "Smart, but not too official."

Hugo Boss has built its reputation, according to Baldessarini, by making "men who are not so good looking look good". That is about to change - after 78 years of dressing men, the German firm is turning its attention to women.

The first range of Boss womenswear reached the stores this year. The clothes took three years to design, with planning for the project going back 10 years.

Yet Baldessarini denies that the change is radical, saying: "When we make clothes for men, we already think of women. The woman is very dominant in fashion - she often buys for the man. We have to see through the eyes of the woman."

Boss's womenswear brochure contains simple designs, with an emphasis on black and white. Although the obvious customer is a young, professional woman, Baldessarini maintains the clothes are for all ages. In fact, he seems to have a penchant for older women.

"Your grandmother is not the same as my grandmother," he says. "She is young, fresh, she wants to look good. Things have changed - my grandmother stayed at home all the time."

Warming to his theme, he continues: "The word sexy for a grandmother was impossible until recently." Turning to his bemused PR man, Baldessarini demands: "How is your grandmother?"

"I don't have any grandmothers - they are dead," replies the PR man, triggering nervous sniggers all round.

Originally a family company, Hugo Boss began by making industrial clothes and raincoats. The firm now has three labels - fashion-conscious Hugo, more formal Boss and an exclusive, designer range named Baldessarini.

Hugo Boss is listed on the German stock market, but majority control is in the hands of the Italian textiles empire Marzotto. "The Italians don't tell us what to do," says Baldessarini. "We are the most successful part of their group."

The company this week announced an impressive 93% surge in annual profits to DM213m (£71m), on sales of DM1.8bn.

Baldessarini has been running the show since 1998. He joined the company in 1975, after turning his nose up at the firm's offerings while working as a buyer for a fashionable Munich boutique, Wagenheimer. Hugo Boss's founding brothers, Uwe and Jochen Holy, sought him out to ask what he thought they were doing wrong, then persuaded him to come and help implement his ideas.

He says: "I have never been to a fashion school but I have an instinct, a good feeling for quality."

The son of a textiles wholesaler, Baldessarini was born in Austria but grew up in Munich. He feels more affinity to southern European style than to Germany: "I love the south very much."

He also professes an admiration for the British. "English people have an incredibly classic look. The young generation is open to everything. At the top end of fashion, the British are very good but the middle can be a little dangerous."

He praises Irish linen, Scottish wool and English individuality: "I was in London and I saw this incredibly good looking guy. He was carrying a big sign saying 'for sale' - he was selling himself. That would never happen in Germany."

Baldessarini sees himself as something of a rebel - he never wears a tie. "When I started, I had to face a group of analysts and important people. I thought about wearing a tie, but then I decided to be true to myself."

He links his aversion to neckwear to claustrophobia: "I don't like going on aeroplanes which are full and I don't like going in elevators."

The latter phobia is unfortunate, given that his office is on the top floor of Hugo Boss's stylishly minimalist nerve centre, in the middle of an industrial park near Stuttgart airport. Baldessarini is less than complementary about its provincial location. "I thought I'd do this job here for one or two years - this is not Las Vegas, it's Metzingen," he says.

Hugo Boss has developed rapidly since family control ended in 1992. It has 387 shops, and its clothes are available in 100 countries. The firm's progress was unaffected by revelations that surfaced in 1997 concerning its role in the second world war - Hugo Boss was forced to admit that it had made uniforms for Nazi stormtroopers and for the Hitler Youth.

Baldessarini says: "It was a Mickey Mouse company in those days - it was so small. They did what they got orders to do. It's no different from Daimler - their cars were used to drive soldiers to the front line."

The firm's image was closely associated with power dressing in the 1980s - its clothes featured prominently on the yuppy legal drama series LA Law. In the 1990s, it has softened its act. Baldessarini says: "We've gone from macho man to yuppies to muesli man."

Surely this masculine image will put off women? "The brand is a virgin," says Baldessarini, mysteriously. "We must be very careful with it."

Hugo Boss sponsors the very male sport of formula one - its logos are on McLaren cars. But, the firm points out, it also funds prizes for contemporary artists, a much less testosterone-fuelled activity. Its name will be in lights at the Oscars ceremony, where in past years Hugo Boss has dressed Nicholas Cage and Kevin Costner.

Baldessarini says the underlying quality of the label will see off any doubts, saying: "We offer good quality, but we are not extreme. When you buy a Boss suit, you have confidence. The German origins help."

He reckons the new millennium has heralded a desire for luxury - instead of frequently shopping for modestly priced clothes, consumers are going for just a few top-of-the-market outfits.

"It's a hectic time," he says. "We have the internet, 30-channel television, psychotherapists everywhere. There's too much pressure from everywhere. People want fashion to be simple, harmonious.

"It's like nouvelle cuisine - you used to have a table with 20 different things to share, which was confusing. Now in Germany, you just have three good, honest things. What's on the way is simplicity, but quality."

Baldessarini recalls that a decade ago, his cleaning lady was delighted when he gave her a suit for her husband: "She was very grateful back then. This year, I did it again and she just said 'okay'. Everyone is buying quality for themselves."

He appears slightly flummoxed by aspects of modern life. "I have this new Braun shaving thing and it takes 15 pages to explain how to use it. There's a new radio in may car. For me, it's impossible - I must read 80 pages." It is this kind of hassle, he insists, which makes people desire Hugo Boss's stark suits.

Baldessarini stunned colleagues in 1994 by sneaking off to Gretna Green for a weekend to marry a woman 20 years his junior. The couple live on a hill overlooking Metzingen.

He admits, however, that age is taking its toll. "I'm 56, I don't go to the disco so often now. I look down from my house at night and I see the lights of the town. It looks like Nice. Then I get up in the morning and have to go to work, and I realise it's Metzingen."

webTitle: Are further strategic changes on the cards at property company Great Portland Estates?

fields.headline: Portland manoeuvres
fields.trailText: Are further strategic changes on the cards at property company Great Portland Estates?
fields.body:
Are further strategic changes on the cards at property company Great Portland Estates?

Yesterday's sale of a further £66m of non-core assets suggests not. But a closer look at the statement accompanying the sale suggests otherwise.

Portland did not refer to its £325m shopping centres portfolio as part of its core asset base in the statement, which might mean they are up for sale, say analysts.

A sale, says Deutsche Bank, could lead to a further reduction in Portland's capital base, either by way of debt repayment or funds being returned to shareholders.

A sale of the shopping centres would be welcomed by shareholders, as it would focus the group's remaining assets on its core central London roots. The west end of London remains the strongest part of the UK property market. Great Portland shares closed unchanged at 281.5p.

fields.headline: M&S's price stays unexplained
fields.standfirst: Market forces
fields.trailText: Somebody in the Square Mile keeps chasing Marks & Spencer shares higher, but nobody is quite sure why.
fields.body:
Somebody in the Square Mile keeps chasing Marks & Spencer shares higher, but nobody is quite sure why.

Yesterday the share price of the embattled retailer moved up again, despite bearish comments from Credit Lyonnais.

The French brokerage popped in to see M&S early this week and was not impressed. Repeating its "reduce" rating, it yesterday expressed concern about the performance of M&S's 25 concept stores, which it has spent £60m refitting.

"In my view it is not the format that is going to take them forward. It is not worth the money they have spent," the Credit Lyonnais analyst, Paul Smiddy, said.

According to market gossips, M&S may have abandoned plans to roll out the format any further. Instead, they say, it is going to concentrate on updating the fascia of its stores.

True or not, Credit Lyonnais thinks M&S's present share price cannot be justified by its fundamentals. However, the shares ended 3p higher at 246p. Market professionals reckon that M&S is benefiting from the flight out of technology and telecom stocks.

After Thursday's brief respite, leading shares fell back to 16-month lows as gloom around technology and telecom shares deepened after profits warnings from computing group Sun MicroSystems and mobile phone maker Motorola.

In the tech sector, things were worse. Rocked by the warnings from Sun Microsystems and Motorola, the FTSE Techmark 100 dropped 44.65 points to 2,295.66 - a record low.

CMG was among the worst affected, falling 110p to 690p ahead of Monday's full year figures, while chip designer ARM Holdings , which counts Motorola among its customers, slipped 15.5p to 334.5p.

Other tech sufferers included Psion , which closed 16.25p weaker at 156.75p, and ARC International , 20p weaker at 172p, with professional investors said to be aggressively selling the stock short.

Elsewhere, telecoms equipment marker Marconi fell 32.5p to 484.5p, hit by a downgrade from Goldman Sachs.

It was not all doom and gloom. Royal Bank of Scotland advanced 31p to £15.60p, thanks to a Schroder Salomon Smith Barney upgrade. Lifting its rating to "buy" from "outperform" previously, the broker said it expected RBoS to post strong results next week.

Buyers were also in good sup ply for Standard Chartered , up 14p to £10.45, as analysts continued to wax lyrical about Wednesday's full-year figures.

Lower down the market, golf club operator Clubhaus gained 9.5p to 49.5 on speculation that takeover talks with its mystery predator - widely believed to be Compass International Partners - are close to a successful conclusion. The gossips reckon Clubhaus has agreed to a 60p per share bid.

The widening of the foot and mouth epidemic had dealers casting around to find potential victims. Sausage skin maker Devro , down 0.5p to 56p and milk producer Dairy Crest , off 11.5p to 256p, were among those fingered.

Racecourse owner Arena Leisure was also under pressure but for completely different reasons. Rumours that its bid for the media rights to UK horse racing - through the Go Racing consortium - had hit difficulties saw it shares end 4p lighter at 103.5p.

Reflective ink specialist Reflec was also in demand, rising 1.5p to 9.5p after an upbeat trading statement. Company watchers are convinced Reflec is close to signing a major deal with a supplier of paints to the automotive industry.

webTitle: Video games publisher's stock tipped to rise

fields.headline: At this price?  Eidos
fields.trailText: Despite continued hard times for most technology stocks, Eidos, the video games publisher, has been tipped by some as a stock worth buying cheap, in anticipation of an explosion in the games console market.
fields.body:
Despite continued hard times for most technology stocks, Eidos, the video games publisher, has been tipped by some as a stock worth buying cheap, in anticipation of an explosion in the games console market.

Some early estimates have predicted that combined sales of Sony's PlayStation2 and Microsoft's Xbox could quickly rise to as as much as 140m units a year. On the back of such forecasts, investment magazine Investors Chronicle yesterday named Eidos - which has 19 titles in development for PS2 and nine for Xbox - as a share tip of the week.

As a result, the stock rose 19p yesterday to 274p. However, while the hi-tech heavyweights Sony and Microsoft prepare for mortal combat, their initial battlefield - the US - has entered a period of economic slowdown which is likely to hit the leisure retail sector harder than most.

Some analysts still claim growth in global console sales could be 15-20% a year, but Laurent Gras, of Eidos's house broker Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein, is more measured. He forecasts an increase for European and US sales - dampened by the slowdown - of just 8%. Furthermore, given the drought in sales last year, he suggests this would, at best, take revenues back to 1999 levels.

That said, Eidos has worked hard to develop its catalogue and reduce its reliance on the successful Tomb Raider games series.

Company results for the year to April - a period in which Eidos has issued three profits warnings - will undoubtedly make grim reading but up-beat analysts insist that the bad news is already built into the share price, and there may be good times ahead.

Whether it will be an Eidos game that captures the public's imagination as the new-generation consoles appear in the high street remains to be seen. Certainly the company is as technically able to produce a soar-away success as any other publisher, but for investors it remains an extremely high risk stock.

fields.headline: Go-Ahead hit by 'unwarranted' bid
fields.standfirst: Rail company rises above £6m struggle to turn in 13% rise in profit
fields.trailText: Rail company rises above £6m struggle to turn in 13% rise in profit.
fields.body:
A hostile French takeover bid cost the Go-Ahead group, operator of rail commuter services in London, £6m in exceptional charges but it was able to report a 13% rise in half yearly earnings yesterday.

Professor Sir Richard Halliday, Go-Ahead's chairman, said that the move by the French state-owned company, C3D, still rankled. He described it as an unwarranted bid, which did not offer best value to the company's shareholders.

Go-Ahead's interim pre-tax profit rose to £24.8m from £22m a year ago. Earnings per share rose by 14.6% to 35.4p, and an interim dividend of 4.3p is proposed, up 13% from last year.

Go-Ahead has won the contract to operate the important London south central franchise from the French company, Connex, though a final deal has yet to be agreed with the strategic rail authority. Go-Ahead also operates the busy cross-London Thameslink service.

Sir Frederick admitted that Thameslink and Thames Trains, a third franchise, had not escaped the consequences of the Hatfield rail crash.

"Clearly our passengers have had to endure unbearable overcrowding and delay and they do not suffer in silence," he said.

He explained that systems had been set up to compensate passengers and to try to alleviate the worst difficulties. He conceded that the effects of disruption in terms of lost custom would be expected to continue for some time.

Sir Frederick said Go-Ahead was negotiating an early transfer of the Connex franchise. Go-Ahead has been granted a 20-year franchise by the SRA, but there are handover problems with Connex which must be resolved. The most important is how much Connex will receive in compenation for relinquishing its franchise earlier than required.

An important component of the company's strategy is the increasing need for public transport in London, but facilities for public transport, according to Go-Ahead are inadequate, highlighted by the fact that the expansion of rail services between north and south London will not be completed until 2008.

The company also reported a strong performance in its bus and aviation business, which was boosted by its recent acquisiton of Midland Airport Services and BMI British Midland's ground handling services.

fields.headline: Trade deficit at record high
fields.trailText: Britain's trade deficit with the world ballooned to a record £29bn last year, the largest shortfall between exports and imports since records began more than 300 years ago.
fields.body:
Britain's trade deficit with the world ballooned to a record £29bn last year, the largest shortfall between exports and imports since records began more than 300 years ago.

The main cause was a record £27bn trade deficit with countries outside the European Union according to data published yesterday by the office for national statistics.

Exporters have been complaining that sterling's strength against the euro is cutting into exports to Europe, but the ONS figures showed the trade gap with the rest of Europe gradually closing last year.

In December, the EU deficit stood at less than £0.1bn, while the non-EU deficit was £2.8, another record. For 2000 as a whole the EU shortfall was just £1.7bn - the lowest annual deficit since 1982.

The ONS also revealed fresh estimates of growth in the last three months of 2000, which showed the first signs of a slowdown in consumer spending. Household consumption grew by 0.7% over the quarter to stand at 3.3% over the same quarter a year ago, the lowest annual rate since the beginning of 1997.

"It should provide some comfort to those members of the MPC who have been anxious to see a slowdown in private spending to make room for the government's planned increases in public spending," said Jonathan Loynes, UK economist at Capital Economics.

The contrasting fortunes of EU and non-EU trade is something of a puzzle for economists. The ONS said that a large part of the improvement in the EU trade shortfall has been surging prices for UK oil exports to the rest of the EU.

"Without the trade in oil, the EU deficit last year would have been £9.8bn last year," an ONS statistician said.

Oil may also account for some of the deterioration in the non-EU deficit, according to Danny Gabay, UK economist at JP Morgan. Oil prices surged from $25 a barrel at the start of last year to over $38 at their peak in the autumn.

The ONS also published data showing the dollar is the UK's most common trading currency after sterling, well ahead of the euro. Just under a third of UK imports are priced in dollars, and 27% of exports. The comparable figures for the euro are 23% and 19%.

US multinationals that insist their UK subsidiaries price in dollars account for some of the dollar's popularity. But the euro has been boosted by Japanese multinationals adopting it as their preferred currency.

 The governor of the Bank of England, Sir Eddie George, said yesterday that he was a "euro-pragmatist" rather than a eurosceptic.

"The debate is much narrower than the extremes you hear from people who are committed pro-euro membership or committed anti-euro membership," Sir Eddie said. "My own view is that the arguments are quite finely balanced."

webTitle: We're on the road to nowhere

fields.headline: We're on the road to nowhere
fields.standfirst: Equities travel little in two years
fields.trailText: Equities travel little in two years
fields.body:
The only things missing are the "meltdown" headlines. The markets are stressed, and few in the City are expecting any sort of relief in the short term. On Tuesday, the FTSE 100 index fell back through the 6,000 level for the first time in 16 months. In fact, in broad terms equity prices have done no better than travel sideways for more than two years.

Yesterday, as the Dow Jones industrial average stepped a further 200 points lower and the Nasdaq 100 index fell below 2,000 points for the first time since January 1999 - compared with a high of close to 5,000 - there was another dose of virulent hi-tech angst.

Motorola in the United States, having already issued a first-quarter profits warning, has now fessed up to the fact that it is likely to make a loss at the operating level during the first three months of the year. Everyone knew this mobile handset and semiconductor chip maker was "troubled", but when it started to revise down its own forecasts on total mobile sales around the globe yesterday, it was time for every big telecoms-related company on both sides of the Atlantic to take a bath.

And just to rub it in, Intel vice-president and general manager Hans Geyer stood up at a conference in Cannes and said of the mobile telephone business: "We're facing a situation where an industry is heading for bankruptcy ... even before a 3G [third-generation mobile] call is made."

Meanwhile, Orange is still sitting 12% below the price institutions paid France Télécom the week before last for a 15% stake. It may be a great brand, with great commercial prospects against its competition. The shares are probably cheap on a medium to long-term view. But the immediate effect of this £5bn initial public offering has been to kill the general flotation market stone dead.

For those already on the market, confidence could not be more fragile. The atmosphere is such that a big, established computer services group such as CMG - which is also a member of the Footsie - fell almost 14% yesterday simply on a rumour that a poor trading statement is on the way.

The overall market capitalisation of the telecoms sector has halved to £200bn over the past year. The banking sector, at just over £250bn, recently regained is place as the City's most important group of companies. Even here, valuations have been heavily supported over recent months by takeover hopes - and, correctly, Stephen Byers has now rather deflated that speculation by sending Lloyds TSB to the competition commission.

Over the past six months, the London market as a whole has fallen 12%. Unless there is a sudden improvement in sentiment, we should expect to see a wave of sackings in the City over the coming months. The effects on the wider economy will be very real.

Monster talk

When working at his Philadelphia base, Glaxo SmithKline's boss Jean-Pierre Garnier is said to enjoy nipping out alone for a juicy lamb souvlaki at a local Greek restaurant.

The cerebral Frenchman is not a sociable type - he dislikes the press and endures talking to the City as a barely necessary evil.

In almost unprecedented exposure, he was coaxed out of his shell twice this week - first for annual results, then for a major update and research and development.

These rare appearances threw up some telling points about last year's merger of Glaxo Wellcome and Smith- Kline Beecham.

Mr Garnier and his team discussed plans to break up research and development operations into small centres of excellence. These, it was said, offer all the advantages enjoyed by small biotechnology companies. But this strategy blows away the carefully spun justification for the merger - which was that sheer size, and economies of scale, are crucial in researching and developing medicines.

At the same time, it emerged that Glaxo had been approached as a poten tial marketing partner for AstraZeneca's new heart drug, Crestor.

It is remarkable that AstraZeneca, one of the top five pharmaceutical companies in the world, feels it lacks the marketing muscle to distribute this key product itself.

Glaxo's real commercial advantage is simple - it has more than 8,000 salesmen in the crucial US market, enough to visit each doctor every week.

As the industry consolidates, it is quickly reaching a point where marketing and advertising are more important than technology - in other words, a big company with a weak drug can beat a medium-sized company with a superior drug, simply because it can shout louder, and offer more freebies, when trying to win over doctors.

In a rare moment of candour on Thursday, Mr Garnier described Glaxo as a "financial monster". That could turn out to be a very apt phrase.

fields.headline: Giantkillers and veterans take Oliviers
fields.trailText: It was the day of giantkillers and veterans at yesterday's Laurence Olivier awards, the most comprehensive honours list for the London theatre.
fields.body:
It was the day of giantkillers and veterans at yesterday's Laurence Olivier awards, the most comprehensive honours list for the London theatre.

Marie Jones's short Irish two-hander, Stones in His Pockets, beat works by Alan Ayckbourn and Alan Plater to be comedy of the year. Conleth Hill, one of just two actors in the cast, won the best actor award.

The neglected, 20-year-old Merrily We Roll Along by the veteran composer-lyricist Stephen Sondheim improbably carried off the gong for best new musical plus two other prizes. He defeated two of the biggest names in musicals, Andrew Lloyd Webber for The Beautiful Game and Cameron Mackintosh for The Witches of Eastwick.

Hill had to beat his stage partner, Sean Campion, who had also been shortlisted for best actor. The other three actors on the shortlist were Michael Gambon for his tramp in Harold Pinter's The Caretaker, Simon Russell-Beale for Hamlet and Bill Nighy for his role in the play Blue/Orange.

News of Hill's win was altruistically broken to him by Campion after a performance in Canada, where they are getting ready for a Broadway run of the international hit which began life at the tiny Tricycle theatre in Kilburn, north London.

The duo play all 15 roles in the comedy, which is set during the shooting of a fictional Hollywood film in Ireland. Accepting her best play award, Jones said: "I wrote it for two actors because we didn't have any money".

Sondheim's work, said ironically at the ceremony to have "taken 17 years to become best new musical", was written in 1981 between Sweeney Todd and Sunday in the Park With George. Two of its performers, Daniel Evans and Samantha Spiro, collected best musical actor and actress awards.

The third triumphant production, taking four awards, was the Royal National Theatre's version of the 85-year-old playwright Arthur Miller's tragedy All My Sons.

Julie Walters was declared best actress for her portrayal of the mother, beating among others Jessica Lange for Long Day's Journey Into Night and Helen Mirren for Orpheus Descending. She called her award "the biggest, fattest cherry on the loveliest cake".

The production's remaining awards went to Howard Davies (director), Ben Daniels (supporting actor) and William Dudley (set designer).

Other Oliviers went to: Pauline Flanagan (in Dolly West's Kitchen, by David Hare, for best supporting actress); Singin' in the Rain (West Yorkshire Playhouse and National, for outstanding musical production); Joe Penhall (for Blue/Orange, best new play).

The Royal Opera's The Greek Passion (best new opera production); Deborah Colker (choreography in Mix, for outstanding achievement in dance); and Compagnie Montalvo-Hervieu's Le Jardin Io Io Ito Ito at the Barbican (best new dance production).

The other three actors on the shortlist were Michael Gambon for his tramp in Harold Pinter's The Caretaker, Simon Russell-Beale for Hamlet and Bill Nighy for his role in the play Blue/Orange. News of Hill's win was altruistically broken to him by Campion after a performance in Canada, where they are getting ready for a Broadway run of the international hit which began life at the tiny Tricycle theatre in Kilburn, north London. The duo play all 15 roles in the comedy, which is set during the shooting of a fictional Hollywood film in Ireland. Accepting her best play award, Jones said: "I wrote it for two actors because we didn't have any money". Sondheim's work, said ironically at the ceremony to have "taken 17 years to become best new musical", was written in 1981 between Sweeney Todd and Sunday in the Park With George. Two of its performers, Daniel Evans and Samantha Spiro, collected best musical actor and actress awards. The third triumphant production, taking four awards, was the Royal National Theatre's version of the 85-year-old playwright Arthur Miller's tragedy All My Sons. Julie Walters was declared best actress for her portrayal of the mother, beating among others Jessica Lange for Long Day's Journey Into Night and Helen Mirren for Orpheus Descending. She called her award "the biggest, fattest cherry on the loveliest cake". The production's remaining awards went to Howard Davies (director), Ben Daniels (supporting actor) and William Dudley (set designer). Other Oliviers went to: Pauline Flanagan (in Dolly West's Kitchen, by David Hare, for best supporting actress); Singin' in the Rain (West Yorkshire Playhouse and National, for outstanding musical production); Joe Penhall (for Blue/Orange, best new play). The Royal Opera's The Greek Passion (best new opera production); Deborah Colker (choreography in Mix, for outstanding achievement in dance); and Compagnie Montalvo-Hervieu's Le Jardin Io Io Ito Ito at the Barbican (best new dance production).

fields.headline: Turkish lira loses 36%
fields.trailText: In another day of financial turmoil, the Turkish lira lost a further 10% of its value against the dollar yesterday, breaching the crucial level of 1m to the American dollar.
fields.byline: Chris Morris  in Istanbul and Mark Atkinson
fields.body:
In another day of financial turmoil, the Turkish lira lost a further 10% of its value against the dollar yesterday, breaching the crucial level of 1m to the American dollar.

While IMF officials met in Ankara to find a way out of the financial crisis, President Bush rang from Washington to offer his support to Turkey's prime minister, Bulent Ecevit.

There were growing demands among the public for a big government reshuffle to find a scapegoat for the chaos unleashed in the political row between the Mr Ecevit and President Ahmet Necdet Sezer over the pace of an anti-corruption drive. Deputy prime minister Mesut Yilmaz said the government planned a shake-up of economic management. There were some positive signs amid the chaos, however. Inter-bank lending rates, which had reach 5000% earlier in the week, eased further, and the Istanbul stock exchange rose again.

Analysts said the tourism sector had performed particularly well amid expectations that the cheaper lira would attract foreign visitors.

But at a closing level of 1,079,000 to the dollar last night, the lira has lost 36% of its value in two days, and is threatening to suck in imported inflation, wrecking the government's dreams of a single-digit rate of price rises by the end of 2002.

The decision to float the currency was supported by the IMF, but it destroyed the centrepiece of a programme of disinflation and structural reform, which has been backed by $11bn (£7.6bn) of IMF funds over the last 14 months.

The government has already admitted that it will have to revise its inflation targets.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText:
Vauxhall plants hit by strike
Production at Vauxhall car factories was badly disrupted yesterday when thousands of workers joined a strike aimed at reversing a decision to end vehicle assembly at one of the company's UK plants.
fields.body:
Vauxhall plants hit by strike
Production at Vauxhall car factories was badly disrupted yesterday when thousands of workers joined a strike aimed at reversing a decision to end vehicle assembly at one of the company's UK plants.

The TGWU said its walkout at Ellesmere Port and Luton was supported 100%. Members of other unions refused to cross picket lines. Production of around 400 cars was lost by the strike, which will be followed by a ban on overtime this weekend.

No cars were built at Luton, where production of the Vectra is due to end in a year's time with the loss of 2,000 jobs, while assembly of Astras in Ellesmere Port was badly disrupted. Union leaders held talks today with Vauxhall chairman Nick Reilly and said they would continue pressing for a rethink on the future of Luton.

Overpaid tax at total of £5.7bn
Treasury coffers will be £5.7bn richer this year because millions of people fail to take up all the tax breaks available to them, a study said yesterday. Nine out of 10 taxpayers, as many as 41m people, are thought to be an average £140 worse off because of overpaid taxes.

The TaxAction investigation on behalf of independent financial advisers said financial inertia and a lack of understanding of the tax regime was to blame. The figures come despite a high profile advertising campaign by the Inland Revenue based on its now-retired cartoon character, Hector.

Sporting Index talks fail
Sports and leisure group Enic yesterday confirmed that talks to acquire spread-betting firm Sporting Index had collapsed.

The breakdown of the deal, revealed by The Guardian last month, was due to disagreement over price and Sporting Index's uncertainty over Enic's plans to buy a major stake in Tottenham Hotspur football club. Enic recently confirmed that long delayed talks to acquire bookmaker Victor Chandler International had ended in failure.

230 Polaroid jobs to go
More than 230 workers are to lose their jobs following cutbacks by US corporation Polaroid, it was announced yesterday.

Polaroid said it was declaring a total of 235 redundancies at its Vale of Leven plant near Dumbarton, on the Clyde, which employs a total of 850 people. The job losses, which will be among manufacturing and administration staff, are part of 1,000 job cuts globally over the next three months.

Fraudster sentenced
A former financial adviser was jailed yesterday after being found guilty of fraudulently inducing 18 clients to write cheques totalling £145,000 to his personal bank account.

Malcolm Peter Millward, 50, pleaded guilty to offences uncovered during a two-year investigation by the main City regulator.

He was sentenced to two years and nine months at Nottingham crown court after he admitted dishonestly concealing material facts, making false statements and deceiving clients in order to obtain deposits from them, and abusing his position as a financial adviser to use the money he had obtained from victims to fund his own lifestyle.

webTitle: Mozambique pleads for new flood aid

fields.headline: Mozambique pleads for new flood aid
fields.standfirst: Special report: Mozambique floods
fields.trailText: The authorities in Mozambique said yesterday that they urgently need extra aircraft and money for fuel to evacuate and feed thousands of people stranded by flooding in the central provinces.
fields.body:
The authorities in Mozambique said yesterday that they urgently need extra aircraft and money for fuel to evacuate and feed thousands of people stranded by flooding in the central provinces.

Joao Zamisa, head of planning at the National Institute for Disaster Management, said Mozambique needs more planes to evacuate people and transport food.

"We also need the reinforcement of resources for the rescue operations. Some of the boats are grounded because of lack of fuel," Mr Zamisa said.

Only one helicopter was being used to rescue stranded people, while four others plus two fixed-wing aircraft were ferrying food and medicine to the 17,000 people now living in camps established by the government in flood-hit areas.

Mr Zamisa said up to 10,000 people needed to be moved to safer areas as water levels in the region continue to rise.

Mozambique has appealed for £20m in aid as it battles against floods that have killed 41 people and affected nearly 400,000 people, including the 80,000 made homeless so far.

The former Portuguese colony is still recovering from floods that killed about 700 people and made 500,000 people homeless last year.

That flooding prompted one of the biggest aid and rescue missions in southern Africa.

Since January, Mozambique has endured renewed flooding in the central Zambesi valley after several rivers burst their banks, affecting the provinces of Tete, Zambezia, Sofala and Manica.

Mr Zamisa reported that chlorine was in short supply and that health conditions in the countryside and areas around towns were deteriorating fast because the rain had flooded wells.

In a statement, the disaster management institute said that while this year's floods are not on the same scale as last year's a lot of work still has to be done in affected areas in order to stop the current emergency from turning into another catastrophe.

The central Zambesi valley is bearing the brunt of this year's flooding, which has swept away homes and submerged thousands of hectares of farmland.

The agriculture ministry estimates that 44,000 peasant farmers have been affected by the floodwaters, and that 27,000 hectares (67,000 acres) of crops have been lost, mainly staple foods such as maize, rice and cassava.

Mr Zamisa said that heavy rains in neighbouring Malawi, Zambia and Zimbabwe threatened to swell the Zambesi, Pungoe, Revué and Ligonha rivers, which all flow into Mozambique.

The planning chief said that the government was closely monitoring the situation near the port city of Beira, where the water levels of the Buzi and Save rivers were rising, also because of heavy rains in neighbouring Zimbabwe.

fields.headline: Calculated risk
fields.standfirst: The readers' editor on... the art of publishing without being damned
fields.trailText: On the art of publishing without being damned.
fields.body:
With all that can be said, justly, against journalists, there is one kind of journalist to whom civilisation owes a very great debt, namely the brave and honest reporter who unearths and makes public unpleasant facts, cases of injustice, cruelty, corruption, which the authorities would like to keep hidden, and which even the average reader would prefer not to be compelled to think about. - WH Auden: A Certain World, 1970

Here is a question: is it ethical for a newspaper which campaigns for the reform of the libel laws to seek to use those laws to its advantage? Isn't that what a newspaper is doing when it says to its legal advisers, "Yes, but will they sue?" - and then takes a calculated risk that they will not, and goes ahead with publication?

An element in the calculation may be the huge costs involved in pressing accusations of libel through the courts. To what extent should the nature of the person or organisation be considered? Is the importance of the story worth the risk? Is it a matter of imperative public interest? Do we believe that what we want to say is true?

A few more questions: are the libel laws as they exist more a tool to be used by the rich or powerful to smother the legitimate activities of the intrepid reporter, described above by Auden, than a necessary way to protect the innocent? Or are they really, in their present, rigorous form, much stronger, for instance, than those in the United States, a necessary brake on an irresponsible press?

Calculating the cost of defending and possibly losing libel actions in the English courts can induce dizzy spells. A newspaper's sense of purpose and resolve is tested in these sums. It has to be sure it is right. Many may believe - some Guardian journalists do - that the paper carries insurance against libel. It does not. It used to but the premiums themselves became punitive. When the paper goes to court to fight a libel action it does so knowing that the cost of losing (and sometimes the cost of winning) could represent a severe financial blow.

We shall come back to the question with which I started in a minute, but an essential thing to know is that the decision to publish is the editor's alone, and never the lawyer's. Similarly, it is his decision whether to concede or fight in the face of accusations of libel. It was his decision to fight the libel actions unsuccessfully brought against the paper by the former Conservative MPs Neil Hamilton and Jonathan Aitken. To take decisions of that kind you need great confidence in the journalists involved.

Last week I described the way in which the paper is trying to ensure that everyone on the editorial staff has a basic knowledge of the law affecting journalism. The second of its sessions for newly arrived journalists took place this week, and there will soon be open masterclasses that all Guardian journalists will be able to attend.

The idea, as I explained, is to see that individual journalists have reasonably efficient alarm systems, that they know, at least, when to exercise caution, and when to consult the very good legal advice that is always at hand.

One of the paper's most experienced investigative journalists says that learning about the law, the laws of defamation, and those covering official secrecy and contempt in particular, is essential if the journalist is to fulfil one of his or her essential functions, which is to challenge these laws. "When I started, journalism seemed to consist of finding out things that the lawyer then told you you couldn't put in the paper. I started from the premise that freedom of speech was a good thing and that the law was a series of obstacles to be negotiated, and that could be negotiated if you knew what you were doing.

"So basically I believe that the journalist should have a confrontational rather than a compliant relationship with the law. The law is one of the key battlegrounds on which we fight for freedom of speech. But the only way you can take on the law is by knowing the law."

Another investigative reporter emphasised the need to ensure the highest possible quality of evidence before coming to the question whether or not to publish serious allegations against an individual or organisation: "Short of an admission from the subject, the best is, of course, irrefutable documentary evidence." He concluded his comments to me this way: "This is not to advocate excessive caution, just eternal vigilance."

The editor of the paper says that the first question is: can we successfully defend this? Could we defend it if we went to court? "Occasionally you might think, 'Will they sue?' but I don't think that is exploiting the libel laws."

The lawyers point out that it is not their job to prevent publication but to help publish as much as possible. Getting the stuff into the paper is the general idea.

webTitle: The last word on   Religious schools

fields.headline: The last word on   Religious schools
fields.standfirst: Fanatics have their dreams, wherewith they weave a paradise for a sect -  Keats
fields.trailText: Fanatics have their dreams, wherewith they weave a paradise for a sect - Keats
fields.body:
This week the government announced £1bn investment in scientific research - mainly into biotechnologies, with their potential for advances in medicine and general human welfare. Reflective taxpayers could think of few better uses for their money than investment in the future of us all, so the initiative is welcome.

Last week the government announced increased funding for religion-based schools. The contradiction with the foregoing is dramatic. Adherence to ancient traditions of religious belief is divided among many differing and often competing minorities in our society. Giving them taxpayers' money to run schools in which new generations are indoctrinated in these varying and exclusive ancient belief systems is fundamentally wrong on many counts, chief among them the following three.

First, by using our tax money to subsidise religion-based schools, the government forces those many of us who are opposed to superstitious beliefs and practices to contribute against our wills to their perpetuation. Religion is a matter of private conscience and choice, and as such is not a proper target for public support. If minorities wish to have their children taught in schools which premise belief in gods, astrology, space aliens or elves, they should pay for it themselves.

Second, religion is harmful both to individuals and society when it becomes publicly institutionalised. It harms individuals by distorting human nature through repressive moralities and the inculcation of false beliefs, fears and hopes. It harms society by causing conflicts, wars and persecutions, as everywhere evidenced by religious history including the present. It ought therefore to remain in the private sphere along with other personal matters, like sexual preference (perhaps it needs its own Section 28).

It is unacceptable to people who, for these reasons, are opposed to religion, to see young children being indoctrinated into it. Children should emphatically not be taught as "facts" the myths and legends of ancient religious traditions: to do this to anyone unable to evaluate their credibility is a form of brainwashing or even indeed abuse. Public funds should never be used to that end.

Third, by giving money to a variety of religious organisations - Christian, Muslim, Jewish, Sikh, Hindu - historically and theologically at odds (which indeed mutually blaspheme one another's faiths), the government is helping to entrench divisions. Children of all backgrounds ought to be educated together for greater mutual understanding, not educated apart in religious ghettos, thereby perpetuating the exclusivity and mistrust which must arise if people believe their religion is the only true one and everyone else is wrong - perhaps even that they are dangerous fanatics.

The variety of religious traditions should of course be taught in schools - but as historical phenomena alongside astrology, magic, and other fads of mankind's earlier ignorance. This would not please the religions, who are avid to indoctrinate young people since that is one of their chief means of survival. Few who first meet religion in adulthood are able to take it seriously; priests know that to keep the old faiths alive, they have to get their hands on children. Some religion-based schools are good because they are highly selective - not just (despite disclaimers) in obvious but in covert ways.

Keen, supportive, educated middle-class parents are a strongly self-selecting group. Small class sizes play a crucial part. The government ought to put real resources into making all state schools as good as the best church schools, and not supporting the latter as a cheap alternative to private education for middle-class parents who cannot or will not afford it.

No doubt the government believes it is encouraging good education while showing a kindly face to the different traditions in our society. But the reality is otherwise. It is troubling to find the government funding past superstitions and future science simultaneously, as if unaware of the dramatic inconsistency, and unconcerned about the fact that it is using public money - including the taxes of the many who are emphatically unwilling - to do the former. There is a human rights implication here, which someone would do well to explore in our courts.

webTitle: Are there prairies at the bottom of your garden?

fields.headline: Are there prairies at the bottom of your garden?
fields.trailText: A garden from a hundred packets of seeds
fields.body:
If you look at the lists of gardening books in print, you will find that the volumes devoted to perennials notably outnumber those concerned with annuals and biennials. And if you look at the volumes devoted to annuals, you may well find that they are not really devoted to annuals at all, but to bedding plants which may or may not, strictly speaking, be annuals.

And this fact has some significance. For a part of the neglect of annuals in the gardening press may be put down to an ancient dislike of bedding plants, which were associated with badly run parks. According to this prejudice - for that is what it has become - the foundation of good gardening is the abandoning of bedding plants in favour of perennials and shrubs. And according to a recent, more extreme version, the foundation of good gardening is the abandonment of everything (shrubs, annuals, bulbs, the lot) except perennials: the aim is to create vast perennial ecologies, prairies at the bottom of the garden.

Do you believe in prairies? They may prove an awesome undertaking, and perhaps in the end a somewhat boring prospect; a horror, potentially, if not done well. But then, the same applies to any gardening style.

My strong preference is for a garden, as it were, "open to all the talents" - and that is why I always pay particular attention to the minority of garden writers who look seriously at annuals and biennials. This has nothing to do with bedding schemes (which I am very happy to see done well), but everything to do with getting to know and use the full range of possible plants available.

Some of these flowers are going to die on us after one (annuals) or two (biennials) years. If this fact is too dismaying to contemplate, you have an annuals problem. If the dismay derives simply from the thought that all your planting will have to be done over again, you are overlooking a range of obliging plants which will indeed come back again, and in profusion. An obvious example is (no 41) the common Foxglove, Digitalis purpurea , which will seed itself and come back, being biennial, every other year, and will grow happily under trees and bushes. Excessive devotion to perennials would cut you off from this pleasure, as from the delights of (no 42) Honesty, Lunaria annua . Both the purple Honesty and the pink Foxglove have their white versions. Do you want to live without these? Do you want to live without Honesty?

Another biennial which we allow to colonise a clump of blackthorns is the beautiful umbellifer, (no 43) Smyrnium perfoliatum . When it is performing, the upper part of the plant turns a yellowy green, so that a drift of Smyrnium gives the illusion of a pool of sunlight in a wood.

A similar yellowy green is offered by another umbellifer, or annual herb for full sunlight, (no 44) Dill or Anethum graveoleus . It is a colour found useful by hip florists, who also turn to a self-sowing perennial, (no 45) Lady's Mantle or Alchemilla mollis . Chiltern Seeds offer a version of this called A. mollis "Robustica" , which is the one for cut flowers.

And in the context of so much yellow, and such prolific self-sowing, I must mention a perennial member of the poppy family, Chelidonium majus , and its double version, (no 46) C. majus "Flore Pleno". Chelidonium , known as the Greater Celandine, is a flower of the hedgerow. My seed I collected outside Holy Trinity Church, Brompton Road, beloved of evangelical city slickers (the church, that is). The flower may be too evangelical for some tastes: it certainly spreads the word.

If one was told of an annual which grew to around six feet, had flowers like pink coal-scuttles and smelt of 1950s hair oil, would the prospect be attractive? I like (no 47) Impatiens glandulifera , or, as Chiltern Seeds has it, I. roylei - Himalayan balsam - well enough. It reminds me of the banks of the Wear in Durham, with its exploding seed capsules. But it is super-prolific.

Turn to that essential work of garden reference, Annuals And Biennials by Roger Phillips and Martyn Rix (Macmillan, 1999), and you will find eight pages with illustrations devoted to Impatiens . And these are by no means all Busy Lizzies (versions of Impatiens walleriana ) but include many yellow-flowered species from damp places in China, and some with no names yet.

Like the other volumes by Phillips and Rix, Annuals And Biennials shows photographs not only of the individual plants but also in many cases of the way these grow in their spectacular natural habitats, such as the Mojave desert, Cape Province, or the Himalayan foothills. One gets an idea - whether rightly or not - of the way these flowers might be persuaded to grow naturally in the garden.

Any flower can be made to look ridiculous, through ridiculous planting. One remembers the solemn way in which borders were edged with alternating plants of alyssum and lobelia. Yet (no 48) Sweet Alyssum, Lobularia maritima , grows happily enough when taken out of this context, and allowed to seed itself quietly in some crack or other, at the foot of a wall, or in some paving. And I like finding (no 49) Lobelia erinus growing where some pot or other once stood.

This is one way in which annuals make themselves a perennial feature of the garden. That is not to say that we should expect them all to oblige in the same way, to relieve us of the obligation to think things afresh. It is just that some flowers, such as the charming blue Woodruff, (no 50) Asperula orientalis, can be relied on to remember to renew themselves, even if we forget.

 All the seeds mentioned above may be had from Chiltern Seeds, Bortree Stile, Ulverstone, Cumbria LA12 7PB, or www.chilternseeds.co.uk

fields.headline: The undiscovered country
fields.standfirst: Roger Ballen's pictures of poor whites shocked and infuriated South Africa.  Esther Addley can see why
fields.trailText: Roger Ballen's pictures of poor whites shocked and infuriated South Africa. Esther Addley can see why
fields.body:
The most striking thing about Roger Ballen's photographs is the immediate impulse many of them provoke to look away. An American who has worked in South Africa for two decades, Ballen appears to have spent his time seeking out that country's most desperate, sorry individuals to photograph. From the remarkable documentary portraits of his early work to his more recent, cartoonishly stylised tableaux in the shacks of the poor, Ballen's images are compelling, powerful, haunting.

It is not simply that Ballen has chosen to represent such abject poverty so unsparingly. Rather, much of the power in his work lies in the fact that his subjects (almost all of them white) are often so odd as to be almost unrecognisable as real people. From the blank and drooling twins snapped in Western Transvaal in 1993 to the Deputy Dawg-like prison official with oversized features, they seem almost comically other.

Outland, a new exhibition at the Shine Gallery in London, shows that in recent years, Ballen has moved away from naturalistic portraiture to a more metaphysical representation of "the nature of chaos, death, my relationship between what I think I see and what exists". The pictures feature ugly, wizened, almost ghoulish people. They wear masks, or clasp a knife or a kitten, framed by bare electrical wires or thrift-shop portraits of family members. If this is Ballen's metaphysical vision, it is a dark one indeed.

The photographer has been heavily criticised in his adopted homeland for, he believes, exposing the myth of prosperous white South Africa: "They show something that people don't want to see." Others claim he exploits those he photographs - wheeling out a succession of freaks and feeding on the morbid, repulsed fascination of his audience. It is a charge Ballen refutes with weary exasperation. "In England, if I sat on the tube one day, I think 95% of the time I could come up with very similar images. I'm trying to find a universal class of people."

He is frustrated that the image that has had the most positive response in his career is a simple portrait of a black labourer. "People who don't understand my photography look at that one picture, and that's the only image they can relate to because it has a bit of romance to it. It doesn't ask too many questions."

A New Yorker by birth, Ballen developed a love of photography in his teens when his mother worked with the legendary Magnum studio. After university he spent five years hitch-hiking around the world before settling in South Africa, where he met his future wife and was able to practise his other great love, geology. He earns his living in the mining trade and undertakes no commercial photography, but the two disciplines, he says, sit happily together. "I look for mineral properties, evaluate them and make a feasibility study to determine whether it's viable to make a mine out of them. You're looking at the surface and trying to go below it. My photographs are very much about layered meaning."

It is this meaning, says Ballen, that he wants to uncover, rather than making any commentary on the situation of the people he photographs. "The questions I'm asking are not dealing with the issues of South African reality. They deal with more abstract, aesthetic issues. It is important that people understand that those are the type of questions I ask myself, rather than 'is white South Africa coping with the new regime?'."

He sees himself in the tradition of Samuel Beckett or Francis Bacon, making dark representations of the human condition. But, he says, he is more open to criticism because he uses the naturalistic medium of photography. None of this quite lets Ballen off the hook, however. One photograph in Outland features three young men, all clearly with learning difficulties, posed in a grotesque dance holding vinyl singles and electrical wire. How involved were they in the creative process? The question is inescapable. Nor does his claim to be beyond politics ring entirely true: his decision to leave documentary photography came in 1994, just as apartheid ended and the representation of poor, dislocated white South Africans lost much of its ironic force.

His response is hardly calculated to assuage liberal sensibilities: "Sure, some of these people have disturbances, but I do what I can to help. They call me up all the time and ask me to come over. If they have a medical problem I'll do what I can to help." The last thing Ballen is interested in, in any case, is assuaging liberal sensibilities. "I'm not a person who lives my life for social causes. I'm living my life for existential causes."

As for exploitation: "All I can say is, pick any 10 photos out of your newspaper and ask yourself, is the photographer exploiting the subject? The issue of exploitation exists in everything humans do." That may just be the metaphysical point he is mining for.

 Outlands is at the Shine Gallery, 3 Jubilee Place, London SW3 (020-7352 4499) from February 28 to April 24.

webTitle: May the Fourth be with you

fields.headline: May the Fourth be with you
fields.standfirst: Today's politicians could learn from the RSC's stunning Henry IV, says  Michael Billington
fields.trailText: Today's politicians could learn from the RSC's stunning Henry IV, says Michael Billington
fields.body:
It is widely accepted now that Henry IV Parts One and Two are the twin summits of Shakespeare's genius. Even if Michael Attenborough's production, in its move from Stratford's Swan to London's Barbican, seems visually austere - nothing much scenically except a raked, dun-coloured stage and an overhanging screen - it is tremendous where it truly matters: in conveying the endless moral ambivalence of Shakespeare's characters.

Take Falstaff. Poets and critics who don't go to the theatre much tend to sanctify the character: Swinburne wrote of his "moral elevation" and Auden compared him to Christ. But Desmond Barrit, far more than at Stratford, brings out superbly his mix of anarchic wit and monstrous cruelty. Barrit's Falstaff is excellent company in an Eastcheap tavern. But he never lets you forget that Falstaff is also a profiteer who recruits 150 ragamuffins, con-temptuously dismisses them as "food for powder" and casually informs us that all but three have died in battle. And how can one get sentimental about a Falstaff who, in Part Two, fleeces Justice Shallow of £1,000 and then tells us he plans to treat him as a butt for Prince Harry's "continual laughter"?

By making you listen closely to the text, Attenborough highlights Shakespeare's constant moral ambiguity. The cliched view of Prince Hal is that he is a calculating creep. But the beauty of William Houston's performance is that he shows a man torn between duty and desire. The high point comes in the role-playing tavern scene when he gives Falstaff due warning that he will have finally to reject him - at which point a desperate Barrit hammers on Houston's knees crying: "Play out the play." What Houston gives us, most intelligently, is a long-term strategist seeking to extricate himself from a world of instant gratification.

The presentation of these plays as part of an unfolding cycle also lends extra richness to David Troughton's massive Henry IV. As Bolingbroke in Richard II, he emerged as a shrewd political opportunist. What comes across here is his ability to re-write history and to persuade himself that it was his "humility" that won popular allegiance. Troughton's Henry remains a crafty politician to the end: when he urges Hal "to busy giddy minds with foreign quarrels" it might be George Bush senior talking to Dubya about Iraq. But Troughton also beautifully highlights the emotional constriction of a father who, at one point, yearns to embrace his son but who instead gives him a wary pat on the shoulder.

Much could be said about this engrossing, six-hour experience: the Gloucestershire scenes, in particular, bring joyous tears to the eyes as Benjamin Whitrow's crumbling Shallow quietly patronises Peter Copley's lean, slippered and even more senile Silence. But the overwhelming feeling at the end of the day is of Shakespeare's genius in encompassing all of England in two plays and of Attenborough's success in probing his restless moral intelligence.

 In rep until April 18. Box office: 020-7638 8891.

fields.headline: Living with the enemy
fields.trailText: Last night's TV
fields.body:
You could be forgiven for thinking that it is either drugs or fine wine that inspires Jessica Stevenson and Simon Pegg to deliver the deliriously wonderful Spaced (Channel 4). After all, the world in which Daisy and Tim - their hopeless but hopeful characters - live is very like this one, only slightly weirder. How, you may wonder, can the pair deliver a comedy that can move from the achingly true scene of grown men wrestling like 10-year-olds to the arrival of mysterious Matrix-esque men-in-black trying to kidnap Daisy without coming over all naff and stupid?

From the mundane minutiae of real life to the ridiculous (and then on to the even more ridiculous), Spaced's success lies in its ability to seduce us into accepting its universe, which may be just a couple of millimetres away from our own along the raggedy measuring-tape that spans the space-time continuum. It is a place we'd like to think exists in reality and one that definitely exists in the daydreams and reveries of the audience at which Spaced is aimed. The scenes of alternate possibilities - of Daisy kicking the boys' butts in a wrestling bout à la Buffy, as opposed to meekly declining their offer of a wrestle, which she actually does - work well because they are so true. Who among us doesn't play out Things As They'd Like Them To Be - which normally involves putting the boot into an unsuspecting world? That we can take these events-that-are-not-events as seriously as any keen observation about flat-sharing or friendship is testament to the strength of Pegg and Stevenson's writing.

Their approach to the sitcom credits the viewer with intelligence, which other writers might like to note. Indeed, Spaced is one of the few programmes on television - and perhaps the only British show - that acknowledges how important popular culture, and television especially, is in people's lives. For a generation weaned on TV, Spaced is ideal viewing. Daisy typing to the music of Murder, She Wrote, or she and Tim pretending to be Shaggy and Velma from Scooby Doo, aren't silly in-jokes - they are endearing truths. In fact, Pegg and Stevenson are sober geniuses. With not a melting clock or funny woman made of cheese (not in the first episode, at least), Spaced is deliciously surreal.

fields.headline: Dunford Bridge
fields.trailText: A Country Diary
fields.body:
The recent news that the shooting rights are for sale on one of the last forbidden bastions in the southern Pennines is most interesting. Wanderers on the broad heather moors of Snailsden have always had to run the gauntlet. Its privacy has been strictly enforced; Snailsden is a byword for exclusion. The 4,000 acre-moor also has the distinction of being one of the first places to practice grouse driving, in about 1842.

In keeping with national trends, the game records for Snailsden over the last quarter century show a generally declining annual crop of grouse shot - 528 brace in 1975, 94 brace in 2000, though, of course, there are large variations from year to year. There are no public rights of way over the moor and this has long been a bone of contention, when ramblers have struck out across the line of grouse butts heading, maybe, for the far-off sentinel of the Holme Moss television mast and so upset sitting grouse. There have been periodic angry confrontations with the keeper and his beaters when trespassers have come striding across the head of Ramsden Clough, heading for the upper reaches of Winscar Reservoir.

Here, too, is the source of the River Don, on the lonely, moortop crest of Withens Edge. It starts as a trickle burbling east to flow into an arm of Winscar Reservoir almost within sight of the gamekeeper's cottage at Wetshaw Edge.

There is a hopeful note in the sale particulars, however. webTitle: Letters: Williams Shawcross is not a spy

fields.headline: I'm no spy
fields.trailText: Paul Foot is entitled to think my books "boring" and my views wrong (Comment, February 20). He also suggests I have been a British spy. This is not true.
fields.body:
Paul Foot is entitled to think my books "boring" and my views wrong (Comment, February 20). He also suggests I have been a British spy. This is not true. This was alleged by a Czech secret policeman whom I knew as the Czech education attache here when I was writing a book about Dubcek in 1969-70. Far from trying to suppress this rubbish, I wrote about it at length in the Spectator. It was easily dismissed.

More important was the attache's allegation that Jan Kavan, a courageous Czech dissident, was a communist agent. This claim, which Mr Foot rehearses but does not dismiss, was believed by rightwing Czech politicians and some gullible British journalists. I went to Prague to testify on Kavan's behalf. I am glad to say I was believed. Mr Kavan has since become Czech foreign minister.
William Shawcross
London

webTitle: Jakarta's men watch as killers run riot

fields.headline: Jakarta's men watch as killers run riot
fields.standfirst: Special report: Indonesia
fields.trailText: The pile of 30 unwrapped corpses swarming with flies and lying haphazardly behind the hospital in Sampit yesterday encapsulated the horror of the ethnic unrest sweeping central Kalimantan, in Indonesian Borneo.
fields.body:
The pile of 30 unwrapped corpses swarming with flies and lying haphazardly behind the hospital in Sampit yesterday encapsulated the horror of the ethnic unrest sweeping central Kalimantan, in Indonesian Borneo.

Few of the bodies were intact. Several had been decapitated, some had missing limbs, while the intestines of many others were spewing out of craters made by repeated machete blows. Even the hospital staff, accustomed to the stench of death after receiving more than 100 bodies in the last six days, were struggling to cope with the rancid smell, as there was no room in the mortuary.

One girl, who could not have been more than five years old, stood out. Lying slightly apart from the others, her head was attached to her neck by just a thin sinew of muscle and skin.

Her crime was that she, like all the others piled up around her, was Madurese. After almost 80 years of often rocky relations with the indigenous Dayaks, the settlers from the densely populated island of Madura, north-east of Java, are persona non grata in a region most consider to be their adopted homeland.

It is impossible to gauge how many people have been killed since the conflict flared last Sunday in Sampit, a town 480 miles north-east of Jakarta. Last night Indonesia's state news agency put the number at 200; most people in Sampit believe it is several times that.

The fact that all but a tiny handful of the fatalities are Madurese is one of the clearest signs that this is a clinical exercise in ethnic "cleansing".

There are well over 20,000 Madurese refugees living like sardines in the grounds of the Sampit local government office, but there are no similar camps full of Dayaks. And while thousands of Dayaks, armed with spears, axes and machetes, were patrolling the region yesterday, there were no reports of similar groups of Madurese warriors.

Local Dayak leaders say they are not willing to compromise with the Madurese. "We'll only be satisfied when they have all left," said Andung Rachmat, a spokesman in Sampit. "We won't allow ourselves to be trampled on anymore."

As he was speaking, the crowd around him started whooping and hollering and waving their weapons as a truck swept past parading another Madurese head.

The authorities appear to be condoning the Dayaks' tactics. No effort is made to prevent them patrolling near the main refugee camp. Police and soldiers stood watching as building after building in Sampit was razed yesterday. No member of the security forces was visible outside the main towns.

There are currently fewer than 900 police and soldiers covering the whole conflict area. Another 1,400 are due to arrive in the next 24 hours.

The provincial police commander said there was only one realistic way to end the unrest. "From our dialogue with the people, it's clear the violence will only stop when there are no more Madurese in the area," Brigadier General Bambang Pranoto said.

The government is doing extremely little for the refugees. The lucky have received two small packets of instant noodles in the last five days and a few litres of water. Many have received no food and little to drink.

"We are just eating the wind," said Bunario, who was a driver until Sunday. "A couple of children have already died of hunger."

Many refugees believe that the lack of food is a deliberate ploy by the authorities. "The government are doing all they can to encourage us to go," said Sulistiawati, a young mother of two.

No one knows how long it will take to restore calm. As Dayak gangs yesterday began systematically gutting the homes of Madurese, Gen Pranoto admitted that the violence was spreading.

It will also take days, if not weeks, to evacuate all the Madurese. Three ships are due to arrive in the next 24 hours but they will only be able to carry 7,000 people back to Java.

"Only God knows why these two groups can't live together," Gen Pranoto said. "And only God knows when this will end."

Seeds of conflict

Who are the two sides?

Indigenous Dayaks and migrants from Madura, an island north-east of Java. The first Madurese arrived in Kalimantan (the Indonesian half of Borneo) more than 75 years ago, with the majority moving in the 1960s and 70s

Why do they hate each other?

The Dayaks claim the Madurese are rude, dishonest and have usurped much of the economic and political power. The Madurese, who have a nationwide reputation of being aggressive, say the Dayaks cannot cope with outsiders being more successful than them

What sparked the current violence?

Local police say two disgruntled civil servants paid a group of Dayaks to attack a Madurese housing complex in the town of Sampit. The Madurese allegedly retaliated, which led to the mobilisation of thousands of Dayaks to chase out all the Madurese

How is the crisis likely to be resolved?

Both sides and the authorities accept that the Madurese will no longer be able to remain in central Kalimantan, and that peace will only return to the area once they have all left. This could take several weeks.

fields.headline: Hit for sex
fields.trailText: I was astonished at the high price of condoms when I arrived last year. In my home country of Australia they are less than half the price of high street chemists and supermarkets here. (Free childcare, February 22).
fields.body:
I was astonished at the high price of condoms when I arrived last year. In my home country of Australia they are less than half the price of high street chemists and supermarkets here. This could point to a reason for the high rate of teenage pregnancies (Free childcare, February 22). At almost a quid a shag, that's a big hit on the teenage budget unless one plans ahead. And teenagers often don't have the opportunity to plan ahead.
Simon Rumble
London
simon@rumble.net

webTitle: Letters: The Shoe Museum in Marinika

fields.headline: Shoe in
fields.trailText: If John Aglionby had cared to look around the Shoe Museum in Marikina City he would have found a lot more apart from some of Imelda Marcos' shoes (The shoe must go on, G2, February 21).
fields.body:
If John Aglionby had cared to look around the Shoe Museum in Marikina City he would have found a lot more apart from some of Imelda Marcos' shoes (The shoe must go on, G2, February 21). There are other shoes connected with important people or events and a history of shoemaking in the area. If the reference to the museum being in a "small, two-storey building" was meant to be disparaging, he should be aware that the building is preserved for its historical significance. The Iron Butterfly may have just "inaugurated" this museum but I was there 10 months ago.
Mick Lacey
Reading

fields.headline: Verging on the ridiculous
fields.trailText: A while ago, my neighbour hood decided we had had enough of the council cementing over our nice grass verges (Police get powers to stop home protests, February 22).
fields.body:
A while ago, my neighbour hood decided we had had enough of the council cementing over our nice grass verges (Police get powers to stop home protests, February 22). We got up a petition and took it a to the home of our local councillor, wielding placards and chanting such unmentionables as: "Don't be mean, keep them green." The protest group consisted of families with young children, the local vicar, professionals and several pensioners ... Terrorists?
Helenann Francis
Oxford
The Terrorism Act 2000 is, on George Monbiot's account (Comment, February 22), one of the most potentially dangerous pieces of legislation in a long time. Should we form a campaign for the repeal of the act - or would that itself be an act of terrorism under the terms of the act?
Terry Jones
London

If use of the Public Order Act 1986 can lead to charges for "Troops Out" posters, what is gained by the introduction of yet more discretionary police powers? How will these similarly worded amendments themselves be interpreted in time by the police?

Trying to persuade, peacefully yet forcefully, Alan Sugar to resign would presumably allow the police to act since his libel action shows how "distressed" he felt. Not dissimilarly worded sections in the 1994 Public Order Act aimed at hunt saboteurs have seen the courts extending the wordings in effect to include the doing of acts preparatory to protest such as running across an adjoining field with citronella. Little hope on that evidence of the courts interpreting these new powers restrictively so as to accord with Article 11 of the European Convention of Human Rights.
David Mead
Norwich Law School
