webTitle: Letters: Rail firms on the line

fields.headline: Rail firms on the line
fields.trailText: You report (Names considered for manslaughter charges in Hatfield crash, February 23) that neither Railtrack nor Balfour Beatty will face corporate manslaughter charges and that British Transport Police says this is because there is no legislation. But legislation is not necessary.
fields.body:
You report (Names considered for manslaughter charges in Hatfield crash, February 23) that neither Railtrack nor Balfour Beatty will face corporate manslaughter charges and that British Transport Police says this is because there is no legislation. But legislation is not necessary. A company can face charges if a sufficiently senior manager is charged with manslaughter so that his or her criminal liability can be identified with that of the company. The requirement for the common law offence of corporate manslaughter, as originally outlined by Lord Denning in a case in which he compared a company to a human body, is that the manager concerned needs to be a "controlling mind" of the company.

However the reluctance of the director of public prosecutions to bring to court any senior managers means that only a handful of corporate manslaughter cases have ever been brought. After the Southall rail crash, the DPP attempted to prosecute Great Western trains without prosecuting a senior manager alongside the company, but this was thrown out by the judge as being not possible under common law.

The real question is why the DPP is not looking at prosecuting senior managers over Hatfield? What is going to be achieved by scapegoating people who are insufficiently senior to be identified as controlling minds? Is it again a question of doing something for the sake of being seen to do something (as over Southall), rather than really holding the decision-makers to account, which is what the public wants to see happen?

You should also know that the bereaved of Ladbroke Grove are still demanding a proper consideration of corporate manslaughter charges over that disaster. So far there has been none and the letter we received giving reasons for the failure to prosecute contained serious errors of fact and omission.
Louise Christian
Solicitor for bereaved families from Southall and Ladbroke Grove rail crashes
louisec@christianf.co.uk

fields.headline: The truth about the Mail
fields.trailText: As a former Daily Mail staff journalist, I compliment Andy Beckett on his article (Mail order, G2, February 22) detailing the savage illiberalism of my old employer.
fields.body:
As a former Daily Mail staff journalist, I compliment Andy Beckett on his article (Mail order, G2, February 22) detailing the savage illiberalism of my old employer. He wonders "...whether these millions of people (readers), who are sharing the Blair boom, will continue to welcome the bleak view of Britain the paper puts out". Wearing my new hat as a media analyst, I can tell him - not for long. The readership of the much more vulnerable Mail on Sunday is already in slow, medium-term decline. (Sundays are reflective periods and the instant fixes of Mail philosophies do not bear prolonged scrutiny: result, boring newspaper).

This sense of alienation will spread to the Daily Mail when a second-term Labour government further emphasises the concept of one-nationhood and social responsibility. In my projection, the Mail, under the inflexible editorship of Paul Dacre, will be stranded in its extreme rightwing glass tower, sales will falter and then fall back in 2003 at the latest.

This is something my old Mail editor, the arch-marketeer Sir David English, would never have allowed to happen. Seeing the political writing on the wall, he would have already tailored the paper's politics to commandeer the role of "conservative conscience" of New Labour.
Barry Baker
Bristol

The real problem with the Daily Mail is that Tony Blair has shown such craven cowardliness towards it, and the Sun, frightened of the "scare" headlines. As a result we have the first prime minister since the inter-war years whose government's policies are perversely dictated by newspapers that peddle racism, fear and hate. Mr Blair is not a man of long-held beliefs and principles and has allowed himself to be compromised by fear of the Sun's white van man, and the well-fed, middle-class women who sadly, but willingly, consume the fear and hate dolled out by the Mail each morning.
Mike Abbott
Kew, Surrey
mikea@redbirdcom.com

My only comfort is that on the same day as your article, the Labour government announced child support for teenager mothers, maybe a potent symbol that the tide is turning; that ministers are becoming more forthright on policy and will in the future increasingly flex their muscles to trounce this amateurish and absurd form of journalism.
Walter Bernard
Greenford, Middx

The danger of the Mail is that, bizarrely, it has managed to get itself taken seriously. The priggish, self-righteous, moralising, highly judgmental, simplistic, ignorant and prejudicial somehow manage to come across to its unquestioning readers as a reasonable, man on the street/woman on the train, informed response. I would like to be able to disregard it as the irrelevant, ignorant twaddle it is, but I actually am unnerved by it. Let's hope it is a cult that has run its course.
Heather Harvey
London

As you leave a commuter train at a London terminus the carriages are littered with Daily Mails. The FTs, Telegraphs, Times and Guardians are being carried into offices, but the world has first been seen through the windows of the Mail.
Paul Gunnion
Glasgow

You might like to know that I buy the Mail only for the Coffee Break page which lasts just the length of my lunch break. The rest gets binned without a glance.
Cuillin Bantock
London

webTitle: Leader: Huntingdon gang must be punished

fields.headline: Malicious protesters
fields.standfirst: The Huntingdon gang must be punished
fields.trailText: It is difficult to get into the contorted mindset of people prepared to inflict severe injuries on fellow human beings in the name of animal rights.
fields.body:
It is difficult to get into the contorted mindset of people prepared to inflict severe injuries on fellow human beings in the name of animal rights. Brian Cass, aged 53, bravely turned up to work yesterday at Huntingdon Life Sciences (HLS), where he is managing director, after a malicious attack by a gang of thugs presumed to be animal rights activists. He was ambushed by Balaclava-clad attackers who beat him with baseball bats and threw gas into the eyes of passers-by who courageously came to the rescue.

In a civilised society, demonstrations against abuses of human rights are usually - even in war-torn Belgrade - conducted in a peaceful way. Not to do so undermines the morality of the case right from the start. The idea that it is justified to inflict injuries, possibly risking death, on humans to prolong the lives of animals reveals a set of quite grotesque values.

In the case of HLS, it is not as if they are torturing pets. Almost 90% of the experiments are carried out on rats and mice, which are regarded as vermin in a household environment. About 75,000 animals a year are used at HLS in heavily controlled conditions designed to make the whole process as humane as possible. The results of these experiments have proved vital in treating diseases including cancer, heart and lung problems and Parkinson's disease.

Contrast that with the real world, where, according to a recent report, 275m animals, mainly rats and mice, are killed every year by cats in a gratuitously brutal way. fields.bodyText: It is difficult to get into the contorted mindset of people prepared to inflict severe injuries on fellow human beings in the name of animal rights. Brian Cass, aged 53, bravely turned up to work yesterday at Huntingdon Life Sciences (HLS), where he is managing director, after a malicious attack by a gang of thugs presumed to be animal rights activists. He was ambushed by Balaclava-clad attackers who beat him with baseball bats and threw gas into the eyes of passers-by who courageously came to the rescue. In a civilised society, demonstrations against abuses of human rights are usually - even in war-torn Belgrade - conducted in a peaceful way. Not to do so undermines the morality of the case right from the start. The idea that it is justified to inflict injuries, possibly risking death, on humans to prolong the lives of animals reveals a set of quite grotesque values. In the case of HLS, it is not as if they are torturing pets. Almost 90% of the experiments are carried out on rats and mice, which are regarded as vermin in a household environment. About 75,000 animals a year are used at HLS in heavily controlled conditions designed to make the whole process as humane as possible. webTitle: Letters: Countryside Alliance, Irvine and Eminem

fields.headline: Outfoxing country folk
fields.trailText: Now we are confined to the city (Walkers warned to stay away from animals, February 23), will the the Countryside Alliance be urged to keep out of London?
fields.body:
Now we are confined to the city (Walkers warned to stay away from animals, February 23), will the the Countryside Alliance be urged to keep out of London so as not to contaminate each other or put our beloved pets, tame squirrels and foxes (who have sought asylum here from the tyranny of some country folk) at risk?
Brian Snow
London

Three young lives sacrificed in a pointless car chase, the only victim of which should have been the insurer of the vehicle (Car thieves died in police chase, February 23). How many more people will have to be killed before the police realise the cost of pursuing adolescent joy riders is simply too high?
Simon Ball
London

What does it say about lawyers if to get them to donate £200, less than an hour's work for many of them, they need to be appealed to by no less a personage than the lord chancellor ('Arrogant' Lord Irvine, February 22)?
David Herskovic
London

Re Elton John's duet with Eminem (Elton embraces Eminem in face of protests, February 23): I can't believe that anyone would agree to perform with an artist who has made such vile, unspeakable records. I thought Eminem had more sense.
Will Maclean
London

A friend has just returned from a day-trip to France. While he was there he did some shopping and the bill, in euros, was 86.40. This is 86 euros and 40 whats?
Alexandra Kersley
London

The suggestion (Letters, February 21) that Tony Blair's register of drug dealers include a guarantee of purity is an excellent idea. A high-as-a-kite mark, perhaps?
Simon Coward
Dudley, W Mids

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In the article which appeared on page 2 of the first edition on December 30 under the headline East End chancers cash in as BBC pays for silence and on page 7 of the final edition that day under the headline BBC hush money for loudmouth, we described an incident during filming of a BBC television drama in the Columbia Road area of east London.
fields.body:
In the article which appeared on page 2 of the first edition on December 30 under the headline East End chancers cash in as BBC pays for silence and on page 7 of the final edition that day under the headline BBC hush money for loudmouth, we described an incident during filming of a BBC television drama in the Columbia Road area of east London.

We said wrongly that a potter was making threats to shout during filming unless he was given money. Although the potter was not named, the long-standing business of S & B Evans & Sons, and in particular the senior partner in that business, Mr Robert Alan Evans, has been identified as being the potter in question. In fact, the action described had nothing whatsoever to do with Mr Evans or S & B Evans & Sons and we apologise without reservation to them both for any damage and distress caused by this error.

In an article headed Sex, lies and Victorians, page 2, Saturday Review, February 17, we attributed to the author Peter Mendes the conclusion that the British Museum authorities had destroyed "the greater part of [Henry] Ashbee's collection of pornographic fiction". The writer of the article actually said that Mendes had concluded that "the British Museum authorities destroyed the greater part of Ashbee's collection of 'poorly produced, illustrated pornographic fiction (particularly in English) of the 19th century', perhaps some hundred items of which no other copies are known to exist".

A caption on page 2 of today's pre-printed Saturday Review wrongly states that the photograph shows the writer David Thomson in his study in 1994. It should read 1983. He died in 1988.

Airline food does not deserve the headline, Do you eat the desert? G2, page 6, yesterday.

Elsewhere, we had puddings where they should not have been. A story about prisons, page 1, referred to reform of the "just desserts" policy.

The readers' editor writes about publishing without being damned, page 7, today's Saturday Review.

fields.headline: Clinton's folly
fields.standfirst: He mutilates his reputation - and hers
fields.trailText: With the Clintons you need to be on permanent guard against the distorting effects of the peculiar loathing they have attracted over the years from the American right.
fields.body:
With the Clintons you need to be on permanent guard against the distorting effects of the peculiar loathing they have attracted over the years from the American right. The Clinton-haters include some nasty specimens, a number of whom congregated around Kenneth Starr in his interminable hunting expeditions against the former president, first over Whitewater then over Lewinsky. But my enemy's enemy is not an infallible guide to right and wrong.

A full account of the ex-president's pardons has yet to emerge. Congressional investigations are under way and even though they are Republican-led may turn up some facts. The National Enquirer, which broke the story about retainers paid to Hillary Clinton's brother by two of the pardonees, has not finished its inquiring.

But we know enough to say the eve-of-departure spree by Bill Clinton constituted self-mutilation in terms of his reputation. The pardons have hurt Hillary (assuming she was not involved), interrupting her early days as a senator and blowing a hole in any further political ambitions she may entertain. Worse, Mr Clinton's playing fast and loose has distracted the Democrats from focusing on what is, administratively speaking, an assured debut by George Bush, or exploiting the residual anger felt across the United States at the way he won the presidential election.

Presidents and their spouses cannot be blamed for their siblings and it may well be that neither of the Clintons acted at the behest of Hillary's brother, Hugh Rodham. His size, Bermuda shorts and resemblance to that other black sheep, Billy Carter, should not be held against him. But he has apparently traded not just on his proximity to power, but on the belief that, as president, Bill Clinton was open to persuasion, perhaps even financial inducement.

That is the Clintons' real offence - the way they allowed an impression to build up, even among those predisposed to sympathise with their plight in recent years, that they might act venally given half a chance. Hillary once identified, probably without too much exaggeration, the conspiratorial nature of the forces arrayed against them. That should have counselled the utmost caution.

Did they not realise that carting truckloads of goodies out of the White House let alone the Rich pardon would feed their detractors? Putting pelf before political self-protection is as inexcusable as it is puzzling.

webTitle: Leader: NHS disputes need quick solution

fields.headline: Time for compromise
fields.standfirst: NHS disputes need quick solution
fields.trailText: Is the "once in a lifetime opportunity" going to be lost? Seven months ago, the biggest fillip the national health service had received since its launch in 1948 was provided by the government's 10-year health plan.
fields.body:
Is the "once in a lifetime opportunity" going to be lost? Seven months ago, the biggest fillip the national health service had received since its launch in 1948 was provided by the government's 10-year health plan.

It involved the largest sustained increase in health spending (a 35% increase in real terms over four years) in the history of the service; a restructuring, cutting through professional demarcation boundaries to make the NHS more patient friendly, but with ideas that had already proved themselves in some part of the system; and, most amazing of all, the united backing of doctors, nurses and managers.

Some 24 leading names literally signed up to the core principles in the plan's opening pages. It was George Alberti, president of the Royal College of Physicians, who declared it a "once in a lifetime opportunity". Yet from the beginning, there were two medical grumbles, which have rumbled on for seven months and finally broke out this week.

The first came from family doctors, who have a genuine grievance. A primary care-led plan set out to expand GPs by a mere 7%, while hospital consultants were to increase 30% by 2004. Nine out of 10 people who use the NHS never get to a hospital. Last week's announcement from the health secretary made this gap even worse: a 9% rise in GPs over nine years, compared with a 50% rise in hospital consultants.

As our social affairs editor reported this week, GPs are on the point of mutiny. They are planning a manifesto, which will be distributed to all parliamentary candidates in the forthcoming election. They accuse ministers of starving family doctor services for "more sexy" hospital investment. The British Medical Association committee representing 30,000 GPs passed a vote of no confidence in the government last week in protest over an unexpected cut in expense allowances.

The second grievance concerns the new contract for hospital doctors, finally published this week, under which new hospital consultants would lose their right to practice private medicine for seven years, but in return receive generous salary increases: an initial hike of £10,000, followed by further rises of £22,500 over 16 years up to £82,500.

The BMA is up in arms, suggesting the right to private practice is a fundamental human right. They fail to mention a single other profession which enjoys this right - it was conceded in 1948, as a deliberate NHS bribe to divide the BMA, and win over the hospital doctors by "stuffing their mouths with gold". Nor does the BMA mention the subsidy which each of its consultants receives: free medical school costs now averaging £200,000.

The health secretary is right to reform the contract so that the current perverse incentive, in which there is a financial interest in long waiting lists to increase private work, is reversed. Medics were given plenty of notice there would be change. Long before the plan was published, ministers were talking of "revisiting the 1948 settlement". Even so, they should have moved more quickly to resolve both these industrial grumbles. They are in danger of eroding the enormous goodwill and enthusiasm which the plan generated within the NHS.

But the BMA should also recognise the weakness of its position. First its forces are divided: GPs angry over the expansion of consultants. Second, there is little unity within consultant ranks. Only a minority of the 25,000 consultants perform private practice. The vast majority, already working fulltime, will find the new package extremely attractive. Time for both sides to compromise.

webTitle: What funding for young fashion designers?

fields.headline: Riches for rag trade
fields.standfirst: Cash-strapped is not a good look, but two big designers went bust this year. Liz Stuart looks at the funding available to those who are just starting out
fields.trailText: Cash-strapped is not a good look, but two big designers went bust this year. Liz Stuart looks at the funding available to those who are just starting out.
fields.body:
London Fashion Week is not only the industry showcase for the best designs, but also a victory march for those who have managed to find the money to get their work off the drawing board and on to the catwalk.

Big British names who have gone bust this year include Hussein Chalayan (2000's British Designer of the Year, who has gone into liquidation) and Frank Usher, who this week went into administrative receivership.

However, the chief executive of the British Fashion Council (BFC), John Wilson is very upbeat about the design industry and the business success rate of young designers.

"The design side is doing very well. In 1992, British designers had a turnover of around £200m, but that is now getting up to £700m.

"I would say that people are no more likely to fail when starting up in this industry than any other, it's just that the failures are more high profile. And in fact the cost of putting on a catwalk show in London is less than half what it would cost in Milan or New York," he says.

"Overall the clothing and textile industry in this country is having a bad time, with manufacturing increasingly being done abroad. But that does leave spare capacity in the factories and designers should exploit this," he adds.

The government has admitted that more needs to be done to help designers starting out in business. This week, textiles minister Patricia Hewitt unveiled the second stage of an official action plan to boost the clothing industry.

New initiatives include a project targeting the wool and worsted industry, another to retrain workers made redundant from the textiles industry and a series of regional events at which designers and clothing companies can meet business advisers.

Ms Hewitt also said that the funding for London Fashion Week has been increased by 35%, £1m has been invested in technical textile companies with a further £1m to come, £2m has gone to retrain people within the industry and £1.5m has been given to create a new clothing and textile supply chain, from yarn spinner to retailer.

So what sources of funding are available to people breaking into the clothing industry? The Marks & Spencer New Generation award divides £120,000 between designers exhibiting at the two London Fashion Weeks each year: they receive between £10,000 and £15,000.

"Each year around 130 people apply for the award," says Mr Wilson. "We look at a range of criteria, including samples of collections, as well as checking business information such as who their customers are and what their turnover is, although we don't expect them to be too far down the track."

And the Vidal Sassoon bursary, which this year has been awarded to Eley Kishimoto, gives £25,000 and business and marketing mentoring from Procter & Gamble.

There is also non-specific funding available from the BFC, which often takes the form of subsidies as well as advice: "Because of our assistance, British designers have the chance to make an entree on catwalk activity much earlier than their counterparts overseas," says Mr Wilson.

The London College of Fashion also operates a business technology support unit. This gives financial and business advice to designers, as well as a long-term networking facility. Professionals are also given access to rentable studio space and staff who can be hired on an hourly basis to create samples.

 The DTI launched a website with details of support for people in the industry this week. The BTSU at the London College of Fashion, tel: 020-7514-7536.

fields.headline: Will bulls fight off the bears?
fields.standfirst: Experts are divided on whether the market is about to go into freefall, writes Patrick Collinson
fields.trailText: Experts are divided on whether the market is about to go into freefall, writes Patrick Collinson.
fields.body:
Investment experts were in fierce disagreement this week as the FTSE-100 fell through the 6,000 level; some say it heralds the start of a Japanese-style 10-year bear market, while others believe that corporate UK will bounce back and send share prices jumping.

The economic doom-mongers do not have to cast far to find evidence to support their pessimism. The US economy has slowed dramatically from its super-heated growth in recent years, while the financial crisis enveloping Turkey has once again put the spotlight on debt and inflation problems in emerging economies.

The London stock market has now been directionless for close to two years, bubbling up towards 7,000 then falling back to 6,000. Only in recent days has it found that there are not many buyers even at 6,000.

As the graph opposite shows, London shares are now among the worst performers in the world's stock markets, with the FTSE-100 showing a four-year record that puts it at the bottom of European bourses.

"People are feeling more cynical about shares at the moment," says Justin Urquhart Stewart of Barclays Stockbrokers. "Reasons to be cheerful are difficult to find and more people are staying away from the market."

For small investors, the lack of direction in markets could not come at a worse time. February and March are traditionally the time of the year when money floods into Individual Savings Accounts (Isas) ahead of the end of the tax year, but this time more money is expected to stay in cash waiting for a new home.

Last year, investors piled into technology funds - with disastrous consequences. According to Hargreaves Lansdown, one of the biggest investment advisers in the UK, there is no theme to investment this year. It lists Fidelity, led by its Managed International fund, as its current best seller, followed by Framlington Health, Aberdeen Global Champions and Gartmore European Focus.

So what do the bulls and bears say about the year ahead for investors?

The bear

Excess credit, excess borrowing, deeply overpriced shares, ridiculous valuations; the London stock market is heading for a prolonged bear market similar to the decade-long decline in Tokyo after the bubble economy of the 80s, according to David Kauders of Kauders Portfolio Management.

Mr Kauders has been in the investment wilderness for many years, but says his forecasts of long-term deflation are coming through. "We are at the early stages of a very long drawn-out bear market. We've got to learn from the Japanese experience; we've got similar problems to the ones they had, it's just that they're not so visible right now because things have been temporarily fixed by easy credit."

Mr Kauders has not bought shares since 1986, and does not even dabble in corporate bonds, usually seen as a safe haven during risky markets. Property is also heading fast into negative equity. Instead he splits investors' portfolios 60/40 between US Treasury bonds and British Government bonds, called gilts.

"My investors have had perfectly respectable growth and income, and should carry on doing so. If you bought a US Treasury bond yielding 9% in 1990, just think what sort of returns you are earning. Higher rate taxpayers should do a gilts Isa - buy direct, not through an Isa manager - but apart from them there's not a lot of point in taking out an Isa," he says.

The bull

Don't Worry, Be Happy is the tune from Legal & General, one of the biggest investors in the London stock market. Its investment director, David Rough, who controls £114bn in investors' cash, says the market wobbles below 6,000 should not be a cause for undue concern, and predicts that by the end of 2001 the FTSE-100 will climb above its record high, ending up 20% at around 7,200.

Profit warnings from big US and UK companies are currently depressing the market, but the worst will be out of the way by the end of the first quarter, predicts L&G.

It says that the UK is in fundamentally sound economic shape, but this is not being represented in stock markets. L&G is particularly bullish about smaller companies, whose profits are insulated from an American downturn, unlike multinationals.

It adds that because the London stock exchange has risen less rapidly than other markets over the past few years, it will also be less at risk from a severe correction downwards.

The economic doom-mongers do not have to cast far to find evidence to support their pessimism. The US economy has slowed dramatically from its super-heated growth in recent years, while the financial crisis enveloping Turkey has once again put the spotlight on debt and inflation problems in emerging economies. The London stock market has now been directionless for close to two years, bubbling up towards 7,000 then falling back to 6,000. Only in recent days has it found that there are not many buyers even at 6,000. As the graph opposite shows, London shares are now among the worst performers in the world's stock markets, with the FTSE-100 showing a four-year record that puts it at the bottom of European bourses. "People are feeling more cynical about shares at the moment," says Justin Urquhart Stewart of Barclays Stockbrokers. "Reasons to be cheerful are difficult to find and more people are staying away from the market." For small investors, the lack of direction in markets could not come at a worse time. February and March are traditionally the time of the year when money floods into Individual Savings Accounts (Isas) ahead of the end of the tax year, but this time more money is expected to stay in cash waiting for a new home. Last year, investors piled into technology funds - with disastrous consequences. According to Hargreaves Lansdown, one of the biggest investment advisers in the UK, there is no theme to investment this year. It lists Fidelity, led by its Managed International fund, as its current best seller, followed by Framlington Health, Aberdeen Global Champions and Gartmore European Focus. So what do the bulls and bears say about the year ahead for investors? The bear Excess credit, excess borrowing, deeply overpriced shares, ridiculous valuations; the London stock market is heading for a prolonged bear market similar to the decade-long decline in Tokyo after the bubble economy of the 80s, according to David Kauders of Kauders Portfolio Management. Mr Kauders has been in the investment wilderness for many years, but says his forecasts of long-term deflation are coming through. "We are at the early stages of a very long drawn-out bear market. We've got to learn from the Japanese experience; we've got similar problems to the ones they had, it's just that they're not so visible right now because things have been temporarily fixed by easy credit." Mr Kauders has not bought shares since 1986, and does not even dabble in corporate bonds, usually seen as a safe haven during risky markets. Property is also heading fast into negative equity. Instead he splits investors' portfolios 60/40 between US Treasury bonds and British Government bonds, called gilts. "My investors have had perfectly respectable growth and income, and should carry on doing so. If you bought a US Treasury bond yielding 9% in 1990, just think what sort of returns you are earning. Higher rate taxpayers should do a gilts Isa - buy direct, not through an Isa manager - but apart from them there's not a lot of point in taking out an Isa," he says. The bull Don't Worry, Be Happy is the tune from Legal & General, one of the biggest investors in the London stock market. Its investment director, David Rough, who controls £114bn in investors' cash, says the market wobbles below 6,000 should not be a cause for undue concern, and predicts that by the end of 2001 the FTSE-100 will climb above its record high, ending up 20% at around 7,200. Profit warnings from big US and UK companies are currently depressing the market, but the worst will be out of the way by the end of the first quarter, predicts L&G. It says that the UK is in fundamentally sound economic shape, but this is not being represented in stock markets. L&G is particularly bullish about smaller companies, whose profits are insulated from an American downturn, unlike multinationals. It adds that because the London stock exchange has risen less rapidly than other markets over the past few years, it will also be less at risk from a severe correction downwards.

fields.headline: Compensation? It's downright criminal
fields.standfirst: Machete victims Lisa Potts won huge sympathy over the niggardly payment she received. But Richard Colbey finds Jack Straw's plans to increase such payments less than generous
fields.trailText: Machete victims Lisa Potts won huge sympathy over the niggardly payment she received. But Richard Colbey finds Jack Straw's plans to increase such payments less than generous.
fields.body:
Within days of heroic nursery nurse Lisa Potts complaining she had been awarded derisory compensation after shielding children from a machete waving attacker in 1996, Home Secretary Jack Straw announced plans to review criminal injury payments.

Of course, cynics will see this as no more than a piece of crude electioneering, particularly as the much heralded increases, on close examination, only raise the sums set in 1996 by less than the rate of inflation.

Ms Potts has attracted tremendous public sympathy and Mr Straw's proposals, perhaps coincidentally, do appear to be of some assistance to those like her who suffer multiple injuries.

The principle of state compensation for victims of crime was first established in 1964 when the Criminal Injuries Compensation Board was set up. A panel of QCs was appointed to determine awards which would be assessed in much the same way as the courts would consider payments. Many of the Board's decisions were relied upon by lawyers and the courts in deciding how much to award accident victims. However, in 1996, as a cost-cutting exercise, the Board was phased out and replaced by the Criminal Injuries Compensation Authority, which determines its awards according to tariffs reflecting a list of around 300 types of injury. Extra may be paid where the victim has been off work for more than 28 weeks.

The decision about compensation is made by relatively low-level civil servants, with a right of appeal, such as Ms Potts exercised, to a specialist panel, which no longer consists entirely of lawyers. The delay of more than four years in Ms Potts' case exemplifies the dilatory way in which this panel proceeds.

For all its shortcomings, the British scheme is in fact one of the most generous in the world: the £200m paid annually is more than in America, despite that country having more than four times the population and a much higher crime rate.

Jack Straw's proposals, likely to come into effect in April, will increase most awards by 10%. Those for injuries that are most emotive, and hence attract most publicity, will rise by more. The minimum for rape will go up from £7,500 to £11,000. Victims of serious childhood sexual abuse will be entitled to £8,200, rather than the present £6,000. Payment for the loss of a front tooth will rise by 10% from £1,500 to £1,650 and the loss of an index finger from £7,500 to £8,250.

Trivial injuries do not qualify and there is a minimum payment of £1,000. A mere black eye would not lead to compensation, but could if it was accompanied by cuts and other bruising. There are special rules for cases of domestic violence as no award can be made if there is any chance that the perpetrator might benefit from their partner getting a payment. Payments have never been made to those who contribute to their own injuries.

"The scheme is not intended to provide consolation prizes to the losers of street fights," remarked one adjudicating QC sagely in the Board's early days.

Those with serious criminal records, whether or not for violence, have their compensation reduced. Ms Potts' initial award of £8,000 was increased on appeal to nearly £50,000, though she had hoped for much more - £20,000 of this was for the post-traumatic stress disorder she suffered, which will permanently disable her, and £28,784 was given for loss of earnings.

More controversially, she only got a further £750 for damage to her arm and £250 for scarring. Far more would have been given by a court, but only 10% of the normal level is currently allowed by the CICA for a second injury in the same attack, with 5% for a third, and nothing for other injuries.

For all the government's hints about how Mr Straw's generosity would have benefited Ms Potts he actually only intends increasing these proportions to 30% and 15% respectively, which would have increased her award by a miserly £2,000.

 Richard Colbey is a barrister.

webTitle: Obituary: A reader remembers Ken Kiff

fields.headline: Letter
fields.trailText: Arturo Di Stefano writes: Ken Kiff (Obituary, February 16) was an integral member of the staff at the Royal College of Art's painting school during the late 1970s and early 80s.
fields.body:
Arturo Di Stefano writes: Ken Kiff (Obituary, February 16) was an integral member of the staff at the Royal College of Art's painting school during the late 1970s and early 80s, which, at that time, included tutors of the calibre of Peter de Francia, John Golding, Philip Rawson, Keith Critchlow and Yehuda Safran. It was an real Elysium of rare minds, engaged in various disciplines, brought to bear on the métier of painting. As students, we were incomparably blessed.

Kiff's courteous diffidence as a tutor contrasted with the frank character of his art - its radical appraisal of imagery and colour, each weighted the same in the balanced equipoise of his pictures. We have lost a major artist prematurely, his future images locked within him.

webTitle: How to buy a cheaper car

fields.headline: Ys and wherefores
fields.standfirst: A wave of new-reg cars will hit the forecourts this week and sales are expected to be lively. Patrick Collinson looks at the best deals on offer
fields.trailText: A wave of new-reg cars will hit the forecourts this week and sales are expected to be lively. Patrick Collinson looks at the best deals on offer.
fields.body:
Wednesday night will see one of Britain's more vulgar modern traditions as new car buyers count down the minutes to midnight so they can be first off the forecourt with the latest Y-registered cars. Sales are expected to be brisk: new car prices have fallen steeply over the past year in response to a "buyers' strike" over rip-off British prices.

But souring the party was a damning report this week from the European Commission which revealed that despite high-profile price cuts, British drivers still pay far more than their EU cousins for nearly all makes of car. A Mazda 323 sells for £5,307 in Denmark, but £11,106 in the UK, or 99.3% more, while a Fiat Bravo, at £9,997, is 94.2% more than in Denmark.

However, the report focused on prices before tax, which is particularly severe in Denmark and which means that in reality Danish drivers pay more than Britons to drive away in a new car. By the same logic, British petrol is the best value in the EU, it's just that we pay high tax.

So this week Jobs & Money set out to find the best prices for new cars, inclusive of all the taxes and charges a buyer has to pay. First stop was Carpricecheck, a website which independently compares prices from dealers, manufacturers, importers and internet e-tailers. Jobs & Money asked it to find best prices on a range of cars plus we carried out independent checks at a number of traditional dealers.

Lesson one is that list prices for cars are still substantially above the price you should pay, despite the adverts which proclaim hefty price reductions. Lesson two is that importers are still cheaper than buying domestically - but the differential is narrowing. Lesson three is that traditional dealers, while often at the bottom of the price league table, are by no means always the worst option and, if buying a luxury car, may be the cheapest.

Importers

Importers, led by One Swoop, topped the tables in five out of the six categories, knocking £1,800 off the price of a Ford Focus and £1,350 off a VW Golf. But they have a major drawback - delivery times can run up to four or even six months.

Oneswoop marketing director Tom Buehlmann says that delivery can be as short as four weeks if buyers opt for selected models rather than demanding a long list of specifications. But he admits that delays are frustrating, and in some cases have worsened.

"Customised delivery averages around three months, and we are finding that manufacturers are being increasingly difficult, with some increasing their delivery times. The surcharge they require for right hand drive has also gone up in a number of cases, which is pretty unjustified," he says.

The decline in UK list prices means that Oneswoop's price advantage has slipped. "On March 1 last year, when the site launched, we averaged savings of 35%-40% off UK list prices, but that is now more like 20%. But that is still a very significant price gap, so there are large numbers of people trying the import route."

A frequent concern about personal imports is that EU-sourced cars have warranties lasting just one year, while UK-sourced cars have three-year warranties. But Mr Buehlmann says this is simply scaremongering by UK dealers; all Oneswoop's cars come with three-year warranties.

Internet e-tailers

The new internet retailers of cars, such as Direct Line's JamJar, are not as cheap as the importers - often £500-£1,000 more - but promise delivery more rapidly, usually four weeks, but currently three months for Ford Focuses because of heavy demand.

JamJar obtains its cars from Dixons Motors, the third biggest dealer in the UK. Its spokesman Justin Skinner says: "Our focus is on UK supplied cars as we see a limited life span for the import route because UK car prices are coming down. Imports can take up to six months to deliver."

The level of discount varies widely between different makes of car, and can be zero on some cars. For example, JamJar currently has big discounts on Vauxhall Astras, but is able to sell the Toyota Yaris at list price only. Under an EU-approved block exemption from usual competition rules, car manufacturers can still pick and choose who they want to sell to. "They are still able to control prices, which cars we can sell, when and how. It's very much a supply driven rather than demand driven industry," says Mr Skinner.

JamJar is campaigning against the renewal of the block exemption when it expires on October 1 2002, and says if it is lifted, new car prices will fall by an average of £500 and save British car buyers around £1bn a year.

Forecourt dealers

In our survey, dealers came out badly, offering list prices only and in some cases even charging above list price. However, in the luxury car market they beat all other outlets, including the private importers. Carpricecheck.com was able to source a UK dealer offering a Jaguar S type at nearly £3,000 below list price, while JamJar could only discount by £422.

Haggling with dealers can bring prices down further, and arming yourself with price quotes from services such as carpricecheck.com gives the buyer added power. The company also recommends that drivers should start negotiations during the last 10 days of the month; its system reveals that better prices are offered in 61% of cases during the last few days of the month as dealers look to reach sales targets.

Cover that costs more than a car

Car insurance which costs substantially more than the value of your car? If you are under 25 and a first-time policy buyer, you'd better get used to it.

This week Jobs & Money sent out its editorial assistant Juliet Shedden to find the best quotes for a VW Polo her sister is giving her. The car is 13 years old, has high mileage and is worth, at most, £1,000. Yet Ms Shedden was shocked to be given insurance quotes as high as £1,500, while some insurers simply refused to offer cover.

Ms Shedden is 23, lives in central London and therefore falls into the band of drivers that insurers appear to most dislike - the under 25s. "I did a great deal of searching on the internet and telephone for insurance quotes and was pretty horrified at the quotes. The worst came from a company called Sabre, which wanted £1,534.05. It's really made me think twice about whether I can afford to accept my sister's gift."

It could have been worse. Young males are charged even more, says AA spokeswoman Rebecca Hadley. "Young drivers are over-represented in accidents. One in six motorists is under 25 and one in four accidents involve someone under 25," she says. A recent AA study found that accidents involving young males are more serious than those involving young females, resulting in substantial personal injury claims. "Young men's driving is worse when there are other males in the car, when they show off," says Ms Hadley, while female drivers are likely to drive carefully.

Ms Shedden contacted 12 companies to find a decent quote. "Churchill Insurance and Liverpool Victoria refused to give me a quote because of my age. Churchill's response was simply: "We aren't competitive in that age bracket" but they did recommend another insurer. I found Find useful as a website, although getting a 'quick quote online' took 20 minutes, with some sites not recognising my postal code and some crashing," she says.

The majority of quotes were in the £700-£1,000 bracket except for Admiral, which offered the best quote at £362.60 plus a 10-month accelerated no-claims bonus, after which premiums go down considerably. A spokesman for Admiral Insurance said they specialised in drivers under the age of 25, those who live in London and the south-east and female drivers.

Young people on low incomes will want to spread payments over the year, but Ms Shedden found that this can add a further £100 to the bill. Many young drivers cut costs by insuring in their parents' home town even though the car is kept elsewhere, a practice the Association of British Insurers says is fraudulent, but difficult to detect and control.

Plan your route to a cheap loan

Need cash to help finance a new Y-reg car? Picking the wrong finance package can add thousands of pounds to the cost of a car, particularly if you opt for expensive "payment protection" deals.

Northern Rock topped the tables for cheapest loan rates when Jobs & Money checked out finance deals for X-reg cars, but recently it has been beaten by Chartered Trust Platinum.

We asked lenders for monthly repayments on a £5,000 car loan spread over three years. Chartered Trust Platinum (0870 606 1732), a subsidiary of Lloyds TSB, charges £158.41 per month without insurance (APR 9.1), making a total payment of £5,702.76. Northern Rock's £159.05 per month (APR 9.4) adds up to £5,725.80 over the three years. Lombard Direct, Nationwide, Tesco, Sainsbury's and Vivid all offer APRs below 10%.

Propping up the table are some big names: Lloyds TSB's car purchase loan has an APR of 15.9, with total payments of £6,226.20 over three years, or £523.44 more than Chartered's loan - even though it too is in the Lloyds empire. Halifax, Royal Bank of Scotland, Barclayloan and Birmingham Midshires all have APRs of more than 15.

All loan applicants are vetted through credit scoring systems, so if you have suffered repayment problems the low-cost deals will be closed to you. Northern Rock, however, insists that its loan rates are available to 98% of applicants.

Beware: you will be encouraged to take out expensive payment protection - call centres always give the "with insurance" price first. In some cases this can add 15% to the total repayment costs.

There are alternatives to personal loans; deferred car purchase, hire purchase and personal contract plans. Deferred car purchase, offered by Alliance & Leicseter, Direct Line and NatWest, allows you to buy a swanky car without huge monthly payments, but the catch is a chunky final payment. Hire purchase is a decreasingly popular option. The finance is secured on the car, so it may be repossessed if you do not keep up repayments. Personal contract plans, offered by manufacturers and big dealers, give a low initial monthly payment plus a minimum guaranteed future value, and are most useful when buying a high price car with a high resale value.

Chartered Trust Platinum (0870 606 1732), a subsidiary of Lloyds TSB, charges £158.41 per month without insurance (APR 9.1), making a total payment of £5,702.76. Northern Rock's £159.05 per month (APR 9.4) adds up to £5,725.80 over the three years. Lombard Direct, Nationwide, Tesco, Sainsbury's and Vivid all offer APRs below 10%. Propping up the table are some big names: Lloyds TSB's car purchase loan has an APR of 15.9, with total payments of £6,226.20 over three years, or £523.44 more than Chartered's loan - even though it too is in the Lloyds empire. Halifax, Royal Bank of Scotland, Barclayloan and Birmingham Midshires all have APRs of more than 15. All loan applicants are vetted through credit scoring systems, so if you have suffered repayment problems the low-cost deals will be closed to you. Deferred car purchase, offered by Alliance & Leicseter, Direct Line and NatWest, allows you to buy a swanky car without huge monthly payments, but the catch is a chunky final payment. Hire purchase is a decreasingly popular option. The finance is secured on the car, so it may be repossessed if you do not keep up repayments. Personal contract plans, offered by manufacturers and big dealers, give a low initial monthly payment plus a minimum guaranteed future value, and are most useful when buying a high price car with a high resale value. fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Avalanche kills four in Austria
fields.body:
Avalanche kills four in Austria

A German couple and their two children, aged 11 and 13, died yesterday when an avalanche engulfed their car on a road in Austria.

The family from Garmisch-Partenkirchen was hit by a 300-metre wide avalanche near Obergurgl, southwest of Innsbruck.
Kate Connolly
Berlin

Women hanged for prostitution

More than 1,000 Afghans watched yesterday as two women convicted of prostitution were hanged in Kandahar's sports stadium.

Two other women and 10 men were lashed and jailed for adultery.
AP Kabul

Rabid mice go missing

Officials were searching the Lithuanian city of Siauliai yesterday for 23 rabies-infected mice which disappeared from a laboratory.

Police say the mice, found to be missing on Monday, may have been stolen to sell as snake food.
AP Siauliai

Slovak nuclear expert killed

The head of the Slovak Nuclear Energy Research Institute was shot dead early yesterday at home in Piestany, police said. Reuters, Bratislava

Golden days for Hong Kong loo

Jeweller Lam Sai-wing has fitted his shop toilet out in £3.3m worth of gold and gems. Toilet bowls, basins and doors are made of solid gold.
AP, Hong Kong

webTitle: Police raids uncover 'orphans for sale' racket

fields.headline: Police raids uncover 'orphans for sale' racket
fields.standfirst: Arrest of woman in Russia reveals web of bureaucratic corruption around adoption of 600 children by Italians
fields.trailText: When the secret policemen raided Nadezhda Fratti's flat in Volgograd, in southern Russia, they were fascinated to find sheafs of fake documents bearing the signatures of judges, education officials and local heads of social services.
fields.byline: Ian Traynor  in Moscow and  Rory Carroll  in Rome
fields.body:
When the secret policemen raided Nadezhda Fratti's flat in Volgograd, in southern Russia, they were fascinated to find sheafs of fake documents bearing the signatures of judges, education officials and local heads of social services.

There were wads of roubles and US dollars, said a source in the FSB counter- intelligence service, and lists of clients. There were scanners and a computer to create the documents, and official stamps without which no Russian bureaucratic transaction can be made.

Ms Fratti, in her 40s, a native of Perm, Siberia, who is married to an Italian and has dual Russian and Italian citizenship, was remanded in custody last Friday after the raids at the end of January. She is charged with falsifying official documents related to the adoption of Volgograd orphans over a period of seven years for desperate Italian couples.

Between 1993 and last year she is suspected of having arranged the illegal adoption in Italy of up to 600 children. Nikolai Bichekvost, a senior investigator in the Volgograd prosecutor's office, said Ms Fratti was paid £1,700 for every child.

"I've been working as an investigator in Volgograd for 20 years and this is the worst case of its kind I've seen," he said.

Gennady Romodanov, director of the biggest infants' orphanage in Volgograd, confirms that Ms Fratti was a well-known mediator in foreign adoptions in the region. "She had dealings with my home and two other children's homes, all institutions with new-borns to three-year-olds. And she had dealings with orphanages for older children. In the past few years 200 babies in my home have been adopted by foreigners in arrangements brokered by Fratti."

After emigrating to Italy in 1989, Ms Fratti came to Volgograd in 1993 and set herself up as a translator, assisting Italians seeking to adopt children in Russia. She was the local representative of the Arcobaleno, or Rainbow, adoption agency based in the affluent northern Italian town of Padua. The agency was set up the same year as Ms Fratti arrived in Volgograd.

She is alleged to have pocketed around £1m in seven years, illegal earnings under Russian rules which ban adoption profiteering but were only introduced last year by President Vladimir Putin.

According to the Italian embassy in Moscow, Arcobaleno is a reputable agency which has been operating in Russia for years. However, last November Italy's Commission for International Adoptions - a branch of the department of social affairs - excluded Arcobaleno from a register of 45 authorised adoption agencies.

The education ministry in Moscow, which under the law has to accredit all foreign adoption agencies in Russia, says it has not heard of Arcobolena.

The Fratti case has outraged Russians and alarmed children's rights experts in Russia. But Arcobaleno's rival agencies were already suspicious, astonished at Ms Fratti's success in bringing high numbers of children from Russia to Italy. "We knew they must be breaking the rules. We work flat out and at most get two dozen kids a year. The magic formula was obvious," said the head of another agency in the Veneto region of northern Italy.

Corrupt

"With the Russian authorities it is always difficult. You would be asked to make so-called donations to mysterious institutions," said Lisa Trasforini, of Ai.Bi, an agency in Melegnano, near Milan. "We have authorisation to operate in Russia but we are not going there until the situation improves. It is too corrupt."

The legal morass and the pervasive corruption surrounding Russian adoption procedures mean that it is the institutionalised children, living in abject conditions in a country in the throes of a major public health crisis, who are the victims. According to a recent western study, there are 650,000 abandoned children in Russia, a figure which has doubled in three years, while 230,000 are in the crumbling state orphanage system.

The conditions are so wretched that 90% of the children require psychiatric treatment within four years of living in an orphanage, said Galina Krasnitskaya of the Russian Children's Fund.

It was effectively impossible for foreigners to adopt a Russian infant until 1991. But in the past decade the country has been flooded with foreign adoption agencies. The number of foreign adoptions rose to 6,200 in 1999, two-thirds of them going to America, while financially-strapped Russians are adopting in ever fewer numbers - 7,000 the same year.

Italy is the second biggest recipient of Russian children, the number increasing from 197 in 1996 to 834 in 1999.

The 1990s was a period of "legal chaos", said Irina Kuznetsova, a lawyer in the Russian parliament specialising in adoption. "Western agencies were working in a legal vacuum for eight years. Because of that, there was lots of abuse of the system.

"There's a huge number of foreign agencies from most European countries operating here, from New Zealand, Canada, Israel, and around 90 from the US," said Vladimir Ustinov, the prosecutor general. "They're turning adoption into a market. Cases of inhuman treatment of Russian children by foreign citizens are frequent."

The popular tabloid Komsomolskaya Pravda proclaimed this week: "Our bureaucrats are sending healthy children for foreign adoption while potential Russian adopters are being offered invalids."

The authorities keep a databank of 80,000 children available for adoption and in theory there have to be three Russian refusals on a given child before he or she can be adopted by a foreigner. In practice, as is alleged to be the case with Ms Fratti, orphanage directors, local education officials and judges demand and receive bribes from the foreigners.

A Russian television documentary on the Volgograd scandal, to be screened on Monday, will demand to know what has happened to the 600 children, and imply that they have fallen into "bad hands", though there is no evidence of anything untoward happening to any of the 600-plus children involved in the Fratti case.

Mr Romodanov, the Volgograd orphanage director, enjoys a good reputation in the city as a caring and skilled child expert. "If we had had any doubts about this woman, we would never have cooperated with her," he said. But Russian investigators say they have already examined 200 of the 600-plus cases and found fiddled paperwork in 173 cases. A secret police source said he suspected that senior education officials in Moscow were involved.

A glimpse into Ms Fratti's world has been given by La Repubblica, the Italian daily, which reported that she was an orphan who was adopted. She is quoted as saying that she knew "in her heart the best thing for abandoned children".

webTitle: Marilyn Monroe estate to sue over nude photos

fields.headline: Marilyn Monroe estate to sue over nude photos
fields.trailText: The issue of who owns the images of the famous dead could be decided in a case arising out of the sale of nude photos of Marilyn Monroe.
fields.body:
The issue of who owns the images of the famous dead could be decided in a case arising out of the sale of nude photos of Marilyn Monroe.

The case concerns not only the originals and negatives of the famous "red velvet" Playboy photos taken before Monroe became a big star, but also the intellectual property in them because her release signature is included in the deal.

The photos have been put on sale by Tom Kelley Jr, whose father took them more than 50 years ago. The auction will take place on March 22 in Los Angeles and on the internet. Bidding is expected to start at about $700,000 (£480,000).

But the Monroe estate is now trying to block the commercial use of the star's image and argues that her signature giving permission for a photo shoot in 1949 does not entitle the owner of that piece of paper to exploit her image.

CMG Worldwide, representing the estate, has indicated it will take legal action to ensure the image is not exploited.

Monroe, who died in 1962, left her image and name to her acting coach Lee Strasberg and the Anna Freud centre, a London psychiatric institute. Strasberg's widow is still a beneficiary along with the centre.

A CMG spokesman said the photographs were of "minimal value" and warned potential buyers that they were not buying the image for commercial use but merely the photos and negatives. "Kelley can sell the photographs of Marilyn Monroe if he wants, but that is all he is selling."

Mr Kelley's agent, Gary Saal, disagrees with the estate, arguing that computer technology, combined with the release form, mean the pictures could be used in a variety of ways.

"Say... someone wanted to take the image of Marilyn Monroe and dress her up, turn her into a moving image and have her purchase an airline ticket," he said. "With the model release form you are allowed to create derivative images. Moving figures? Absolutely."

webTitle: Dealer convicted of fraud as the aboriginal art world fights back

fields.headline: Dealer convicted of fraud as the aboriginal art world fights back
fields.standfirst: To feed a booming market, dealer admits he embellished works signed by a well known artist
fields.trailText: To feed a booming market, dealer admits he embellished works signed by a well known artist
fields.body:
An Adelaide art dealer was found guilty yesterday of selling forged Aboriginal paintings - the first successful Australian prosecution for fraud in the booming market in indigenous people's art.

John O'Loughlin, 54, was placed on a three-year good behaviour bond, after he sold dot paintings signed by one of the most respected native artists, Clifford Possum Tjapaltjarri, to two art dealers.

O'Loughlin admitted that the paintings were not "wholly" the work of Possum, whose canvases have sold for thousands of dollars.

Philip Hall, chief executive of the National Indigenous Arts Advocacy Association, called Possum's work an "absolutely outstanding" part of the $A2.5bn (£930m) aboriginal art market.

"What they did to that poor man is absolutely disgraceful," Mr Hall said. "They've used and abused him for their own personal financial gain."

More than 6,000 aboriginal artists work in the remote and arid central region, known as the "dead centre". Fraudsters have long exploited such artists' lack of knowledge of copyright law.

They have also played on collectors' ignorance of the symbolism of authentic dot paintings.

O'Loughlin claimed in court in Sydney that Possum had made him an honorary "cousin".

He said that after they ate kangaroo intestines together, Possum asked for his help. "Only on that one occasion did he say to me, you can do the dotting - you are my cousin," O'Loughlin said. "I took it then that I could and he never objected to it after that."

O'Loughlin admitted to embellishing and "finishing off" paintings by Mr Possum. The paintings all carried Mr Possum's signature, but the artist told the court he signed the work when he was drunk and intimidated by the art dealer.

Traditional aboriginal bark paintings first became popular with a white audience in the 1950s, before the Papunya Tula people cultivated a collectable contemporary style with innovative "dot painting" in the 1970s. Such works have more than tripled in value during the last decade.

But much "indigenous art" is fake - imported from Asian sweatshops or mass-produced by backpackers paid to be "dot painters".

Questions of authenticity are complicated by the fact that it is common practice for the families of Australian desert artists to do the "dotting" or "filling in" of a work, which is then signed by the artist.

A senior indigenous painter is often the custodian of a symbolic "story" featured in a painting, but will delegate its visual depiction to younger relatives.

"The authenticity question is a complicated one, because a person may put a name on a work if they own the story even if they haven't done any of the production," said Ken Polk, professor of criminology at Melbourne University. "In some aboriginal settings what is critical is the ownership of the story, not the production of the work."

Brenda Crost, curator of indigenous art at the Art Gallery of Western Australia in Perth, said there had always been collaboration, but the western art world craved individual stars. "Artwork has to have a single author because it is more valuable," she said.

Although native-art forgeries were "rampant" in the past, aborigines have wised up, said Cathie Craigie, the director of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander arts board.

Last month, Pro Hart, 72, another of Australia's most recognisable aboriginal painters, called on police to investigate the theft and forgery of his work in the past 30 years.

Hart now marks all his paintings with a coating detectable by a hi-tech scanner. Other artists try to protect their interests by selling solely through 105 non-profit aboriginal community art centres.

But Ms Craigie said a system of labelling to prove authenticity launched last June was patchy because it depended on artists from far-flung places coming forward to register.

Australia's western-derived legal system has trouble dealing with fraud in aboriginal art, Ms Crost said.

"Copyright laws relate to individual artists, whereas many of the works ripped off are communal property. The intellectual property of the work belongs to the community and that's why it's so destructive for many artists. They feel they've failed to look after the stories that have been handed down to them."

"There is a story attached to our art," said Mr Hall. "This is the thing that people don't understand - they are not just looking at a painting and buying a painting, they are buying a story."

Others who ran into trouble

Elizabeth Durack Admired white artist, aged 81, who revealed she had created a black alter ego, Eddie Burrup, in whose name she painted indigenous art. She went on doing so until her death from cancer last year, arguing that there was no deception. Some senior men from the Nyoongar people supported her, believing she was possessed by the spirit of an aboriginal artist.

Kathleen Petyarre Indigenous artist who won the 1996 National Aboriginal Art Prize in Australia. The media alleged that her Welsh-born boyfriend helped paint her winning work. An inquiry by the Museum of the Northern Territory exonerated her.

Mudrooroo Won plaudits and literary prizes across Australia for his six novels and four volumes of poetry. But in 1996 the 57-year-old aboriginal author was unmasked by his sister, Betty Polgaze, as Colin Johnson, an Australian with no aboriginal blood and an Afro-American grandfather.

Wanda Koolmatrie Aboriginal author who won an award for best first work by a woman writer in 1995 with her autobiography, My Own Sweet Time. Two years of being mysteriously unavailable for interviews followed, before it was revealed "she" was Leon Carmen, a white middle-aged Australian. The former taxi driver accused critics of discriminating against whites in favour of aboriginal and immigrant writers.

Sakshi Anmatyerre Highly regarded indigenous painter, who sold works to the Sultan of Brunei and the actor Paul Hogan. Three years ago, it was revealed that this talented artist was a Calcutta Indian, Farley French, who took a new name in 1992.

webTitle: Calls for legal child sex rebound on luminaries of May 68

fields.headline: Calls for legal child sex rebound on luminaries of May 68
fields.standfirst: Some causes championed in the Paris revolt are now seen as very troubling
fields.trailText: Jean-Paul Sartre, Simone de Beauvoir and the current French health and education ministers Bernard Kouchner and Jack Lang were among the signatories of petitions in the 1970s calling for paedophilia to be decriminalised, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
Jean-Paul Sartre, Simone de Beauvoir and the current French health and education ministers Bernard Kouchner and Jack Lang were among the signatories of petitions in the 1970s calling for paedophilia to be decriminalised, it emerged yesterday.

A number of extraordinary documents have surfaced - in the wake of accusations of possible child sex abuse against the former student revolutionary Danny Cohn-Bendit that are forcing France's intellectuals to confront the values of the May 1968 revolution and its aftermath, a period that witnessed probably the biggest change in sexual behaviour in recorded history.

The petitions were issued after a 1977 trial that saw three men jailed for non-violent sex offences against children aged 12 and 13. "Three years in prison for caresses and kisses: enough is enough," one petition, signed by Mr Kouchner and Mr Lang, said.

"French law recognises in 12- and 13-year-olds a capacity for discernment that it can judge and punish," said a second petition signed by Sartre and De Beauvoir, along with fellow intellectuals Michel Foucault, Roland Barthes, Jacques Derrida; a leading child psychologist, Françoise Dolto; and writers Philippe Sollers, Alain Robbe-Grillet and Louis Aragon. "But it rejects such a capacity when the child's emotional and sexual life is concerned. It should acknowledge the right of children and adolescents to have relations with whomever they choose."

Such tracts and manifestos were not just acceptable but fashionable at the time. "A lot of good came out of 68, but we have to face it now, the era was naive," Roland Castro, an architect who was a prominent figure in the uprising, said yesterday. "We said everything and its opposite, hastily, without reflection. And in trying to break out of all the old barriers, we ended up pulling them down altogether."

Now an MEP for the French Green party, Mr Cohn-Bendit has been severely embarrassed by the resurfacing of an article he published in 1975 about the "erotic" nature of his contacts with children at an alternative kindergarten in Frankfurt, where he lived and worked after being kicked out of France for his part in May 68.

"Certain children opened the flies of my trousers and started to tickle me," he wrote. "I reacted differently each time, according to the circumstances ... But when they insisted on it, I then caressed them."

Mr Cohn-Bendit has insisted that the passages "bear no relationship to reality", that he has never been a paedophile, and that the article - taken from a book, Le Grand Bazar - was "a product of its time, of our anti-authoritarianism; pure provocation, designed to shock the bourgeoisie".

At the time, the book and Mr Cohn-Bendit's TV appearances to discuss it, got critical acclaim.

Some 20 children then in his care, now in their 30s, and their parents have written an open letter in his support, and Frankfurt prosecutors said yesterday there was "quite clearly" no case to answer.

But some at the time went further. Writer Tony Duvert praised "the great adventure of paedophilia" and raged at "the fascism of mothers". Philosopher René Scherrer urged "the removal of all sexual taboos - nothing should be outlawed".

Across the Rhine, the reassessment of May 68 is all about politics and violence. Mr Cohn-Bendit's close friend and fellow 70s radical Joschka Fischer, now Germany's foreign minister, is under fire over footage showing him striking a policeman. He also faces a judicial investigation into allegations that he lied about contacts with suspected terrorists in the 70s.

In France, the debate is more about sex. "Cohn-Bendit should resign, and he should do it now," declared Philippe de Villiers, a senior conservative. "For how many paedophiles have his appalling statements served as justification, or even encouragement?"

One signatory of the 1977 petition, Philippe Sollers, admitted yesterday that "there were so many manifestos, we signed them almost automatically". What shocked him now, he said, was that "the whole problem of violence against children was simply not a social problem at the time", but is now.

Libération, the left-leaning French newspaper that emerged from the barricades of 68, devoted four pages to the issue yesterday. It pointed out that in the 70s, French leftists held "a very serious debate about whether parents should leave their bedroom door open when they were having sex".

May 68 did not invent paedophilia, said Libération's editor Serge July. "The existing moral order was the enemy," he said. "The cultural revolution that followed May 68 was a social triumph in many, many ways. But its discourse on the sexuality of children has served to legitimise practices that are, at times, criminal."

fields.headline: On the street with the drinking classes
fields.trailText: Seryozha's 24-hour store on the corner of our street is one of the blessings of our neighbourhood. Shopping and driving remain a trial in Moscow, so Seryozha is ideal for that late-night jar of cheap caviar, hunk of black bread and wee bottle of vodka.
fields.body:
Seryozha's 24-hour store on the corner of our street is one of the blessings of our neighbourhood. Shopping and driving remain a trial in Moscow, so Seryozha is ideal for that late-night jar of cheap caviar, hunk of black bread and wee bottle of vodka.

Customers are spoiled for choice. Seryozha has more than a dozen brands of vodka, maybe 18 different bottled beers, then the fizzy cans of alcohol-laced sugar that are all the rage. These lethal tinned cocktails are treated as soft drinks, as is beer. No self-respecting Russian drinker considers beer alcoholic - indeed, it is officially classified as a soft drink.

The sign on Seryozha's shop proclaims "Baker's". But one shouldn't take these things too literally. True, he does sell bread, though the concept of freshness is a relative one. Three times a week I wearily go through the ritual with the bread girl. "Is the bread fresh?"

"Of course, it's yesterday's."

There's also a cheese counter and a section doling out grim cold cuts. But there's only ever one queue at Seryozha's, and that's for the drink. Like the hundreds of similar little shops across the city, Seryozha's is essentially an off-licence, with its round-the-clock opening hours guaranteeing a steady stream of customers day and night.

They're mostly street drinkers. There's no stigma attached to being half-cut on the streets of Moscow. Indeed, these little stores serve as a substitute for the pub or cafe societies of other European countries.

Invariably every evening - rain, hail or shine and currently in temperatures of -20C - a little huddle of drinkers congregates outside the baker's. This is what passes for social life for the majority who can't afford the much higher prices in the bars and coffee houses.

In Seryozha's you can buy a bottle of extra-strong Russian-brewed beer for 30p. In a bar it might cost five times that. Hence the al fresco socialising in the depths of winter.

One of the most striking sights for a newcomer to Moscow must be the scale of street drinking. In the parks, in the metro, huddled outside stores, walking down any city street, young men or prim middle-aged women clutch bottles of beer and cans of carbonated alcohol.

It's less common to see someone clasping a bottle of vodka, though the average Russian male is reckoned to imbibe almost a litre (just under two pints) of the hard stuff a week.

Temperance, in short, is not a word that figures prominently in the vocabulary of most Muscovites, though there was a 20th century tradition of bald Russian rulers resorting to prohibitions, propaganda campaigns, and other bureaucratic means to stamp out the demon drink.

After the revolution, Lenin - bald, preachy, and a virtual teetotaller - continued with the dry laws the Romanovs imposed in 1914 at the outbreak of the first world war. Mikhail Gorbachev - bald, preachy, and abstemious - traumatised the Russian male by rationing vodka in 1985 which, in turn, made many old country crones rich from the moonshine boom.

Vladimir Putin - going bald, ascetic, and stern - has limited himself so far to pushing up vodka prices by 30%. It remains to be seen if he'll opt for anything more drastic.

It was the 90s, the era of Boris Yeltsin - thick shock of white hair and alcoholic - that put public drinking on the streets of Moscow, replacing Mr Gorbachev's temperance campaigning with the culture of the binge.

Gennady Kolomentsev, a KGB colonel who ran the Kremlin's catering service for 40 years, revealed last week that Mr Yeltsin used to order several bottles of vodka and cognac every day from the Kremlin cellars. Thick-haired Leonid Brezhnev was also an avid vodka tippler, though in later years he became an obsessive weight-watcher, according to the colonel. Bald Nikita Khrushchev was, as usual, the exception to the rule, knocking back Ukrainian vodka by the bottle.

Mr Putin, we are told, is more of a red wine tippler. And his time in Germany has also left him partial to a Pils. But not on the street.
