fields.headline: The trouble with Vanessa...
fields.standfirst: How many years of higher education does it take to be photographed wearing a vat of whipped cream and a shell-shocked smile?
fields.trailText: How many years of higher education does it take to be photographed wearing a vat of whipped cream and a shell-shocked smile?
fields.body:
We all know that when it comes to celebrities there is the A-list - Madonna, Prince William, Posh Spice - and the B-list - Jerry Hall, Jeremy Irons, Scary Spice - and the C-list - Jordan, anyone who's ever played Dr Who, Sporty Spice. But what list is Vanessa Feltz on? Who put her on it? And isn't there some sort of Celeb Complaints Council we can petition to take her off it, and out of our faces forever?

On the whole, we're pretty tolerant of our celebs over here. We tend not to shoot 'em (John Lennon) or have special vans fitted out with torture chambers in which to put them to a gory end (Steven Spielberg). We realise that these sad souls have something missing in their lives that stops them from being content with the normal amount of love that most of us make do with from our friends and families; we are patient as they show us their tits, take off their knickers and blame their quite grotesque neediness on the fact that they once saw Mommy kissing Santa Claus when they were six years old.

But in return for our gracious forbearance, we ask that they have a little something going for them - just a little. They don't have to be rocket scientists, or even great at what they do, but a bit of charm and a bit of style never goes amiss. Catherine Zeta-Jones, say, or Martine McCutcheon are good examples of celebs towards whom there is enormous public goodwill. This is not so much for their characters or their talents - which may or may not turn out to be remarkable; the signs in both cases are good - but for their guts, their glamour and their pizazz. No matter how radiantly beautiful they look and what credits they rack up, they retain the common touch; both from underprivileged backgrounds, they tell their tales of woe with wry humour and move on to the next thing. And we cheer them.

On the other hand, most of us feel confused and rather resentful when we see "celebrities" paid vast sums of money out of our pockets, via the television licence, who are actually about as celebrated as syphilis. And we feel the same perplexed vexation when we are asked to admire "personalities" who have all the sheer molten magnetism of a dressing doll. Andy Warhol prepared us for the day when everyone would be famous for 15 minutes - but he couldn't have imagined these dog-days, when celebrities are uncelebrated and personalities have none, but plug on nevertheless as though they were Marilyn Monroe, Mahatma Gandhi and Limahl all rolled into one.

No one sums up this species of celebrity better than Vanessa Feltz. (Incidentally, nothing sums up the confusion and cretinism of the modern BBC more than their huge investment in her, or the reason why "real people" TV has become so incredibly popular, but that's another story.)

Far more than Tara, Tamara, Victoria or any of the It Girls - who are just moderately attractive, demi-posh chicks who like having their picture taken, same as they always have, only now it's in a G-string rather than jodhpurs - Feltz is a moral fable for our times; on how celebrity has become therapy, rather than the elevation of the most attractive and/or talented, which it traditionally was.

Feltz is an interesting case because, unlike the surging swirls of pretty girls who hit the TV screens every year in search of fame as "presenters", she actually had several things going for her that might have helped her avoid the celebrity sausage-machine.

She had an education, a family, she was in her 30s and, best of all, she wasn't seen as being particularly good-looking. In any decade before the 90s, she'd have been "safe"; she wouldn't have dreamed of apeing the hundreds of under-qualified girls who attempt to jostle their way into the sad bordellos of showbiz, using their beauty the way a young, working-class boxer uses his fists - to get out.

But in the 90s, when Helen Mirren and the Women's Institute got their kit off for the hacks, everyone threw caution to the wind. Call it pre- millennial hysteria if you like - whatever, this well- educated, middle-aged housewife was suddenly acting like Denise van Outen, banging on about her brilliant sex life and altogether giving us more information than we needed. Who exactly was it at the BBC who decided she was just what the doctor ordered to send the daytime ratings rocketing? Whatever, millions of pounds of public money were thrown at her.

Feltz signifies far beyond her immediate self in another thing; she was vastly over-qualified for the job she took on, namely that of on-air agony aunt, leading the chorus of woe from the council estates. (Not just over-qualified but temperamentally unsuited for the compassion racket, perhaps; this is a woman who so begrudged her widowed father his happiness with his second wife that she didn't speak to him for years on end.) In the contempt she showed her guests, we saw the sour whine of the Blair-led graduate, who is qualified up to the eyeballs and just can't believe they have to deal with the common herd as they serve them in Starbucks. Not surprisingly, the public reacted by switching off.

Feltz lost both her billet and her husband and set about "reinventing" herself - that other great buzzword of our time. She lost a lot of weight, and that is now her thing; once famous for being fat, she is now famous for being thin. What will she do when this ceases to be a selling point? At what point will this educated and cultured woman choose to set herself some other goal than being a human hula hoop? Does she ever wonder why she bothered swotting for that First? How many years of higher education does it take to be photographed wearing a vat of whipped cream and a shell-shocked smile?

When Feltz was fat, she gloated about it; now she's thin, she gloats about that. But being thin is nothing to be proud of - any more than being fat is. (And no guarantee of beauty, either - who's the cutest, Sophie Dahl at size 16, Feltz at size 12 or Calista Flockhart at size 8?) It's amazing, isn't it, that someone can have a Cambridge First and still not realise that pride should be what we attach to our achievements, not our measurements.

Fat or thin, married or single, Feltz remains a chilling warning to the rest of us fat, middle-aged types about the vast vistas of humiliation which await us if we really start believing that looks matter more than books.

fields.headline: Buy a car
fields.trailText: How to...
fields.body:
Buying a new car is clearly a big decision. You need to do a lot of detailed research, comparing urban cycle mpg, depreciation costs and load-carrying capacity across a wide range of cars. And then, when you've finished all this research, you get the car you fancied in the first place, even if it has the mpg of an armoured personnel carrier and the depreciation of a dot.com share.

It's always a good idea to test drive a new car. It's called a test drive because you suddenly feel as if you're doing your driving test again. The 10 minutes you have in the car will be the worst 10 minutes of driving you've done since you were with your dad in Sainsbury's car park.

And it doesn't help that the salesman will be pointing out the superb road-holding as you accidentally mount a kerb because you can't find the clutch. It's much better just to sit in the driver's seat in the showroom, hold the wheel tightly and make quiet vrooming noises.

At some stage, the salesman might lift the bonnet for you to have a look at the engine. It's very difficult to know what to say at this stage, as you feel as if a waiter has taken you to have a look at the kitchen. Just say something like, 'So that's where they put it', and then ask to see something useful, such as how you get the filler cap off.

There are some sharp practices in car sales, and one of the worst is the cut-and-shut, in which two halves of old cars are welded together. Look out for subtle little signs, such as the front half of the car being a Ford Escort and the back a Vauxhall Viva. It's easy to spot dodgy second-hand car places, because they are obliged by law to put up those little lines of blue, red and white flags. Just think of these as the equivalent of Police Line: Do Not Cross ribbons around the site of an attempted robbery.

When you're inspecting a car, some people think that kicking the tyres is a good idea. This does two things: a) it tells the vendor that you know nothing about cars, and b) it tells you that your shoes aren't as thick as you thought they were. Kicking the body panels isn't allowed, as this is, technically speaking, vandalism.

fields.bodyText: Buying a new car is clearly a big decision. You need to do a lot of detailed research, comparing urban cycle mpg, depreciation costs and load-carrying capacity across a wide range of cars. And then, when you've finished all this research, you get the car you fancied in the first place, even if it has the mpg of an armoured personnel carrier and the depreciation of a dot.com share. It's always a good idea to test drive a new car. It's called a test drive because you suddenly feel as if you're doing your driving test again. The 10 minutes you have in the car will be the worst 10 minutes of driving you've done since you were with your dad in Sainsbury's car park. And it doesn't help that the salesman will be pointing out the superb road-holding as you accidentally mount a kerb because you can't find the clutch. It's much better just to sit in the driver's seat in the showroom, hold the wheel tightly and make quiet vrooming noises. At some stage, the salesman might lift the bonnet for you to have a look at the engine. It's very difficult to know what to say at this stage, as you feel as if a waiter has taken you to have a look at the kitchen. Just say something like, 'So that's where they put it', and then ask to see something useful, such as how you get the filler cap off. There are some sharp practices in car sales, and one of the worst is the cut-and-shut, in which two halves of old cars are welded together. fields.headline: Good Housekeeping
fields.standfirst: 'We go to lunch wondering if the sous-chef will run amok with his chopper'
fields.trailText: Dulcie Domum: 'We go to lunch wondering if the sous-chef will run amok with his chopper'
fields.body:
Fred and I are in Tobago. The moon looks different here. It lies on its back with its legs in the air - as if it, too, is on holiday. Fred has been here before, and raved to me about the deep, dark peace, the voluptuous rainforests, the Bible-reading grandmas. But Tobago has changed. Our travel rep warned us not to carry much cash, not to stop for hitchhikers and, above all, not to go to secluded places with young men we've just met. So it looks as if Fred will have to have a very different holiday this time.

He will, anyway - because he's with me. We're an odd couple. Fred is Leonard Bernstein, I, in my tropical print sarong, am Tuigamala. But the hotel is full of odd couples of all races and sexes. We, as a mere bisexual and asexual, are boringly conventional. But the oddest are Harold and Joan from Doncaster. "We don't reckon much to Tobago," Harold informs us, queueing for the pawpaw. "Joan had set her heart on a ride on one of them inflatable bananas they have in Barbados. And the barbecue last night were an insult."

There are no inflatable bananas in the waters of our beach - only fishermen, pelicans and laughing gulls. The surf thunders below our windows like artillery. I sit on the balcony feeding watermelon to blue birds. Behind us the deep, dark rainforest creeps up the mountainside. Before us the sea glitters all day, then turns to mercury at dusk. I am mesmerised. There are bananas, but they are not inflatable. They are tiny and called "fig". They taste of the Garden of Eden. But is there a serpent here? We go down to lunch wondering if the sous-chef will run amok with his chopper. Or perhaps the beautiful, smiling waitress will pronounce a voodoo curse, or steal my purse. But no. We help ourselves to a salad of Darwinian variety, containing leaves, nuts, fruits, mushrooms, herbs, a mermaid's murmur and a hummingbird's hum.

Aunt Elspeth lent me her binoculars and a book, Birds Of Trinidad And Tobago, and I feel obliged to spot the odd parrot before we return, just to placate her. The beautiful waitress tells me the best place to see birds is under the yellow tree by the swimming pool, at dawn or dusk. At dusk I am there, training my binoculars on a ruby-topaz hummingbird, when Harold of Doncaster strolls up, drying his paunch.

"This swimming pool's an insult," he informs me.

"So are the hummingbirds," I reply. "Deeply disappointing."

He doesn't hear. He doesn't listen. "I've got a friend in Planning," Harold confides. "He'd have a nervous breakdown if he could see what goes on here."

Night falls with merciful swiftness. We return to our rooms and dress for dinner: gleaming white fish, grilled with lime juice, and crisp, cinnamon-scented pumpkin fritters, etc. An excellent local band plays. The English dance, tentatively, like people taking medicine or being brave - they dance like damaged automata on the Antiques Roadshow.

"That's nowt," remarks Harold in passing. "You should've seen the limbo dancer we had in Barbados. Gold lamé shorts, the lot."

Next afternoon, we go to a small hotel called Arnos Vale, where they feed the birds at teatime on a high white veranda overlooking the distant sea. First a crowd of big, brown, pheasant-like creatures come. They are cocricos - the national emblem. "Cocrico!" they shout, unsurprisingly. They gobble up most of the grub, and disappear. Other, smaller birds arrive. But the star waits until it is very late and shady - about 5pm. Then the motmots arrive. The big star turn. An iridescent blue head, a soft green velvety back, a blushing russet breast, and a great long tail like a pair of tennis racquets. The motmot says little. It doesn't do much, either: just sits around waiting for food and adoration. I can feel myself falling in love with it. Ornithology will be my theology. I shall become a female Bill Oddie - a sucker for anything in feathers.

We try to tell Harold about the motmots, but he doesn't listen. "Do you realise," he tells Fred, "that half Tony Blair's cabinet's composed of bloody poofters?"

Fred smiles demurely. "How very reassuring," he replies. The only crime on Tobago, we reckon, was the fact that Harold had been let in.

fields.headline: Food
fields.standfirst: The British consumer's attitude to veal calves smacks of hypocrisy, argues Joanna Blythman
fields.trailText: The British consumer's attitude to veal calves smacks of hypocrisy, argues Joanna Blythman
fields.body:
Many British people won't eat veal because they regard it as one of the cruellest of all meats in terms of its production. At the root of our objections lies the dominant production system on the continent, where flavourless white veal is cheap and ubiquitous, its pallid tenderness achieved by abruptly and prematurely separating calves from their mothers at birth, then confining them entirely indoors in small crates with slatted floors and no room to turn around. There, they are fed only on milk powder and water, and kept in a permanent state of anaemia until they are slaughtered. No wonder we call for a boycott.

However, such objections are mainly historical. The veal crate will be banned throughout Europe by 2007, and is already illegal in the UK. Also, many consumers remain unaware that every day on British dairy farms thousands of veal calves are shot dead simply because they have no commercial value.

And there, in a nutshell, is the problem. The milk we drink comes from cows that are kept pregnant and in calf so they will lactate. Their female offspring are reared as the next generation of milkers, but what about the male calves? Before BSE, many of our bull calves were exported live to factory farms on the continent, where they were reared and slaughtered as white veal. Thankfully, BSE regulations put paid to that particularly repellent trade - although a further consequence of BSE is that there is now no market for more mature beef from the dairy herd, which is where the disease originated. Consumers today want young beef from dedicated beef animals (suckler herds), not second-grade dairy beef. So dairy farms up and down the land are either selling their male calves solely for their skins or are just routinely shooting them and then burning the carcasses. "It is most depressing," one farmer told me. "You're up helping the cow to calf at night, then shooting her offspring in the morning."

If those calves were raised humanely for meat, however, this practice might well stop. Most conventional farmers see no future in veal, but organic farmers are beginning to look for ways to avoid this enormously wasteful slaughter, not least as its scale has grown commensurately with the boom in demand for organic milk. Helen Browning, for example, has been producing veal on Eastbrook, her organic farm in Wiltshire, for the past five years. Here, the calf stays with its mother for the first few days after birth and is then "mothered up" with and suckled by an older dairy cow (a sort of bovine wet-nurse system), until it is slaughtered at about five months of age. In that time, the calf is free-ranging, usually outdoors, and has ready access to natural feedstuffs such as oats and hay. This way, it has a healthy diet and a decent life, albeit short.

This approach results in rosé veal meat, the premium type of veal that is known in France as "veau sous la mère" - the meat has a pale, rosy hue, because the calf has eaten a varied, natural diet; a slightly firmer texture, because the calf has been able to exercise; and also a better, more beefy flavour.

But the very concept of "high- welfare" veal is, for many consu-mers in Britain at least, a complete contradiction in terms, albeit one predicated entirely on a basic lack of understanding. "We had plans to market veal from other organic farms," says Helen Browning, "but we have found that we are struggling with marketing even our own. If we saw orders pick up, that would give us confidence and we'd scale up our production." More than anything, it seems, while consumers can recognise the vast difference between, say, the raising of a broiler chicken and its organic, free-range counterpart, the generic term "veal" seems to evoke a blanket prejudice.

We are creatures of habit, too. While Italian cooks automatically turn to veal mince for a lasagne, or to veal shin for osso buco, the meat is far more unfamiliar to British consumers. That's hardly surprising, as only a few independent butchers sell the slightly more welfare-friendly meat from "loose-house" systems, in which, though the calves are kept indoors, they are not crated. Even supermarkets sell such veal only in minuscule volumes. Otherwise, veal is used mainly by restaurants of a classical French inclination, none of which can properly function without a bubbling stock pot of "fonds bruns" based on veal bones.

It is, then, a matter of education if the British consumer is ever going to understand that there are as many nuances in the production of veal as there are in any other meat. The only veal "abstainers" who really show a consistent and logical position in the whole debate are vegans - their forgoing of dairy products is based on the fact that they believe dairy farming is intrinsically cruel, not least because calves are taken away from their mothers prematurely so that poor old Daisy can be milked to exhaustion.

The rest of us, on the other hand, seem to be suffering from a large dose of hypocrisy - or, to put it more charitably, confusion - that we really ought to confront: if we drink milk, we should be prepared to eat at least some veal, otherwise we are first contributing to and then turning a blind eye to (if not condoning) one of modern farming's most unpleasant and profligate practices

fields.headline: The Questionnaire: Elaine Feinstein
fields.standfirst: Elaine Feinstein was born in Bootle, Merseyside, in 1930. After grammar school she read English at Newnham College Cambridge. She worked for Cambridge University Press and later became an assistant lecturer at Essex University. A novelist, poet and translator, she has published 15 novels and 10 collections of poetry. She has also written TV and radio plays, and many biographies. Her much-anticipated biography of Ted Hughes is due out later this year. Her latest novel, Dark Inheritance, has just been published.

She has also written TV and radio plays, and many biographies. Her much-anticipated biography of Ted Hughes is due out later this year. Her latest novel, Dark Inheritance, has just been published.
fields.body:
What is your idea of perfect happiness?
Laughter, surrounded by people I love, with good wine and fruit on the table.

What is your greatest fear?
Being trapped for days in a small underground room.

With which historical figure do you most identify?
v The 20th-century Russian poet Marina Tsvetayeva, who shared most of my faults - domestic laziness, for instance - but was altogether disciplined in her work.

What objects do you always carry with you?
Car keys. Sometimes I swing them from one finger, to remind myself I can leave if I get bored.

What do you most dislike about your appearance?
My knobbly feet.

What is your favourite smell?
A marinade of rosemary, ginger, mustard and fresh garlic.

What is your favourite book?
War And Peace.

How did you vote in the last election?
Labour. With enthusiasm.

How will you vote in the next election?
Labour. Maybe with less enthusiasm.

Should the royal family be scrapped?
It would have no effect on the divisions in society.

Do you believe in capital punishment?
No. We get things wrong too often.

Which living person do you most despise?
Any bully. From the playground lout to Milosevic.

Have you ever said 'I love you' and not meant it?
No. But love is a complicated emotion.

Which words or phrases do you most overuse?
I probably say 'I love you' more often than I should.

When and where were you happiest?
Living in a commune in Portugal Place, Cambridge, in the late 50s.

What single thing would improve the quality of your life?
A south-facing terrace.

Do you believe in life after death?
No. But who knows? There are lot of people I'd like to see again.

fields.headline: I hate Hannibal
fields.standfirst: Wild boar in Kent and Dorset have already broken into outdoor pig units and mated with domestic sows, producing hybrid piglets
fields.trailText: Wild boar in Kent and Dorset have already broken into outdoor pig units and mated with domestic sows, producing hybrid piglets.
fields.body:
I went to see the film Hannibal the other night and disliked it intensely for its combination of tedium, depravity and gore. But it may have served some purpose if it has made people less sentimental about wild boar. The wild boars in the film have been trained to be ferocious man-killers with a taste for human flesh, and eventually they tear a man to bits in a particularly repulsive scene.

Normal wild boars are not like that, of course, but it is conceivable that they could be made to be. They will eat practically anything, and they regularly devour mice, rabbits, birds and snakes, as well as roots, tubers, mushrooms and fruit. They are also by nature extremely fierce, but probably trainable. Some people say they are more intelligent than dogs.

As John Vidal explained recently in the Guardian, they have started to re-colonise southern England after being declared extinct in Britain more than 300 years ago. It is estimated that there could already be as many as 500 of them roaming the woods of Kent, East Sussex and Dorset - a figure that could grow by six or seven times over the next 10 years, given their enthusiastic breeding habits.

The first sightings of boars in the wild were in the late 1980s on Paul McCartney's estate in Sussex near Peasmarsh. They were assumed to have escaped from John Aspinall's nearby wildlife park or from one of Britain's handful of wild boar farms. They will never go back again, except by choice, for they are shy, elusive and uncatchable. Unless they are all killed, England will be swarming again with wild boar, as it was in the Middle Ages when boar-hunting was considered the noblest and bravest of outdoor sports.

Some conservationists are whooping with joy. Britain's largest mammal, the king of the forest, has returned after an absence of a few centuries. But not everyone is so pleased. Arable farmers do not like having their crops trampled. Nature-lovers are already mourning the destruction of bluebell woods. Sheep farmers have reported wild boar attacks on lambs. Motorists have been involved in collisions with them.

The most worried people are pig farmers, who fear they will spread swine fever and other pig diseases. As the Ministry of Agriculture has confirmed, wild boar in Kent and Dorset have already broken into outdoor pig units and mated with domestic sows, producing hybrid piglets. "This contact between free- living wild boar and domestic pigs could provide a transmission route for the spread of disease," the ministry has said. One can easily envisage an end to organic pig farming, while it is still only in its infancy.

Then there are the gardeners. They may not have suffered much yet, but they surely will. I know something about the wild boar's consideration for gardens from having a house in Tuscany, where thousands of them live. A freshly-watered garden offers a most tempting spot for night-time foraging. We tried putting flashing lights outside the house to frighten off the wild boar. A man even sat all night in a window with a gun. But still the lawn looks like a ploughed field. Although most Tuscan villages have squads of wild boar hunters who go out after them with guns and packs of hounds, they continue to multiply and wreak havoc, especially in the vineyards. Wild boar are surprisingly fond of grapes.

Admittedly, wild boar have a certain strange beauty and primeval grandeur about them, and nobody would want them eliminated in their natural habitat, which is forest. But there is little forest left in England, and there are an awful lot of gardens and farms. Having no natural predators in Britain, wild boar will be killed by nobody if not man, and there is already some interest among English field sports enthusiasts in the idea of hunting them. But using hounds for the chase will, of course, be forbidden if the anti-foxhunting bill becomes law.

Having made such a recent appearance in England, wild boar are not classified as game and enjoy no legal protection, so we can kill them all the year round if we want to. Perhaps we should get on and do it, if only to annoy the conservationists. In Italy and America they have been successfully bringing back the wolf, now a protected species, to much popular consternation, though the Italians do nothing about the mass poisoning of dogs and cats.

Scottish Natural Heritage, which is whimsically planning to introduce Canadian beavers to Scotland at the taxpayers' expense, has been advised to sterilise the first batch in case they ruin the fishing and then can't be got rid of. Countries change, landscapes change, and you cannot introduce a new animal species without affecting ones that are already there. For the wild boar, the south of England is hardly the ideal home.

Some conservationists are whooping with joy. Britain's largest mammal, the king of the forest, has returned after an absence of a few centuries. But not everyone is so pleased. Arable farmers do not like having their crops trampled. Nature-lovers are already mourning the destruction of bluebell woods. Sheep farmers have reported wild boar attacks on lambs. Motorists have been involved in collisions with them. The most worried people are pig farmers, who fear they will spread swine fever and other pig diseases. As the Ministry of Agriculture has confirmed, wild boar in Kent and Dorset have already broken into outdoor pig units and mated with domestic sows, producing hybrid piglets. "This contact between free- living wild boar and domestic pigs could provide a transmission route for the spread of disease," the ministry has said. One can easily envisage an end to organic pig farming, while it is still only in its infancy. Then there are the gardeners. They may not have suffered much yet, but they surely will. I know something about the wild boar's consideration for gardens from having a house in Tuscany, where thousands of them live. A freshly-watered garden offers a most tempting spot for night-time foraging. We tried putting flashing lights outside the house to frighten off the wild boar. A man even sat all night in a window with a gun. But still the lawn looks like a ploughed field. Although most Tuscan villages have squads of wild boar hunters who go out after them with guns and packs of hounds, they continue to multiply and wreak havoc, especially in the vineyards. Wild boar are surprisingly fond of grapes. Admittedly, wild boar have a certain strange beauty and primeval grandeur about them, and nobody would want them eliminated in their natural habitat, which is forest. But there is little forest left in England, and there are an awful lot of gardens and farms. Having no natural predators in Britain, wild boar will be killed by nobody if not man, and there is already some interest among English field sports enthusiasts in the idea of hunting them. But using hounds for the chase will, of course, be forbidden if the anti-foxhunting bill becomes law. Having made such a recent appearance in England, wild boar are not classified as game and enjoy no legal protection, so we can kill them all the year round if we want to. Perhaps we should get on and do it, if only to annoy the conservationists. In Italy and America they have been successfully bringing back the wolf, now a protected species, to much popular consternation, though the Italians do nothing about the mass poisoning of dogs and cats. Scottish Natural Heritage, which is whimsically planning to introduce Canadian beavers to Scotland at the taxpayers' expense, has been advised to sterilise the first batch in case they ruin the fishing and then can't be got rid of. Countries change, landscapes change, and you cannot introduce a new animal species without affecting ones that are already there. For the wild boar, the south of England is hardly the ideal home.

fields.headline: All the home's a stage
fields.standfirst: They know all about you, they're choosing your cushions, and they'd like you to take a seat at the table. Meet the show home stylists: more sophisticated than ever and hell-bent on a sale
fields.trailText: They know all about you, they're choosing your cushions, and they'd like you to take a seat at the table. Meet the show home stylists: more sophisticated than ever and hell-bent on a sale
fields.body:
Bruce Oldfield? John Rocha? Philippe Starck? Not the sort of names you'd usually associate with mass-market show homes. What springs to mind is an overdressed brick box, decorated in Barbara Cartland pinks and screaming aquamarines; all swags, frills and wallpaper borders, bowls of simulated vegetables and, eek!, potpourri.

But these trumped-up marketing suites are now being styled by top-name designers in bold, cutting-edge schemes. "We are selling a lifestyle," is the mantra of the modern developer, and whose lifestyle depends on the nature of the "potential purchaser profile". Some still get off on limed oak; others can't live without Smeg.

"The purchaser profile is very important," insists Dawn Kitchener of Connections In Design, a national company that rustles up show home interiors for all sorts of housing schemes. Her brief, in essence, is to "create the desire to buy", but first she needs to know exactly who the buyers are. That's not too difficult, I imagine. The defining factors must, surely, be location and spending power. But, no, Kitchener likes to "visualise" her purchaser. Whoever they are ("go-ahead young professionals, city slickers, 30-plus high-earners"), she sets out to second-guess those vital aspirations and merchandise accordingly.

"As a company, we are very aware of changing fashions and what turns people on," says Kitchener, who has just dressed a Nottingham flat in lilac and pewter. Home buyers, she continues, are better educated, more label-conscious, and have higher expectations these days. And one of the most significant new trends in home marketing, she observes, is in forging close relationships with big names in design, architecture and, indeed, fashion.

John Rocha, for example, has put his name to design elements of L3, a just-launched city-centre scheme in Liverpool. Bruce Oldfield OBE, haute couturier to the rich and famous (Catherine Zeta-Jones, Jerry Hall, Jemima Khan and the late Princess Diana), has created four "signature" show homes at Kew Riverside, a salubrious housing development in Surrey. And super-designer Philippe Starck is a proactive partner in YOO, the developer behind YOOnw8, a loft-converted 30s telephone exchange in Maida Vale, London.

So what, exactly, do you get in a Starck show home? Slinky chrome dining chairs, mink egg cosies, white cotton linen, Chanel No 19 gel moussant, a grinning gnome stool, glass candelabras, mountains of fresh citrus fruit, copies of Wallpaper*, no curtains.

And what about the Oldfield? Walls clothed in panels of soft suede or navy pinstripe wool, daring colours, floor-sweeping white drapes in pleated silk (vaguely Issey Miyake), triple-milled soap bricks, potted cacti and copies of House & Garden arranged on a low "light-box" table (his own design).

According to Oldfield, doing show homes has proved a great way to launch "a new career in cushion scattering" (a testing ground, in other words, for his new range of furnishings and fabrics). For the developer St James Homes, it's the ultimate marketing coup. Kew Riverside (or QR, as it's known) is the kind of development that claims to offer "a total solutions, bespoke concierge service": the lowest-priced apartment is the one-bed (yours for £245,000). But QR is built on 26 acres of redundant Thames Water sewage works. A bit of kudos, a bit of "full-on glamour", was required.

Oldfield doesn't have much truck with all that purchaser profile stuff. "I dutifully listened to all the marketing gobbledegook and the earnest discussions about 'end-users'," he says. "But I still did exactly as I pleased." In essence, Oldfield acted as the creative director: he chose the colours and textiles; sourced classic images from the Hulton Getty photographic library; loaned original catwalk sketches. But the nuts and bolts or, as Oldfield puts it, "the nick, nacky noos" (the aspirational footwear, the reading material, the low-maintenance plant life, the Harvey Nichols wasabi and ginger dressing - all those little details that humanise a few hundred square feet of real estate) were the work of the ubiquitous Connections In Design.

First impressions of the one-bed apartment, however, are pure Bruce Oldfield. A bedroom chair wears a ballgown of moiré silk complete with bow-tied back; the bed, dressed in a quilted Puffa-style duvet, sits on a luminous pink light box that casts an ethereal mauve light over the pale blue carpet. "There's a degree of 'what the hell' in show-home design," says Oldfield. "It's a fantasy, a bit of theatre."

To Dawn Kitchener's satisfaction, most potential purchasers who wandered in during the first few days were thirtysomething professionals, mostly women - exactly what she had visualised. Oldfield would have been equally delighted to meet the pair who fingered the silk chiffon curtains, and stroked the pink, poodley wool cushions and pronounced the decor "very tactile". St James Homes must be pleased, too. Kew Riverside's one beds have sold out.

Show homes do work. Even developers who like to think that their purchasers are far too sophisticated for such trifles have to admit that all that styling makes a difference. John Hitchcox, the developer behind YOOnw8, is one of them. As an early pioneer of the London loft movement, he was a former member of the shell-and-core school, offering sandblasted building sites dressed, perhaps, with a single iconic chair.

"Looking back, it was arrogant to assume that buyers can visualise the potential of an empty space," he says. "Most people tend to live in fairly normal environments, they don't know anything about design or construction - why should they? If you want to sell something extraordinary, you have to stimulate their imaginations."

Together with Starck, Hitchcox has now come up with a formula for helping buyers "define their own living environment", a combination of personalised internal architecture and a choice of hundreds of fixtures and fittings, all divided into four lifestyle categories: Nature, Classic, Minimal and Culture. The show home (1,250sq ft at £600,000) is an example of the latter, and though it reflects Starck's idea of home ("love, a fire, a good pillow and a good sunbeam in the morning at breakfast"), it's not pure Starck (though he did handle the nick-nack shopping personally).

The buyers Starck visualised are the kind that shop in Hermès, wear cashmere sweaters and Italian slippers, eat organic (muesli and dozens of bottles of Biologica olive oil), read French; they cook, are possibly vegetarian (jars of black pasta, whole peanuts, dried chillies), they entertain and they are about to sit down to a weird simulated meal of teeny baby carrots, embryonic courgettes (slightly withered) and miniature red cabbages, all laid in artistic rows on square black plates with gold chopsticks. Their world is permeated by the ultimate artificial reality: views of leafy Maida Vale, represented by huge back-lit photographs in the windows, in a bid to hide the messy construction site that currently dominates the vista.

Hitchcox remains resistant to the idea of selling a packaged lifestyle, but 70% of buyers went for the Culture option, presumably because that's what they saw. The Starck label has worked, too - Liam Gallagher and Nicole Appleton have been in twice. They are talking about buying a whole floor.

There is nothing so glamorous about Redrow Homes' 51 02 development in central Bristol, targeted at young urban singles and childless couples. Former theatre designer Lulu Nikolai was hired to dress the two show apartments. It was a fairly tough assignment. The raw material - a 70s building that housed the offices of the now-defunct Avon County Council - was once voted the city's ugliest building. Though £80,000 for a studio flat overlooking the four-lane junction of a major traffic island is not exactly cheap, Nikolai went for an effective low-budget look.

Against a background of Pepper kitchen units, Smeg appliances and Italian lighting by Eglo and Artimede, she set out to create one "chilled masculine" environment and another in the homely feminine mode. "The one-bedroom flat is based on the typical young bachelor, he might be gay, he might not, but he's a busy guy," she says. "He's probably not in very often, but when he is, he wants to show off, he wants to look blokey and technically-minded. Colour is often a problem for a man, so I went for a monochrome palette with a splash of bold colour."

The two-bedder, she continues, is based around "a traditional professional couple - no children, busy lifestyle, but spend a bit more time at home". There is a lilac bedroom, M&S clothes, a whacky home-office with pictures of magazines (Stuff, Maxim, Elle Deco) printed on to a grey carpet and jeans-pocket pen holders on the wall.

"I've absolutely fallen in love with the two-bedroom flat," said one university student wandering around on the day of the public launch. "If only I had £200,000."

In the one-bedroom flat, a couple of chilled blokes are sprawled on Nikolai's leather banquette dreaming about an open-plan kitchen/ living space, furnished with Ikea, Habitat and a couple of stage-set tables made from sheets of clear glass supported on the legs and torsos of retired shop-window mannequins. Bedroom accessories include red lamps - with feet - red rubber drapes, fake fur, fragrances by Jean Paul Gaultier and Paco Rabanne. There's Brylcreem, Imperial Leather and Arouse Me massage oil in the bathroom.

"You've got to throw a little bit of humour into these things," says Nikolai. She pauses. "I'll be brutally honest: it's all about sexuality. You've got bodies, you've got rubber, a bit of leather, lots of touchy-feely stuff. In both flats, I really wanted to highlight the bedroom side of things."

Laurence Llewelyn-Bowen can't be far behind - Clothes Show/ Home Front presenter Jeff Banks has already created two "stunning new house styles" at Clements Park, a Crest development in Brentwood. What do you get in a Jeff Banks show home? Khaki and beige, walnut dining furniture, zebra and leopard prints, a bit of oriental theming. Not my cup of tea, but Banks's advice to buyers is worth noting: "If you are looking for quality, look at the door hinges," he urges.

And, yes, while you're at it, look at the building site. Every show home has one.

fields.headline: Goddess of love
fields.standfirst: That hair. Those glasses. Nana Mouskouri's image has been with us for more than 30 years. She is the biggest-selling female singer in the world, but can you hum any of her tunes? Dea Birkett meets the pop icon whose heart belongs to everyone
fields.trailText: That hair. Those glasses. Nana Mouskouri's image has been with us for more than 30 years. She is the biggest-selling female singer in the world, but can you hum any of her tunes? Dea Birkett meets the pop icon whose heart belongs to everyone
fields.body:
Love is in the air. It's in the crimson soft furnishings, in the pendulous chandeliers, in the Diet Coke my charming companion is sipping, in every sweet, unaffected sentence she utters. Nana simply can't stop talking about the power of love. "Love is for me everything. We need to feel that we are loved, we are appreciated. Love is to be appreciated," she says, her perfectly glossed lips separating around the straw.

We may be sitting in a Parisian hotel lobby, but we're in a land where the only language is lines from my 64-year-old companion's slushy, over-sentimental songs. Our conversation contains no meaning beyond them: "I realised that if I was singing, there was love for me, people liked me. And it's so important to feel that you are loved. And in order to be loved, you have to deserve it."

The world's best-selling female singer is addicted to obvious affection. She craves it, feeds on it, and ladles it out by the lyric load. Our meeting began with me cynically counting the number of times the bespectacled woman sitting opposite uttered the word "love". I counted 23. "A record for an interview?" I jotted down in my notebook. A further 10 minutes, and there had been 15 more. But sentimentality is seductive, and within half an hour my own sentences were littered with soft, shallow mutterings, and I, too, sounded like a stuck record. Something had gotten hold of my heart. Before long, I found myself half-humming, half-asking, "What is love about?"

This was not how I had intended our encounter to begin. I had been determined to go in hard. "Why do you always part your hair down the middle?" and "Is that plain glass in your spectacles?" were the two questions I had lined up to fire first. Destroy the woman's accoutrements, I thought, and she'd be stripped bare. There's nothing more to Nana Mouskouri than a distinctive hairdo and some outdated face furniture.

But, oh, how deceived I had been. Nana Mouskouri has sold more than 200 million records, receiving over 300 gold, platinum and diamond discs. Adaptation rather than innovation is her style, transforming even the most demanding lyric into easy listening. Her songs are nearly always written for others and then executed, often more successfully, by Nana. There are no frontiers in her musical world. She's attempted The Beatles, The Rolling Stones, Kris Kristofferson, James Taylor, Dolly Parton, Cat Stevens, Bob Dylan, Bette Midler, Charles Aznavour, Edith Piaf, Marlene Dietrich, Neil Young, Georges Bizet, Neil Sedaka, Franz Schubert, Judy Garland, Ella Fitzgerald, Nat King Cole, Carole King and Don Maclean.

She's recorded more than 1,350 songs, in German, English, French, Spanish, Greek, Portuguese, Japanese, Dutch, Hebrew, Italian and Corsican. It's often not possible to tell in which language she's singing - as if it mattered. She always sings in Nana-speak. Her singing always sounds so effortless. It demands only to be listened to; her apparent ease puts us at ease. It reminds us, perhaps, of being sung to sleep as children; it is comforting, lulling, never threatening. She doesn't belt but oozes out the tune, as if there were nothing more natural than singing before thousands. She isn't showy on stage; it is her quietness that holds us, the suggestion that each of us is alone with her.

She appeals to the most simple and basic emotion in everyone, anywhere. She is passion without the merest soupçon of smut. She is the ambassador of untainted, asexual love, and every continent embraces her universal message. She's vast in Venezuela and big in Korea. When a concert in Christchurch, New Zealand, was transmitted on the radio, a telegram arrived from a base at the South Pole. "Dear Nana, We're so sorry not be at the concert tonight, but we still are so happy that you are only a three-hour flight away from us." Only in Britain does the whiff of cynicism linger over her. Only here is she seen as a joke.

Joanna "Nana" Mouskouri started looking for love at a young age. She was born in Crete on October 13, 1936, the daughter of a cinema projectionist. Two years later, they moved to Athens and lived in a house behind the open-air cinema where her father worked. It was the eve of world war. "I remember the bombs and the horror, the people I saw dead from hunger in the street. When you see things like that, you never forget. The first thing I asked my father was why people die. He said because people don't like each other, they hate each other, and that's when they make war. I thought there was no love. So I started to search for love since I was a little girl. I used to say there must be some love alive inside of me."

Already, she was composing the soundtrack of her future career. Her mother, a thwarted singer, enrolled her two daughters at the Hellenic Conservatoire in Athens, where Nana remained for nine years. Seduced by the city's nightclubs, where she began to work, she was asked to leave the classical conservatory. Success came seemingly without effort, winning every competition that she entered, from the first Greek Song Festival to the 1960 Mediterranean Festival in Barcelona. In 1961, she had her first gold record with White Rose Of Athens, selling more than one and a half million copies in Germany alone. She was only 25, and the four-lettered word - love - was already her hallmark. "I had so many complexes when I was younger. I thought I wasn't worth anything. The only thing I realised - when I was singing, is that people would smile to me, would like me. So it became somehow my security, singing. Singing made me come out of all my complexes, trust the world, trust that there is love."

Her life and her lyrics became indistinguishable. A year later, she was in New York with Quincy Jones recording the classic jazz album, A Girl From Greece Sings. Two years later, she represented Luxembourg in the Eurovision song contest. If love was her slogan, versatility was her strength. The night of the contest, Harry Belafonte happened to be in town and watched Nana's performance on TV. He remembered once seeing the young Greek singer in an Athens nightclub, asked to be introduced and invited her to audition in New York. From 1964 to 1966, they toured North America together. "He was the artist who influenced me most, encouraged me to be myself no matter what happens. Harry taught me how to choose my songs in order to give my personal message," she says.

In 1969, her first record for the English market, Over And Over, was released. It stayed in the charts for more than 100 weeks. Her first concert at London's Albert Hall sold out in hours. The BBC launched a television series, Nana With Guests. At last, Britain, too, was in love with her.

France had already fallen. And characteristically, she thanked them for it by adopting it as her homeland. Now living in Paris and Geneva, she takes me to the Olympia theatre and we sit in the empty late-afternoon seats, staring at the empty stage, reminiscing, Nana-style. "I remember the first time when I came here in the 60s and I saw Edith Piaf. I couldn't understand one word of what she was singing. But I was so moved, so moved. I was crying. I was so impressed, this little woman singing on that stage. When I went out, my friend took me across the street and I looked at the lights and the name of Edith Piaf. My friend said, 'Well, you look at this name now. One day your name will be written there.' I said, 'No, no. It will be far from possible.' I didn't dare say that I am able to go on that stage where that wonderful woman was. For me it was a sacred stage. It was a place I never thought I would be able to sing myself."

But, of course, she did. Shortly afterwards, in 1969, she was asked to replace Gilbert Becaud for a three-week run. She was three months pregnant with her first child, Nicholas. "We had only Monday off, and on Sunday we had two concerts. I sang Farewell Angelina, Ton Amour, Little Drummer Boy... It was a big break for me. Artistically, I was born at the Olympia."

Nana is modest, but not self-deprecating. She knows her biggest help has been herself. "The door was opened for me, and I recognised it was a good door. This is one thing to my credit. The ancient Greeks, they used to say that Lady Luck is a very beautiful girl with magnificent curly hair and she walks among other people in the street. One should recognise her and grab her from the hair, out front, because behind she is bald. When I was asked to play here, reasonably I should have said 'No', because I was pregnant. But then I said, 'I have nothing to lose'. I should try it. And I didn't lose."

But to conquer the world, love is not enough. "Discipline," says Nana, in an accent that makes it sound like a dirty word, the only one in her multilingual vocabulary. "It's important to live in discipline." Twenty days after giving birth to her second child, Helen, who now sings with her, she went back to work. Every day since, she has lain on her back, placed a box on her diaphragm, and done breathing exercises, watching the box move up and down. Then she tucks her toes under a bar and does sit-ups. For 40 years, she has been singing two hours each morning. If she has a concert in the evening, she sings for two hours in the afternoon as well.

"In the bath?" I joke, and for the first time she looks at me with disapproval.

"Music for me was never a pastime," she says. "I don't sing in my bathroom, not at all. It is a serious thing. I have a studio in Geneva, and here in Paris I have a small room in my apartment. I'm there by myself with a small piano. I want to be concentrated in it, that is very important. You can never achieve something if you don't take it seriously."

She has little sympathy for shirkers. "You have to choose a certain way in your life. When I was young, all the other girls smoked. But I realised that if I wanted to be a singer, it wasn't healthy. If I have to work the next day, I have to go to sleep early."

Lack of civic discipline is why she now finds Athens impossible for any more than brief visits, although she remains patriotic to her birthplace, having represented Greece in the European Parliament and campaigned for the return of the Parthenon Marbles.

"Discipline," she mutters.

After two days together, I begin to take risks. I decide it's time to make a request I haven't dared earlier, for fear of causing offence. She famously refused one journalist with a shriek of, "Oh, no, I feel naked without them!"

"Could you possibly take off your glasses?" I ask, ready to receive her rare wrath.

"Yes, of course," she replies immediately. Without the black frames, she looks even younger, and wonderfully girlish. "I cannot see beyond two to three metres," she says, waving her black rims around. "I thought I was ugly as I was, and with glasses I was even worse. The doctor told me, 'If you wear your glasses, your poor sight will not get worse. But if you don't wear them, it will be worse.' I just started regularly to wear them, although I hated them." She was nine years old. "This is discipline," she explains.

Little did the doctor know that those frames would become the most famous pair of spectacles in the world. We can all draw a picture of them by heart. "When I became very popular, they said, 'Now you can't go around like this with those glasses, being like you are. You have to become blonde, be fashionable.' And I said, 'No, if the people like me like this, maybe they will go on liking me like this. There is no reason why should I change.' And I wanted to be honest with myself and stay as I was. I stayed like this."

Her hair never grows, her gold hoop earrings never tarnish. I tentatively suggest that most women, by the time they reach their 60s, have experimented with a number of different styles, or at least different haircuts. "Not me," pipes up Nana. "I spent my time until 25 or so trying to change. I tried to cut my hair, long hair, braids, everything. And then one day I realised my hair was like this. And then I didn't want to change. It was not an image, but it became an image. Of course, today I have to put colour shampoo in my hair because it is white."

Artifice, like sex appeal, appears to pass this lady by. Perhaps that is why a myopic Greek girl became the most successful, enduring female solo artist in the world? Nana thinks so. "Because I was very honest and sincere about what I was doing. And maybe because it was so simple, not at all complicated. Others are prima donnas or artistes that people idolise, but they don't touch them. Me, I was a person that they could touch. I remember when I was pregnant with my son, everybody would write to me letters - I have problem with my children, I have problem with my husband. I was like a family, and I still am. I am part of them, of the people, in many countries."

We often judge others by their friends. Nana Mouskouri should be judged by her fans. Her importance to them cannot be underestimated. Their devotion is not subject to the whims of fashion. They are not fickle. They do not desert her. They stand by her for years, from puberty to approaching their pensions. And, despite what you may presume, they are not all blue-rinsed ladies. She has a huge young gay male following. (One joke goes, "How do you come out to your parents? Show them your Nana Mouskouri collection.") Her fans don't care if the rest of us snigger. They are self-aware enough to dub themselves Nana-raks or Mousketeers. Please do remember, Nana rose to fame before stars became suspicious of their following. It was before Pink Floyd built The Wall to keep them from their adoring supporters, the same people who bought their records and made them millions. Before Posh and Becks had Chester Zoo closed to the public so they could take around baby Brooklyn unpestered. Before Madonna spent just 30 minutes on stage at her latest Brixton concert, calculating that would be enough to satisfy the adoring throng.

Nana has always liked her fans. She feels indebted to them. "What I needed all my life is to be loved. I sing my songs and I get this love I need to have. That's what I get back." She's never had a bodyguard. We walked along a Paris street together, her with that hair and those glasses, and people stopped to shake her hand. She said she likes being recognised. She never spends less than two and a half hours on stage; she says she feels she owes it to those who have come to give them a good evening. She is fond of her fans, and wears a brooch given to her by a Danish fan - a ruby encrusted red ribbon.

It's not surprising, therefore, that her songs sell so well. People rarely buy one or two Nana CDs; they buy all of them, every record, every re-release. They are loyal to her because she is loyal to them. In a tumultuous industry, she's remained with the same record company throughout her career. "They worked with me to make it. Why should I leave now that I've made it?" she asks.

David has every one of her albums, more than 800 of them. He's a sensible, highly successful 43-year-old director who lives in Brighton. He is also a proud Mousketeer. I introduced David and Nana over lunch in, at Nana's suggestion, Café de Flore on Boulevard St Germain, where de Beauvoir and Sartre used to hang out. I was nervous about the meeting. Stars are often snooty towards their fans. But within a few precious moments, Nana and David were huddled up in the booth. Listening in to their conversation was like intruding on long lost lovers. There were continual declarations of affection for each other. "I was 16 and having some trouble in my life, and then I switched on the television and you were singing. I thought - this woman understands," starts David. The song was I Dreamed You. (I start humming...)

"I set out to sing searching for love with a big, big love. Then somebody listens and needs the same thing," says Nana.

"You've never let me down. You have been the soundtrack of my life. There's not a day I don't play your music," says David, taking a break to order Croque Madame. Nana, like a dutiful lover, orders the same.

"There's so much love in your work," says David. She grasps his arm: "Oh, you make me cry." The Croque Madame arrives. It may be just fried egg and cheese on toast, but Nana declares it delicious, the perfect choice. "I sing for one person. I do not sing for everybody. But then everybody is one," she says.

"We all think it's our Nana. Everybody," responds David.

One day, she says, they may get married, they always mean to. Andre is Nana's underbelly. He's wearing a peach-coloured, box-shaped jacket, which even Oxfam would have a problem putting a price on. While Nana's decorations are tastefully understated, Andre sports (rather than wears) an emerald flowered tie, gold watch and gold link bracelet. Why have we forsaken this honest, lovely lady? Where did our love go? For almost 20 years, since Nana With Guests folded in 1981, she has been lost in an emotional wilderness. While she continued to tour and soar throughout the rest of the world, Britain hardened its heart. That hairdo! Those glasses! The only people who were proud of her image were female impersonators.

But that was the 80s, when we were all material girls and boys. Perhaps the tide of emotion has changed. Perhaps we are ready, once again, for Nana Mouskouri. Perhaps it is time to cast out cynicism. Perhaps we will, after all, get back that loving feeling. We just have to hum it, and she'll surely sing it.

As we parted, sitting close in the back of her chauffeur-driven car, Nana, her helmet of hair intact, leant over and said, full of meaning, "Thank you so much for introducing me to David. It was really, really..." She is looking for words. "Lovely."

A few days later, I received a note from David. "Thank you so much for introducing me to Nana. Now I know it's true - dreams can come true." That's love for you.

We may be sitting in a Parisian hotel lobby, but we're in a land where the only language is lines from my 64-year-old companion's slushy, over-sentimental songs. Our conversation contains no meaning beyond them: "I realised that if I was singing, there was love for me, people liked me. And it's so important to feel that you are loved. And in order to be loved, you have to deserve it." The world's best-selling female singer is addicted to obvious affection. She craves it, feeds on it, and ladles it out by the lyric load. Our meeting began with me cynically counting the number of times the bespectacled woman sitting opposite uttered the word "love". I counted 23. "A record for an interview?" I jotted down in my notebook. A further 10 minutes, and there had been 15 more. But sentimentality is seductive, and within half an hour my own sentences were littered with soft, shallow mutterings, and I, too, sounded like a stuck record. Something had gotten hold of my heart. Before long, I found myself half-humming, half-asking, "What is love about?" This was not how I had intended our encounter to begin. I had been determined to go in hard. "Why do you always part your hair down the middle?" and "Is that plain glass in your spectacles?" were the two questions I had lined up to fire first. Destroy the woman's accoutrements, I thought, and she'd be stripped bare. There's nothing more to Nana Mouskouri than a distinctive hairdo and some outdated face furniture. But, oh, how deceived I had been. Nana Mouskouri has sold more than 200 million records, receiving over 300 gold, platinum and diamond discs. Adaptation rather than innovation is her style, transforming even the most demanding lyric into easy listening. Her songs are nearly always written for others and then executed, often more successfully, by Nana. There are no frontiers in her musical world. She's attempted The Beatles, The Rolling Stones, Kris Kristofferson, James Taylor, Dolly Parton, Cat Stevens, Bob Dylan, Bette Midler, Charles Aznavour, Edith Piaf, Marlene Dietrich, Neil Young, Georges Bizet, Neil Sedaka, Franz Schubert, Judy Garland, Ella Fitzgerald, Nat King Cole, Carole King and Don Maclean. fields.body:
I was rather disappointed that David Newnham's excellent feature on sleep (Snooze From Nowhere, February 17) failed to mention a phenomenon that many of us experience - accurate dream premonitions. From the age of 12, when I dreamed the Derby winner two days beforehand, I have experienced many such dreams of near future events - though, to date, no luck with dream visions of lottery numbers.
Percy Weston
Stevenage, Herts

Kevin Sampson's evocative article about Tranmere Rovers (The Wild Rovers, February 17) will have struck many chords with those of us football supporters who eschew the prawn sandwiches for pasties. However, I would like to point out that on that fateful afternoon in May 1987, it was Torquay United who supplied the drama, not Rovers, as we scored the the equalising, league-status-saving goal in the 94th minute against Crewe, the extra time coming because a police dog called Bryn came on to the pitch to bite Torquay player Jim McNichol. And, while Rovers finished a 'healthy' fifth from bottom, Torquay United stayed up on goal average.
Jack Critchlow
Torquay

Any chance of features on Merseyside's other two great clubs: Liverpool and Liverpool Reserves?
Richard Carter
Wirral, Merseyside

Julie Burchill reveals a scorching contempt for wealthy suburban gardeners (February 17), a class she partly identifies by their purchase of a mysterious item, a 'truckle'. She presumably means 'trug'. I suggest that with a childhood in Bristol where, as is attested in these pages, the letter 'L' gets added to almost everything, young Julie may have heard that what posh ladies carried flowers in was a 'trugl'.
Snoo Wilson
London SW4

It's nonsense to suggest Popstars or Big Brother are superior viewing to the comic genius in a dramatisation like Love In A Cold Climate (Julie Burchill, February 10). Fiction in Nancy Mitford's case, was no 'lie'. She came from the world she wrote about in all its hypocrisy, and vanity (Evelyn Waugh actually rebuked her for exposing the aristocracy so completely.)
Vicky Wheeler
Glasgow

My ginger tom has never caught a small mammal or songbird (Dear Weekend, February 17). He prefers to gorge on Felix and Arthur's, and slob out on the sofa all day. Must be the other ginger tom down the road.
Sue Hall
Cornwall

...as for the killer ginger tom down the road, I'm so sorry... he's mine.
Bette Baldwin
Bristol

In her article, A People Killed Twice (January 27), Julia Pascal dismisses the claim that the death of huge numbers of Armenians during the first world war was the result of civil war. There is some non-partisan scholarship devoted to this issue: yes, a horrific number of Ottoman Armenians died between 1915 and 1920, but so did an even larger number of Ottoman Muslims in the same area.
CGA Clay
University of Bristol

webTitle: Savers the winner in bank war on the web

fields.headline: Savers the winner in bank war on the web
fields.standfirst:
Marianne Curphey marks your card on the market-beating interest rates available as competition for business hots up

More net news
fields.trailText: Marianne Curphey marks your card on the market-beating interest rates available as competition for business hots up.
fields.body:
If it wasn't for the internet, finding a good interest rate for your cash would be a tough call following the recent rate cut by the Bank of England. But there is now so much competition between banks to make their mark in the virtual world that there are some market-beating rates available.

Not all of these rates appear in savings best-buy tables because they are being offered as rates on credit balances in current accounts. Even so, the league table of savings rates for no-notice accounts are dominated by web accounts.

Six out of the top 10 no-notice savings accounts in the best buy table from Moneyfacts are web accounts. The e-banks are offering market-beating rates in order to ensure enough people sign up for their products and they reach critical mass. For some providers, like Egg, which tops the Moneyfacts table, it will start to become profitable when it has sold several products to customers with a savings account.

Egg holds number one position in the Moneyfacts league for its Investor account, which is only open to customers who invest in the Egg Isa (Individual savings account). This makes it unsuitable for people who want to use all their Isa allowance to invest in stocks and shares. It pays 7% on balances of £1 and above.

Nationwide building society, which this week prompted a mortgage war by cutting its variable rate for existing as well as new borrowers, has an e-Savings account which pays 6.70% for balances over £1. Close behind is Halifax's Web Saver at 6.35%, Intelligent Finance's Direct Access paying 6% and Egg's Internet Only, also paying 6%.

You can, however, earn up to 7% on credit balances if you open a current account with Cahoot, the new e-bank from the Abbey National. It doesn't appear in the Moneyfacts savings table, however, because it is a current, rather than a traditional savings account.

Some of the high headline rates available from the new internet banks are likely to be loss-leaders and won't be available for ever. First-e, for example, used to pay one of the best interest rates on the market for savings account, at 6% gross, but it has introduced three bands of interest rate and has just dropped the rate to 4.5% gross for balances under £5,000. For balances of £100,000 or more, the rate is 5.5% gross. Its current account is paying 4.75% gross (down from 4.88% gross before the last interest rate cut).

First-e does not offer an overdraft facility or cheque guarantee card. It does offer a savings account, but you are encouraged to use both accounts as pure internet accounts and you may be charged for making telephone calls.

Smile from the Co-operative Bank, pays a top rate of 6% gross on its savings account but to qualify for this you have to have a current account into which you pay your monthly salary or £1,000 a month. In fact, Smile once again topped the league of internet banks in a league table compiled by Gomez, the internet quality measurement firm.

The Smile current account pays 4.85% gross AER (compounded interest rate) on interest on credit balances and has an interest-free overdraft facility up to £500.

The savings account pays a better rate of interest if you already have a current account for balances over £1 or more. The basic rate is 5% gross AER but you could earn an extra 1% gross on your savings by opening both a current account and a savings account.

Nevertheless, canny investors who were planning to switch their current accounts and who get in quickly can enjoy high rates on credit balances. Gomez has drawn up an Internet Banker Scorecard for current accounts from online banks according to ease of use, customer service, product lines and overall cost. According to the latest report, the league is as follows:

1. Smile

2. Nationwide

3. Cahoot

4. First Direct

5. Royal Bank of Scotland

6. Halifax

7. Intelligent Finance (IF)

8. Abbey National

9. NatWest

10. The Woolwich

The interest rate war began when Prudential first launched the Egg account as a loss-leader. The account paid the best interest rate on the market. Although Egg eventually lowered the rate and announced this week that it was putting a planned current account on hold, its internet-only savings account is still competitive.

Egg has three savings account options - one is internet-only and the other two offer the option of a telephone or postal account or a cashcard account.

 Marianne Curphey is editor of Guardian Unlimited Money. She is the author of E-Cash, a guide to managing your money, bank account, mortgage and investments online.

fields.headline: Court downfall of a childcare 'saint'
fields.standfirst: Carer of the year urged children to make up claims of sex abuse
fields.trailText: A woman described as a saint on the BBC's Children in Need after she adopted more than 36 children and fostered many more was yesterday criticised by a judge as a liar and a risk to children.
fields.body:
A woman described as a saint on the BBC's Children in Need after she adopted more than 36 children and fostered many more was yesterday criticised by a judge as a liar and a risk to children.

Jeanette Roberts, 61, was said to be a deceitful, unscrupulous woman who locked up children for long periods and encouraged them to tell stories of sexual abuse. The court heard that children were "clearly at risk" in her care.

Miss Roberts, a devout Christian, has had more than 80 children and young adults pass through her care and has won numerous awards including carer of the year, as well as being the focus of television documentaries and books for her work with children with learning difficulties and behavioural problems.

But her methods were questioned in a judgment handed down at the end of the longest case in the history of Britain's family courts. Mr Justice Hughes criticised her ethos, which involved children changing their name to Roberts and losing contact with their birth families.

The family division of the high court found that Miss Roberts and one of her adopted children, Karen Roberts, who eventually came to help run the Old Convent, in Bicknacre, Essex, encouraged some of the children to make confessions of sexual abuse. It found that Karen Roberts, who suffers from a schizo-affective disorder, also stole £26,000 in criminal injuries compensation from two of these children, with Roberts's knowledge.

The court heard allegations from two families that children had been improperly influenced into making claims of sexual abuse and giving false evidence at the Old Bailey. Two defendants were acquitted but one was sentenced to 12 years. He has maintained his innocence and the children - now adults - have admitted they lied.

The judge believed that this was part of a pattern in the Old Convent. He said: "I am satisfied that both Jeanette Roberts and Karen Roberts, convinced in their own minds that there had been sexual abuse, subjected the children to intense and probably emotionally charged questioning until they told stories which it was believed were there to be told."

He went on: "Jeanette was and remains very likely to question children in such a way as to produce wholly unreliable accusations of sexual abuse."

The court action was brought by Essex county council following concerns about children in Miss Roberts's care. Social services had applied to remove six children but yesterday Mr Justice Hughes said only two would not be returned.

The case followed a raid on the home in November 1998 when more than 100 police officers and social workers removed everyone residing in the Old Convent. Most were vulnerable adults who had once been children in Miss Roberts's care and were allowed to return, but Essex county council said the six should be removed because they might suffer harm.

Mr Justice Hughes said: "That contention is founded upon a large number of very serious complaints about her care for children over very nearly the whole of the 30 years mentioned." These claims of abuse are all denied by Miss Roberts.

The judgment says the complaints "include a great many histories of children unduly influenced in what they said to outsiders... Of these the most serious were the statements of no less than five children from two different families that as a result of improper influence by those at the Old Convent they had made allegations that they had been sexually abused in their former homes when they had not."

Claims that the regime was habitually violent were not founded but the judge said there were occasions when children were smacked, sat on and treated roughly and that "although Miss Roberts generally held herself notably in check, from time to time she lost her temper".

Children had been "disciplined by being confined to their rooms, often locked in", and one autistic child was locked in his room with no one else in the house except a very disabled child. A boy of 22 months was locked in his room at 8am on the day of the police raid. The key could not be found. The judge accepted this was sometimes done because there were so many difficult children to deal with, but what was done was bad practice and potentially dangerous.

Last night, social services and adoption agencies came in for criticism for allowing one woman to adopt so many children and for failing to detect the flaws in her regime sooner.

Mike Leadbetter, Essex director of social services, conceded that there was a lack of coordination and cross-checking between the authorities. "The problem was that no one ever really added the numbers up. Each case was treated individually by social workers and the courts," he said.

An additional problem, he said, was Miss Roberts's public status as a "paragon" of virtue, which meant the adopting authorities gave her a very sympathetic hearing.

Mr Leadbetter defends his authority's decision to spend £6m pursuing the case on the grounds that it had no choice. "With over 120 complainants and such a huge number of allegations, it would have been a breach of duty under the Children Act not to investigate," he said.

Ian Grant, the senior manager seconded to lead the social services investigation, maintains that the raid by police and social workers - the object of bitter criticism by Jeanette Roberts's supporters - was "carefully planned to cause minimum disruption".

The British Agencies for Adoption and Fostering agreed that Miss Roberts's powerful image - along with local authorities' desperation to place children seen as virtually unfosterable or unadoptable - explained the laxity in her case.

Felicity Collier, the director, said: "This distressing case demonstrates that we can be no less rigorous in protecting children placed in foster care and adoption, than at home with parents or in residential care."

Miss Roberts began caring for children in the late 1960s in the East End of London when she was 30. A qualified nurse, she befriended neglected children and started a club for them and soon she began taking children into her home.

She gave up work in 1972 to devote herself to the care of the children. In 1980 she took in 19-year-old Karen Chilvers, just out of borstal for robbery, with a history of hard drugs, mental illness, depression and aggression, and she became a key adult in the home.

In 1985, the ever-expanding family moved to a run-down converted convent with spacious grounds. Over the years charity donations of more than £1m helped turn it into a home. More than 80 children and adults have been in her care. Many display disturbed behaviour, some have severe physical or mental handicaps.

Because she took in children that no one else wanted, and for her success, Miss Roberts became the focus of media and charitable attention. In the foreword to Roberts's biography, Esther Rantzen describes her as "a unique human being who has discovered her own way to heal and survive".

But Miss Roberts became the focus of suspicion because of her unconventional methods. Most children who went to the Old Convent changed their names to Roberts and were encouraged to take a new first name as well. Everyone called Miss Roberts mum. Relationships were allowed within the family and some members married. Children born within the family believed their mothers were their sisters and that Miss Roberts was their mother.

Allegations of abuse and other matters surfaced and Essex police launched Operation Camberley to investigate.

All charges were dropped in the criminal case and Miss Roberts was left to fight to get the children back in her care.

In court she fought to stop the details of the judgment being published but Mr Justice Hughes told her there was a public interest because of the numbers of children she cared for, because of the unusually extensive and expensive investigation and because the Old Convent had been given more than £1m in charity money.

The judgment looked at criticisms of the methods used during the police raid but concluded that they were "steps conscientiously taken in the belief that they were necessary for the protection of the children and vulnerable people".

But her methods often worked and the judgment noted: "In a number of cases children who were very disturbed on arrival have displayed much better behaviour after a while living there." The judge also noted that a number of risks no longer existed and applauded Miss Roberts's "unusual level of commitment to children and other vulnerable people in her care [which] brought undoubted benefits to many".

But his judgment also found that "Jeanette and her adult associates have an undoubted capacity for deception" and that there was "no doubt that there were throughout the years many occasions when children were roughly handled and smacked".

The judge said he "met a great deal of outright untruth" from Miss Roberts and other adults at the Old Convent. Miss Roberts wrote a letter to an adoption agency saying her brother committed suicide: he is still alive. She also told lies about how old her parents were when they died in order to be able to adopt more children.

Additional reporting by Richard Smith
