webTitle: Ethical reasons why beagles have to die

fields.headline: Ethical reasons why beagles have to die
fields.standfirst: Animal research  HLS defends its production line
fields.trailText: Buffalo, a large, soppy-eyed beagle, is taking his exercise at Huntingdon Life Sciences. For 20 minutes he and 23 other beagles are released from their 6ft x 6ft pens and allowed to trot up and down the 60ft passage that separates the cages. Buffalo grubs at a plastic bone, and nuzzles one of his colleagues before being scooped up into the arms of his handler. "Hello my lovely, my little baby," she says, staring down with eyes almost as soppy as his. She has given all the dogs names she says, but Buffalo is her favourite.
fields.body:
Buffalo, a large, soppy-eyed beagle, is taking his exercise at Huntingdon Life Sciences. For 20 minutes he and 23 other beagles are released from their 6ft x 6ft pens and allowed to trot up and down the 60ft passage that separates the cages. Buffalo grubs at a plastic bone, and nuzzles one of his colleagues before being scooped up into the arms of his handler. "Hello my lovely, my little baby," she says, staring down with eyes almost as soppy as his. She has given all the dogs names she says, but Buffalo is her favourite.

Buffalo is 12 weeks into his life at Huntingdon, which has the capacity to house more than 1,000 beagles. He is used to the routine; he takes his breakfast, dosed with the substance he is here to test, at around 9am before being returned to the pen. Once an hour to a chorus of excited yelps, a technician walks the passage looking for signs of adverse reactions to the substance.

Commercial confidentiality prevents HLS from revealing the nature of the substance Buffalo and co are being exposed to but it could be an agri-chemical, a drug or a food additive. Once a week Buffalo is taken out and weighed, his urine and faeces collected for analysis, and once a month a blood sample is taken. In 40 weeks when the trial is concluded Buffalo will have reached the end of his useful life and will be killed with barbiturates, along with all the other dogs in the trial.

This is when the real work begins. Postmortems will be conducted. Samples of all major organs will be taken, slides prepared and treated before being passed to HLS's laboratories where the effects of the substance on the dogs are assessed. Meanwhile the next round of testing will have begun. Buffalo's pen will have been hosed down and another beagle will have taken his place.

This unsentimental production line is the way of animal-based research, and very few companies do more of it than HLS, Europe's largest contract research organisation.

The legislation requires that you use the minimum number of animals and cause the absolute minimum amount of distress."

Cass insists that other methods of research, including computer modelling and in vitro simulations of human organs, are not sufficiently developed. "We would all like to believe that one day it would be possible to ensure these levels of safety without using animals but the human body...is a highly complex mechanism that no one really understands.

"Everybody that works here has made an ethical decision about their role," says Cass. "Working here you are in a position where you are challenged in a way you are not if you are making springs or beans. Normal everyday people are doing this work and the last thing they want to see is an animal in distress. The biggest safeguard we have is the people doing the work, because you cannot carry out this research without caring about animals and if you care about them you want high welfare and low stress."

Demands

Around half of the research at HLS involves animals and is designed to meet the Animal Scientific Procedures Act (1986) which demands that a wide range of drugs, food additives, industrial chemicals and domestic products is tested before being released on to the market. Animals are dosed orally, intravenously or by inhalation to examine the effects of agri-chemicals on fish and other farmed animals in simulated environments. As a result around 70,000 dogs, monkeys, rats, mice, geese, pigs, sheep, fish, honeybees and earthworms are killed at HLS every year.

As we tour the laboratories and animal facilities, the latest in a long line of journalists invited in to HLS in a determined counter-offensive, Cass's faith in his employees' ethical rigour seems justified. Battered by the campaign which characterised them as torturers and in one case "a murdering paedophile", they are at pains to explain the welfare procedures and to justify their roles. The only subject they tip-toe round is death. No one uses the word kill. Animals are "put to sleep", "put down", even "terminated", but none is killed.

In the primate unit Brian (not his real name) is responsible for HLS's colony of crab-eating macaques. In a low windowless room they are housed between three and six to a cage, each equipped with swings, tyres, forage food trays and pipes similar to those you would see in a zoo. As we enter the monkeys chirrup and swing for their visitors. A technician in overalls, yellow gauntlets, white apron, face mask and protective goggles steps into the cage and one sits on his shoulder and begins to groom him. These animals are dosed daily by oral gavage, a tube pushed down into the stomach to ensure the entire dose is ingested.

"These are the animals of last resort," says Brian as we chatter back at the macaques and stroke their bald, tattooed chests through the bars. "They are captive bred before transport, so the life they have here is the same as that they have always known. Yes these animals are going to die, but while they're alive we try and give them as good a life as possible. We never like to put them down but when we do we try and do it with respect," he says gently.

"We have people working here who have chosen to work with animals as their career. To characterise them as torturers and such like is an insult. Since the campaign started I have thought about chucking it all in but I'm not going to."

Under current legislation and according to the dominant body of scientific opinion, animal testing is a necessary stage in the development of everything from cancer treatments to coffee sweeteners. Shac and others argue that the use of animals is immoral, ethically unsound and bad science. Greg Avery, Shac's founder, equates the campaign to the ANC's struggle against apartheid and compares pro-animal testing arguments to those Hitler used to justify eugenics.

In between the two sit the vast majority, beneficiaries of medicines and sweet coffee but uncomfortable with the idea of puppies and pussycats dying in the process. Shac and HLS have one thing in common; they know where they stand. So too does Buffalo's handler, who sees no contradiction in loving and caring for an animal bred to die.

 In 1999, the last year for which figures are available, 1,408 licences for testing were granted and 2,656,753 animal experiments took place in UK labs. More than 50% of these were conducted on rodents.

 It takes, on average, eight years and £330m to bring a new medicine from the laboratory to the pharmacist.

 In the early stages, substances are screened for known toxins.

 The second phase, which can last up to two years, involves animals. Legislation requires that drugs are tested on two mammals, one of them a large non-rodent.

 Following the animal stage, which can last up to two years, clinical trials on humans begin. There are three stages of clinical trials, usually beginning with the most seriously ill sufferers of a particular ailment. Only when these tests are satisfactory is the drug put on to the market.

 Opponents of animal testing advocate using lab-based reconstructions (in vitro) and computer modelling (in silico).

webTitle: BBC boss calls for privacy law

fields.headline: BBC boss calls for privacy law
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The BBC's most senior editorial policy executive yesterday called for a carefully drafted privacy law to replace the "partial and back-to-front" series of court rulings under the Human Rights Act.
fields.body:
The BBC's most senior editorial policy executive yesterday called for a carefully drafted privacy law to replace the "partial and back-to-front" series of court rulings under the Human Rights Act.

Phil Harding, the BBC's controller of editorial policy, expressed concern about the law developing from rulings granted to celebrities who were more concerned about their lucrative magazine deals than privacy.

Mr Harding suggested that an individual's right to privacy should be protected in law, but stressed that the media should also be free to hold politicians and public figures to account.

"Privacy should not be used as an excuse to avoid accountability," Mr Harding told a lawyers' conference yesterday.

He cited the case of Catherine Zeta Jones and Michael Douglas, who obtained an injunction preventing Hello! magazine publishing unauthorised pictures of their wedding after they had concluded a £1m publication deal with rivals OK!

"If I invite in a photographer from... [a] magazine for a fee of £1m so that the photographs of my so-called private wedding can then be sold to hundreds of thousands of total strangers, otherwise known as magazine readers, haven't I then surrendered all reasonable claims to privacy?

"And if I then go to court to take action against a rival magazine for trying to publish photographs of the same wedding, isn't the real reason for the action that I want to safeguard my £1m deal?"

The injunction granted to OK! was overturned on appeal, but in what is widely regarded as one of the most important judgments on privacy under the Human Rights Act, the appeal judges said the couple had "a powerfully arguable case" for a right of privacy.

Mr Harding expressed concern about a case in which Grampian police, citing the Human Rights Act, refused a request from the Aberdeen-based Press and Journal newspaper to identify a man found dead at a roadside because his family did not want him to be named - even though the head of the drugs squad was involved in the inquiry.

Such an interpretation of the act would have allowed the killer Rosemary West to veto the revelation of the suicide of her husband, Fred.

webTitle: Media mogul ties up Europe cable

fields.headline: Media mogul ties up Europe cable
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: American media mogul John Malone tightened his grip on the European cable industry yesterday after he seized control of the continent's largest cable operator and acquired a controlling stake in six German cable companies.
fields.body:
American media mogul John Malone tightened his grip on the European cable industry yesterday after he seized control of the continent's largest cable operator and acquired a controlling stake in six German cable companies.

His Liberty Media led a consortium of investors to 55% of Deutsche Telekom's remaining cable assets on the same day that he took a further $1.4bn stake in the parent company of the Dutch-based cable company United Pan-Europe Communications.

UPC's cash comes through its parent, UnitedGlobalCom run by long-time Malone acquaintance Gene Schneider and it will receive a $1.4bn cash injection from Liberty in exchange for 54m shares.

UnitedGlobalCom will pass on $1bn to UPC, which is €7bn in debt after a planned merger with Excite@Home disintegrated in December. "For UPC, this cures a short-term problem, but for a hefty cost," said one analyst.

Friday's deal comes two days after UPC bondholders vetoed a plan to trade 75m UGC shares for $200m cash and Liberty's 25% holding in Telewest, the UK's number two cable operator. The new agreement gives him a 43% holding in UPC, which makes him the single largest shareholder. A spokesman says that "strategic control" is still in the hands of UGC management. But observers say UGC has become little more than a vehicle for Mr Malone's international investments.

Mr Schneider is chairman of UGC, and his son, Mark, is chairman and chief executive of UPC. Schneider senior sold his previous company to Mr Malone in 1991, and the two Colorado natives have been business associates since the early days of the US cable industry.

Liberty Media announced in July 2000 that it would consolidate its myriad international holdings and since then has transferred cable holdings to UGC in exchange for an increasing stake in the company.

Analysts say it's only a matter of time before the stakes in German cable companies also purchased yesterday from Deutsche Telekom are transferred to UPC or its parent.

 Embattled telecom equipment maker Lucent said yesterday that it had secured a $6.5bn lifeline from J P Morgan and Salomon Smith Barney.

webTitle: Campaign gloves are off between redtops

fields.headline: Campaign gloves are off between redtops
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: At last. The debate, or at least the material to inform the debate, is being presented to the public by the media.
fields.body:
At last. The debate, or at least the material to inform the debate, is being presented to the public by the media. The media, note, not the government, which remains resolute to concentrate on a euro-free election. It will fail.

The BBC joined battle with its Europe and Us week; the Observer made a heroic contribution; and the Guardian almost made the euro-debate fashionable, by devoting a cover story to it in its trendy G2 section.

For once the Euro-sceptics took a back seat. Apart from the Daily Mail's continuing attack on the planned European rapid reaction force and its impact on Nato, the sceptics were quiet. This has not happened in a long time.

But first, a classic example of how the debate is muddled, with data being selected or spun to provide comfort to one side or the other.

On the same day, both the Euro-sceptic Sun and the Euro-enthusiastic Mirror carried stories giving the attitudes of finance and big business to the euro. Each story supported the editorial line of the newspaper in which it appeared.

So the Sun, under the headline City aces vote 2-1 to keep the pound, said that: "Britain's top financial gurus ... warned that scrapping the pound would put Britain's booming economy in peril." And it quoted an un-named guest at a banquet held by the Futures and Options Association as saying: "This shows that the world's top moneymen have a clear idea of what's right for this country." Is that the way guests at Futures and Options Association banquets speak? I don't know, never having been to one.

The rival Mirror had a different take. "Two-thirds of UK's top firms say join euro," ran the headline. The result of the 2001 Reuters Survey of UK Larger Companies was a "devastating kick in the teeth for William Hague and his euro-sceptic extremists".

The Mirror backed up this article with a leader indicating how strongly it plans to campaign for the euro. The tide is about to turn, it said. "The signs are good for the government getting the backing it needs. The Mirror believes the choice is this: Do you want your pay in euros or your dole money in pounds?"

The gloves are off between the redtops, and they at least seem to believe that good, old-fashioned campaigning is what is required. The BBC, smarting under attack for pro-euro bias, brought us a week of Euro-programmes. You could easily have missed it, so many were scheduled far away from mainstream hours.

The TV contribution was light, although those too young to vote in the referendum were best served with a daily dose of Europe in Newsround. But for adults, the four programmes offered were all after 10 pm. The TV coverage started with the big guns - or these days light peashooters - of Panorama, now buried away late on Sunday night.

Referendum Street was a classic example of why television is so bad at handling issues. The need for both balance and pictures serves only to trivialise. Subjecting a single north London street to a euro referendum "campaign", and inflicting on the innocent inhabitants a knock on the door from Austin Mitchell and David Mellor was not conducive to high-level debate.

Will Hutton, leader of the Referendum Street pro campaign, saw it differently, and in a triumphant piece in the Observer celebrated the fact that Referendum Street had been convinced by the arguments of the pros, an initial anti-euro view in the street being turned into a majority in favour of the euro.

Hutton put it down to the pros, like himself, being nicer people. "Scepticism is a darker credo than the sunnier worldview of the pros," he wrote, "and this comes through in the style, culture and personality type attracted to the twin camps."

So the real referendum will come down to which camp has more style and culture. One hopes there will be more to it than that. The same edition of the Observer contained by far the most helpful, and accessible, contribution to the debate so far.

If the BBC wants to understand how balance can be made interesting it should turn to How to make sense of the euro debate, the Observer's special report last Sunday. Extracted from a new book by Anthony Browne, it dealt fairly and thoroughly with both the economic and political arguments.

It accepted that the argument is neither clear-cut nor simple, neither straight bananas nor straight advantage to Britain. It conceded that the emotive and political arguments, about sovereignty and the Queen's head on our banknotes, will be "far more influential in a referendum than the relatively dry and arcane arguments about economics."

For those who haven't, it is well worth reading, and is on the Observer website.

Things are looking up.

 Peter Cole is professor of journalism at Sheffield University

fields.headline: LSE inquiry into EuroTelecom
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: A stock exchange investigation is expected to be launched into the dramatic collapse of hi-tech infrastructure specialist EuroTelecom, which was yesterday forced to call in administrators just nine months after it raised £17m through an AIM flotation.
fields.body:
A stock exchange investigation is expected to be launched into the dramatic collapse of hi-tech infrastructure specialist EuroTelecom, which was yesterday forced to call in administrators just nine months after it raised £17m through an AIM flotation.

The Yorkshire-based firm's dramatic reversal in fortune has left several high profile investors nursing heavy losses, including ex-Leeds United boss Chris Akers and former businesswoman of the year 27-year-old Amanda Staveley.

Investors who bought into the float at 150p a share saw the stock suspended last night after last trading at 4.5p.

A spokesman for the London Stock Exchange emphasised that he could not comment on individual firms, but added, "we would always look at cases where a company has working capital difficulties within 12 months of a share issue".

PricewaterhouseCoopers has been appointed as administrator after talks seeking to find a rescuer to ease "working capital difficulties" failed.

The expected inquiry is likely to focus on how Euro-Telecom, which initially told shareholders that it would not consume big quantities of cash, managed to burn through its financial resources at such a rate.

Shareholders have been startled by its sudden misfortune and a bitter split has developed between the company's executive management and non-executive directors.

Non-executives, led by Mr Akers in his role as chairman, are thought to have been unhappy at the quality and regularity of management accounts presented to them by chief executive Phil Derry. The non-executives commissioned accountants BDO Stoy Hayward to conduct an independent audit of the figures.

Three directors, including finance chief David Linell, have quit the firm in the last month. Ms Staveley has also resigned and is trying to buy back the 49% stake in a Cambridge hi-tech business park she sold to EuroTelecom last summer.

fields.bodyText: A stock exchange investigation is expected to be launched into the dramatic collapse of hi-tech infrastructure specialist EuroTelecom, which was yesterday forced to call in administrators just nine months after it raised £17m through an AIM flotation. The Yorkshire-based firm's dramatic reversal in fortune has left several high profile investors nursing heavy losses, including ex-Leeds United boss Chris Akers and former businesswoman of the year 27-year-old Amanda Staveley. Investors who bought into the float at 150p a share saw the stock suspended last night after last trading at 4.5p. A spokesman for the London Stock Exchange emphasised that he could not comment on individual firms, but added, "we would always look at cases where a company has working capital difficulties within 12 months of a share issue". PricewaterhouseCoopers has been appointed as administrator after talks seeking to find a rescuer to ease "working capital difficulties" failed. The expected inquiry is likely to focus on how Euro-Telecom, which initially told shareholders that it would not consume big quantities of cash, managed to burn through its financial resources at such a rate. Shareholders have been startled by its sudden misfortune and a bitter split has developed between the company's executive management and non-executive directors. Non-executives, led by Mr Akers in his role as chairman, are thought to have been unhappy at the quality and regularity of management accounts presented to them by chief executive Phil Derry. The non-executives commissioned accountants BDO Stoy Hayward to conduct an independent audit of the figures. Three directors, including finance chief David Linell, have quit the firm in the last month. Ms Staveley has also resigned and is trying to buy back the 49% stake in a Cambridge hi-tech business park she sold to EuroTelecom last summer. EuroTelecom led the rescue bid but negotiations with several parties - including the cash rich Just2Clicks came to nothing. Just2Clicks' chief executive, Karl Watkins, is thought still to have some interest in doing a deal in a personal capacity.

webTitle: Powell the pick from left field

fields.headline: Powell the pick from left field
fields.trailText: Jon Brodkin meets Eriksson's possible answer to England's left-back conundrum.
fields.body:
Chris Powell was standing in the physio's room at Charlton's training ground yesterday when he was informed by one of the club's press officers that he had been named in the England squad. After emerging from the bottom of a ruck of excited team-mates the left-back spluttered five words: "Are you winding me up?"

At the age of 31, having spent most of his career in the lower divisions and been dropped by Charlton after Christmas, Powell was entitled to be dubious. Early yesterday morning he had been woken by a friend to be told of media speculation that he was about to be summoned by Sven-Goran Eriksson, but he had treated that with suspicion.

Even after the news was confirmed, Powell seemed shocked to be seen as a possible answer to England's left-side problem.

"Everyone's been choosing their own England squad recently and I wasn't even in my own squad," he admitted, having plumped for Ashley Cole and Gareth Barry. "I can't believe it. This has come as a total surprise. I didn't even know the management had been watching me."

A vivacious character renowned for his beaming smile and huge CD collection, Powell was a late developer. Rejected by Crystal Palace, who sent him on loan to Fourth Division Aldershot and then sold him for nothing to Third Division Southend, he did not break into the Premiership until he was 27 with Derby. This is only his fourth season in the top flight.

Last night's headline in the London Evening Standard - "Sven picks Chris who?" - will sum up the feelings of many. That Powell worked with Peter Taylor at Southend and Steve McClaren at Derby may have helped, but there was no need to ask whether he had given up on playing for his country. His words when he approached Jamaica before France 98 said it all.

"Some will say I'm being a johnny-come-lately by offering my services to Jamaica," he remarked then. "But the chance to go to the World Cup doesn't come along for many, and I'll never make it with England."

Jamaica never called but England have and suddenly he might get to Japan and South Korea for more than a holiday. His inclusion seems an example of how Eriksson and Tord Grip have arrived without preconceptions. "I saw him two or three times," Eriksson said. "Tord saw him other times. He is a natural left defender so why not see him?"

Powell's qualities were plain to see when Charlton beat Newcastle last Sunday. Strong and quick in defence and adventurous coming forward, he set up Matt Svensson's goal with a typically impressive cross.

Sold to Southend after only five Palace appearances in 1990, Powell spent six years at Roots Hall in the Third, Second and First Divisions before Premiership-bound Derby paid £750,000 for him.

"I remember when Jim Smith of Derby phoned me up and said: 'What about Chris Powell?'" the former Southend manager Barry Fry said last night. "I told him to take him, that Chris was absolutely different class.

"He never gives the ball away and he's so quick that he'll get out of trouble if he ever gets done. I'm delighted for him because he's one of the nicest lads anyone could wish to meet."

Powell's form since Alan Curbishley brought him to Charlton from Derby for £850,000 in July 1998 has been impressive. An ever-present last season as Charlton made it back into the top flight, Powell found himself dropped for six matches after the 5-0 Boxing Day defeat at West Ham but since regaining his place he has looked sharp.

A Christian and a family man, who has overcome the tragedy of seeing a daughter die only three days after being born, there seems little question of him getting too carried away by this call-up.

"He was always very level-headed, Mr Cool," Fry said. "It didn't matter if I was throwing teacups at him or telling him he was the best player in the world he just took it all on board. He's got a lovely attitude."

That easy-going personality was evident when he was an apprentice at Selhurst Park. "He was a coaster," said Tony Finnigan, a former Palace team-mate and now his representative as part of the Wright, Wright, Wright agency. "He would coast through the training because it was easy to him and he wouldn't push himself if he didn't have to.

"If he's honest with himself that's probably one of the reasons they didn't retain him. They probably thought: 'He doesn't say a lot or shout.'"

If Powell plays against Spain on Wednesday he will become the first Charlton player to be capped by England since Mike Baily in 1965. In the excitement of the call-up he left his mobile phone in the boot of John Salako's car when Charlton travelled north for today's game at Coventry, and it seems there will be plenty of messages.

"I'd sum him up in one word: a gentleman," Finnigan said. "He'd be the first on your list if you were having a party." Powell is now entitled to throw one for himself tonight.

fields.headline: Simon Burnton's Diary
fields.trailText: Trevor Sinclair serves up Hammers and mash.
fields.body:
 Footballers can be the strangest of beasts. Take, by way of example, Trevor Sinclair's mashed potatoes, cooked as he watched West Ham beat Manchester United in the FA Cup a couple of weeks ago. "When I was watching the game I was cooking a Sunday roast at the same time, and I was cooking some boiled potatoes," he says. "But we scored when they were about ready so I thought if I take the boiled potatotes off the hob, then United are going to get an equaliser, so I ended up having mashed potatoes. It worked so I'm not going to change it. It's definitely mashed potato from now on."

 Wycombe's manager Lawrie Sanchez embarrassed himself after his side's dramatic penalty win over Wimbledon last week. Incensed by the decision to concentrate TV coverage on the game between Tranmere and Southampton at Prenton Park, he stormed: "If they knew anything about football they would be down here rather than at Tranmere." Asked if he knew the score of the other game, which the First Division strugglers astonishingly won 4-3, he said: "I don't care, but if it was a better game than this I'll eat my hat." Let's hope it tasted better than Sinclair's spuds.

 What's in a name? The latest winners of the Blackburn Sunday League fair play award are Punchbowl FC.

 Great Moments in Modern Footballing History (Part 1): It's a penalty! Oh no it isn't!

 Fabio Capello wisely signed a new contract as manager of Roma before their controversial defeat by Liverpool (see above), but he still had to agree to an unusual clause. Capello was only granted the new £2.5m-a-year deal after allowing the club to put his name to a new aftershave, Don Fabio.

 When Liverpool fans were detained for 90 minutes in the Stadio Olimpico after their 2-0 win over Roma, the Italian club considerately provided them with some amusement - a video of their 1-0 win at Old Trafford earlier this season. In contrast, when Roma were knocked out of the Uefa Cup at Anfield a week later, their fans were taunted by the song Arrivederci Roma, which came blaring out of the PA system within minutes of the final whistle.

 Roma may have been unhappy with the referee, but he was apparently not the worst of the week. Bruno Paixao, in charge of Academica Coimbra v Imortal in Portugal's second division, got into a bit of trouble in the tunnel after the game. According to police allegations, he "deliberately waved his sex organs at policewomen . . . and exposed his private parts four or five times". Paixao counters: "I am an educated 26-year-old, and I will sue the police for defamation."

 Our policy of betting on rank outsiders flopped last week, with all our tips toppled and Deportivo Wanka living up to their name by losing 4-0 at Alianza Lima. So we have changed tack, entering the world of "multi-league parlays". We have bet £25 on each of two combinations of 11 results at potentially massive reward. With any luck, a week hence, Diary will be sipping pina coladas on a Cuban beach. Hasta la vista.

fields.headline: Beckham is below par
fields.trailText: David Beckham may be the popular choice for England captain but he is currently playing well below his best for Manchester United, Steve McClaren admitted yesterday.
fields.body:
David Beckham may be the popular choice for England captain but his form at club level drew an admission from Manchester United yesterday that the midfielder was playing well below his best.

"David will be the first to admit he is not playing to his usual standards," said Steve McClaren, United's assistant manager. "He is one of the greatest players in the world but playing to that level every Saturday and Wednesday is extremely difficult and he has been through a dip in form. He knows it and he knows what he has to do about it."

Beckham's recent form was encapsulated by two peripheral Champions League performances against Valencia and, with the England captaincy to be announced on Monday, he will go into tomorrow's game at home to Arsenal under new scrutiny.

"Sometimes with great players it takes them to work out what is wrong for themselves," McClaren added. "What I will say is that David's attitude has been fantastic. It is nothing to do with concentration or anything else, it is just a question of form.

"People may be marking him differently these days but he can cope with that, and I don't think that's the reason. I don't care if it's the best left-back in the world facing him, David is such a great player that when he is on song nobody on the opposition can affect his game."

Sven-Goran Eriksson visited Newcastle to ask whether the former England captain Alan Shearer would consider coming out of international retirement prior to naming his first squad.

Shearer, 30, who returns from a nine-week absence after knee surgery this afternoon for the visit of Manchester City, met with Eriksson and the Newcastle manager Bobby Robson this month, but will not be adding to his 63 caps and 30 goals.

"I told Sven 'sorry, but you've come too late,'" said Robson yesterday. "He wanted to know whether there was any chance of a comeback but I confirmed that Alan had retired and would not change his mind. He had made a clever, wise judgment. I told Mr Eriksson there were other candidates and other younger players and it was up to him to pick them."

"I'm as interested as anybody else in Mr Eriksson's selection," said Shearer. "But currently I have more important things on my mind."

Gavin McCann was celebrating a remarkable rise to the England squad after returning to the Sunderland first team at the start of December following a knee injury sustained more than a year ago.

He said: "I really didn't expect it. It was difficult for me in the early part of the season because of the injury. But I have been pleased with my performance in recent weeks."

McCann's manager Peter Reid added: "For the modern-day midfield player, he has everything. He's a very good player who deserves it. He's matured as a lad and will get better."

Alaves striker Javi Moreno, the Spanish league's leading scorer, has been called up for Wednesday's friendly against England. The 26-year-old former Barcelona apprentice has scored 16 goals this season. Spain's coach Jose Camacho has recalled the Barcelona pair, Josep Guardiola and Luis Enrique.

The England Under-21 coach Howard Wilkinson has included three new faces in his squad; the Tottenham defender Alton Thelwell, Manchester United's midfielder Mark Wilson and the Newcastle striker Shola Ameobi.

fields.headline: Three-nil down, hmm? Just give it a cloven hoof
fields.standfirst: Ron's in the dugout
fields.trailText: What a week of football! ... handbags on the pitch and teacups in the dressing room ... marvellous!
fields.body:
Ref! ... Offside! ... Ref! ... Ref! ... Right ho ... let's clear this offside malarkey up once and for all! ... active _ hmm? _ inactive _ was he interfering _ wasn't he? _ isn't it? _ lets get to the bottom of it _ more in a minute!

What a week of football! ... handbags on the pitch and teacups in the dressing room ... marvellous! ... First up Sunderland v West Ham ...

Man of the match Stuart Pearce! ... a vintage performance! ... like a fine wine he's er _ quite old! ... two broken legs and he bounces back ... ho ho! _ like Tigger!

And that nickname actually comes from his interest in psychotherapy! We had a "Psycho" in our Fulham team of '61 ... but that was because he'd stuffed his mother and put her in a rocking chair!

Harry reckons his veteran defender is a perfect example to the kids! ... "He kicks them up in the air on the training ground, gets up their arse and tackles them"! _ eh, Harry? ... oh, it's a figure of speech ... But be fair! ... isn't "Psycho" one of those punk rockers? _ Sex Pistols, isn't it?... remember the Jubilee? ... the filth and the fury _ We all went Radio Rental! ... the brick through Mrs Manager's new TV ... A good example to the kids, Harry? ... young Jamie Redknapp in safety pins and a green mohican? ... would he have bagged Louise? ... hmm? ... or one of those girls in a cat-woman mask and laddered fishnet stockings! hmm? ... er hmmmm ... er ...

West Ham go marching on ... "I'm forever blowing bubbles" ... isn't it? ... reminiscent of Michael Jackson in his pomp! ... a far more savoury role model for the young 'uns ... hmm? ... marvellous!

Kanoute! ... caught offside 11 times before lunchtime _ or was he? ... Back to that in a minute!

But a right old cockney knees-up as he finally picks the lock and makes off with the spoils in the great East End tradition! ... Peter Reid takes it on the chin: "We'll bounce back" ... ho ho! ... like *#@#*n' Tigger!

And Harry's luck's in! _ after Sunderland, Man United and er ... Walsall ... they draw Tottenham! ... expect a "cracker"! ... nil-nil!

George Graham's seen the light - "Two or three players through your youth policy can save you £30m or £40m" ... far cry from the free-spending George who'd happily bung away hundreds of thousands on that Danish chap Jensen!

... And as the speculation continues on the managerial merry-go-round ... Gregory for Newcastle! ... Royle for United ... er, one of mine, actually ... time for a look at George's heir apparent ... ho ho! ... great stuff!

Glenn Hoddle's perennial relegation strugglers Southampton _ now smug in mid-table mediocrity ... head to Merseyside for their Cup replay with troubled Tranmere ... two goals ruled offside at the Dell _ more about that in a minute!

Dark clouds over Birkenhead ... Tranmere deep in the drop zone _ John Aldridge can't sleep! ... "it's doing me in!"

From the dark end of the street _ to the bright side of the road _ Glenn has an aura about him ... hmm? _ Three-nil up in 45 minutes at Prenton Park ... looks like he's home and dry ... game-over! and I've decided on an early night ...

But once through the turnstiles, a strange mist came rolling across the Mersey till I could hardly see in front of me ... losing my bearings entirely, I found myself standing at a crossroads in the eerie light ... when the sound of galloping hooves! _ terror gripped me ... the four horsemen of the apocalypse?

... Throwing myself into a ditch, I watched as two fellows on a small donkey thundered out of the fog ... "Tord, we vill miss the second half" ... "Cool it, Sven" ... eh?

As they passed, I was suddenly aware of two figures in the gloom ... long black leather overcoats making a sinister pact: "... Success will be yours in the Axa _ but then you will go down to the other place ..."

A handshake ... a crash of thunder ... and one of the strange mephistophoph _ mephistiphelophelos ... mephosiphifeli ... er, you know ... the scouse bloke with the goatee ... races off back in the direction of the stadium .... I stood rigid with fear as his colleague brushed past ... treading on my foot ... and as the lightning flashed ... a glimpse of a forked tail _ and a bag of discarded teacups?

The next morning I woke to the imprint of a cloven hoof on my Hush Puppies, and the news of Tranmere's mighty victory over the Saints ...

... And a reader's letter! _ Chelsea fan Mark Pitts of Chiswick writes: "Ron, do you think there was a half-time bust-up between Ranieri and the lads, or is it all 'a load of cobblers' like Mr Hutchinson says?"

Ho ho! ... Colin Hutchinson? ... hmm? ... talks just like Ken, doesn't he? ... But Mark, who cares? ... Claudio's tactical wizardry certainly secured him a safer route to Europe with Chelsea than the poisoned chalice of the FA Cup ... you ask Ruud _ ask Gianluca!

... Expect Claudio still to be in residence at the Bates motel as the Intertoto Cup kicks off! ... rejigging his formation silently from his rocking-chair high in the west stand..

... And this week's ... One to Watch! ...Vieira! _ nickname St Patrick! ... ask Claudio "... If you touch him it is like touching God" ... Damn right! ... I bumped into him on Wednesday night and my damaged toe healed up! ...marvellous!

webTitle: O'Neill makes a martyr of sinned against Sutton

fields.headline: O'Neill makes a martyr of sinned against Sutton
fields.trailText: Celtic look to extend their lead at the top as Hibs visit Parkhead.
fields.body:
The Celtic manager Martin O'Neill yesterday defended his striker Chris Sutton from accusations of dangerous play ahead of tomorrow's meeting with second-placed Hibernian.

The £6million striker was accused by the Motherwell manager Billy Davies of going over the top on Scott Leitch during Celtic's 1-0 midweek league victory at Parkhead; Leitch left the ground of crutches. O'Neill claimed Sutton has suffered more than most in terms of physical attention from defenders this season.

"I think on the most part Chris Sutton comes across as a big and quite physical player," said O'Neill. "And the referees generally look at him and think he should be able to look after himself.

"Generally, I believe he is more sinned against than an actual sinner himself. A number of times I've watched him in matches where he has his back against defenders and commits a few fouls himself, but overall he gets thumped about a bit."

The in-form winger Bobby Petta is losing his battle to be fit, having already missed out on a possible call-up to the Dutch international squad this week due to injury.

Celtic know a win would virtually assure them of the title. They are 14 points clear of Hibs and 15 ahead of Rangers; three points tomorrow would make the gap almost insurmountable.

Dundee have signed the Argentine left-back Alberto Garrido in time for today's televised clash with Rangers. The 26-year-old, who has played in Italy and Spain, has signed on a free transfer until the end of the season and could go straight into the team at Dens Park. Player-manager Ivano Bonetti has eight first-team players out injured, including himself.

For Rangers, Lorenzo Amoruso is expected to return for his first game since January 2. Kick-off is at 12.55pm and will be televised live for pay-per-view broadcast.

Fifth place is at stake at Tynecastle, where Hearts face sixth-placed Dunfermline, one place below them but level on points.

The Hearts manager Craig Levein says he will have no hesitation in playing Juanjo despite the Spanish striker turning down the club's offer of a new contract. Juanjo's agent this week broke off negotiations and branded the club's new terms as "ridiculous."

The Kilmarnock manager Bobby Williamson says while he is delighted that Dundee United have started winning games, he still wants to take three points off the league's bottom side when they meet this afternoon. Williamson has no fresh injury worries but Andy McLaren is suspended. The teenager Paul Di Giacomo is drafted into the squad.

United have lost just one of their last six, despite struggling to pick up points at the beginning of the campaign. They go into this game after a convincing win against Motherwell in the Scottish Cup last week. United have lost both previous encounters this season, although the Tannadice reverse was overshadowed by a horrific injury to their defender Jamie Fullarton.

webTitle: Sven's snapshot offers a little hope to everyone

fields.headline: Sven's snapshot offers a little hope to everyone
fields.trailText: No new England manager will ever have a clearer view of the game, one less distorted by conventional wisdom, past mistakes, or prejudice argues Richard Williams.
fields.body:
From Joe Cole, 19 years and three months old, to David Seaman, 37 and a half, the squad of players announced yesterday by Sven-Goran Eriksson represents a snapshot of English football as it exists at this precise moment, with all its tangled history and its promise of a brighter future. Perhaps no new England manager will ever have a clearer view of the game, one less distorted by conventional wisdom, past mistakes, or prejudice.

After Wednesday night, Eriksson himself will have passed beyond that state of grace. When the whistle blows to start the friendly against Spain at Villa Park, he will begin to amass a store of first-hand experience with which to colour his future judgments. His opinions will no longer be based on purely objective criteria but on the knowledge of what players have done, or failed to do, for him.

This first squad is, then, particularly interesting, while not being remotely definitive. He admitted yesterday that after watching 20 matches around England in six weeks, plus a trip to Madrid to watch Steve McManaman, he could not guarantee the accuracy of his judgment on all 31 members of the squad. "We might have made some errors," he said. "We might have left some players out who should be in, and put some in who should be out. Who knows? But the door is definitely open to all English players."

By allowing himself an unusually large selection - something which, he said, will not be repeated - Eriksson not only gave himself some insurance against this weekend's inevitable crop of injuries, but took advantage of the chance to make a lot of players feel appreciated. These include the young and the old, the much decorated and the previously overlooked.

In the last category, the inclusion of Chris Powell of Charlton Athletic and Ugo Ehiogu of Middlesbrough sends out a particularly powerful message. Every English player in the Premiership now knows that he has spent the last six weeks playing for a place in Eriksson's thoughts, which is no bad thing to be told.

With an average age of 28, the squad reflects the general belief that international players reach their peak in their late twenties. It also mirrors the nature of Eriksson's squad at Lazio. Even when money was no object in acquiring the world's finest talent, he chose to place his faith in such veterans as Diego Simeone and Fabrizio Ravanelli. "Age is not important to me," he said yesterday, "as long as they can do the job."

His first England selection shows no particular bias - with one exception. The inclusion of eight Manchester United players, Eriksson said, should be "no big surprise to anyone" in the light of their good form in the league and in Europe, and his words hinted that the Old Trafford contingent will form the spine of the team. With the exception of Teddy Sheringham, 34, and Wes Brown, 21, all the United players are between 24 and 28, and should therefore be around their prime at the time of the 2002 World Cup.

United sent Eriksson mixed messages in their 1-1 draw against Valencia at home in the Champions League on Tuesday night, starting well but losing their shape and momentum after a quarter of an hour. David Beckham showed little of the spirit expected from a pretender to the captain's armband, but Andy Cole took his goal with cool precision and Eriksson's comments yesterday made it clear that the 28-year-old's experience in Europe counts for more than his failure to score in 10 international appearances to date.

While making the most of the understanding the United players have developed under Sir Alex Ferguson, Eriksson is unlikely to go as far as Ron Greenwood, who marked his debut as England manager in 1977 by picking seven Liverpool players and received scant reward for his faith in a dismal goalless draw with Switzerland at Wembley.

The inclusion of West Ham's young midfield trio is less likely to be reflected in the starting line-up, although one or two may come on as substitutes. "Joe Cole is a big talent, one of the biggest I've seen in this country so far," Eriksson said, giving encouragement to those who believe that the youngest Cole's talent is a key to England's fortunes over the next decade.

There are places for complete tyros, such as Gavin McCann and Ashley Cole, and for those who might have feared that they had passed their sell-by date, like Seaman, or blown their chance, such as Kevin Phillips, who gets a call despite performing without distinction twice under the manager's gaze.

Keen to establish good relationships with club managers, Eriksson explained that the decision to omit Steven Gerrard came after a conversation with Gerard Houllier, who told Eriksson that the young midfielder would be able to play either for Liverpool in the Worthington Cup final on Sunday or for England on Wednesday, but not both. "We decided it would be best for him to stay at Liverpool and do his normal work," Eriksson said. "We don't want to destroy his future either with England or with Liverpool."

Eriksson paid tribute to the "extremely positive" welcome he has received in England. "Everywhere I've been I've felt at home, and I'd like to say thank you to everyone for that, from the car-park attendants to the chairmen of all the clubs who have greeted me as a friend. Also to the supporters - I've heard a lot of 'Good luck' and 'Come on, Sven'. I know that this has been a honeymoon. I don't know if it's finished yet. I'll tell you that next weekend, when I start going to matches again."

For a man who has spent the past 20 years in daily contact with players, the last six weeks have been a curious experience. "I've never watched so many football matches in my life," he said. On Monday morning, when he meets the squad for the first time, the watching stops and the work begins.

fields.headline: There's nothing like a knockout
fields.trailText: Interest in cup football appears to be on the wane, yet tomorrow's Worthington Cup final has the chance to remind people of its great appeal.
fields.body:
Interest in cup football appears to be on the wane. Certainly the Premiership and Champions League have banished the FA Cup to the wings.

Yet tomorrow's Worthington Cup final, the first English final to be played in the Millennium stadium in Cardiff, with Wembley closed, has the chance to remind people of the appeal of knockout competitions. While leagues can prolong the suspense, teams win on points. In cups one blow can make nonsense of logic.

Liverpool, third in the Premiership and conquerors of Roma in the Uefa Cup, will be expected to beat Birmingham City, pushing for a play-off place in the First Division, tomorrow afternoon. In terms of quality there is little comparison between the sides.

This competition, however, has a history of bringing out the beast in underdogs. Queens Park Rangers' memorable triumph of 1967, when as a Third Division team they came from behind to beat West Bromwich Albion, then in the First, at Wembley set the tone for Swindon beating Arsenal in the 1969 final.

Since then such unfancied names as Stoke City, Norwich City and Oxford United have won the trophy. Luton Town surprised Arsenal in the 1988 final and few expected Sheffield Wednesday to beat Manchester United in 1991. Only last season Tranmere Rovers reached the final, where they lost narrowly to Leicester City.

Gerard Houllier's Liverpool side, therefore, will be taking Trevor Francis's Birmingham team just as seriously as they approached Roma. Birmingham, remember, have already knocked out three Premiership opponents - Tottenham, Newcastle United and Ipswich - to get this far.

True, Premiership sides are taking an increasingly ambivalent approach towards the Worthington Cup but neither Liverpool nor Birmingham have won enough in recent years to regard tomorrow's final as a sideshow.

For Liverpool winning a trophy would provide tangible evidence of the transformation Houllier has achieved in restoring standards of passing, organisation and all-round team play which once were taken for granted at Anfield.

Winning a Champions League place remains Liverpool's priority and Houllier will continue to rotate his strikers but, whatever team he selects, Birmingham will have to cope with the power of Emile Heskey, the pace of Michael Owen or, as seems very likely, the goalscoring instincts of Robbie Fowler.

Liverpool have not won a trophy since 1995, when Steve McManaman scored twice as Bolton Wanderers were beaten 2-1 in the final of the Coca-Cola Cup. In the same season Birmingham won the Auto Windscreens Shield when they beat Carlisle United at Wembley with a goal in sudden-death overtime.

The fact that a crowd of more 76,000 watched that game is a measure of the support Birmingham can still command. Dele Adebola, Geoff Horsfield or Danny Sonner could each give Brum a rare taste of glory, although Liverpool should win by a goal or two.

3pm tomorrow / Referee D Elleray (Harrow) / TV Sky Sports 1 2pm, ITV highlights 5.35pm

fields.headline: Eriksson elects to go large
fields.trailText: England's new coach makes room for youth and experience in his squad of 31 players to face Spain at Villa Park.
fields.body:
The intense study of English football recently undertaken by Sven-Goran Eriksson and his assistant, Tord Grip, has apparently been an exercise in mass observation. Yesterday the nation's new Swedish coach announced a squad big enough to fill a single-decker bus, leaving standing room only.

For Eriksson's inaugural match, the friendly against Spain at Villa Park on Wednesday, the England side will be selected from 31 players provided everyone comes through the weekend unscathed. Eriksson has promised to make generous substitutions but for all to be involved England would need to be taking on Spain at football, rugby and rowing's coxed fours.

"Squads of this size will not be the norm," Eriksson explained yesterday. "It is just that for my first game I want to talk to as many players as possible and get to know them. Who knows, we might have forgotten some, although I have to say that never in my life have I seen so many matches in such a short space of time."

For those omitted, apart from the likes of Gareth Southgate, Martin Keown and Steven Gerrard, who are unfit, the international prospects are bleak indeed. Paul Ince and Dennis Wise, who might have harboured some hope of a recall, and David Batty, who like Stuart Pearce and Paul Merson would have been amazed to get a mention, can consider themselves not forgotten but passed over.

Then again there may still be hope for everybody. Take Christopher George Robin Powell, a 31-year-old left-back whose career largely involved trudging around the lower divisions until he tasted Premiership football first with Derby County and now with Charlton Athletic.

Ten years ago Powell, then at Crystal Palace, was on loan at Aldershot. Now he finds himself jostling for an England left-back vacancy made more open by Gareth Barry's switch to the Under-21s, Graeme le Saux's lack of action at Chelsea and the non-inclusion of Sunderland's Michael Gray.

Doubtless Powell's cause has not been hindered by the fact that he has played for Eriksson's two English assistants, Peter Taylor and Steve McClaren, at Southend and Derby. "I have spoken to both but not specifically about this player," Eriksson said yesterday. "But Powell is a good left defender, so why not have a look at him?"

Presumably as much goes for Everton's Michael Ball, now impressing as a centre-back but originally a promising left wing-back, and Ashley Cole, the remarkably composed and confident Arsenal 20-year-old who has been standing in at left-back for the injured Silvinho. "I was told England had no left-backs," said Eriksson, who has also recalled Manchester United's Phil Neville to emphasise the duffness of such information.

Manchester United players make up a quarter of Eriksson's squad and arguably only Phil Neville and Nicky Butt would struggle to get into an England 22. "This is natural," said Eriksson. "Manchester United are top of the Premier League and doing well in the Champions League."

More significant may be the fact that Eriksson has also included the trio of young West Ham United midfielders who four weeks ago outpassed, outmanoeuvred and outwitted Sir Alex Ferguson's team in an FA Cup tie at Old Trafford. Joe Cole (19), Michael Carrick (19) and Frank Lampard (22) are all there; unlikely to play as a unit against Spain but already bringing a mist to the eyes of those old enough to recall the contribution made by Bobby Moore, Martin Peters and Geoff Hurst, all Upton Park academicians, to England's 1966 World Cup triumph.

"We have seen West Ham a lot," said Eriksson, "and these three players are excellent talents. Joe Cole, like Ashley Cole, may not yet be 100% ready for England, but if they are in the squad they will have a chance of playing."

The size of Eriksson's choice has enabled him to acknowledge the fast-maturing talents of the teens and twentysomethings while giving himself the option of retaining the experience of someone like Teddy Sheringham, 35 in April. Yet he has only the Spain friendly in which to form an opinion about the shape and substance of the teams he will field in the World Cup qualifiers against Finland and Albania at the end of next month, so his room for experiment is limited. Barring injuries, therefore, it seems that Sol Campbell, a possible captain, and Wes Brown or Rio Ferdinand will play in the middle of a back four flanked by Gary Neville and Powell or Ashley Cole. David Seaman may start in goal against Spain but Nigel Martyn or David James will probably finish. Yesterday the nation's new Swedish coach announced a squad big enough to fill a single-decker bus, leaving standing room only. For Eriksson's inaugural match, the friendly against Spain at Villa Park on Wednesday, the England side will be selected from 31 players provided everyone comes through the weekend unscathed. Eriksson has promised to make generous substitutions but for all to be involved England would need to be taking on Spain at football, rugby and rowing's coxed fours. "Squads of this size will not be the norm," Eriksson explained yesterday. "It is just that for my first game I want to talk to as many players as possible and get to know them. Who knows, we might have forgotten some, although I have to say that never in my life have I seen so many matches in such a short space of time." For those omitted, apart from the likes of Gareth Southgate, Martin Keown and Steven Gerrard, who are unfit, the international prospects are bleak indeed. Paul Ince and Dennis Wise, who might have harboured some hope of a recall, and David Batty, who like Stuart Pearce and Paul Merson would have been amazed to get a mention, can consider themselves not forgotten but passed over. Then again there may still be hope for everybody. webTitle: Adebola out to eclipse old mate Fowler

fields.headline: Adebola out to eclipse old mate Fowler
fields.trailText: The Nigerian striker hopes to finally make a name for himself after a career spent in other people's shadows.
fields.body:
As Dele Adebola muscles around the Millennium stadium turf tomorrow, towering above his team-mates and eye-balling Liverpool's man-mountain Sami Hyypia, it will be hard to believe he has spent his career in people's shadows.

The striker, a lifelong Liverpool fan, was dwarfed as a teenager by his team-mate Robbie Fowler's exploits in junior football on Merseyside. Then, having made his mark with Birmingham, he received four international call-ups from Nigeria. "But they'd usually send the faxes to Wolves after mixing me up with Ade Akinbiyi," he sighs, his timbre broad Scouse.

It is 38 years since Birmingham City beat their bitter rivals Aston Villa in this competition to claim their only major trophy. More than 31,000 Brummies, gorged on commemorative blue baltis and a trio of Premiership scalps, will invade the Welsh capital hoping Adebola can finally make a name for himself by eclipsing a revitalised Fowler.

"I suppose I was his Emile Heskey," he says, recalling school days playing alongside Fowler for representative sides, running up cricket scores against shell-shocked defences. "Not that Robbie needed much help. Even at that age he was unbelievable and would score a hat-trick every other game. It was an achievement to finish second top-scorer."

The Fowler-Adebola partnership flourished, supplied by the subtle promptings of Tony Grant, now of Manchester City, in midfield. Having won the English Schools Trophy with Merseyside, Liverpool's Steve Highway offered Adebola YTS terms at Anfield.

"Crewe also made an approach and I realised I'd have a better chance of playing professional football at an earlier age there," he says. "Anyway the thought of going to Liverpool with the amount of attention Robbie was generating was too daunting. He had so much talent I couldn't see anyone else being taken seriously."

Adebola's career has never followed conventional lines. He made his name under Dario Gradi as a powerful target-man, yet his game incorporated the refined nature of Alexandra's slick style. A £1.2m switch to Birmingham followed in 1998 but, despite a goal ratio of one every four games, the 25-year-old became a victim of his manager Trevor Francis's desire to "freshen up" his strike force and he was transfer-listed last summer.

A £1.5m move to the newly promoted Spanish Primera Division side Las Palmas fell through after a quibble over a medical - "they saw some blood on my knee and wanted to cut me open, but Birmingham refused". So, unperturbed, Adebola embarked on the scenic route to European football via the Worthington Cup.

He scored in City's 5-0 win at Southend in the first round, plundered two goals as the Blues became the only team to beat Tottenham at White Hart Lane this season and added to his tally in the competition against Newcastle and Sheffield Wednesday. Yet, despite establishing him self as Birmingham's joint leading goalscorer with 10, he remains technically out of favour and up for sale.

"In the gaffer's opinion it was a justifiable move; in my opinion it was not. But in fairness to him, I've not once gone in and asked him about it," he says in a mystifyingly matter-of-fact way. "He [Francis] could have used it as a short sharp jolt to jump-start my season but I've played in 32 games now and have been reasonably consistent. You can't maintain shock treatment like that."

The Millennium stadium would be the ideal stage on which to prove his point although, with City maintaining their strong-arm push for promotion - they are currently fourth in the First Division - the season's biggest prize lies further ahead.

"The manner in which we have beaten the three Premiership clubs in the cup shows we could hold our own if we do go up," Adebola says, "and the final will prove another test of that.

"Nobody's going to let themselves down by going missing during the game. We're relaxed about it. We'll give a good account of ourselves, and fate will take care of the rest."

webTitle: Houllier's pot coming to the boil

fields.headline: Houllier's pot coming to the boil
fields.trailText: The Liverpool manager likes it in England and is eager to land his first prize in Cardiff.
fields.body:
The thing to remember about Gerard Houllier is that, for all the mildly academic air, reminding us that he was once a schoolteacher, and the occasional dramatised shrug in the style of Henri Leconte, he comes from the coalfields and his father was a small-town butcher. Civilised, amusing, convivial, thoughtful, a believer that "in this job you need a philosophy and a vision", Houllier is also a realist, fully prepared to send his players out with their sleeves rolled up and ready to fight for a result against a more accomplished side, as they did against Roma at Anfield in Thursday's Uefa Cup tie.

You do not graduate with honours from places like Arras, Lens and Noeux-les-Mines - the small club famous for producing the great Raymond Kopa, the son of an immigrant Polish miner - without acquiring a knowledge of the harsher arts of football management, and during his first two years with Liverpool he needed to apply all the lessons of his apprenticeship in northern France. And at times, under pressure from the expectations of an army of devoted fans with long memories, the strain showed.

This time last year, for example, Houllier was feeling more than a little frustrated. Eliminated from both domestic cup competitions, inconsistent in the league, not involved in Europe, his team played only two competitive fixtures in the month of February. In order to keep them match-fit, he had to take them to Malta to play a friendly. Tomorrow, by contrast, when Liverpool travel to Cardiff to meet Birmingham City in the Worthington Cup final, it will be for their sixth competitive match in 23 days.

So now, with the pressure at its most intense, is the time when even the most sceptical season-ticket holder can begin to glimpse the results of the work the 53-year-old Frenchman has done since he took sole charge of the club in December 1998, requesting the fans to show patience. The rebuilding not just of the team but of the club's morale, the expansion of the squad (at a net cost of around £20m), and the application of his footballing philosophy are all on display as Liverpool attack on four fronts. The sense of exhilaration and renewal around the club is as hard to miss as the giant steel frame of the new training centre rising at Melwood, overlooking the pitches on which generations of Liverpool heroes have honed their craft.

Tomorrow comes the new generation's first chance to establish themselves as winners in the Liverpool tradition. "It would mean a lot," Houllier said earlier this week, "because of this club's history. To me it would probably mean a significant boost to the confidence of the team. It would say to them, 'We can do it and we can keep on going.' We want to keep that momentum. If you win something along the way, it increases the self-belief of the players. We have the squad to cope with it, and the way I see them they feel relaxed and happy to be challenging on every front."

For all the present wave of optimism it will not be until the end of the season, when the final results are in, that he can say for sure whether the Liverpool renaissance is on schedule. "If you look at where we are right now, it shows a massive improvement compared to two years ago and one year ago," he said. "We're in the last eight of the Uefa Cup and the FA Cup, we're in the last two of the Worthington Cup and we're third in the Premier League. Last season we finished fourth and we want to improve on that. If you ask any member of the playing staff, he will say that playing in the Champions League is the target."

Houllier is not slow to point out the issues - such as the purchase of Emile Heskey and Vladimir Smicer - on which his critics have been proved wrong. "The funny thing when you're a manager is that you sometimes smile because people discover things that you spotted about two years ago," he said. "I always thought Vladimir was a really talented player who could do a good job for us. Last season he was knocked back by injuries but this season his record is practically as good in terms of goal assists as Beckham's for Manchester United, which is a reference point. And he's scored eight goals, something like that. He was unfairly criticised because he was not physical. Maybe people didn't like Vladimir because he doesn't kick people. He just kicks the ball. And if you ask every member of the playing staff here, they'd say it's better to have him with us."

The return to form and fitness of Robbie Fowler and Michael Owen is also a cause for satisfaction, although Houllier reacts badly when the term "rotation" is heard in connection with his strikers. "I don't like the word," he said. "It's never been used by me. You sometimes feel that you have to rest players because you want to keep them fresh. When you're tired and you're less sharp, you're not so quick on your feet and then you pick up an injury. I rested Robbie against Manchester City in the league and three days later he scored two goals against West Ham."

Nor was Houllier ever worried about Owen's future at a time when the prodigy's goalscoring instinct appeared to desert him. "I thought he was fine even when he was missing some chances. At least he got himself into position to score. I'm not worried about him because he's strong-willed. He's a winner in his soul. He's still a young boy, only just 21, and he needs a bit of time to build up his game. I don't want to have a Ronaldo thing and lose him."

The reaction to the first of Owen's goals in Rome showed Houllier the strength of the squad's collective spirit. "When your bench celebrates a goal the way they did, and when the guy who scored comes to the bench like that, then I'd say you've got a good team unity building around that."

The squad is also now flexible enough to absorb the long-term absence of two playmakers, Jamie Redknapp and Patrik Berger, while integrating such recent arrivals as Igor Biscan, the 22-year-old midfielder from Croatia Zagreb, and Gregory Vignal, the 19-year-old full-back from Montpellier. Both these newcomers, although at very different stages of their careers, looked equally at home on their recent debuts.

But the most significant new acquisition is undoubtedly Jari Litmanen, signed for nothing from Barcelona after three months of quiet negotiations. "We took him as a fourth striker, but I wanted a different profile from the others," Houllier said. "He's a go-between, a link player between the midfield and the attack - more of a nine and a half, as we say in France. He's a good passer who likes to make the final pass, and he gives different options to whoever is playing with him. He's also tougher than I would have thought. He may be a star player but to me he's a team player. That's the main thing."

Litmanen's absence through injury was keenly felt as Liverpool battled against Roma at Anfield on Thursday, and there is a belief that the Finn's arrival could have the same effect as that of Houllier's friend Eric Cantona, another "nine and a half" who became the unexpected catalyst of success at Manchester United. "We'll see. You media like to label people very quickly. That's easy. But I don't know yet. I need to see more of him. All I know is that every time he's come on, he's done well."

Like his compatriots Arsene Wenger and Jean Tigana, Houllier holds on to his sanity within the madness of the English game by insisting on his right to personal privacy. He is acutely aware of the ability of English newspapers to exploit the most innocuous revelation and, although we know he likes books and music, it may be some time before we discover whether this French exile prefers Camus to Sartre or Francoise Hardy to France Gall.

What we do know is that he loves football and footballers, a feeling that began when he watched his father play for the town team, and he was willing to talk, at least, about the man who most profoundly shaped his approach to handling players.

"I'm not somebody who has heroes," he said, in answer to a question about people who had impressed or influenced him as a young man. "You take some bits of philosophy from many people and adapt them to what you do. But one of the managers I worked with, when I was a young assistant at Noeux-les-Mines, was Guy de Beugny. He's not well known but I think he was probably 10 years ahead of time, if not 20, in coaching and preparation of the players. He was really the one who totally changed my approach.

"He was a thinker. He showed me things I had never seen before, despite all the courses I'd been on. He could prepare a team to counter-attack, or to play build-up football, or to play possession football. It was a very forward-thinking and modern approach, in which everything starts from skills. Even if you're working on the physical side, do it through skills. And the players improved a lot. I think the success I've had is owed to him. Maybe you're disappointed. Maybe you'd have expected me to say Herrera. Or Capello . . ."

Well, Helenio Herrera, maybe, after the uncharacteristic display of quasi-catenaccio defending which narrowly thwarted Fabio Capello's Roma this week. But Houllier is by nature a progressive, and his central role in the recent success of French football, as national coach and then technical director, is reflected in the pride he takes in the achievements of French players and coaches in England.

"First of all, I'm proud that the players play good football and show a good image. They're good ambassadors for French football. And I'm very proud of what Arsene has done and what Jean is doing at the moment. Three French managers here, we're under a bit more pressure. We've got to be good. And I always thought Jean would be a good manager. Very strong guy, good personality, great sense of humour. And he's a winner."

In a recent interview with a French magazine Houllier appeared to hint at an eventual return home, possibly to another job with the federation. It was a distortion, he said this week, in the sense that he was merely giving a polite reply to a question about whether he would consider such an offer, were it ever made.

"The thing is, I have no plan and absolutely no agenda. Three months before the World Cup in 1998 I didn't know I was going to come here. All I knew was that I'd been 10 years with the national team and at the age of 51 you look at yourself in the mirror and say, do you want to go back into the firing line? And the offer from Liverpool came in."

He may not have a plan - and the length of his contract is something else he will not discuss - but, when the Anfield mission has been completed, might he not fancy a move to Italy, say, or Spain?

"No. I like it too much here. I'm a bit like Arsene in that respect. We like the people, we like the country, I like the culture. A Premiership game is always exciting, you know?" And English football, in return, is more exciting for the presence of an increasingly vibrant and authoritative Liverpool side, apparently ready to take the next step.
