"We'll see. You media like to label people very quickly. That's easy. But I don't know yet. I need to see more of him. All I know is that every time he's come on, he's done well." Like his compatriots Arsene Wenger and Jean Tigana, Houllier holds on to his sanity within the madness of the English game by insisting on his right to personal privacy. He is acutely aware of the ability of English newspapers to exploit the most innocuous revelation and, although we know he likes books and music, it may be some time before we discover whether this French exile prefers Camus to Sartre or Francoise Hardy to France Gall. What we do know is that he loves football and footballers, a feeling that began when he watched his father play for the town team, and he was willing to talk, at least, about the man who most profoundly shaped his approach to handling players. "I'm not somebody who has heroes," he said, in answer to a question about people who had impressed or influenced him as a young man. "You take some bits of philosophy from many people and adapt them to what you do. But one of the managers I worked with, when I was a young assistant at Noeux-les-Mines, was Guy de Beugny. He's not well known but I think he was probably 10 years ahead of time, if not 20, in coaching and preparation of the players. He was really the one who totally changed my approach. "He was a thinker. He showed me things I had never seen before, despite all the courses I'd been on. He could prepare a team to counter-attack, or to play build-up football, or to play possession football. It was a very forward-thinking and modern approach, in which everything starts from skills. Even if you're working on the physical side, do it through skills. And the players improved a lot. I think the success I've had is owed to him. Maybe you're disappointed. Maybe you'd have expected me to say Herrera. Or Capello . . ." Well, Helenio Herrera, maybe, after the uncharacteristic display of quasi-catenaccio defending which narrowly thwarted Fabio Capello's Roma this week. But Houllier is by nature a progressive, and his central role in the recent success of French football, as national coach and then technical director, is reflected in the pride he takes in the achievements of French players and coaches in England. "First of all, I'm proud that the players play good football and show a good image. They're good ambassadors for French football. And I'm very proud of what Arsene has done and what Jean is doing at the moment. Three French managers here, we're under a bit more pressure. We've got to be good. And I always thought Jean would be a good manager. Very strong guy, good personality, great sense of humour. And he's a winner." In a recent interview with a French magazine Houllier appeared to hint at an eventual return home, possibly to another job with the federation. It was a distortion, he said this week, in the sense that he was merely giving a polite reply to a question about whether he would consider such an offer, were it ever made. "The thing is, I have no plan and absolutely no agenda. Three months before the World Cup in 1998 I didn't know I was going to come here. All I knew was that I'd been 10 years with the national team and at the age of 51 you look at yourself in the mirror and say, do you want to go back into the firing line? And the offer from Liverpool came in." He may not have a plan - and the length of his contract is something else he will not discuss - but, when the Anfield mission has been completed, might he not fancy a move to Italy, say, or Spain? "No. I like it too much here. I'm a bit like Arsene in that respect. We like the people, we like the country, I like the culture. A Premiership game is always exciting, you know?" And English football, in return, is more exciting for the presence of an increasingly vibrant and authoritative Liverpool side, apparently ready to take the next step.

webTitle: Nationwide accuses rival of false claims

fields.headline: Nationwide accuses rival of false claims
fields.trailText: The boss of one of the country's best-known mortgage lenders yesterday launched an astonishing attack on a rival which claimed to offer a better deal to borrowers.
fields.body:
The boss of one of the country's best-known mortgage lenders yesterday launched an astonishing attack on a rival which claimed to offer a better deal to borrowers.

Brian Davis, the chief executive of the Nationwide building society, wrote to his counterpart at the Halifax, James Crosby, accusing the bank of using "false comparison" and demanded that it "refrain from making false claims".

The spat between the two chief executives comes at the end of a week when the battle for mortgage business intensified, with both high street lenders aggressively cutting rates to home owners. Nationwide was the first to move its rate when on Monday it introduced a new base mortgage rate of 6.49%, undercutting the high street banks by as much as one percentage point.

But Halifax - which became a bank four years ago and is the country's biggest mortgage lender with 2.5m customers - was close behind with a cut in its standard variable rate to 6.75% from 7.5%.

Both lenders said the cuts would mean gains of up to £30 a month for the average borrower with a £60,000 interest-only mortgage.

Around 400,000 of the Halifax's 2.5m customers have standard variable rate mortgages, a type that is becoming less popular. They will have to apply to transfer to the lower rate.

The battle is fierce for the business of the one in three homeowners a year that move their mortgage. Brian Davis, the chief executive of Nationwide, accuses the Halifax in the letter - entitled "Misleading Customers" and seen by the Guardian - of "misinformation".

"Competition is one thing, misinformation is another," Mr Davis writes.

He accuses Halifax of making a "patently untrue claim" on BBC radio and "misleading statements" on a breakfast broadcast on Tuesday.

Mr Davis appears to have been angered with Halifax's claim that its decision to change the way it calculates interest payments takes its headline mortgage rate to below that of the building society he runs.

He also writes that the gap between Halifax's rates for new customers and those offered to existing customers - one of the reasons why millions of homeowners move their loan each year - is still "significant".

The Nationwide boss also disputes Halifax's claims that it cannot automatically transfer its existing customers to the new products because of contractual arrangements.

"Isn't it true to say that the only reason you are not moving existing customers on to your new deal automatically is that you are relying on their inertia not to take up your offer?" Mr Davis asks. He concludes by asking "Halifax to provide the public... with correct information and to refrain from making misleading claims."

Halifax stood by its claims and insisted it was widely advertising its new range of products and that its telephones had been deluged by calls from its customers. A spokesman for Halifax said: "We stand by everything we said. Our announcements are about a better deal for existing customers and winning more new customers".

Mr Crosby, said the spokesman, would reply to Mr Davis. "We always write back when somebody writes to us."

fields.headline: A pungent, heartbreaking Strauss
fields.standfirst:
Jon Vickers
Wigmore Hall, London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Jon Vickers
Wigmore Hall, London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
A legend in his lifetime, Jon Vickers has come out of retirement to celebrate his 75th birthday with, astonishingly, his Wigmore Hall debut. The Canadian tenor, whose Otello, Tristan and Peter Grimes were considered definitive by some, has chosen not to sing, however, but to speak in public for his comeback.

Strauss's curious Enoch Arden forms his material. A melodrama for reciter and piano, it was written in 1897 for the sometime actor Ernst von Possart, who was Strauss's boss at the Munich Court Opera. Tennyson's poem is the source. Enoch, a mariner who has fallen on hard times, sets off on a voyage to the orient, only to be shipwrecked on a desert island on the return journey. He's eventually rescued and returns to England to find that his wife Annie, believing him dead, has married their childhood friend Phillip. Enoch conceals his identity and spends the rest of his life living a lie so that the couple can remain in peace.

Tennyson might seem an odd choice for Strauss, though the poem examines several themes that he was later to explore more fully in his operas. The emphasis on the formation of new relationships as a consolation for the desperation of abandonment prefigures Ariadne auf Naxos. There's more than a hint of Rosenkavalier in Enoch's decision to sacrifice himself for the happiness of his beloved. There's also a strong whiff of anti-clericalism in the work. Tennyson uses the tale to question the workings of a seemingly less than beneficent deity. This may have appealed to Strauss, who was an atheist.

Vickers, however, is a committed Christian and he strips the vein of sardonic irony from the piece to replace it with intense religious fervour. His delivery is slow, incantatory. He speaks as he once sang, with a mixture of delicacy and raw power. His voice remains beautiful, its bronze tone undimmed by age. He has a fondness for lingering over pauses which occasionally breaks the flow of the verse, though there are terrifying moments - Annie's grief, Enoch's horror when he realises what has happened in his absence - where Vickers scales the tremendous heights of declamatory, tragic intensity that infused his operatic performances and made him one of the greatest of postwar artists.

The piano-writing, which punctuates the narrative rather than illustrates it, betrays a strong debt to Schumann and more of Brahms's influence than Strauss would ever have admitted. But there are some wonderful effects - pungent chromatic surging, and weird, uneasy trickles over sustained pedals - and Vickers's accompanist, the Brazilian Jose Feghali, plays it immaculately. The ovations, both when Vickers walked on to the platform and when the performance was over, were extended and heartfelt. Many, myself included, were simply grateful to have the chance to hear this remarkable man once again.

fields.headline: Down the Line
fields.standfirst:
Peacock Theatre, Dublin,
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Peacock Theatre, Dublin,
Rating: ***
fields.body:
Paul Mercier's recent plays have ambitiously crossed time: in Native City, for instance, he depicted a century of Dublin life through a deconsecrated Protestant church. As a result, he crashes through the normal conventions of stage narrative, to create a vast, compacted cascade of human experience. The dramatic effect is mixed, but he always delivers a sting of emotion. Down the Line is another such but this is the first not directed by Mercier himself, but instead by Lynne Parker, using the Abbey Theatre's resources.

Set over the 1980s, it concerns a suburban, lower-income family as the kids gradually come of age and leave the nest through matrimony or alienation. In Angela Davies's cutaway rabbit-warren set, we look in on a series of Christmases, weddings, and down times in which marriages unravel and faultlines show up between siblings.

The affably indulgent civil servant father is hen-pecked by the hard-bitten, conservative, suspicious mother. The talented elder son, once the golden boy, rarely visits now, having overshadowed the equally talented daughter, whose husband is, by common consent, worthless. The younger son, a punk musician, becomes a father with a blissed-out vegetarian hippie, while the first child to go to college, Deirdre, veers from lefty student politics to a psychiatric episode that seems to leave her alone and unmarriageable.

This is soap-flavoured social realism: decent people doing the best for each other, but ultimately separated by prejudice, selfishness or generation gaps. It's very true material, and some real humour emerges from the cacophony, as when the mother furtively baptises her grandson in the kitchen sink. Oddly, it's difficult to detect Parker's directorial stamp: her marshalling of proceedings is very Mercier-like. Some of the acting is a little young, but they do suggest the subtle maturing of the characters.

Mercier's unmistakable voice runs, rather distractingly, through all the characters. As in his last production, We Ourselves, you sometimes strain to understand the stories behind the action. He delivers undeniable stabs of heartfelt emotion, but ultimately there are too many characters for true resolution.

Until March 17. Box office: 00 353 1 878 7222.

fields.headline: A one hit wonder?
fields.standfirst: You can see all your financial information on a single page, but some fear aggregation may cause aggravation, says Rupert Jones
fields.trailText: A new type of service that could revolutionise the way we manage our finances is just months away from arriving in the UK.
fields.body:
A new type of service that could revolutionise the way we manage our finances is just months away from arriving in the UK.

Several banks are currently in discussions about setting up websites where people would be able to access all their financial information in one place - a sort of online one-stop shop that would pull together all your different holdings with different companies and present them on one easy-to-read page.

So instead of having to dig through files in search of a multitude of statements and documents, or logging on to lots of different websites, you would simply go to one site to view and monitor your current account, savings account, investments, mortgage, credit card and so on.

It is a bit like a hi-tech ver sion of a bank statement, except that it would be one that contains every single bit of financial information which is relevant to you.

This one-click access to all your financial information has been dubbed "aggregation" and - surprise, surprise - it's a US concept. Aggregation has been making waves in the US for a year or so, and it is estimated there are now around 1m people there using these services.

Now, as happens with most things over there, it's on its way over here. No one in this country yet offers data aggregation but online bank Egg said this week that it is "fully expecting aggregation to reach the UK market within the coming months", while Barclays says it is something it is actively working on.

Corillian, a leading e-finance software company, reckons that by early summer we will start to see one or more banks offering fledgling services.

Aggregation clearly offers the greatest benefits to those people with lots of online financial products. It could mean that someone with an online savings account, current account, credit card and share-dealing account with four different providers would no longer have to log on to each of these to check their current financial position - all the information would be available in one place.

However, many of the US services also allow people to input and update information about their offline accounts and things like loans or insurance in order to create a complete picture of the user's financial life.

In the US the services are typically run by big banks such as Citibank and Chase, and internet portals such as Yahoo! They are usually free and are updated every day. You can see what's in it for these companies - knowing everything about your finances puts them in a very powerful position and enables them to target you with offers tailored to your needs.

But the main reason why aggregation is likely to prove hugely controversial when it hits the UK can be summed up in one word: security.

How it works in the US is that when you sign up for one of these aggregation services, you have to give the company all your user names and passwords for the online banks and other sites whose details you want to add to your personal page. The techno-wizards running the service then enter these sites on your behalf, call up your up-to-date information and transport it back to your page - a process known as "screen-scraping".

The sites insist your passwords and financial data are kept secure and private but it's not hard to see why aggregation is a potential minefield. Giving out your user names and passwords to third parties is clearly fraught with risks and is something net users are told time and again they must not do. In fact, online banks warn their customers they could be liable for any losses if they don't keep their security details safe.

Growing numbers of Americans are clearly willing to accept the risk and give their log-in information to aggregation service providers, but as Ian Giles at Corillian points out, people in the UK are "a little bit more reserved and a little less trusting about giving out user IDs and passwords".

Rightly so, many might think, bearing in mind the spate of internet security blunders we have seen over the past few months, involving major players such as Barclays and PowerGen.

In fact, it's difficult to envisage the UK's financial watchdogs being happy about a system that involves people handing over their security details. So what's the answer? What seems more likely to happen in the UK is that banks and others offering these services will get to gether and agree to share customer information. That way, they would be able to obtain information on someone's holdings with another bank in a secure and controlled way. This is what is happening in Australia, where five or six banks are getting together to pass data down the line to each other where people have consented for this to happen.

Alternatively, Barclays says what may happen initially is that rather than giving out their security details, customers will have to type in their own information on the site.

Cahoot, the online bank launched last year by Abbey National, says that like other banks it is interested in the concept. But marketing director Tim Sawyer says he has serious concerns about security. Unless an official data-sharing system was set up, or another way was found to overcome these worries, he thinks Cahoot would be unlikely to take part in giving out people's information.

As things stand, there is nothing to stop a fraudster posing as an aggregator on the net and asking for people's user names and passwords, then clearing out their accounts and vanishing overnight with the loot.

Alternatively, if a legitimate site was broken into by hackers, who would be liable - the aggregator site, the individual for giving out their codes, or the person's bank for passing on their financial information?

There are clearly a lot of issues to iron out but most experts agree that aggregation is coming to the UK in some form. As we face more and more pressures on our time, and increasingly turn to the internet to fulfil our needs, the ability to get one-click access to all our financial information is likely to prove very appealing to many people.

fields.headline: Big guns go to war on the home front
fields.standfirst: Halifax and Nationwide have been slugging it out in the mortgage market. Rupert Jones reports on who gets what in the aftermath
fields.trailText: This week saw an outbreak of fresh hostilities in the home loans war as Halifax and Nationwide announced headline-grabbing cuts in their mortgage rates.
fields.body:
This week saw an outbreak of fresh hostilities in the home loans war as Halifax and Nationwide announced headline-grabbing cuts in their mortgage rates.

In all, more than 900,000 borrowers will benefit immediately from the cuts, with some set to enjoy savings of as much as £1,000-plus a year. The moves will put pressure on other leading lenders to slash their borrowing costs too or risk facing an exodus of unhappy customers.

It's great news for consumers but people shouldn't get too carried away by their apparent phenomenal generosity. Look closely and you'll find some caveats and catches lurking in the small print. And remember that lower mortgage rates usually mean cuts in savings rates.

First the good news. If you're a borrower with the Halifax or the Nationwide, you are on the standard variable mortgage rate and you're not tied in by early redemption penalties, you are quids in. Halifax has announced that its new variable rate will be 6.75%, down from 7.5%, which means someone with an average £60,000 repayment mortgage will see their monthly payments fall from £448.55 to £414.54 - a saving of £34.01 a month, or £408 over a year.

Meanwhile Nationwide is switching more than 500,000 standard variable rate borrowers on to its new "base mortgage rate," which means that the interest they pay falls from 7.09% to 6.49%. A customer with a £60,000 repayment mortgage will save £23.01 a month, or £276 a year.

But Halifax borrowers won't be transferred automatically on to the new lower rate - they will have to ask to be moved. That means borrowers who are either unaware of the change or who don't get round to asking to be transferred will stay stuck on the higher rate.

As an added plus, Halifax is moving from annual to daily interest calculation for its borrowers, which reduces your costs and means that though Nationwide boasts the lower rate, both lenders' rates work out broadly similar over the long term.

fields.headline: Conor McPherson's cocaine and cardigans
fields.standfirst:
Port Authority
New Ambassadors Theatre, London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Port Authority
New Ambassadors Theatre, London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
All good dramatists carve out their own territory. Conor McPherson's, as we know from The Weir and Dublin Carol, is that of the waste, solitude and sadness that lie behind the convivial face of Ireland. He is the laureate of missed opportunities; and even if this new play, presented by Dublin's Gate Theatre, doesn't extend his range, it shows him occupying his familiar terrain with glittering wit and assurance.

In his most recent plays McPherson has ventured into dialogue. Here he returns to monologue - a natural form for loneliness. And we listen, intrigued, as three generations of Irishmen tell their tales. Kevin, the youngest, finds himself helplessly ensnared by the beautiful Clare. Dermot, a married middle-aged loser, is hilariously and mistakenly caught up in the world of a showbiz agent. And the widowed Joe, living in a Catholic old folks' home, is haunted by the memory of a woman he recklessly loved.

The narrative links between the tales are tenuous. What matters is that the three men, while representing different facets of Ireland, all occupy the same emotional wasteland. Kevin's world is that of half-assed pub bands, Dermot moves in the shiny milieu of the Emerald Tiger and Joe faces his end in a nice, nun-run home. But McPherson's point is that the Irish male is congenitally clumsy in dealing with affection and treats women as either idolised Madonnas or base sex objects.

It's a point he has made before, and I think it emerges more strongly in The Weir, where the disruptive presence of a woman exposes the sexual excitability of the rustic topers. I also wish McPherson would return to the dynamic interchange of dialogue. But he writes like a recording Irish angel and, for a man who is barely 30, has an uncanny empathy with older generations. The best story is that of the dim Dermot, who, thrust into a fantasy world of hot women, VIP lounges and cocaine snorts, realises he is sustained only by his neglected, immensely tolerant wife.

McPherson directs his play with unadorned simplicity, punctuating the stories with the clang of a ship's bell. His actors also do him proud. Eanna MacLiam has all the bright-eyed naivete of a young man shying away from love. Stephen Brennan perfectly captures the wild comedy of a middle-aged no-hoper embroiled in a shiny world of success. And Jim Norton, with his cardigan and bunched shoulders, peerlessly conveys the timorous spirit of a man who caught a glimpse of true love and let it disappear. My suspicion is that Chekhov and William Trevor are McPherson's mentors; like them he has a poetic understanding of what might have been - and of the pathos of quietly extinguished hopes.

Until March 31. Box office: 020-7369 1761

fields.headline: QC beefs up Equitable fight
fields.trailText: Vanni Treves, the new chairman of Equitable Life, has hired a top QC to overturn the court ruling which forced the world's oldest mutual insurer to put itself up for sale.
fields.body:
Vanni Treves, the new chairman of Equitable Life, has hired a top QC to overturn the court ruling which forced the world's oldest mutual insurer to put itself up for sale.

If the leading counsel hired by Mr Treves, himself a senior lawyer, finds grounds to contest the law lords judgement last summer, this could eventually result in Equitable Life's policyholders being returned to the position they were in early last year.

This would mean the 90,000 holders of so-called guaranteed annuity policies would not be owed £1.5bn in payments which the law lords ruled they had been unfairly denied. It would also mean that holders of policies which are not guaranteed would no longer face reductions in their policies to rectify the position of those with guarantees.

He has hired leading silk Nicholas Warren QC to explore whether the judgment can be "amended" in some way, and Mr Warren - who has wide experience of financial cases and sometimes sits as a judge - will deliver his initial view early next month.

But because Mr Treves, who officially takes up his position on March 1, acknowledges that finding grounds to try to overturn the ruling by the highest judges in the land was a "long shot", he will set up a "war room" next week to try to formulate a compromise between the two groups of policyholders.

"It will be a group of people whose first and absolutely non-negotiable priority will be to put together a compromise which is technically foolproof but is also easy to articulate, understand and absorb," he said. The proposal is to give the 90,000 people a one-off payment in return for them giving up their rights to the guarantee.

Mr Treves will also embark on a charm offensive of Equitable's policyholders to try to win their support for any deal to buy off holders of guaranteed annuities. He intends to tour the country to meet with policyholders.

Mr Treves, a partner at law firm Macfarlanes, is foregoing the £300,000-a-year salary he was offered. He has a personal interest in finding a solution as he has £560,000 worth of policies, once all guaranteed but now split evenly between those with and without guarantees to avoid accusations of bias.

fields.headline: Mister Heracles
fields.standfirst:
West Yorkshire Playhouse, Leeds
Rating ****
fields.trailText:
West Yorkshire Playhouse, Leeds
Rating ****
fields.body:
What is a hero? When does the defender of the state become just a murderer, and should we be surprised when the man who has been trained to kill does so indiscriminately, like a machine mowing down all in his way? If there was ever a hero who carried within him the seeds of his own destruction it was Heracles, son of a mortal mother and the god Zeus, a man born to be a master of the universe.

In poet Simon Armitage's startlingly effective new version, based on Euripides's original play, Heracles is suspended in time and space, between past and present. Our first sight of Heracles (played by Adrian Bower) is as an astronaut. This is a man who has reached for the stars and twinkles as brightly in the imaginations of the people. This is a hero who can navigate the Sea of Tranquillity, drop in like the Milk Tray Man and defeat flesh-eating viruses - all before breakfast.

If that makes Armitage's version sound tricksy, it is not, largely because the production negotiates the no man's land between past and present with consummate skill and because Armitage's language has a flinty immediacy. It is capable of being down to earth and beautiful at the same time.

Take Heracles's return, his unexpected appearance just in the nick of time that prevents his family being burned to death by the weasel Lycus. He circles his arms around the wife and children that were about to be used as firewood and one of the chorus remarks: "Today has been put back." Such a simple phrase, so apt, and one that catches like sand in your throat.

The early scenes are immensely affecting, and if the ultimate catastrophe doesn't have the same emotional impact, Armitage can take comfort from the fact that Heracles's sudden descent into murder was a dramatic teaser that Euripides didn't entirely crack either. Armitage's idea of having Heracles's madness start with a hi-tech box of mind-bending tricks is neat, but it's still too contrived an explanation for his rampage. Perhaps his actions are inexplicable, like the recent real-life case of the ex-soldier who slaughtered his entire family and himself. "Such a nice, cheery man," declared the puzzled neighbours. There is a touch of that ordinary, suburban horror here, with the bodies crumpled on the living-room carpet, a crimson sea of blood.

Laura Hopkins's superb design combines exterior and interior, boarded up crumbling Greek mansion with a more modern scene-of-the-catastrophe setting where floral tributes lie rotting. It sets the tone for an exquisitely acted production that combines the finest control with an almost reckless bravery.

Until March 17. Box office: 0113-213 7700.

fields.headline: Under the Doctor
fields.standfirst:
Comedy Theatre, London
Rating *
fields.trailText:
Comedy Theatre, London
Rating *
fields.body:
Good farce can make your stomach ache, with laughter and with apprehension at what the next moment will bring. Under the Doctor is not good. Most of the fault lies with Peter Tilbury, whose laboured, repetitive writing struggles to raise even a chuckle. But he's not helped by Fiona Laird's plodding production, nor by the hammy performances. This is precisely the sort of excruciating dud that gives farce a bad name.

The format is grindingly familiar. Dr Moulineaux comes home from an all-night session with his mistress to find his wife returned home from holiday. He spends the rest of the morning trying to allay her suspicions, but with every lie he stacks up he uncovers a deception that threatens to send his precarious structure tumbling. Tilbury is fine on intricate plotting - the details are the problem. There are four uses of the phrase "Can't pull the wool over your eyes"; the dismal double entendre "Did you give her one?" crops up; and rather than write real jokes, Tilbury has relied on swearing for laughs. In a weak attempt to discomfort what he appears to thinks of as his deeply conservative and moral audience, he pokes at them with cheap provocations: "All I want," whines the doctor, "is a quiet life; a happy marriage and a bit on the side."

With the profanities, the sex scenes and the murder at the end, Tilbury seeks to subvert the genre, to transform farce into modern black comedy. But he only succeeds in making his play's setting, Paris 1912, even more irrelevant, and in creating the sort of feebly risque drama of the libido run riot (or, as Tilbury puts it in his lofty subtitle, of The Tyranny of Testosterone) that is more usually seen on Channel 5.

It's hard to imagine how this could have been saved in production. Laird doesn't find any solutions; for all the activity, the constant round of entrances and exits, her production drags painfully, and there are yawning gaps where nothing happens. Peter Davison steams and flaps as the doctor, Anton Rodgers maintains an air of lugubrious impassivity as his servant Etienne, but neither provides the kind of star turn that could make this watchable. Major surgery would be pointless: this is one play that should be quickly put out of its misery.

Until May 13. Box office: 020-7369 1731.

webTitle: Register or a fine: that's the business

fields.headline: Register or a fine: that's the business
fields.standfirst: Self-employed workers face an April deadline plus a £100 penalty under inland revenue rules. Phillip Inman reports
fields.trailText: Self employed workers were warned this week that new inland revenue rules could cost them £100 if they failed to register their business before April 30.
fields.body:
Self employed workers were warned this week that new inland revenue rules could cost them £100 if they failed to register their business before April 30.

Tax rules that came into effect on January 30 gave self employed people three months to register or face a new £100 fine.

Revenue officials believe the fine will encourage businesses that currently operate in the "informal" economy and refuse to pay tax to come forward and register with the tax authorities.

The revenue issued a press release on January 10 announcing the change, but tax advisers believe the Revenue should do more to publicise the measure before the April deadline. If the revenue fails to act, they say, thousands of innocent businesses could be fined that would normally wait until until next year to register when they send in their first self-assessment tax return.

"I don't think the revenue has been heinously wicked, but it has done very little to tell people about the change," says Peter Horsman, a tax expert at accountants Saffrey Champness. "The rule change was brought in quite quietly and there has been little or no advertising to tell people about the new rule, none that I have seen anyway."

Legislation already exists requiring registration within three months of starting a business for Class 2 national insurance contributions, a system run by the inland revenue, but it has proved ineffective.

In practice, many people who become self employed first contact the revenue when they submit a tax return. They can wait for up to 18 months before getting their tax affairs in order. A business started in the current tax year, last May or June for instance, doesn't need to file its return until January 2002.

The new rule is designed to add weight to the national insurance regulations.

"The new measures are being introduced to help those starting up a new business. I fear that in practice, they will simply impose a penalty for individuals who are unaware of the new legislation, particularly those who cannot afford early professional advice."

Treasury minister Dawn Primarolo maintained that the measure was designed to stop people drifting into the hidden economy. "We are not prepared to allow honest businesses to be undercut by those in the hidden economy who are determined not to pay their dues, so we are also introducing a penalty for those who fail to notify the inland revenue about their new businesses. Our intention is fairness for all."

But Mr Horsman questions whether the threat of a £100 fine would lure businesses operating outside the tax system, many of which would owe thousands of pounds of tax, to come clean.

"There are benefits in encouraging people to register with the inland revenue sooner rather than later, particularly if it stops people leaving it so long, that they defer registration indefinitely for fear that they may owe a lot of tax. However, I am not sure that introducing a penalty will encourage these people to register, given that they may not be aware of the penalty until it is too late," he says.

"The government says one of the benefits will be better guidance and help from the inland revenue. However, this will depend upon the efficiency of the inland revenue help line. I understand that the help line has already given conflicting advice regarding the registration deadline for those who have already started a new business."

Chris Chadburn, of accountants Baker Tilly, says that people caught by the ruling can negotiate with their local tax inspector. "Most fixed penalties can be mitigated by the taxpayers circumstances. If they owe lots of tax then it might not be possible but if the sums are negligible then they should argue their case." He says anyone who cannot afford an accountant should contact their citizens advice bureau or the charity Taxaid.

A spokeswoman for the revenue said this week that self employed workers with profits below £3,825 would qualify for the small earnings exemption and avoid the fine. Anyone with a reasonable explanation of why they had failed to register would be looked at sympathetically.

And someone who had failed to pay tax for several years could phone a confidential helpline, which would answer tax queries without affecting any future dealings with the revenue, she said. But they were likely to face the fine if their business was not registered.

Inland Revenue tax and benefits confidential helpline: 0845 6086000

webTitle: Why savers must be the ones to profit

fields.headline: Why savers must be the ones to profit
fields.standfirst: Investors have been short-changed by with-profits policies. Now, reports Patrick Collinson, insurers will have to clean up their act
fields.trailText: The Financial Services Authority this week promised a clean-up of with-profits policies, heavily criticised by the Consumers' Association as short-changing investors with poor returns and steep charges.
fields.body:
The Financial Services Authority this week promised a clean-up of with-profits policies, heavily criticised by the Consumers' Association as short-changing investors with poor returns and steep charges.

With-profits policies, such as endowments and pensions, are investments where the saver's cash is put into a mix of shares, bonds and property. The insurance company "smooths" the returns each year, with money set aside in good years to finance payouts when the stock market is weak. But they have attracted criticism for paying out poor returns if savers quit the policy early, and for skimming off billions of pounds into "orphan assets" which are then plundered by shareholders. Critics add that the opacity of the smoothing process allows companies to mask true returns and chronically underpay investors. The closure of Equitable Life, a with-profits company, has also added to concerns about the policies.

In a speech yesterday, FSA chairman Howard Davies surprised the industry by agreeing with many of the criticisms. He described the funds as having "an opaque superstructure, obscure marketing and high charges" and forecast that they will find many fewer buyers in the future.

The FSA is carrying out a review of with-profits funds that will report later this year, but in the interim Mr Davies laid out some of his concerns about with-profits policies. "The annual costs to the investor of with-profits policies can be high, certainly by comparison with, say, an index-tracking fund. Investors typically pay 3.5% over 10 years, and 1.5% over 25 years, in addition to dealing costs, by comparison with around a 1% charge for an index-tracking fund."

He also highlighted poor early cash-in values and the increasing tendency of insurance companies to give a large part of the return in the form of terminal bonuses, only paid out to the few who hold a policy to its full term. Because of higher rates of marital breakdown, "many couples have had to disentangle their long-term investment strategies well before term, with damaging consequences for the returns achieved".

The insurance industry is so worried about the attack on with-profits that Mary Francis, director general of the Association of British Insurers, recently issued a guide to chief executives telling them how to present with-profits to the media. In the guide, insurance company bosses are instructed to tell journalists that: "Equitable's situation was unique and their problem did not arise from selling with-profits."

The Institute of Actuaries - the number-crunchers who sit at the top of insurance companies - have also been stung by the criticism of with-profits and this week issued a report promising greater transparency in future. However, the report was almost immediately condemned as a whitewash by one senior industry figure.

The principal recommendation in the report is that annual statements to investors should contain clear information about how much money the with-profits fund has or has not made over the year. Astonishingly, there is no obligation on insurance companies to disclose how well a with-profits fund has performed. It is this lack of information which critics say makes it so difficult for an investor to challenge the low "surrender value" offered by companies when a policy is cancelled before its full term.

But the report draws back from recommending a complete overhaul of with-profits policies and even within the insurance industry it has been criticised for failing to tackle basic problems. The report confirms that investors leaving the with-profits fund before the full term will still not receive their full share of the investment return.

Problems surrounding terminal bonuses are also left largely untouched. The report recognises that there are concerns about hefty terminal bonuses, but does not propose placing any limit on their size.

Consumers' Association spokesman Mick McAteer said: "We welcome the move towards greater transparency, but we would like to see more done to change the wide discretion that actuaries have to manipulate returns on with-profits policies. The report has also produced performance figures which we believe put with-profits in a flattering light and do not take into account the poor surrender values and low persistency rates on these policies."

What is the Financial Services Authority going to do? Its chairman Howard Davies promises action on four fronts.

Firstly, the degree to which actuaries can use their discretion in setting payouts will be challenged. Secondly, the clarity and transparency of the policies will have to be improved, with "significant" changes in the language used by the industry. "Why can't the phrase 'reversionary bonus' be translated into English, for example," said Mr Davies.

Thirdly, the investment information given to savers will be improved, while finally the industry will have to come up with a redefinition of the phrase "policyholders' reasonable expectations", criticised as a cloak behind which the industry hides.

"My suspicion is that with profits business, in its present form ... will not loom as large in the next 20 years as it has in the past 20," concludes Mr Davies.

fields.headline: Jason Lindner Quartet
fields.standfirst:
Pizza Express Jazz Club, London
Rating ****
fields.trailText:
Pizza Express Jazz Club, London
Rating ****
fields.body:
Jason Lindner produced his latest CD on Chick Corea's Stretch Records, just the right label for a young pianist who likes nothing better than roaring up and down the keyboard with his hands splayed in octaves, often at opposite ends. He hadn't brought his whole big band over from New York's Smalls club, but the pared-down quartet quickly found a depth that fitted the intimacy of the setting. Lindner, still in his 20s, can play very, very well, and his band are a tight-knit but generous bunch who match and spur each other in pace, volume and intensity.

There was no easy way into their first number, a lengthy Latin-influenced piece featuring Jimmy Greene on flute. The music remained stubbornly uncomfortable, Lindner jerky but precise, playing in fingerless gloves that steeped his digits to the required temperature. Soon he had warmed up sufficiently to whip off the gloves during a spot of prepared piano, one hand playing keys and the other piano strings. The band moved into a funkier, faster, more regular section that saw Lindner percussive in his use of hammered-out steps and grand, drunken chords. But he is as happy with dainty little ideas as giant leaps, whether delving into the minutiae of a speedy run or snatching away as if from a hot iron.

A lovely, muted finish to that piece was followed by a serene meditation, which Omer Avital introduced with a poignant melody on double bass. Lindner maintained the poise through the repetition of a two-tone phrase on piano, lulling our ears with persistence and simplicity. Later, Avital seized advantage of a hush to gambol soulfully through the sort of show-stopping solo that most bassists must secretly yearn for. In a slower, bluesy piece, which showed the band at its laid-back best, Greene revelled in ripe low notes on saxophone, enlivened by Lindner's fast trills.

Pizza Express now has its own orchestra, led by Tim Garland, also a Stretch man, but I suspect the full Lindner NYC band could give them a run for their money.

Ends tomorrow. Box office: 020-7439 8722.

fields.headline: Regency Buck
fields.standfirst:
Monarch, London
Rating ***
fields.trailText:
Monarch, London
Rating ***
fields.body:
Regency Buck aim to throw humour and rock guitars at convention. After all, if you name yourself after the star of a porn comic, you're clearly looking to be a bit different. Dave "Disco" McClean - amusing nicknames are part of the deal - seems to be setting the tone when he carries on a red hat complete with antlers, but as the rest of the band assume their rock positions, it's their staid appearance that really surprises. An identical ensemble of grey shirts, grey trousers and black long-sleeved T-shirts convey the impression that here are a bunch of civil servants painting the town, well, grey.

But that's only until the stage is flooded in blue light and singer Chris "Christian" Gordon begins his demonic act. Face underlit, eyes bulging, mouth gaping, he's a scene from the Blair Witch Project come to life, all scary movies and vocoder intonation. When he begins the hard-edged Crystal Clear, when the guitar sound starts to grow and the epic nature of the song becomes all too apparent, Regency Buck suddenly begin to make sense.

They present a Clockwork Orange-like glimpse of the future, with opposing genres sparking off one another to create something new and troubling. A hefty dose of Marilyn Manson metal is mixed with head-nodding dance or improbable disco beats, then spiced up with Gordon's choirboy looks and disconnected, satanic singing. The result is Gary Numan flirting with the Pet Shop Boys, the vocals lacking emotional involvement but the lurking pop melodies warm.

Gordon moves mechanically around the stage, his sense of control evident even when he's howling into the microphone by the way he throws his arm around his waist, holding himself tightly. He enjoys himself on the radio-friendly Change Your Mind, singing its catchy chorus through clenched teeth, the enhanced vocals bringing Abba's Does Your Mother Know happily to mind. This camp quality is fun but occasionally at odds with the biting guitars and air of darkness that Regency Buck revel in.There's a moment in the brooding Deliverance - all computerised vocals courtesy of McClean and growls from Gordon - when the guitarists, led by Paul "Duke Ironfist" Westwater, suddenly make a synchronised turn and become the Shadows, somewhat spoiling the notion that the apocalypse is nigh. Then the band fall back into their own separate spaces, never interacting with each other, never speaking to us.

The fusion of styles is clever and tightly performed and Regency Buck create a much grander sound live than they do on record. But it's the anything-goes ethic that's truly appealing - though they never did wear that hat.

fields.headline: Byers refers bid for Abbey
fields.standfirst: Analysts say Lloyds TSB's four-month wait is driven by election pressures
fields.trailText: Lloyds TSB last night remained resolute in its determination to take over Abbey National even though its £19bn bid faces a four-month delay because of an investigation by the competition authorities.
fields.body:
Lloyds TSB last night remained resolute in its determination to take over Abbey National even though its £19bn bid faces a four-month delay because of an investigation by the competition authorities.

Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, finally referred the controversial bid to the competition commission and the hostility between Abbey and Lloyds escalated.

Abbey also indicated that it was prepared to press ahead to try to consummate its merger with Bank of Scotland, even while the investigation into the Lloyds deal - which would involve 9,000 job cuts and 600 branch closures - was continuing. BoS described the situation as "dynamic".

Shares in all three banks fell on the news, which had the effect of reducing the value of Lloyds's offer to £17bn, or just above £12 for each Abbey National share; the price fell 36p to £11.03 yesterday.

Mark Pain, finance director of Abbey, which is refusing to succumb to Lloyds TSB's advances, likened his predator to the troubled retailer Marks & Spencer. "They've got a chairman [Sir Brian Pitman] who stayed too long and chief executive [Peter Ellwood] who's no good for the job," he said.

Mr Byers gave the competition commission until June 12 to submit its report on Lloyds's bid, which he said had raised concern at the office of fair trading about current accounts and small business.

Even though Mr Byers insisted he had followed the advice given to him, this failed to prevent criticism by City analysts that political pressures were playing a role so close to an election. This was heightened by the fact that Mr Byers had left the publication of his decision until the last moment.

The City believes that Lloyds' ambitions to take over Abbey National are in effect on hold until the verdict of the competition commission. "The proposed merger would lead to the elimination from the market of one of the the most significant branch based competitors to the UK's four largest banks," Mr Byers said. "This might result in a substantial lessening of competition, particularly in the market for current accounts," he added. He also cited concerns about the provision of banking to small business, in which Abbey National is an aspiring player.

Peter Ellwood, the chief executive of Lloyds, said: "We feel we've got a very good chance of getting clearance." He and his advisors will set out to prove to the watchdog that competition is rife in the current account market, with "three dozen players" fighting for business and citing Abbey's "de minimus" share of the small banking market.

Ian Harley, the chief executive of Abbey, however, said: "It is a very strong referral. The government seems to want competition outside the big four". The big four - Lloyds TSB, Barclays, HSBC and NatWest - between them have a 70% share of the current account market.

While the banks now begin arguing their respective cases to the competition authorities, shareholders appeared resigned to sit out the uncertainty of the coming four months. One shareholder in all three banks said: "The whole thing should be on a level playing field. I don't think there's any grounds for Bank of Scotland and Abbey National to push forward."

Analysts at Fox-Pitt Kelton, an investment bank, said: "We believe the referral was driven as much by political considerations as by competition concerns. In the lead-up to a general election, it is unlikely that the Labour party would wish to be seen to be sanctioning a deal that will ultimately lead to branch closures and staff losses, both politically sensitive issues at the moment. Ultimately, we believe that the deal will be allowed through".

The main players in a long running battle

Ian Harley
Ian Harley, the chief executive of Abbey National, allowed himself a small smile at 11am yesterday when the statement containing the news the unwelcome advances of Lloyds TSB faced a four month delay hit the stock exchange.

The statement contained the information many think would have been music to his ears. He was in fighting form last night, insisting it would be difficult for Lloyds TSB to pass the competition hurdles.

Accused by some in the City of trying to hide behind the referral, Mr Harley now has some breathing space to try to convince shareholders that Lloyds TSB should be given short shrift if its attempted takeover is eventually cleared. Mr Harley has received a mixed reception among City investors and before the Bank of Scotland talks were leaked he found himself defending calls from his shareholders for a change at the top.

Some think he faces an uphill struggle in winning the support of investors, who may prefer the lure of Lloyds TSB's cash than a nil-premium merger with Bank of Scotland. He disputed Lloyds claims of shareholder support, saying, "people will tell you what you want to hear".

Peter Ellwood
The chief executive of Lloyds TSB remained upbeat yesterday despite facing a delay of at least four months in his £19bn attempt to take over Abbey National.

A career banker, Mr Ellwood has lived in the shadow of outgoing chairman Sir Brian Pitman, and is determined to use a takeover of Abbey to give Lloyds TSB enough bulk to complete a major deal in Europe in the months ahead.

He insists the deal will eventually be cleared, and while the City appeared to have some sympathy with him yesterday, the referral of the bid is the last thing he needed.

Armed with arguments as to why the banking environment is highly competitive, Mr Ellwood is at the helm of the bank just as its star status with investors is starting to appear slightly tarnished. The publication of annual results last week did not match the usual hallowed status granted the bank, which in the past five years has earned a reputation for takeovers of TSB, Cheltenham & Gloucester and Scottish Widows.

Lloyds abandoned its pledge to cut costs and analysts interpreted that as a demonstration of why Mr Ellwood needed Abbey.

Peter Burt
Peter Burt, the blunt chief executive of Bank of Scotland, received a standing ovation when he launched his audacious, yet ultimately ill-fated, bid for NatWest over a year ago.

Now the 25-year veteran of the Edinburgh-based bank faces the danger of being left at the altar twice. While he is respected for his management of the bank, City sources believe he will be reluctant to rush into an Abbey deal while there is any chance Lloyds TSB could be successful.

Some in the City even believe that Mr Burt and his board have a latent suspicion of Barclays, and privately wonder whether the charismatic Matt Barrett might be tempted to shift his attentions north of the border once the competition authorities' views are clear. Yet Mr Burt and his camp of followers are also convinced that Lloyds TSB's advances on Abbey National do raise serious concerns for the competition authorities.

While his talks with Abbey National got off to a frosty start, relations are now said to be more amicable. He dined with his counterpart at Abbey National only last week. A last supper, perhaps?

webTitle: UK listing authority to join FSA

fields.headline: Watcher over a proud tradition
fields.standfirst:
New role and new rules will help to keep London's markets transparent and fair

Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: It was a little over nine months ago that the UK listing authority found a new parent in the form of the financial services authority and it is only a matter of weeks before the former leaves the City and joins the FSA at Canary Wharf.
fields.body:
It was a little over nine months ago that the UK listing authority found a new parent in the form of the financial services authority and it is only a matter of weeks before the former leaves the City and joins the FSA at Canary Wharf.

We will have some new neighbours, who are among the world's leading international financial firms and who have made a very significant contribution, over a long period of time, to the success of London as a financial centre.

It is a remarkable achievement that in an increasingly competitive environment, London continues to maintain market share in many international financial markets. The authority has been the gatekeeper to the London markets for almost 2,000 British companies and about 500 international companies.

None of this would have been possible if London had not established a strong reputation for operating fair and clean financial markets. There is no doubt that standards here are high and that market participants have confidence in our markets and in the regulatory framework that ensures fair play. All successful financial centres witness lapses in conduct, whether intentional or not, and we must guard against the integrity of London's markets being compromised in any way.

One issue that has attracted some comment in recent months is the alleged misuse of information. As we have said before, there is nothing more corrosive of market confidence than the feeling that some investors are deliberately excluded from an inner circle of privileged counter-parties. We are devoting considerable effort to ensuring that London's high standards of conduct are maintained in this area: by maintaining our longstanding requirements on listed companies to announce, without delay, price sensitive information to the market as a whole and not just to a chosen few; and by putting in place a regime to tackle market abuse. We will get new powers to fine those who fail to meet these standards once the financial services and markets act comes into force later this year.

We certainly regard the rules for listed companies as hugely important in underpinning the integrity of the London equity markets. There are, on average, 700 announcements a day from the pool of well over 2,000 companies listed in London. In fast-moving markets, the timely flow of accurate and complete price sensitive information from listed companies to the market as a whole is crucial, especially in today's environment with more retail investors taking an active interest in the equity markets.

A company's regulatory obligation is to ensure that information which comes from itself, its advisers or agents is given without delay to the market as a whole and that it is complete and not misleading. It is important that companies maintain a clear policy on investor communication, including procedures for the control and dissemination of price sensitive information.

Our rules do not prevent companies from holding private meetings with analysts and investors to discuss matters already in the public domain and we have published some practical guidance on how these meetings should be conducted to ensure that our regulatory requirements are met. Revised guidance will be issued in the spring.

We have studied a range of practices adopted by companies that attempt to demystify these private meetings and enhance transparency. Some companies choose, for example, to summarise the contents of a meeting in an announcement, while others allow the media and other investors to listen in to a briefing by making arrangements for it to be broadcast over the web or by holding a conference call. A US survey last year found that more than 80% of companies have opened conference calls to the public and nearly 50% are broadcasting briefings over the web. These sorts of developments are welcome and should enhance investor confidence.

We will also acquire powers this year to address a significant gap in the ability of the British authorities to deal with so-called "market abuse". Britain has had for some time criminal offences in relation to insider dealing and market manipulation which cover all market participants but only a relatively narrow range of very serious misconduct.

Up until now, only those authorised by one of the financial services regulators, or members of an exchange, have been subject to any form of regulatory sanction if their market conduct falls below acceptable standards but stops short of constituting a criminal offence. A civil offence of market abuse has been established under the Financial Services and Markets Act that will level the playing field between unauthorised and authorised market participants and close the "regulatory gap".

The regime will directly address abuse involving the misuse of information and the FSA will be making guidance available, in the form of a code, that provides clarification of the types of behaviour that will and will not amount to market abuse. We have undertaken extensive public consultation on the code over the past two years and will publish a final version in the spring.

As we take this work forward we are committed to developing a regulatory environment that will continue to support the development of London as a leading international financial centre. Today's financial markets need a regulator with appropriate powers to ensure the maintenance of market confidence, an adequate degree of investor protection and to deal effectively with the small minority whose behaviour threatens to spoil the party for everyone else. In this way, the FSA will continue to play its part in ensuring that London remains a thriving and internationally competitive financial centre.

Paul Geradine is FSA Director for Listing.

Edmond Warner is on holiday

fields.headline: Why it pays to do your duty before you go
fields.standfirst: Why wait until you're dead to divide up the estate? John Edwards looks at how to give your assets to loved ones, not the taxman
fields.trailText: Inheritance tax is no longer a problem just for the wealthy. Nowadays it is a potential threat for a very large section of the population. The tax becomes payable at 40% on any estates worth more than £234,000, including the value of the family home. That means a lot of estates have a considerable tax liability - for example, an estate of £400,000 faces tax of more than £66,000.
fields.body:
Inheritance tax is no longer a problem just for the wealthy. Nowadays it is a potential threat for a very large section of the population. The tax becomes payable at 40% on any estates worth more than £234,000, including the value of the family home. That means a lot of estates have a considerable tax liability - for example, an estate of £400,000 faces tax of more than £66,000.

What many people do not realise is that by using special inheritance tax schemes, even those with modest fortunes can obtain relief from inheritance tax - even if they were to die the next day.

It is also possible to provide yourself with tax-free income for the rest of your life, or to protect yourself from having to pay long-term care bills, while still making sizeable gifts to your beneficiaries.

Some inheritance tax schemes seem very complicated, primarily because they are based on trusts. And giving away large amounts of your capital may seem frightening, especially if you will not have much left after making the gift.

But bear in mind that the purpose of having capital is primarily either to provide extra income or to safeguard yourself against future strains on your finances, such as the need to fund long-term care. If these things can be achieved while cutting inheritance tax bills then it is well worth considering the plans available.

There are a number of different types of plan. "Instant discount" schemes cut your liability to inheritance tax immediately. They are based on the general principle that the inland revenue accepts that the value of a gift is reduced if there is an irrevocable commitment attached to pay "income" or insurance premiums for a specified period.

For example, if someone makes a gift of £100,000 conditional on the right to draw 5% income annually from it for the rest of their life, this devalues the gift. How long the giver of the gift is likely to live, drawing the £5,000 a year, can be calculated by using mortality tables - assuming that they are in reasonable health. If their life expectancy is 10 years then theoretically the value of the gift goes down by £50,000.

In fact, calculating the discount is rather more complicated than that, since actuarial assumptions about its growth against inflation have to be taken into account. In addition, the revenue requires proof that the donor was in reasonable health when the gift was made to prevent death bed gifts of this type.

Nevertheless, the basic principle applies. Even gifts made by people with limited life expectancy can be discounted quite substantially until seven years has passed, when the whole gift (which qualifies as a potentially exempt transfer) becomes free of any inheritance tax liability.

The same devaluation principle can apply to gifts which have a commitment attached to pay long-term care insurance premiums, instead of income, for the rest of the donor's life - provided that the cost of funding the insurance policy can be quantified.

Tax-free, or more correctly tax-deferred, income from inheritance tax plans can be gained through the gift of a lump sum to a trust being invested in single premium investment bonds. There is a special facility allowing you to withdraw 5% of the original investment for a period of up to 20 years without incurring any immediate tax liability. This facility is available for both onshore and offshore investment bonds.

Onshore bonds pay returns net of standard-rate income tax, but a top-rate taxpayer can defer paying any additional tax for 20 years.

Offshore bonds are often used for inheritance tax schemes because they are more flexible and benefit from the fund not having to pay UK tax. The returns are liable to income tax when brought back to the UK, but they can often be deferred until the best time for the beneficiaries if the money is not required instantly.

And instead of drawing income, you can use the investment in the inheritance tax scheme to fund long-term care insurance premiums tax-free.

A halfway house, if you are apprehensive about giving away too much of your capital, is to use "gift and loan" schemes. With these, you make an interest-free loan to a trust set up for your chosen beneficiaries which invests the money in a single premium investment bond.

The 5% withdrawal facility from the bond is used to repay the loan over a period of up to 20 years, while all the growth from the bond goes into the trust - which becomes free of any inheritance tax liability after seven years.

If, however, you have a sudden urgent need for capital, or simply change your mind, you can demand instant repayment of the outstanding amount of the loan.

If most of your money is tied up in the family home, where you want to live for the rest of your life, you have two main options. One is life assurance, written in trust, that covers the cost of paying the anticipated inheritance tax bill. In this way you can avoid a forced sale of the property on your death. Another option is equity release schemes in which you sell part of your house but can live in it for the rest of your life. The money raised from the sale can either be used to provide additional income or invested to fund long-term care insurance and/or finance an inheritance tax saving plan.

Charges on special inheritance tax schemes can be very high, especially if they use offshore investments. However, if the sums involved are reasonably large, you can usually persuade financial advisers to rebate some of the large commissions they receive or to work on an agreed-fee only basis, with a full rebate of all commission. And the size of the charges can sometimes seem insignificant when compared with the savings made on inheritance tax.

It may be simpler and cheaper just to give money away to your beneficiaries. The problem with doing this is that you have to wait four to seven years before there is any relief from inheritance tax, and you would lose control of the capital.

Using a trust-based inheritance tax scheme enables you to retain some control, provide yourself with some benefits and an instant reduction in tax liability.

Leading players amongst the insurance companies providing these instant discount schemes include Axa Sun Life, Canada Life (formerly Albany Life), Scottish Amicable, Scottish Mutual and Skandia.

They all have different quirks and charging structures, so it is sensible to consult an independent financial adviser to help you find the scheme that suits your particular requirements best.
